Alvin Kenneth "Ken" Loper was born to his wonderful mother, Evelyn, and father, Alvin K. Loper, on April 19, 1938, in Bridgeton, N.J. Having lost his father at a young age, Ken grew up proud of his mother's resilience and achievements as a single parent. Ken was raised as a true Jersey farm boy at heart. He loved to tell stories about his Aunt Hilda and Uncle Joe's farm and the summers that he spent there.Ken met Judith Richardson one summer while driving a bookmobile; it was instant love. Ken then went off to college in West Virginia and became an industrial arts teacher. He began his teaching career in 1964 at Millville High School in New Jersey. That year, Ken and Judy were married on Dec. 19, 1964. In the fall of 1970, Ken and Judy moved their family to Maine, where he would teach for 30 years in the Oxford Hills School District. He taught thousands of students to use all kinds of tools during his 35-year career, but the real truth is that he taught life.Ken and Judy lived in the small community of Paris Hill, where they had a wonderful life bringing up their children, loving each other and helping others while restoring a historic home. Ken was active in the Paris Hill Community Club, Paris Hill Country Club and the South Paris Congregational Church.Upon retirement, he moved to Amelia Island, Fla. He enjoyed many years volunteering in the community with the Police Auxiliary Corp of the Fernandina Police Department. As Ken spent his life improving the lives of his students and those in his communities, he also led a fulfilling life of his own. In fact, when he was faced with heart troubles and survived a near-death experience, he remarked that "it (life) turned out to be better than I thought it would." This hopeful outlook inspired all that knew him.Ken and his wife, Judy, loved long walks on the beach and time together. Their lives were a true love story. Ken was a wonderful son, husband, father, grandfather, neighbor and friend.Ken's love, strength and kindness inspired many during his life. He will be sorely missed by his family, friends, and colleagues. He is survived by his loving wife, Judy; his children, Zane Loper, life partner, Tanya, Kathy Benowitz, her husband, Jeff, Gabi Cullinan and her husband, John; his grandchildren, Ellex, her husband, Jake, Kelton, Mackenzie, Devyn, Reilly, Hannah, Hitoshi and his wife, Grace.In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Police Auxiliary Corp of the Fernandina Beach Police Department.Join us for a sharing of memories on Dec. 18, 2023 from 11 a.m. until 2 p.m. at the Alday Cottage, 15 N. Sixth St., Fernandina Beach, Fla.

Obituary for Janette E. Brown at Zentner-Beal Funeral Home Janette's Obituary Janette E. (Duckert) Brown passed away peacefully on March 24, 2020, at the age of 81 at Agrace HospiceCare, Inc. in Fitchburg. She was born on December 17, 1938 the daughter of Vernon and Evelyn (Krueger) Duckert, Sr. Jan grew up in the Cambridge area and graduated from Cambridge High School in 1957. She married her forever dancing partner Gerald Brown on November 14, 1959, a date that persists in the record books as the coldest day on record. The couple then began farming and raising their family in Belleville. They hosted the Dane County Dairy Breakfast in 1983. Jan's family was everything to her, for the last sixty years she loved watching her kids and grandkids grow and participate in sports and activities. Jan also loved polka dancing, family gatherings, bowling, fishing, drives around the countryside, traveling, and attending shows. She was a member of the Zwingli United Church of Christ-Paoli, Montrose Budget Busters, and many agricultural organizations including Wisconsin Master Farmers and FFA alumni. Jan will be dearly missed for her jokes, potato casserole, card games, and the goodie bags for the grandkids. Jan is survived by her husband of sixty years, Jerry, children Brian (Yogi) Brown, Doug (Karen Fiene) Brown, and Jackie (Greg) Schulting, daughter-in-law Kristy Brown, ten grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren. She is further survived by her brothers Vernon (Betty) Duckert, Jr., Glenn (Gert) Duckert, and Marvin (Darlene) Duckert, sisters Dorothy "DeeDee" Zell, Diane (Dave) Brunk, Marie Galston, and JoAnn Duckert, sister-in-law June Duckert, sister-in-law and brother-in-law Dorothy (Jim) Goings, brother-in-law George Brown, nieces, and nephews. She was preceded in death by her parents, son Curt, father-in-law and mother-in-law George and Grace Brown, brother Howard, in-laws Bill Galston, Gene Zell, Betty (Don) Erickson, Mary (Jack) Brissee, Helen (Art) Hohlstein, and Shirley Brown. Due to the ongoing public health crisis, private family funeral services will be held with interment in the Paoli Cemetery. A public celebration of Jan's life will be held at a later date. The Becker-Beal Funeral Home of Belleville is assisting the family. The family would like to thank the staffs of Meriter Hospital and Agrace HospiceCare, Inc. for their attentive and compassionate care for Jan in her final days. Private Family Service Express your condolences with flowers sent to Janette's memorial service Or, Order By Phone 888-579-7953 Code: 2014348P View & Sign

LACONIA-----Clyde M. MacDonald, 79, of Darby Drive, died on Monday, November 27, 2023, surrounded by his family at Concord Hospital-Concord.Clyde was born May 22, 1944 in Laconia, the son of the late Ernest MacDonald, Sr. and Ethel (Diack) MacDonald.Clyde was a veteran of the United States Army.He was a production control manager for NH Ball Bearings, he worked there for 50+ years.Clyde enjoyed fishing, drag racing and classic cars, and coaching Hockey. Most of all he adored his family and spending time with all of them.Survivors include a son and daughter-in-law, Randy and Sandie MacDonald; three grandchildren, Abigail and Mark Cordoza, Zachary Drouin, and Cameron and Ashley Drouin, a great grandson, Lincoln Drouin, sister, Rose Marie and Roger Allen, and numerous nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. He was predeceased by his wife, Sandra A. MacDonald, brothers, Ernest MacDonald, Jr., Alfred MacDonald, sisters, Patricia Brunt, Yvonne Bristol, Janet Stall,Calling hours will be held on Friday, December 1, 2023 from 5:00pm - 7:00pm in the Carriage House of the Wilkinson-Beane-Simoneau-Paquette Funeral Home, 164 Pleasant Street, Laconia, N.H.A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday, December 2, 2023 at 10:00am at St. Andre Bessette Parish-Sacred Heart Church, 291 Union Avenue, Laconia, N.H.Burial with Military Honors will follow in the family lot at Union Cemetery, Academy Street, Laconia, N.H.For those who wish the family suggests that memorial donations may be made in Clyde's memory to a charity of one's choice to aid military veterans.Wilkinson-Beane-Simoneau-Paquette Funeral Home & Cremation Services/603Cremations.com, Laconia, NH, is assisting the family with arrangements. For more information and to view an online memorial, please visit wilkinsonbeane.com.

DENISON - Callie Irene Cassita Dixon was born July 9, 1927 in Petty, Texas, the daughter of Robert and Beth Cassita. She attended Paris Public Schools.After moving to Denison she united with the Antioch Baptist Church. She worked many years at Texas Instruments until her retirement.Callie passed away early Wednesday morning at Texoma Medical Center in Denison.She was preceded in death by her husband, Don Dixon; parents, Robert and Beth Cassita; sister, Ruby Council; brothers, Wayne Cassita and Julius Cassita and also her only son, Edward (Sid).Those left with cherished memories are; her sister, Olevia Cassita; nieces, Tanya and Carla Cassita; nephews, Kenneth, Zachary, Urlie, Reggia and wife Teresa Cassita; grandson, Tan Lyday; great grandchildren, T.J. Taylor, Tre'lon Lyday, La'Darrious Turner; great-great granddaughter, Liliana Gentile and two special friends, Mary and Pat.Callie will lie in repose Sunday from 1-6 p.m. at Waldo Funeral Home, Sherman.Funeral Services will be Monday, August 1st at 1 p.m. at Antioch Baptist Church, 700 W. Walker St., Denison, with Rev. Manuel Gardner, Pastor officiating. Callie will be laid to rest in Oakwood Cemetery, Denison.Arrangements have been entrusted to James E. Smith with Waldo Funeral Home, Sherman. The online register book can be signed at www.waldofuneralhome.com

RICHARD KOELLNER Einan's at Sunset On Saturday, February 29, 2020, Richard Koellner, loving husband and father of two children, passed away at the age of 81. Richard was born on April 18, 1938 in Fort Madison, Iowa to William and Beatrice (Vonderhaar) Koellner. On December 28, 1963, he married Siglinde Huth and they raised two children, Pia and Shaun. Richard was preceded in death by his father, William, and his mother, Beatrice, his brothers Albert, Fred, Jim and granddaughter Nicole. He is survived by his wife Siglinde, his two children, Pia (Jim) and Shaun (Tanya), their children, Dana (Tom), Eric, Kelsey (Casey), Preston, Patrick, and Xavier, his brother Bill (Marty), sister, Judy (Lambert), and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Richard retired from the BNSF Railway after many years of faithful service. He had a passion for collecting telephone insulators, coins, jigsaw puzzles, and board games. In his free time, Richard enjoyed playing bridge with his many good friends, fishing, card games, and watching sports. Most knew Richard for his personality and friendship. He was involved with Knights of Columbus council 3307, and was always eager to volunteer his time where needed. The Funeral Mass will be held at Christ the King Catholic Church in Richland, WA on Saturday March 7, 2020 at 11:00am. The family asks in lieu of flowers you may donate flowers to a church of your choice. Express your thoughts and memories on our online Guestbook at www.einansatsunset.com

Helen "Wanda"' Burlingame, 94, of South New Berlin, passed away Friday evening, Jan. 10, 2014, at her home in South New Berlin.Wanda was born in Norwich on July 10, 1919 the daughter of Claude and Mabel Marvin Rathbone. She was raised in the Chenango County area and has made her home in South New Berlin for the past 50 years. In her early working career she had worked as a waitress in Norwich and for 24 years was employed by the Broome Developemental Center as a caregiver. Wanda was a person who loved people in general as well as her animals. She was a kind hearted soul who always had a comment. A very caring and giving individual, she always saw the humor in everything and was tough to embarass. Wanda is survived by her daughters Debra Miles of Sherburne, Kandase Burlingame of South New Berlin, her son LeRoy Gale and wife Dottie of Ormond Beach, FL, her sisters Edna and Mary, her brother Claude "Sonny" and several grand and great grandchildren.Wanda was predeceased by her husband Kenneth Burlingame in Oct of 1973.Services for Wanda will be private and at the convenience of the family.Please consider memorial contributions to the South New Berlin Fire Dept. South New Berlin, NY 13843.

Philip L. KennisonRetired 30 year veteran U.S. Air Force CHELMSFORD -- Philip L. Kennison, 92, a 30 year veteran of the U.S. Air Force, having served during World War II, the Korean Conflict and the Vietnam War, died Thursday morning at his home in Chelmsford surrounded by his loving family.He was the husband of the late Romaine D. (Carignan) Kennison who died in 2005.Born in Bristol, CT, March 5, 1924, the son of the late Vinal W. and the late Constance J. (Boulier) Kenneson, he attended Terryville, CT schools and went on to attend the Armed Forces Institute College.Philip entered the Armed Forces in 1940 and over a distinguished 30 year career, through three wars, he proudly served his country with honor and distinction, retiring as a CM Sgt. In addition, he worked as a civilian with the Department of Defense.Philip is survived by three daughters, Romaine D. Sharpling of Whitehouse, TX, Cathy J. Levangie and Susan P. Kennison, both of Chelmsford, MA; a son, Philip L. Kennison, Jr. of Orlando, FL; two grandchildren, Lisa Powell of Waco, TX, and Crystal Levangie of Lowell, MA; four great-grandchildren; two great-great-grandchildren; a brother, Vinal Kenneson of Chicopee, MA; and a sister, Ella Arsenault of FL.At his request, private Funeral Services were held for the family. E-condolences at odonnellfuneralhome.com. Those wishing may make contributions in his memory to The Wounded Warrior Project. Arrangements by the O'DONNELL FUNERAL HOME - Lowell - (978) 458-8768.

Nellie Shek 83, of Queens Village, died Tuesday, January 17th of Alzheimer's disease.  Her funeral ceremony and interment were held on Thursday, January 19th.  Nellie was born February 5th, 1928 in Havana, Cuba to the late Isaac Warszavsky and Berta Rumianik. Her beloved stepfather, the late Jaime Novomodi, always referred to her as "the daughter of my heart".   In 1948, she married her childhood sweetheart Sidney Shek in Havana, after Sidney had recovered from wounds he received in action during World War II in Europe.  After their wedding, Nellie and Sidney lived briefly in Brooklyn, NY and then moved to Queens Village where they raised three sons.  Theirs was a loving and joyful marriage, which ended when Sidney succumbed, in 1997, to illness related to his military service.  Nellie and Sidney's sons - Charles, a social worker, William, a veterinarian, and Mitchell, a dermatologist - credit their accomplishments to Nellie's love, hard-work and fierce determination to assure that they had opportunities not available to her in depression-era Cuba.  Nellie was fluent in three languages including her native Spanish, Yiddish learned as child and English learned after moving to America.  During her life she worked as a teacher's aide, a seamstress and a sales representative for Nina Shoes.  Nellie's lifelong devotion to her family, friends and community were legendary.  She served several terms as president of the Bell Park Jewish Center sisterhood, and she volunteered at a local hospital.  Nellie was honored on many occasions for her service to the Jewish community and in thanks for her volunteer work.  Because she was always present in times of need, Nellie will be irreplaceable as mother, grandmother, neighbor and friend.  Her everlasting humor, beauty, energy, passion, strength and love will be deeply missed by those who survive her including her sister Sarah Lehman, her sons, their wives Myroon, Jill and Norma and her grandchildren Joshua, Max, Alex, Denise and Debra.Contributions in the memory of Nellie Shek may be made to any of the following:Taub Institute Columbia University Medical CenterATTN: Dr. Richard Mayeux630 West 168th Street, P&S Box 16New York, NY 10032212-305-2391https://giving.columbia.edu/giveonline/Bell Park Jewish Center231-10  Hillside AvenueQueens Village, NY 11427718- 464-9144ATTN: DEVELOPMENT DEPT.Alzheimer's Association New York City Chapter 360 Lexington Avenue, 4th Floor New York, New York 10017http://www.alz.org/nyc/

Born in Collinwood, Wayne County, Tennessee, on October 12, 1931, he grew up in earshot of the planer mill. Broke his arm falling off a horse when a youngster, he learned how to swing a bat cross-handed, later to excel at golf the same way, cross-handed. He joined the Air Force in his teens and served in Okinawa during the Korean War, sending photos of the painted B-29's home to his family. He met a girl, later his wife, Syble Hunter, at the rail station while going off to war. She happened to be sending her brother off to the same conflict. They wrote during his time overseas, and fell in love as penpal wartime sweethearts. James and Syble married upon his return, and used the GI bill to graduate from the University of Tennessee in record time, working at the cheese factory to help pay some bills. Unsure whether to work for a prominent local dairy production facility in Knoxville, or go to graduate school, he embarked on his life's profession and passion teaching college students and growing up young men and women to maturity and a healthy profession in the dairy industry. He finished his Masters at the Ohio State University and decided to make a few dollars as an instructor at Mississippi State University to pay for his growing children, Dana Keith and Pamela Dawn Martin. Realizing teaching at the college level required a PhD he returned to The Ohio State University and finished, becoming the first person from Wayne County, Tennessee to hold a doctorate degree. After taking a position with the University of Georgia, he became a nationally recognized coach of the dairy products judging team, which won national titles several years in a row in dairy product judging. The leadership at South Dakota State University recognized an enthusiastic and inspiring teacher, and brought Dr Martin to Brookings, where he continued to win the dairy judging in the U.S. with a new group of students. Gaining a reputation for finding every one of his students professions in the industry, Clemson University called on this teacher, now recognized by the National Dairy Science Association and editor of the Cultured Dairy Products Journal. His beloved alma mater, Ohio State U called on him again to become department head of the Food Science and Nutrition. This time his preeminence as a liaison with industry enabled him to raise funds for a chaired professorship at Ohio State, and he became the first professor to be honored by becoming that chaired professor at Ohio State. With his elderly parents Luther and Auda ailing back in Tennessee he returned to Mississippi State to nurse his parents and his wife's during their senior years. In Starkville he rode his crazy cross-handed golf swing to several trophies in faculty golf competition, regularly taking time to travel to play golf with his son. Always devoted to the Lord, he took time to be Training Union director and a youth Sunday School teacher when his children were growing up. He was chairman of deacons at Milledge Avenue Baptist Church in Athens, Georgia when they built a new sanctuary. Upon his arrival in South Dakota the pastor that baptized him in Knoxville Tennessee, showed up on his doorstep asking for help in starting a Baptist Student Union at South Dakota State. He met with a banker in Brookings and convinced him that the Southern Baptist Convention could afford to pay for a new church and BSU building in Brookings. A husband and father who was committed to his family, he led by example in teaching his children to make family a part of their lives, even if it meant travelling long distances to make sure he was there for Chsistmas and summer vacations with his parents and extended family. He was a life-long friend and sacrificial giver who put wife and family first. He will be missed. Dr. James H. Martin is preceded in death by his parents Auda and Luther Martin of Collinwood, Tennessee. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Syble Martin, of Starkville, Mississippi and his children Dana Keith Martin and wife, Jaye, of Houston, TX and Pamela Burchill and her husband Thomas, of Fort Worth, TX. He is also survived by his grandchildren, Jordan James Burchill and wife Kaela of Austin, TX and Kelli Martin Chambers and husband Alex, of Houston, TX. Visitation is scheduled for Tuesday, June 29, 2021 from 10:00-11:00 a.m. at First Baptist Church in Starkville, MS, with the funeral service immediately following.  Burial will be in Memorial Garden Park in Starkville.You can leave the family a condolence at: www.welchfuneralhomes.com.
Arrangements under the direction of National Cremation Society, Fruitland Park, FL.

Lucille Lewis Osborn - Obituary - West Roxbury, MA - P. E. Murray - F.J. Higgins - George F. Doherty Funeral Home | CurrentObituary.com Lucille Osborn was born on November 1, 1929 in Jennings, Florida. She moved to Boston, MA in her early twenties, met and married Sephus Osborn on March 25, 1950. From this marriage, nine children were born, one of whom preceded her in death. Her husband Sephus left this world on May 25, 2013 after 63 years of marriage, Lucille passed away on Friday February 14, 2020. She left behind to cherish her memories three daughters, Debra Hollaway, Michelle and Dionne, and five sons, Sephus Jr., Steven Sr., Michael, Duane, and Lawrence. She was predeceased by her daughter Lisa Osborn Kelley. Lucille was blessed with six grandchildren, Vanessa Hollaway, Crystal Hollaway, Steven Osborn Jr, Darryl Kelley II, Keyla Kelley, and Zaria Osborn Pight, and two great-grandchildren, Noelani Hollaway and Kaiden Kelley. She also leaves behind one daughter-in-law, Gloria Osborn (wife of Steven Sr.), and a large number of nieces, nephews, and friends. Private funeral and interment services. Content is coming soon...
Burial arrangements under the direction of Lakewood Memorial Park.

Main St., Palmyra, NY 14522.Cecelia was born on Sept. 2, 1927 in Canandaigua, NY the daughter of Dewey and Bertha Brockelbank Herendeen. She married Harry White on Sept. 10, 1949 in Shortsville, NY. Cecelia had worked for several years at Garlock in Palmyra. She was a member of Western Presbyterian Church, the Women's Association and was Past Matron of the Order of the Eastern Star. Cecelia is famous for her Ham Loaf which was a favorite at Rotary Lunches for many years.Cecelia was predeceased by her husband Harry; sister, Dorothy Nessinger and brothers, Jim, Floyd, Lyndon and Carl Herendeen. She is survived by her daughter, Joan (John ) DeFrees; son, Robert (Toni) White; brother, Glenn Herendeen; grandchildren, Nathaniel and Caralyn White and Derek DeFrees and several nieces and nephews.Online condolences @www.rlyostfuneralhome.com

Katherine "Kay" F. (Stefaniak) McLaughlinDOUGLAS - Katherine "Kay" F. (Stefaniak) McLaughlin, 95, passed away on Sun. July 1, 2018 at home peacefully. She was predeceased by her husband of 49 years, James F. McLaughlin in 1991.She is survived by her daughter Kathryn Aldrich and her husband Ralph of Douglas; her son, James F. Jr. and his wife, Debbie of New Market, TN; four grandsons, Eric and Sean Aldrich, and Matthew and James McLaughlin, as well as several nieces and nephews. She also leaves her beloved dog Billy, whom she loved dearly. She is predeceased by four siblings; Annie Greene, Steven Stefaniak, Michael Stefaniak, and Mary Green. Born in Douglas on June 27, 1923, she was the daughter of Albert and Anna (Hutnak) Stefaniak and lived in Douglas most of her life. She was a Douglas High School graduate and the class salutatorian. A homemaker, Kay enjoyed cooking, crocheting, knitting, reading, and playing cards. She was a lifelong member of St. Denis Church. She was a devoted mother, grandmother, and aunt who gave so much love to so many. She will be treasured forever in our hearts.Words cannot express the family's gratitude to her Salmon Hospice team. All her needs were met with great compassion and respect. Their support was invaluable. Thank you- Julie, Katherine, Brian, and Jason, we will never forget your kindness.Her funeral Mass will be held on Sat. July 7 at 10 am in St. Denis Church, 23 Manchaug St., Douglas. Burial will be held in St. Mary's Cemetery, Uxbridge at a later date. There are no calling hours. In lieu of flowers, donations in Kay's memory may be made to Dog Orphans, 90 Webster St., Douglas MA 01516. To leave a condolence message for her family please visit: http://www.JackmanFuneralHomes.com

Robert C. Weiss, a 19-year resident of Avon, Connecticut, passed away on the morning of Wednesday, February 20th following a brief but hard-fought battle with Cancer.Born on June 10, 1963, Bob was raised in Simsbury, Connecticut by a village of loving family members who, in addition to his mother and father, included his six siblings. After graduating from Simsbury High School in 1981 and the Technical Career Institute in 1988 he founded his own IT solutions company, but later joined Aetna Health Insurance in a similar role, leading the development of the company's ever-shifting technology infrastructure for 25 years.Up until his last moments, at the age of 55, Bob remained a chatty and gregarious member of the community, always interested in local happenings. During his free time, he enjoyed rooting for the Red Sox, the St. Louis Rams, and the Syracuse University Orangemen, after his son, Zachary, chose to attend the university to complete his undergraduate studies from 2010 to 2014. He could also rarely be found without the family's Labradoodle, Max, by his side.Bob will be dearly missed by his wife, MaryAnn Zuk Weiss; son, Zachary Weiss; brother-in-law Phil Gelineau; and siblings James Weiss, Patricia Degon, Barbara Leveski, William Weiss, and Kenneth Weiss. He joins his sister, Linda Weiss Gelineau, and parents Eleanor W. Weiss and Sumner B. Weiss in heaven.In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations to be made to Dog Star Rescue and Our Companions Animal Rescue & Sanctuary. Funeral services will be held privately. Family and friends may sign the guest book or send condolences to Robert's family by visiting ahernfuneralhome.com/condolences.

Teresa Lee Ford, daughter of the late Max Lee Ford and Wilma Irene (Young) Ford was born March 27, 1951 in Fullerton, California, where she grew up. Teresa graduated in 1969 from La Habra High School, La Habra, California.Teresa left sunny California in 2003 for the bright lights of Las Vegas, Nevada, where she’d lived approximately five years before enjoying the rest of her years in Missouri.At the tender age of four, Teresa accepted Jesus, happily serving him throughout her life attending Assembly of God Churches. She attended the New Life Fellowship Church of Richland. The friendship of other fellow believers meant a great deal to Teresa, and she valued each one. Her incredible love for God and His Word sent her boldly spreading the Good News of Christ to anyone she would encounter. Teresa stood ready in and out of season to share what Christ had done for her.Teresa worked for twenty-five years with International Client Services for a Semi-Conductor Company making mass flow conductors for computers before retiring.She was a loving proud mother, and grandmother. The name “Mamaw” became the name Teresa was referred to the most even by her daughter, Kathleen’s friends. Her heart was as big as the ocean, and she had plenty of love to go around.Her hobbies included painting, cross stitching, and cooking all kinds of food. Teresa was known for her award-winning Butterhorn cookies. At holiday time her home smelled amazing especially during Christmas as she’d bake twenty-five different Christmas cookies! Family meant the world to Teresa the love she had for was immense. More than anything Teresa wanted to see her beloved great-grandchildren grow up to be awesome young adults. She was so proud of all her family.Teresa had a dream to one day go to Italy. She loved Broadway Musicals and even named her two furry dogs, Molly, and Maybelle after a couple of her favorite musicals. On her fortieth birthday, her daughter took her to see Les Misérables at the Pantages’s Theater while in California. Teresa was overjoyed, loving every moment spent with Kathleen.She is preceded in death by her parents, and one brother, Timothy M. Ford.Ms. Ford leaves behind to cherish her memory one daughter: Kathleen Overman of Richland, MO; two grandchildren: Ryder Patterson and William Overman, both of Richland, MO; two great grandchildren: Killian and Avary; two brothers: Henry Ford (Marylynn) of Richland, MO and Woodrow Ford of Casa Grande, AZ; several nieces, nephews, other relatives, and friends.Teresa loved her country and was very political. However, if one took the time to get to know Teresa, they couldn’t help but love her. “She would help anyone.”On Monday, July 25, 2022, having attained the age of seventy-one Teresa entered into the presence of her Lord and Savior and heard her Master say, “It’s time Come Home My child your work on earth is through, Welcome.”Services were held at 11:00 a.m., Friday, July 29, 2022, in the Memorial Chapel of Richland with Pastor Gray Nordan officiating. Recorded music included, “It Is Well With My Soul,” “How Great Thou Art,” “Old Rugged Cross,” and “Look For Me” were played. Teresa’s daughter shared a touching eulogy of her mother. Serving as escorts were Henry Ford Sr., William Overman, Allen Lair, Ryder Patterson, John Bohannon, and Gary Patterson.Burial followed in the Wair Chapple Dowty Cemetery in Laclede County near Richland, Missouri.Services were under the care and direction of Memorial Chapel of Richland.Memorial contributions may be made in memory of Teresa Ford and may be left at Memorial Chapel of Richland.

Daniel Lambert, Sr. was born on July 27, 1976 to Thomas and Bobbie Lambert in Orange, California. He was the sixth child of eleven children born to this union.Daniel accepted Christ at a young age and joined Morning Star Baptist Church in Long Beach, California under the Pastorship, of his father, Thomas H. Lambert. Daniel served on many ministries in the church. He served on the Usher Board, the Junior Choir, he was the drummer for the Music Department, and he faithfully attended Sunday School. He loved the Lord!As a young boy, Daniel was very quiet and has always had a very giving spirit. He was once told by his mother, "Daniel if your head was not sewed onto your neck, you would give it away!" Daniel truly loved helping people!Daniel attended and graduated from Lakewood High School in Lakewood, California where he also played on the Varsity Basketball Team.He relocated to North Little Rock, Arkansas with his parents in 1996 where he attended Pulaski Technical College. He later joined Second Baptist Church under the leadership of Dr. Kevin A. Kelly.Daniel enjoyed life to the fullest and he was "ole school" at heart! He loved cooking, bar-b-quing, the country life, riding horses, fishing, spending time with family and listening to his West Coast Music. He never met a stranger, ALWAYS laughing, telling jokes, and when he saw you, you were sure to be smiling before he left your presence. He was the most kindhearted, loving, generous, and friendliest person you would want to meet.He loved working with his hands. He could repair, build, and install anything. He was gifted with many talents and he was a skilled carpenter.Daniel's four children were his heart and he looked forward to seeing them. His family was everything to him. He was all about love and he truly loved his family!Daniel Lambert, Sr. departed this life on September 10, 2014. He was preceded in death by his father, the late Pastor Thomas Henry Lambert, his daughter Braylee Michelle Lambert, his sister Portia Latisha Lambert, his grandparents Mr. & Mrs. Ernest Bragg Sr., and Mr. & Mrs. Horace Lambert.He leaves to cherish his memories, his loving mother, Missionary Bobbie Lambert, his children:Daniel Jr., Portia, Daylen, and Zayden; his siblings: Barbara, Bridget, Minister Thomas (Yolanda), Treylon, Minister Ivan, Sarah, Timothy, Naomi, Kimberley (Vernon), Tiatana; a host of nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles, cousins and friends.
Arrangements under the direction of D'Elia Funeral Home, Lakewood, NJ.

Fill not your hearts with pain and sorrow,but remember me in every tomorrow.Remember the joy, the laughter, the smiles,I've only gone to rest a little while.Although my leaving causes pain and grief, my going has eased my hurt,and given me relief.So dry your eyes and remember me,not as I am now, but as I used to be.Because, I will remember you all,and look on with a smile.Understand in your hearts,I've only gone to rest a little while.As long as I have the love of each of you,I can live my life in the hearts of all of you.

Vernon Bell Vernon "Boo" Bell of Texas City, TX went home to be with the Lord on Saturday, February 29, 2020. He was born in Galveston, TX on November 9, 1932 to the late Norvell Bell III and Sarah Sonia Bell. After graduating from Galveston Central High School, he proudly served in the United States Army and later worked at Union Carbide until retirement. Vernon met and married the love of his life, the late Hazel Mae Foster, with whom he shared 57 years of happiness. Vernon is preceded in death by his wife, Hazel Bell; brother, Wardell Bell; sisters, Zaydell Bell and Barbara Montegut. He is survived by daughters, Linda (Milton) Hooper, Patricia Holman and Carmen Bell; grandchildren, Jason, Dominique, Damon (Ashley), Jessica (Todd) and Spencer; a host of beloved nieces, nephews, relatives and many friends. The family will receive friends on Saturday, March 7, 2020 from 3:00pm to 4:00pm in the Chapel of Carnes Funeral Home, 3100 Gulf Freeway, Texas City, TX 77591. Vernon's Celebration of Life will follow at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society at cancer.org. Vernon was truly an amazing man and touched the hearts of many. He will be greatly missed.

He was 90 years old, born on July 19, 1932 to the late James and Eleanore (nee Kurkowski) Cauley.Frank proudly served in the US Army in the mid 1950’s, where he learned computer programming. In civilian life, he continued his career for many years as a programmer, working for many prominent Detroit companies. He loved boating and sailing the Great Lakes, and he was an avid downhill ski enthusiast.Frank is survived by his siblings Sharon (Charlie) Korpal, Thomas (Linda) Cauley, and Lorraine Cauley. He is preceded in death by his parents James and Eleanore, and his brother Phillip Cauley.Cremation arrangements have been entrusted to the Harold W. Vick Funeral Home, 140 South Main Street, Mt. Wilma Davis Meeker  June 10, 2017 Wilma Davis Meeker passed away peacefully in her home. Originally from Missouri, she received a degree in Business Administration in 1948 from the University of Missouri. She accompanied her husband Brice Meeker, a USDA foreign service officer, to Hungary, Hong Kong, the Soviet Union, The Netherlands, and Australia for 30 years. An avid traveler and sightseer, she especially enjoyed being a junior girl scout troop leader in The Hague. They retired to Falls Church, VA where Brice died in 1988. Wilma volunteered for many organizations. She was a Cuddler for newborns at the Fairfax Hospital ICU, a member of The Welcome to Washington International Club, the Golden Racquet Tennis Club, The Embroidery Guild of America, and Dulin United Methodist Church. Her many interests included gardening, quilting, genealogy, birding, tai chi and environmental issues. She moved to the Goodwin House, Alexandria, in 2012. She is survived by her daughters, Kem Meeker Morawski, Lara Meeker, their husbands, her grandchildren Max, Stevia, Cassie, Rebecca, and her sister Velma Frazer in OK. A Memorial Service will be held on Monday, June 19, 2017 at 1 p.m. at Dulin United Methodist Church, 513 E. Broad St., Falls Church, VA 22046. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to The Chesapeake Bay Foundation and Dulin United Methodist Church.www.everlycommunity.com

903-894-7777 Jacksonville 903-586-2213 Bullard 903-894-7777 Windell David "Jock" Beddingfield Windell David “Jock” Beddingfield, 38, of Flint went to be with his Lord and Savior on Wednesday, January 29, 2020. A teacher to hundreds, a mentor to many and a friend to all. Jock will be remembered for his teasing jokes, his wildly entertaining stories, his unfailing work ethic, and his willingness to come at any time of night to help any neighbor, friend or peer in need. Born in Tyler, TX on March 4, 1981, Jock grew up in the back woods of East Texas. While attending Robert E. Lee High School, under the mentorship of Coach Gary Fleet, Jock received many accolades from his success on the football field as well as in the weight room. On February 7, 1999, Jock committed to continue his football career by signing to play Offensive Lineman for Texas Christian University. As a Horned Frog, Jock competed in three collegiate bowl games. After 3 successful years with TCU, Jock returned to his roots to marry his high school sweetheart. On June 2, 2002 in front of friends and family, Jock and Erika Beddingfield were married. On August 29, 2003, they welcomed the light of his life, Mary Taylan Beddingfield. A devoted father and an avid outdoorsman, Jock spent countless hours in the deer stand or on the water. When not actively engaged in outdoor sports, Jock could be found sharing his passions with others. He loved to take his family and friends out every chance he could. Jock is survived by his parents Kitten and Mark Milanovich and Rock Haynes; wife Erika Beddingfield; daughter Mary Taylan Beddingfield; sister and husband Misty and Wes Fortunas; sister and husband Manny and Josh Hobbs; sister Hannah Haynes; nieces Ali Fortunas and Mary Hobbs; nephews David Fortunas, Noah Hobbs, Eli Hobbs, and Levi Hobbs. He is preceded in death by his grandmother Mary Beddingfield and grandfather Johnny Beddingfield. His life will be celebrated with a Funeral Service, Saturday, February 22, 2020; at 11am, at the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, Bullard, TX (23000 County Rd 145, Bullard, TX 75757) with Bishop Brems officiating. There will be a visitation period prior to the service at the church – to begin a 10am. A Graveside service will follow at Flint Cemetery with Bro. Roy Thoene officiating. Deborah Dobinson, age 60 of Springfield, PA lost her battle to ovarian cancer on Tuesday, March 2, 2021. Deborah was born on August 28, 1960.  Raised in Yeadon, PA and graduated from Yeadon High School.The daughter of Kathleen (Worthington) Dobinson Gallagher and preceded in death by her father, Gerard Dobinson, her stepfather, Francis Gallagher and her sister, Kathleen Dobinson.Debbie is survived by sisters Nancy Dobinson Steinmetz, Carole Dobinson McKee and brothers David Dobinson and Gerard Dobinson, niece and nephews David, Paul, Denise, Robert, Bryan, Tommy, Kyle & Aiden.Debbie spent the majority of her life bartending, a job she loved because she was meeting people and getting to know a lot of the same friendly faces over the years. For those of you who remember, Debbie started at the Barbershop, then moved on to Kathryn’s Restaurant, the Lagoon and then she worked the past 14 years at Springfield Country Club. Debbie always thought about her customers, she would always have their favorite liquors/beers ready behind the bar for an event if she knew you were attending.We thank all of her friends and “Yeadon” supporters that have helped her immensely in their financial and emotional support, a special thank you to Sarah who without her support I don’t know how Debbie would have been able to fight the fight that she fought.Relatives and friends are invited to her Funeral Mass Tuesday, March 9, 2021 10:30am at St. Louis Church, 821 W. Cobbs Creek Pkwy., Yeadon, PA 19050. Int. Private.

He was employed at CSX in Cumberland, MD, for many years as an engineer.Anthony was his own person, very simple, but also known to be political, opinionated, and loved a good debate with anyone.He is survived by his parents, Tony and Querina Martinez; wife, Tiffany Martinez; and daughter, Chelsea Martinez, who was his entire world; step-children, Breanna and Corey Malone; grandson, Matthew Brands, Jr.; brothers, Marty, Mark, and Mario; sisters, Valerie and Naomi.Family and friends will be received at the Scarpelli Funeral Home, P.A., 108 Virginia Avenue, Cumberland, on Friday, November 19, 2021, from 11:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.Funeral services will be conducted at the Maryland State Veteran’s Cemetery, Rocky Gap, 14205 Pleasant Valley Rd NE, Flintstone, on Friday, at 1 p.m.Interment will be in the Maryland State Veteran’s Cemetery, Rocky Gap. Military Honors will be accorded by the Fort Cumberland Post 13 Honor Guard.Condolences for the family may be left at www.ScarpelliFH.comLivestream of Funeral Service:Link to Download Livestream (Good for 90 Days After Service):https://vimeo.com/alleganymedia/download/647466983/7829539852Tribute Video:To send flowers to the family or plant a tree in memory of Anthony Christopher Martinez please visit our Tribute Store.

Dan Laguna went home to be with his Lord on Saturday November 13, 2021 in Liberty Hill, Texas with his family by his side. He was born August 11, 1946 in San Diego, California to Louis Laguna and Chloe Dollarhide. He was the youngest of four boys.Dan served in the Air Force during the Vietnam War and spent several years in Japan. At an early age, he started working in the restaurant industry. He had a passion for exceptional customer service, he loved building and making connections with his customers and employees. He helped start restaurants ranging from a fine dining steak house, fish restaurants and market to taqueria’s. Most recently, he had his real estate license and found much joy in helping people navigate selling or buying a home.Dan’s highest priority was to honor Christ in everything he did. He loved the Lord with all his heart, deeply loved his family, and loved and served Christ’s church. His hope, even now, would be that God would use even his death to bring many to know and love Christ. To God be the glory.He is survived by his wife Lisa Laguna; daughters: Denise Salas and husband Eric, and Diana Laguna; sons: Luke, Joel and Roman Laguna; three grandchildren: Lauren Mendelsohn, Stephen Salas, and Logan Laguna; his in-laws, George and Molly Crowe; his sister-in-law, Kelly Klotzbach and husband Jake; brother-in-law, Danny Crowe and wife Rowena; several nieces, nephews, cousins, friends and colleagues.Dan and Lisa were very involved in the Biblical Counseling Ministry. In lieu of flowers they would love a donation to: Grace Community Fellowship, 7600 West State Hwy 29, Suite 6, Georgetown, TX 78628. Please place "Biblical Counseling Ministry" in the memo line.There will be a private burial at Central Texas State Veteran Cemetery at 11:00 a.m. on November 30, 2021. A livestream link is available here: In Loving Memory of Dan Laguna.The California Memorial Service will be Live-Streamed Here: https://vimeo.com/656408160/e8e1484d4f and will begin at 4:00 p.m. on Friday, December 17th, at Hillside Church San Jose, 545 Hillsdale Ave., San Jose, CA 95136.

Verona Island - William “Billy” J. Murray, 42, passed unexpectedly on November 13, 2021 at his home in Verona. He is predeceased by his grandmother, Joan Murray; and his grandfather, Joseph Murray.Billy was a devoted father, son, nephew, and friend who loved hunting, 4 wheeling and mud trucks. Carl Cato Sand of Salem, Missouri passed away on July 27, 2022 peacefully at home surrounded by his family, at the age of 97. Carl was born on May 17, 1925 in Chicago, Illinois to the late Carl and Helen (Mackey) Sand.Carl’s father was a brick layer and worked on buildings and roads, from the St. Louis Post office to the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco he moved his family around the Country for work. Carl joined the Army and married Adeline “Del” he then went off to Germany towards the end of WWII. With knowing the German language, he taught the German kids how to play baseball. He moved his family to Alaska before it was a state; hunting moose to put food on the table, always sharing the bounty of his hunt with families less fortunate. Christmas was especially important for Carl and Del, they would make baskets for the local families, sharing not only a meal, but knitted socks and gloves that Del would wrap and Carl would play Santa. They fostered half of dozen children who he has kept in contact with for many years and adopting one of them. He was also a Boy Scout leader for any years.Carl was a fair, honest, and a generous man to all. He was always there to lend a hand, teach a new skill, or give advice. One of his finest quality was his inherent ability to listen, to absorb and to offer a point of view based on quiet, measured wisdom. He was a man of his word, a man who loved and appreciated all the beauty this world had to offer, whether fishing a good stream, or pond, Carl know the importance of the meaning of natures bounty. Carl came to Salem in 1985. He got involved in playing baseball, woodworking, the senior Olympics, fishing, and other community activities. He made a lot of friends who would stop him while him was out and about to talk of all the good times they had shared. He was a loving and devoted husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle and friend who will be lovingly missed, and always remembered.Carl is survived by his wife of 77 years, Del, of the home; children, Karen Otter, and husband Del, of Sterling, Alaska, Amy Sand-Prichard, of Salem, MO, and Eric Sand, of Alaska; grandchildren, William Carl Prichard, Dionna Prichard, and Diana Mi; sister, Leta Bowman, of Indiana. In addition to his parents, Carl and Helen Sand, Carl was preceded in death by his son Timothy Sand, and grandsons Tim and Corey Young.A Celebration of Life to honor Carl will be held on Sunday, September 4, 2022 at the Salem Chapel of the James & Gahr Mortuary at 3:00PM with Full Military Honors following. Visitation for family and friends will be held prior to the service from 1PM until service time.

Marian Arlene Young, 90, of Wooster, passed away on Wednesday, July 27, 2022 at her home after a brief period of declining health.Marian was born on May 19, 1932 in Holmes County to the late Ellsworth and Goldie (Roberts) Weahry and married George W. Young on Feb. 7, 1950. George preceded her in death on May 5, 2000. Marian retired from the College of Wooster in the Food Service Dept. and had also worked as a waitress and a seamstress. She was a member of the former Westwood Baptist Church. Marian enjoyed collecting Fredericksburg Pottery and cuckoo clocks. She enjoyed going to the car races, auctions and playing Bingo but her greatest enjoyment was being with her family.Surviving are her children and their spouse, Herbert and Carol Young of Supply, NC, Lillian and Ronny Duncan of Shreve and Barbara VanPelt and John Feltey of Wooster; 6 grandchildren, 11 great-grandchildren and a great great-granddaughter; her special friend and companion, Larry Reed with whom she made her home and his four sons, Rory, Steven, Tony and David Reed that she thought so much of and a sister, Mary Ann Duncan of Fredericksburg.Marian was preceded in death by her husband, a daughter, Blanche and her husband Jay Rohrer, an infant daughter, Dora Beatrice Young and sisters and brother, Anna Mae, Lucille, Elsie, Carol, Betty Jean and James.Memorial service will be Saturday, Aug. 6th at 11:00 a.m. at Murray Funeral Home with her son, Rev. Herbert Young officiating. Friends will be received following the service. Memorial contributions may be made to LifeCare Hospice, 1900 Akron Rd., Wooster, OH 44691 or to the funeral home for a benevolent fund to help other families with final expenses, PO Box 183, Fredericksburg, OH 44627.To send flowersto the family or plant a treein memory of Marian Arlene (Weahry) Young, please visit our floral store.

Sarah Hopson was born on July 16, 1933 to Obediah and Lula Nelson, in Batesville, Mississippi. Sarah had eleven siblings, eight of which preceeded her in death.She met Jesse Hopson and the two were married on July 14, 1950. They remained together until Jesse's death on January 3, 2000. Together they had four children, Joseph (Mary), Eva, Jerome, both of whom preceded her in death, and Deborah.She was a farm worker during her early years. After marriage she worked at home raising her family. Although she did not complete her schooling she was a very intelligent and resourceful woman. She always stressed to her children the importance of getting their education. Sarah was a stylish dresser and had a keen eye for quality materials.Another milestone of Sarah's life was when she dedicated her life to Jehovah by water baptism becoming one of Jehovah's Witnesses on July 7, 1962. She served as a pioneer for a number of years and truly enjoyed that life-saving work. Sarah left a very fine example for her children. As a result, three of them dedicated their lives to Jehovah also three of her grandchildren. Another two are now studying the Bible with Jehovah's Witnesses. How happy she will be to see them all when she awakes in the New World!Sarah leaves to mourn her death, her brothers Robert and Johnny, her sister Louise, son Joseph and daughter Deborah. Also her five grandchildren, eight great grandchildren, three great-great grandchildren and a host of family and friends. She will be greatly missed by all.

Keith Chamberlin was born on August 8, 1949, and passed away in Hartford, Connecticut on April 9, 2023, at the age of 73 years old. He was born and raised in Mount James (Saint Andrew), Jamaica, West Indies. He is predeceased by his parents Doris Powell and Roy Chamberlain. He leaves behind his only son, Chezarae Chamberlin, his sister, Olive Johnson, his grandchildren, Nesharae and Dezarae Chamberlin, and a host of nieces, nephews, and cousins.Keith was a devoted father and hard worker. He enjoyed wrestling, horse racing and was a world pool champion. Keith was also a man of many talents. He shared his love of food with his family and friends, with his preeminent dish being stew chicken with rice and peas. He was the jack of all trades with hands of skill. Keith constructed houses, was adept in the art of carpentry, and serviced the mechanism of vehicles. For many years he worked for the City of Hartford, which suited his indefatigable character of ample achievement. Keith was a hard worker and achieved great success in the artistry of his skills. But his greatest life accomplishment was the love he had for his son, Chezarae Chamberlin. His love for his son grew into the cherishment and adoration he contained for his grandchildren, which will remain until the very end of time.To send flowers to the family of Keith, please visit our floral store.

Mary "Meg" Elizabeth Giroux, 28, beloved daughter, sister, and friend of many, was peacefully called to eternal life while in her sleep on February 28, 2014. Mary was a beautiful, talented, artistic, and vibrant young lady who was both kind and generous. She enjoyed traveling and spending time with family and friends - especially long afternoons on her father's boat. She was a hard worker and free spirit who had a contagious personality and infectious laugh that drew those around her closer. She was also greatly cherished by her many aunts and uncles. Being the first born grandchild to the Giroux and Reagle families, Mary set a great example for love, compassion and humility for all other grandchildren to follow including her brother, Nicholas. She will be greatly missed and her legacy will be etched in our hearts forever, until the day we joyfully meet her in heaven. Mary was preceded in death by her grandparents Lucille and Artie Talkington, Pearl May Reagle, Lee Calvin Reagle and Robert J. Giroux; uncle Father Raymond Giroux; and aunt and namesake Mary Elizabeth Giroux. She will be truly missed by her parents Tracie Giroux and Robert (Pat) Giroux; brother Nicholas (fiancé Caitlin Halligan); companion John Swords; grandparents Sondra and Ernie Gurkins of Salome, AZ and Anne Giroux of Wichita, KS; great aunts Florence Hazelbaker of Meeker, CO and Carol (John) Cammuso of Worcester, MA;  uncles and aunts Lance (Mary) Reagle of Missoula MT, Thomas Giroux of Washington D.C., John Giroux of Baltimore, Maryland, Edmund (Azam) Giroux of Deltona, FL, Angela (Steffen )Scheide of Washington D.C., Anne (Paul) Jasinski of Wichita, KS, Martin (Val) Giroux of West New York, NJ, Raymond (Norma) Giroux of Springfield, VA, David (Bela) Giroux of Washington D.C., and Daniel (Christine) Giroux of Wichita, KS; and many first cousins that adored and loved their cousin Meg.  Friends are welcome on Saturday, March 8 from 9 am-12 pm at the Demaine Funeral Home, Springfield, where a service to celebrate Meg's life will follow at 12:30 pm. In lieu of flowers, the family has suggested memorial contributions to the Compassion Animal Hospital, 11088 Marsh Rd, Bealeton, VA.

Doris J. Winslow, wife of Ronald A. Winslow and a resident of Reading for 66 years, died Thursday, August 31 at Wingate At Reading Rehabilitation Center surrounded by her family.  She was 90 years old. Doris was owner and manager for many years with Ron of Winslow's store on Haven Street, a Reading institution from 1950 to the mid-1970s.  The variety store was across from the depot, open 365 days a year and had loyal customers who relied on it for everything from newspapers, donuts and milk to soda-fountain sundaes, greeting cards, and train tickets.    Beginning in the mid-1970s, she was credit manager at Atlas Paper Co., Woburn for many years.   Doris was born in Fort Wayne, Indiana April 13, 1927, the daughter of Donald D. and Helen (Gerken) Long. She attended Defiance College for a year, where she met Ron. After their marriage, she was secretary to the president of the college before she and Ron moved east in 1950.   Doris was especially proud of her home in Reading, where she hosted simple but elegant parties for family and friends.  She also enjoyed time at the family's summer cottage on Crystal Lake, Gilmanton Ironworks, N.H., where for 60 years, she insisted on maintaining a rustic, "camp" feeling, reflected by the rotary telephone with a three-foot cord that was mounted on the wall.   She and Ron also spent winters for about 20 years at their condominium in Naples Fla. where their Super Bowl party was an annual event.   Doris enjoyed gardening and was an avid artist, producing dozens of paintings, many of which her family members hang proudly in their homes.  One of her favorite events was the annual party when the family gathered to make Christmas cookies.  In addition to her husband, to whom she was married for more than 69 years, she is survived by a son, Ronald A. Winslow Jr. and his wife Larkin Warren of Bethel, CT; a daughter Sandra Cronin and her husband Bruce Cronin of Dracut, MA; two grandchildren, Jeffrey Cronin and Jessica Cronin; a step-grandson, Dennis Ostermaier and his wife Leah Panlilio of New York City; a step-great grandson, Aidan Ostermaier; a sister Virginia Corsini of Lambertville, MI.; and many nieces and nephews. A Funeral Service for Doris will be held at the Douglass, Edgerley & Bessom Funeral Home 25 Sanborn St., (corner of Woburn St.) Reading on Thursday Sept. 7 at 10:00 a.m. Funeral Home visiting hours Wednesday 5-8 p.m. Burial at Forest Glen Cemetery, Reading. Those who wish may make memorial donations to the American Cancer Society 30 Speen St. Framingham, MA 01701.

McCabe Andrea L. Bregg Honored Life Services? Richard A. Kar October 20, 1933 - October 8, 2019 Richard A. Kar, age 85 of Roscommon and formerly of Plymouth, passed away October 8, 2019. To Rick, everyone was a friend. Always engaging and entertaining, he had a contagious personality and loved to make people laugh. As a professional talker, he looked forward to conversing with family, friends and strangers alike. As much fun as Rick had in everyday life, he worked just as hard. He spent most of his career working for Ford Motor Company, putting in plenty of long days. With all his dedication and hard work, however, Rick was able to enjoy his life as he deserved. He made wonderful memories traveling, particularly to the Caribbean or anywhere out West. He liked to hunt, fish and play golf, with trips to the casino added in between. And never shy about being the first one out on the floor, everyone knew how much Rick loved to dance. Rick will be deeply missed by all who knew him, especially by his loving wife, children and grandchildren. Rick was the beloved husband of Susan for 58 years. Loving dad of Michael (Kelly) and Michelle (Nick) Meloche. Proud grandfather of Angelina Kar, Madison Meloche and Harrison Meloche. Dear brother of the late Gregory (Dorothy). Visitation for Rick will be held on Sunday, October 13th, from 2:00 p.m. until 8:00 p.m. at McCabe Funeral Home, 851 N. Canton Center Rd., Canton. Ladislado (Lalo) O. Hernandez was born October 17th 1944 to Eugelio and Manuela Hernandez, and passed away peacefully to be with our Lord Jesus Christ on March 3, 2021 at 12:32 a.m. in San Antonio, Texas at the age of 76. He is preceded in death by his parents Eugelio and Manuela Hernandez. Lalo is survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Christina; Two sons, Jorge and Lalo Jr and his daughter in law Cathy; 5 grandchildren, Christopher, Aaron, Desiree, Dominique, and Raven; Brothers, Eugelio, Armando, Rogelio, David, and sister, Florinda; numerous nieces and nephews and other beloved relatives. Lalo worked as a frame and body man for many years while attending school to receive his Associate's degree to become an instructor in auto body repair. William C. Pewsey DVM, age 86, of Storm Lake, Iowa died November 14, 2021 at Methodist Manor Retirement Community in Storm Lake.Funeral Service will be Friday, November 19, 2021 at 10:30 a.m. at Summit Evangelical Free Church in Alta, Iowa. Burial will be at Storm Lake Cemetery. Visitation will be Thursday, November 18, 2021 from 5-7:00 p.m. at Fratzke & Jensen Funeral Home in STORM LAKE. An Odd Fellows ceremony will take place at 7:00 p.m. after the visitation. The Fratzke & Jensen Funeral Home in Storm Lake is in charge of arrangements.William Charles Pewsey was born November 3, 1935 in Storm Lake, Iowa to Hobart and Ruby (Anderson) Pewsey.Bill went to grade school in Hayes Consolidated School and graduated in 1953. He went on to Iowa State University to pursue Veterinary Medicine.Bill graduated in 1959 as the 2nd in his class with a Doctorate in Veterinary Medicine with honors of Magna Cum Laude.On December 29, 1957, Bill was united in marriage to Barbara Lou Cundiff at the Storm Lake Methodist Church. They were blessed with four children: William, Charles, Jennifer, and Melissa.He was a part of the Rotary Club and Odd Fellows. Bill enjoyed gardening, board games, and cards. He was always supporting his children and grandchildren at their sporting events. He loved to travel and visit his family. Bill vacationed to Branson, Missouri, Okoboji, Iowa, Canada, Washington D.C., and Georgia.Those left to cherish his memories are his children: William (Joni) Pewsey of Phoenix, Arizona; Jennifer (Ed) Tullar of Belmont, North Carolina; Melissa (Chris) Richter of Storm Lake, Iowa; daughter-in-law, Malida Rogers of Charleston, South Carolina; sisters: Joan Stickrod of Omaha, Nebraska; Carol Perkinson of Mesa, Arizona; grandchildren: Crystal Pewsey of Phoenix, Arizona; Casey Fulgham of Phoenix, Arizona; Kyle Pewsey of Phoenix, Arizona; Colette Pewsey of Phoenix, Arizona; Matthew Pewsey of Ooltewah, Tennessee; Anthony Pewsey Rogers of Charleston, South Carolina; Emilee Tullar of Chicago, Illinois; Carlee (Colton) Warnke of Reinbeck, Iowa; Katie Tullar of Nashville, Tennessee; Jason (Mallory) Richter of Aurelia, Iowa; Isaac (Bobbie Jo) Richter of Storm Lake, Iowa; great-grandchildren: Eliana Fulgham of Phoenix, Arizona; Ava Fulgham of Phoenix, Arizona; Shea Fulgham of Phoenix, Arizona; Katie Pewsey of Phoenix, Arizona; Easton Richter of Aurelia, Iowa; Callan Richter of Aurelia, Iowa; and extended family and friends.William is preceded in death by his parents, Hobart and Ruby Pewsey; wife, Barbara Pewsey; son, Chuck Pewsey.

David Simmons, 82, of Guin, Alabama, passed away peacefully on Sunday, November 14, 2021 at his daughter’s home in Dyersburg, Tennessee surrounded by his family. His grandchildren and great-grandchildren knew him as “Daisy” and “GG”.He leaves his two daughters, Tina (Nickey) Cantrell of Dyersburg, Tennessee and Shawn (Terry) Traweek of Winfield, Alabama, along with four grandchildren, Whitney (Tripp) Hutto of Lexington, SC; Christopher Cantrell of Lexington, SC; Tyler (Hope) Traweek of Guin, AL; Brooke Traweek of Tuscaloosa, AL; and five great-grandchildren, Caitlin Hutto & Chase Hutto of Lexington, SC; Sawyer Traweek & Sutton Traweek of Guin, Alabama; and Ava Cade of Tuscaloosa, Alabama.He is preceded in death by his wife, Judy Carolyn Estill in 2011; his father, Reverend Howard Simmons and stepmother, Loudene McKinley in 2008; his mother, Clista Cantrell in 1945; and his brother, Roger Ray Simmons of Picayune, MS in 2019.He was born June 6, 1939 in Barnesville, AL to Ludie Howard Simmons and Clista Cantrell. After graduating from Hamilton High School in Hamilton, Alabama, he studied to be a Lab and X-Ray Technician. He eventually retired from Caraway Methodist Hospital in Winfield, Alabama. He was married to the love of his life, Judy Carolyn Estill, for 52 years. David was an avid CB radio enthusiast and was known as “Horsefly” by his buddies. He was also known for his love of cars and worked briefly for Dewell Emerson Auto Sales in Hamilton, Alabama.For the past two years, David was living in Dyersburg, Tennessee with his daughter, Tina Cantrell, and at Morningside Assisted Living in Jackson, Tennessee. Later he was placed on hospice with Avalon Hospice in Dyersburg, Tennessee.David will be greatly missed by all of his friends and family.Graveside Services held Wednesday, November 17, 2021 at 11:00 AM from the Fulton Bridge Cemetery with Bro. Heath Webb officiating.Memorial Funeral Home of Guin, AL directing.

Loren H. Johnson, age 81, of Cleveland, died Sunday, November 14, 2021 at Water’s Edge in Mankato.Funeral Service 1:00 p.m., Thursday, November 18, 2021 at Our Savior’s Lutheran Church, Cleveland. Visitation will be one hour before service at the church on Thursday. Interment with military honors will be in Calvary Cemetery, Mankato. Mankato Mortuary is in charge of arrangements.Loren was born August 25, 1940, in Mankato to Henry and Winnie (Waddell) Johnson. He graduated from Huntley High School in 1958 and attended Mankato Vocational School. Loren was proud to serve his country with the U.S. Army. Loren was united in marriage to Karen A. Baynes on August 25, 1962, St. John’s Catholic Church, Mankato and they made Cleveland their forever home. He did electronic repair for TV’s, security cameras, and VCRs for many years in Cleveland. He then taught electronics at Mankato Vo-Tech for 11 years. He was later self-employed in weather satellite technology, developing the technology until he retired. He was a member of Our Savior’s Lutheran Church. He enjoyed watching trains, his cats, and feeding the birds.Loren is survived by his wife, Karen; son, Patrick (Karen) Johnson of Thornton, CO; daughter, Pamela (Jack) Bestall of Evergreen, CO; grandchildren, Aidan and Mackenzie Johnson, and Kate Bestall; step-grandchildren, John, Keith, and Kelsey Bestall; sister, Myrna Gilland of Mankato; nieces and nephews.Loren was preceded in death by his parents and brother-in-law, Jerome Gilland.To send a flower arrangement or to plant trees in memory ofLoren H. Johnson, please click here to visit our Sympathy Store.

Carolyn S. “Carol” Sue, 76, of Rensselaer, Indiana passed away Sunday, Nov. 14, 2021 at Franciscan Health Lafayette East. She was born Aug. 1, 1945. She grew up in Benton County where she attended grade school at Gilboa and was involved in 4-H. She was a graduate of Remington High School.Carol was a 14-year member of the Rensselaer Lions Club and received the distinction of being named Lion of the Year at the Lions Club cookout on Aug. 24, 2021, in appreciation and recognition of her outstanding service, devotion and loyalty to the club. She was the recipient of the Lions ROAR award, and was the club Lion Tamer and in charge of club decorations. Carol showed up and volunteered for every activity she could, giving freely of her time to help others.She was an active supporter of St. Augustine Catholic Church and the Knights of Columbus. She served on the Board for Habitat for Humanity for many years and worked in the cafeteria at Van Rensselaer Elementary School.Carol was preceded in death by her mother, Leona M. Wilkerson.A memorial mass will be offered on Wednesday, Nov. 24, 2021 at 12 p.m. CST at St. Augustine Catholic Church. Father Joshua Bennett officiating. Burial will be at Mt. Calvary Cemetery at a later date.Contributions in Carol's memory may be made to the Rensselaer Lions Club or St. Augustine Catholic Church.

Charles Dolab, 78 of Bluffton, SC and Banner Elk, NC passed away suddenly on July 28, 2022 in his beloved mountains of North Carolina. He was born in Troy, New York to two immigrant parents from Armenia.  His father passed away when Charles was just eight years old.  He was the youngest of six children, two brothers and three sisters.After graduating from Arizona State University, he joined the Navy where he served in Vietnam.  Upon his return, he set up his CPA practice in Guilford, Connecticut.  He retired at the young age of 45 and moved his family to Asheville, NC.  It was there that he combined his CPA skills with financial planning and worked as a Registered Investment Advisor until his retirement in 2010.He married Sharilynn L. Noland in 1997 and they enjoyed 25 wonderful years of married life.  He was an avid tennis player, loved boating, hiking, fishing, and volunteering at Grandfather Mountain.  Charles loved to travel and could not wait to plan the next trip.  Life was always an adventure with him.  He will be dearly missed.  His faith in Jesus Christ was strong and Heaven is now his eternal home.

On July 28, 2022, the world lost a bit of the precious magic that enchants it: Christine Nanci Ciarrochi Rothrock – a talented logistician, passionate horsewoman and loving wife, mother, and aunt – passed away at the age of 54. She was born in Akron, Ohio on January 26, 1968, to Lawrence and Marianne Ciarrochi. Christine’s earliest encounters with the horses that she would come to love throughout her lifetime came about during annual family vacations to Cook Forest State Park in northwestern Pennsylvania. Christine would later develop a passion for travel that took her to many far-flung destinations throughout the world: Thailand, Russia, Sweden, Hawaii, Italy, and France, to name but a few. Christine possessed an unquenchable zest for life and a thirst for adventure. She was a straight shooter, genuine to a fault and unafraid to let others know how deeply she cared for them. If you knew Christine, you couldn’t help but get caught up in the excitement of the Next Big Thing she was planning. One of her greatest joys was developing an idea or event and making it Bigger and Better, as anyone who attended one of her Game Nights, Super Bowl parties or New Year’s Eve celebrations can attest. Later in life, she found herself living in rural central Ohio, where she embraced letting her inner horsewoman run free. Though she waged a nineteen-year battle with cancer, she never let it define her or slow her down. She did more with her 54 years on this Earth than most might do with twice that time. Christine was fond of saying that all her favorite things in life had heartbeats. She possessed a big heart and managed to find room within it for anyone and everyone she cared for. She was a cherished wife to her husband, Jason, a mother to her son, Justin, and den mother to her dogs, Einy and Cinder, and her horse, Ghost. She also leaves behind her nephews Cory and Tawn (Katherine), her niece Jacqueline, her great nephews Andres and Elliot, her great nieces Kayleigh, Isabella, and Clementine and brothers Jon, Stephen, and Phillip (Zara). No less dear to her but far too numerous to name individually are her many friends, sisters, and those with whom she formed a tribe. You know who you are.A Celebration of Life will take place on Thursday August 4th at 11 AM at the Rutherford Funeral Home at Powell 450 West Olentangy Street Powell, Ohio 43065. A visitation will take place on Wednesday August 3rd from 6 PM to 8 PM, also at the funeral home. Family and friends may visit an hour prior to the service on Thursday. Please visit www.rutherfuneralhomes.com to offer your condolences or to order flowers. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in her name to either Feeding America (https://www.feedingamerica.org) or the National Park Foundation (https://www.nationalparks.org)Rutherford Funeral Home at Powell is honored to care for the Ciarrochi Rothrock Family.

Ms. Carolyn Virginia Graham, 80, passed peacefully into the arms of her savior, on the morning of Thursday, July 28, 2022 with family by her side and under the care of Bethany Hospice.Carolyn was born in Jesup, Georgia on April 3, 1942 the first of seven siblings born to the late Mr. Lonnie C. Graham Sr. and Mrs. Margaret Lightsey Graham.Carolyn graduated Wayne County High School in Jesup, GA in 1961.Carolyn married in 1962, having a daughter, Carolyn Denyse Drawdy St. Martin, and a son, Everett Colvin Drawdy Jr.Carolyn moved to Hilton Head Island, SC in 1966 to be with family, and then later moved to Bluffton, SC in 1972 where she lived until her retirement in 1999.After her retirement, she moved to Florida until 2015 and then decided to settle back down in Georgia where she spent the remainder of her life.She was preceded in death by her parents, a son Everett Colvin Drawdy, Jr. and a brother, Bobby Graham.She is survived by her beloved daughter and granddaughter, Denyse St. Martin of Longwood, FL and Madyson St. Martin of Tampa, Florida, sisters DeAnna Cramer, Anita Blanton (Tony), Gwen Tilton, Debbie Wentlien (Al) and brother, Lonnie Calvin Graham, Jr.A memorial service will be held at a later date.In lieu of flowers, the family requests that you consider a remembrance to a charity of your choosing.

Kathy Kimball ObituaryKathy Kimball, 75, of Essex Junction, VT, passed on July 28, 2022 after brief complications from heart surgery. She leaves her husband of 51 years, Steve Kimball, of Essex Junction, brother, Milton Karten of Colorado Springs, CO; son, Grant Kimball, and daughter-in-law, Lori Pietryka, both of Essex Junction, VT and Reid Kimball, of North Hollywood, CA. She is also survived by her daughter, Brady Kimball, of Stratham, NH.Born July 5, 1947 in Metuchen, NJ, Kathy dedicated her life to education. Upon graduating from Wilkes University in 1969, she moved to New Orleans to work for Steve’s company, Readak Educational Services. Her love for teaching was sparked through her experiences with Readak, introducing a revolutionary study skills program at private schools around the United States and in the Caribbean.In 1974, Kathy and Steve moved to Harvard, MA and continued to grow Readak into a global education organization. In 1991, she focused her efforts locally, and began working as a special needs tutor at the Harvard Elementary School, until her retirement in 2013.Kathy enjoyed traveling around the world with her husband, cooking from scratch, reading, and spending time with family and friends. Her warm personality and dry sense of humor will be missed by those who knew her.In lieu of flowers, the Kimball family encourages those wishing to pay their respects to consider donating to the charity of their choice in memory of Kathy.To plant a beautiful memorial tree in memory of Kathy, please visit our Tree Store.

Larned – Raymond Kent Frick, 69, passed away April 10, 2023 in Topeka, Kansas.He was born July 30, 1953 in Larned, the son of Raymond George and Alma Mae Debes Frick.A lifetime area resident he was a farmer-rancher and a member of Larned United Methodist Church. He attended Zook Consolidated School until the 6th grade and graduated from Larned High School in 1971. He was a member of Garfield Lions Club and Garfield COOP Board. He was one of the first members of the Pawnee County Fair Board and was instrumental in the construction of the fair buildings. Kent was a 4-H supporter, member and project leader of the Zook Zippers 4-H club. He enjoyed helping with livestock sales, shooting sports and the bucket calf project. He was a Pheasants Forever committee member and instructed hunter’s safety courses. Kent was a lifetime hunter and traveled to various states to hunt deer, elk, antelope, and bear. He had a passion for the land and farming which he shared with his children and grandchildren. Kent loved attending his kid’s and grandchildren’s sporting events and livestock shows.On May 11, 1974 he married Karen Kay Fyler at Larned; she survives.Other survivors include: four children, Dr. Christina Frick (Brent Maxwell), their children, Grayson, Kole and Addison Maxwell, Larned, Melissa (Matt) Brossard, their children, Harley and Carter Brossard, Topeka, Kurtis (Holly) Frick, their children, Chayse, Kaden and Paisley Frick, Larned, and Audra (Dustin) Geiger, their children, Natalie and Mason Geiger, Topeka; sister, Kim (Terry) Fairchild, Overland Park.He was preceded in death by his parents.Funeral service will be 10:00 a.m. Wednesday, April 19, 2023 at Larned United Methodist Church with Pastor Tricia North presiding. Visitation will be 9:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. Tuesday, April 18, 2023 at Beckwith Mortuary, Larned, with family present from 6-8 p.m. Burial will be in the Larned Cemetery.Memorials may be given to Pawnee County 4-H Foundation in care of Beckwith Mortuary, PO Box 477, Larned, Kansas 67550. Personal condolences may be left at www.beckwithmortuary.com.To plant Memorial Trees in memory of Raymond Kent Frick, please click here to visit our Sympathy Store.

Ella Ann Kimble, age 92 of Moundsville, WV, formerly of New Martinsville, passed away Monday, April 10, 2023, at WVU Camden Clark Hospital, Parkersburg, WV.She was born April 23, 1930, in McConnellsville, OH, the daughter of the late Carlos and Monna Alice (Sutton) Kendle.Ella was a member of Hillview Terrace Church of Christ and Pine Street Church of Christ; she was always active in church; loved to travel; enjoyed Sarah’s dogs; and was very helpful, kind and caring to people.In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Lyle Franklin Kimble; a daughter, Monna Alice Kimble; a brother, Melvin Kendle, and a sister Lucille Finley.Survivors include three children; Lyle Franklin (Becky) Kimble, Jr of Peach Tree City, GA; Rebecca Sue (Johnny) Weekley of Paden City, WV, and Sarah Ann Kimble, of Moundsville; two grandchildren, Lyle Franklin (Melissa) Kimble, III, of Smyrna, GA and Tifny Jo (Brian) McFadden, of Newnan, GA; two great grandchildren Charlie & Cameron; Sarah’s dogs, Rusty and Anna; her dear friend, Marilyn Martin; and her best friend of 83 years, Sarah Johnson.Family will receive friends on Friday 10am until time of Funeral Service at 1pm at Grisell Funeral Home & Crematory 751 Third Street, New Martinsville with Evangelist Andy Robison officiating.Interment in Paden Memorial Gardens, Paden City.

Emeline Hannah Dustin Brown died at her home, Oakland Farm, near Waterford, on December 16, 2009.  Born on June 24, 1914, in Philadelphia to George Kimball and Lily Gross Brown, she was preceded in death by brother Charles Gross (Thomas) Brown, and sisters Josephine Brown, Mary Louise Wildes Brown, Katherine Franklin Brown, and Violet Dudley Brown.  Oakland was the home of the Browns and their ancestors from 1757, when forebear Joseph McGeach/McGeath settled there.  In 1976, the state of Virginia awarded the Brown family a bicentennial plaque honoring their more than two centuries of ownership.The Brown family formerly maintained homes in Philadelphia and Royersford, Pennsylvania and had extensive land and railroad interests in Florida.  Hannah often related the family's arrival for the summer months from Philadelphia when she was a child at Point of Rocks, Maryland.  The train would make a special stop and let them off: Edgar Beans of Waterford met them with his horses and carriage.  Their dog, "Uncle Dash," would race ahead and greet them, panting, on the front steps when they arrived.  In 1976, Hannah and her sisters closed their house in Philadelphia and retired to their Waterford farm.  The Brown siblings were remarkable for longevity.  All but an infant sister attained more than 90 years.A longtime member of St. Francis DeSales Catholic Church in Purcellville, Miss Brown taught CCD and was a member of the Women's Council.  She and her sisters were known for their love of animals:  many a stray dog and cat found its way to their door and none was turned away.  No immediate family survives.  Memorial donations may be made to Blue Ridge Hospice, 333 West Cork Street, # 405, Winchester, VA 22601; St Frances DeSales Church, 37700 St., Francis Court, Purcellville, VA 20132; Humane Society of Loudoun County, P.O. Box

James David Julien, 75, of Independence, MO passed away peacefully on October 9, 2019. He was a devoted husband to his wife Ruth who preceded him in death. James was born in Leavenworth, Kansas on June 24, 1944 and adopted at age two by Dorsey and Wilma Julien. A graduate of Raytown High School class of 1962, he attended Central Missouri State College at Warrensburg and worked as a welder in the Plumbers and Gas Fitters Union Local No. 8. He entered the US Army where he proudly served his country in the 101st Airborne as a First Lieutenant Combat Infantry Platoon Leader during the Vietnam War earning two Bronze Medals for bravery in combat from 1967-1969 and was a long standing member of the American Legion Post 21, the home post of Harry S. Truman. He will be honored by many for his dedication to those he served throughout the years. James enjoyed dancing, old westerns, hunting, fishing and country music. He leaves behind his beloved dogs Butch and Twiggy, his daughter Stacy Lombardo (John) and his son James Julien II (Noel), step-children, Steven Kramer, Anne Kramer Rule and Sarah Noernberg (Joe); grandchildren David, Regina, James, Nickolas, Bailie, Marty, Ellie and Nathaniel; extended family and friends. Visitation will take place on Wednesday, October 16th, 2019 from 12-1 p.m. at Park Lawn Funeral Home, 8251 Hillcrest Road; Graveside service with full military honors will follow in Green Lawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers please send donations in his memory to the Wounded Warrior Project, PO Box 758516, Topeka, KS 66675 or online at support.woundedwarriorproject.org

Janoski, 94, of Cambridge Springs, passed away, Wednesday, October 9, 2019 at Marquette Hospice House. She was born on June 1, 1925 a daughter of Carl Buell and Vena Coons Buell.
