Obituary for Russell Meyer | Moody Funeral Service & Crematory "We strive for a quality of service that will give you a service of quality." Russell Meyer November 9, 1934 ~ October 9, 2019 (age 84) Dr. Russell Meyer, age 84 of Stuart, Virginia passed away on Wednesday, October 9, 2019, at his home. He was born in Hillman, Michigan on November 9, 1934, to the late John Meyer and Manya Chemlewski Meyer Bowen. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by one son, Russell Hamilton Meyer, and one brother, Rene Meyer. Dr. Meyer graduated from Vineland High School, received his undergraduate degree from the University of Indiana, and then completed his medical education at the University Of Indiana College Of Medicine. Russell truly enjoyed being a doctor and serving his patients. He ran a successful practice in Virginia Beach called Eye Specialist for 33 years and was highly thought of by his loyal employees and patients. Dr. Meyer faithfully served his country in the U.S. Navy and had achieved the rank of Captain. He will be remembered for being gentle, humble, and kind to everyone he met. His family will always treasure the memories of a wonderful husband and a loving father. Dr. Meyer is survived by his wife, Donna Touchstone Meyer, of the home; five children, Manya Marie Meyer of Vineland, NJ, Harrison Bowen Meyer of Virginia Beach, VA, Jesse Daniel Meyer and wife, Jillian Canada Meyer of Virginia Beach, VA, Allen Touchstone of Honolulu, HI, and Aubree Noelle Touchstone of Stuart, VA; three grandchildren, Henry Winston Meyer of Virginia Beach, VA, Ferida Cralle and husband, Joseph of Fredericksburg, VA, and Lara Moon and husband, Buddy of Fredericksburg, VA; four great-grandchildren; Mickey Moon, Charlotte Moon, Joseph Cralle, Jr. and John-Paul Cralle; and two brothers, William Adolph Meyer of Vineland, NJ and Pete Meyer and wife, Pat of Charlotte, NC. A celebration of a life well-lived will be held at the home at 7:00 p.m. on November 9, 2019, what would have been his 85th birthday. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to St. Paul School, 231 Flower Gap Road, Cana, VA 24317. Online condolences may be sent by visiting www.moodyfuneralservices.com. Celebration of Life at 7:00 PM on November 9, 2019. Directly place your order here. Kyrma Ruth Welton, age 90, of Camas, WA passed away peacefully on March 4, 2021.She was born February 5, 1931 in Visalia, CA to Dr. Kyrmel Lawisch Hickman and Ruth Blood Bennett. In 1951, Kyrma married John (Jack) Webster Welton in the Logan, UT Temple. Kyrma was a devoted wife and mother. She lived all over the world with Jack and their children, including American Samoa, Tonga, Australia, and Hawaii.  Kyrma loved to spend time with family, play games, and watch sports. She was a faithful member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints. She served in many callings, including as a worker in the Fresno Temple. Kyrma lived a life of cheerful service. When Jack became ill, she selflessly cared for him every day for many years until his passing. The family is filled with peace knowing that they are together again. She was preceded in death by her parents, husband, and sister Judith Ann Mazzoni. She is survived by her four children Jon (Bettie), Lori (Kerry Poulson), Scott (Jana), and Marc, 13 grandchildren, and 18 great-grandchildren.  To send a flower arrangement or to plant trees in memory ofKyrma Welton, please click here to visit our Sympathy Store.

Oleta Mae Cox Roark, age 93 of Graham, Texas, died peacefully on July 29, 2022, in McKinney, Texas. The funeral service will be at the First Baptist Church in Graham, Texas, on August 6, 2022, at 10 a.m under the direction of Morrison Funeral Home. Rev. Richard Segars and Rev. Jerry Blake will officiate and interment will be at Pioneer Cemetery.Oleta Mae Cox Roark was born on August 7, 1928, at her family home near Loving, Texas, to John Malcolm and Mable (Reeves) Cox. She gave her life to Christ at the age of 8 years old at the Loving Baptist Church in Loving, Texas. She went on to marry Rufus Wayne Roark on August 31, 1947, in the “old” First Baptist Church in Graham, Texas, where they first met, by the Rev. Dallas Lee. The First Baptist Church remained a special place for them throughout their lives together as they raised a family within the Church and were lifelong members.Oleta retired from the Hexcel Corporation after working 28 years as an accountant, but most of her time, energy, and efforts went to serving the Lord as a member of the First Baptist Church. There, she sang in the Celebration Choir, was a Sunday School and Training Union Teacher, Departmental Director of the Fourth Grade, and a Children’s Choir Director. However, the Adult Choir and the Ladies Ensemble, “Highest Praise,” was where she felt led to continually serve and witness for her Lord. After she retired from Hexcel, Oleta acted as the “Tour Director” for the Adult Choir as she planned and coordinated many concerts and fellowship trips to destinations such as Branson, Missouri.Oleta was also a devoted wife, mother, and grandmother; she loved her family deeply and passionately throughout her life. She is survived by her son & son-in-law, Mack Roark & Larson Rose, of Brooklyn, New York; her son and daughter-in-law, Ross & Kathy Roark, of McKinney, Texas; a grandson, Hunter Roark, and a granddaughter, Harper Roark, of McKinney, Texas; a daughter-in-law, Dale Roark of Hendersonville, Tennessee; and former son-in-law & husband, Jim & Stuart Freides, of Miami, Florida. She is survived by many brothers and sisters and their spouses: Gwen Dyrud of Laurel, Maryland; Marlene & Richard Champion of Benbrook, Texas; Maxine & Charles Tucker of Azle, Texas; Betty Frazer of McKinney, Texas; John Ben Schlittler of Rising Star, Texas; and Willard & LaDonna Schlittler of Bryson, Texas. She is also survived by a host of precious nieces and nephews that she loved dearly.Oleta was preceded in death by her husband of 71 years, Wayne Roark; her father, John Malcolm Cox; her mothers, Mable (Reeves) Cox, Oleta (Deering) Cox, and Elmina (Caudell Schlittler) Cox; and her son, Scott Roark.Memorials in her name can be made to the Music Ministry of the First Baptist Church, 620 4th Street, Graham, Texas, 76450, or to the charity of your choice.Her family will receive visitors and friends at Morrison Funeral Home from 5 to 7 p.m., on Friday, August 5, 2022.To send flowers to the family in memory of Oleta Roark, please visit our flower store. John Stokke-----79, Granville, ND, passed away on Friday, July 29, 2022 in a Minot hospital.John William Stokke was born September 8, 1942, the third son of Iver and Dorothy (Busch) Stokke in Minot, ND. He was raised on the family farm and attended School in Granville, where he graduated in 1960.After graduation John enlisted in the United States Navy where he was stationed in Bermuda. John was honorably discharged on September 6, 1963.Following his discharge, John returned to the family farm, where he enjoyed the farm lifestyle. He also worked in maintenance at the Minot Air Force Base, making sure the runways were always clear of snow. Following his retirement, John continued to live in Granville, ND, where he resided at the time of his death.John was a member of the Granville American Legion Post #155, where he held various offices. He enjoyed target shooting, hunting and having breakfast at the Memorial Diner in Granville with his friends. He loved sharing his strong convictions on every topic, but was also tolerant of his more liberal relatives on the West Coast. John will be remembered for his faith, determination, sincerity, his great sense of humor and his love for his family and friends. He will be dearly missed by all who knew him.John is survived by his brother: Edwin (Marcia) Stokke Vancouver WA; sister-in-Law, Carole Stokke, Tigard, OR; nieces and nephews; Keith Stokke, James Stokke, Iver Stokke, Rebecca Tryon, Kathy Erwin, Debbie Locke and Eugene Stokke.John was preceded in death by his parents, brothers Vern, Eugene, M. Wesley Stokke and nephew Daniel Stokke.Visitation: Saturday, August 6, 2022, 9:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m. at Hope Congregational Church, Granville, ND.Funeral Service: Saturday, August 6, 2022 at 10:00 a.m. at Hope Congregational Church, Granville, ND.Graveside Service: Saturday, August 6, at 12:00 p.m. at Rosehill Cemetery, Norwich, ND.In Lieu of flowers, memorials may be given in John’s memory to Hope Congregational Church, of Granville or to a location of Donor’s Choice.

Ronnie Doran, 60, of Baton Rouge, passed away peacefully on July 29, 2022, surrounded by his two daughters. Ronnie was born on August 5, 1961 to Buddy and Jewel Doran in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. After graduating from Tara High School in 1979, he worked at the family business, Doran's Tires and Alignment. He then started his own company, Doran Enterprises, focused on Real Estate Development in Baton Rouge and the surrounding areas. Ronnie was passionate about outdoor activities and could often be found boating, fishing, golfing, or enjoying time on the beach. Ronnie and his dad worked for months to build his dream home on the Tickfaw River. He also spent his time at his condo in Destin, Florida which was his little slice of paradise. He was also a huge supporter of live music in the Baton Rouge and Destin areas. Ronnie is survived by his two daughters, Elise Ewing (Hunter) and Camille Doran, his parents, Buddy and Jewel Doran, his brother, Randy Doran, and his sister, Tracy Doran. Anyone who knew Ronnie knew that he was a loving father, son, brother, and friend. There will be a memorial for Ronnie on Friday, August 5th, to celebrate what would have been his 61st birthday, from 11am - 1pm at the Santa Maria Clubhouse.

Virginia Nell Zimmerman, née Blessing, passed away on July 29, 2022, after gracing us with a long and fabulous 90 years. She was born to William L. Blessing and Nell Kate Carey, in Colfax, Washington, on October 19, 1931, but it was Yakima she called home.Virginia graduated from Yakima High School in 1949, and later went on to work for Pacific Northwest Bell Telephone and West Coast Airlines, followed by 30 years as a career guidance counselor with the Washington State Department of Employment Security.She married Harvey W. Cottle in 1950, and the two shared three children, Gail, Alan, and Mark. She married Joseph D. Zimmerman in 1977, to whom she remained married until his death in 2016.Virginia enjoyed a party with friends and family more than most, particularly if it came with a good gin martini, and anytime she had a glass in hand, a biting and hilarious quip wasn’t far behind. She also loved to host her friends and family for any and every reason she could find and enjoyed cooking and baking for such occasions. She even taught her granddaughters a few favorite recipes throughout the years.Virginia loved theater, music, and visual art, and consumed as much of it as she possibly could. She also loved to travel, which took her everywhere from the bright lights of Broadway, to her ancestral home of Ireland, a favorite trip she was able to take with her husband, Joe. She was a lifelong avid reader and frequent movie-goer, so much so that some of her final days were spent picking apart the differences between a book and its new movie adaptation.Virginia was of strong Christian faith, and in her later years attended St. Michael’s and St. Timothy’s Episcopal Churches in Yakima, Washington.Virginia was preceded in death by her parents, William L. Blessing and Nell Kate Carey, her brother, William L. Blessing Jr., her husband, Joseph D. Zimmerman, her cousin, Stanton Smart, and her nephew, Stanton Blessing. Virginia is survived by her children, Gail Cottle, her husband Ren Brown, Alan Cottle, his wife Monica, and their daughters Alex and Mackenzie (Phil Ward), Mark Cottle, his wife Lauri, and their daughters Morgan and Alison (Hugo Santalucia), and great-grandson, Jack. She is also survived by her niece, Kelly Swoboda, her husband Mike. Her legacy and values will live on through her kin, who share her zest for life and love of family.A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, charitable contributions in Virginia’s name can be made to The Yakima Symphony Orchestra, The Yakima Humane Society, or a charity of your choice, and sent in care of Brookside Funeral Home (PO Box 1267, Moxee, WA 98936).Virginia’s family would like to offer a special thank you to the staff and caregivers of Yakima Valley Memorial Hospital and Cottage in the Meadow, for their care and kindness during Virginia’s ﬁnal days.Brookside Funeral Home is caring for the family. Memories and condolences may be shared at www.brooksidefuneral.com.To plant Memorial Trees in memory of Virginia Nell Zimmerman, please click here to visit our Sympathy Store.

ObituaryJeffie Sue Neyendorf, age 83, of Fort Walton Beach, Florida, peacefully passed away April 11, 2023. She was born on February 8, 1940, to Matthew and Maude Chambers. Sue married Robert Neyendorf, Sr. on October 16, 1968, in Georgia. Shortly after marriage, they relocated to Fort Walton Beach, Florida, where she became a homemaker. She worked a short time at Bacon’s By The Sea Resort before starting her career with Okaloosa County School District and retired. Sue worshiped with her family at Westwood Baptist Church where she was a member of the choir and was a pianist. Among many things Sue loved were her family, friends and cooking. Her macaroni and cheese was the best in the universe.. just ask any one of her grandchildren. She loved to travel with her best friend, Doris, to find all the great bingo spots, as well as playing locally. Sue loved to frequently travel back to her birthplace in the Georgia mountains.Sue is survived by her children, Joe Johnson of Toccoa, Georgia, Robert (Dwana) Neyendorf of Niceville, Florida, and Matthew Neyendorf of Fort Walton Beach, Florida; twelve grandchildren; eighteen great grandchildren; and four great great grandchildren. Sue is also survived by her sister, Edith (Bill) Bullock of Fort Walton Beach, Florida; and numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. She was preceded in death by her husband, Robert Neyendorf, Sr.; children, Janet Susan Neyendorf, Steve Johnson, Nancy Johnson and Susan Polson; brothers, Jerry Chambers and Larry Chambers; and sisters, Janette Smith and Diane Harper.Graveside service to be held Sunday, April 16, 2023 at 1:00 p.m. at Beal Memorial Cemetery.

Gary Bill Posey of Midland died Sunday, March 2, 2014 in his home.  He was born March 9, 1965 in Marshfield, Missouri, the son of Charles D. and Jo Ann (Mannan) Posey of Hackett.  Gary graduated from Hartford High School and was immediately employed by the Sebastian County Road Department, where he became a Senior Heavy Equipment Operator.  Gary retired from the SCRD on September 30, 2013 after serving the county for 30 years.   Gary was awarded a plaque by Sebastian County Judge David Hudson in sincere appreciation for his many years of service to Sebastian County.Gary was a member of the Friends of Foreign Wars Post #8845.  He was an avid deer and turkey hunter with numerous trophies collected in the sports.  Gary was known to keep himself busy seven days a week.  In addition to the before mentioned activities and his work with the county, Gary could be found in his own wood working shop designing and making beautiful projects.  Gary also enjoyed working with his cattle alongside his longtime surviving loving companion, Tami "Smurf" Burrows.  Gary is also survived by his mother Jo Ann Posey; two sisters, Jo Lynn Posey of Bonanza, Deborah Ann Burgess of Hackett; one brother, David Lee Posey and wife, Toni of Midland.  Gary had countless friends from many age groups and walks of life.  Gary was preceded in death by one infant brother, Charles David Posey, Jr., his maternal grandparents, Johnie and Aster Mannan; his paternal grandparents, Clarence and Mary Posey.Graveside service will be 2 p.m., Thursday, March 6, 2014 at Hartford Memorial Park under the direction of McConnell Funeral Home of Greenwood. Honorary pallbearers will be the Sebastian County Road Department Employees.To sign an online guest book, please visit www.mcconnellfh.com
Arrangements under the direction of Griggs-Schooler-Gordon Funeral Directors, Amarillo, TX.

Our Mama, Our Mickey, My Mickey… Michelle Marie Baugh (Baker) of Adrian, Mich., died Friday, April 8, 2016, surrounded by her loved ones after a long struggle with COPD. She was born Oct. 4, 1950. The beloved daughter of Keith M. and Mildred R. (Potes) Baker. After graduating from Madison High School in 1968, she married Bruce (Mike) Baugh on Nov. 22, 1968, and they were blessed with three wonderful children, Jenna (Shane) Waldrop, Kelly Baugh and Richard Baugh. She worked mostly as a nurse's aide and had a special way with the elderly. Michelle also worked at ACO Hardware and become quite the DIY expert. Above all her most beloved job was being a stay-at-home mom. Her children will cherish that time spent together and the memories they made. Surviving her in addition to her children are her sisters, Kathy (Mike) Bemis, Julie (John) Wellnitz, Jennie (Al) Zubke and all of their families; her grandchildren, Joshua, Emily and Alyssa Helminiak; her namesake, Jillian Michelle Baugh and Jayden Jimenez; and one very special great-granddaughter, Amya Regalado. After their divorce she remained close to her former husband, Bruce, and his wife, Regina Baugh, and his family, especially Bobbi "Mom Baugh," her forever mother-in-law. They all held a special place in her heart. She was preceded in death by her parents, Keith and Midge Baker; her brother and sister-in-law, Keith Alan and Cindy Baker. The loves of her life were her children, her family and her precious dog, Einstein. She brought so much love to others and found pure joy in doing so. She always said that "Love is in the Details" and lived her life proving that. 'Til we meet again, we'll remember you always, Our Mama, Our Mickey, My Mickey.Funeral services for Michelle will be held on Tuesday, April 12, 2016, at 1 p.m. at Anderson Funeral Home, Adrian, with the Rev. Bruce Jewett officiating, to be followed by cremation. Visitation will be held on Monday from 1 to 5 p.m. at Anderson Funeral Home, Adrian. Visitation will also be held on Tuesday from  noon until 12:45 p.m. prior to the funeral service at Anderson Funeral Home, Adrian.You may send condolences to the family at www.andersonfuneralservices.com. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to her children to help offset expenses. Envelopes are available at Anderson Funeral Home, Adrian.

WILLIAMSTOWN - Carl Peter Hannus, fondly known as "Pete," passed away peacefully Sept. 2, 2017 with his two daughters at his side .Peter was born on Nov. 28, 1946 in Northampton, Massachusetts, and spent his early years in Amherst enjoying the surrounding farms before moving with the family to Williamstown. Peter graduated from Mt. Greylock High School in 1964. He was an avid musician, playing the clarinet in his high school band and performing for musicals and concerts. He went to Boston University to study music and worked as road manager for a jazz fusion band, Osmosis.Peter then studied television repair via correspondence school before moving back to Western, Massachusetts. He carried on his passion for music by playing his guitar for his daughters. He made television repair house calls for many years before shifting with the times to computer chip testing. He retired to Vermont in 2013 to be closer to his grandchildren.In addition to playing music, Peter was an enthusiastic fisherman, a competitive pool player, and an avid fan of all things science fiction. He was most comfortable at home on a Sunday with the Boston Globe in his hand and the weeks' papers stacked at his elbow, determined to read every inch.Peter leaves behind his daughters, Jessame Hannus, and Amy Skapof, son-in-law Max Skapof, grandchildren Zoey and Theo Skapof; two sisters, Cindy Hannus and Barbara Hannus Crossman, and his brother, Ralph Hannus, as well as five nephews. He was predeceased by his parents, Reuben and Dorothy Hannus. His family will gather for a private celebration of Pete's life in Williamstown this fall. Donations in his name may be made to the VNA Respite House in Colchester, Vermont.To sign a Guest Book, express condolences, share memories and read other obituaries, go to the online obit.

Hillsborough, NJ- Vicki Thoden, 69, entered into eternal rest on Monday, June 22, 2020 at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital Somerset in Somerville, NJ. Born in St. Joseph, MO, daughter of the late William (Talmadge) Turner and Patricia (Johnson) Turner, she had resided at the Rehab at Rivers Edge in Raritan NJ.Vicki dedicated her life to raising and taking care of her family. She loved her cats and spending time with friends and family. She enjoyed art, calligraphy, writing, music and movie soundtracks. She opened her heart and her home to many of her son’s friends. She was quick to be nice and friendly to strangers and always gave as much as she could to her community. She volunteered her whole life from helping at the schools to pet adoption agencies. She loved and cared for her grandson, and will be deeply missed by all who knew her.Beside her father, Vicki was predeceased by her grandmother Ruby Turner.Vicki leaves behind to cherish her memory her loving mother, Patricia Turner, her husband Richard Thoden, her cherished sons, Troy Thoden and his wife Jen, and Ross Thoden. She will be deeply missed by her cherished grandson Jamisen Thoden whom she adored. Vicki is also survived by her brother, Vince Turner and his wife Deann, and sister, Diane Turner (Hart).Private funeral arrangements have been entrusted to Fucillo & Warren Funeral Home, 205 South Main Street, Manville, NJ 08835.

Mr. David Wayne Norman, 71, of Winterville and Northeast Georgia passed away Friday, March 5, 2021 at his home.He was a native of Las Vegas, Nevada, and the son of the late Walter and Louise Norman. Mr. Norman graduated from Mercer University with a Bachelor’s Degree in Business & Economics. He taught Motorcycle Mechanics at North Georgia Technical College, Clarksville, GA, as well as being a self-employed Master Motorcycle Mechanic. He served his country in the United States Navy. Madeline Brison, age 90, of Toughkenamon, PA went home to be with the Lord on March 5, 2021.  She was the wife of the late James Irving Brison who died in 1999 and with whom she shared 54 years of marriage. Born in London Grove, PA she was the daughter of the late Ernest Bowman and Eleanor Davis Bowman. She received her education in the Unionville School.Madeline was a Domestic Engineer for several private families.  She also worked in several local drinking establishments as a barmaid/manager with Sam’s Inn being her main tenure.  She retired from The Country Butcher where she was able to flourish with her self-taught cooking skills, ultimately acquiring the name “The Potato Salad Lady”.She excelled in handmade crafts, participating in craft shows, then eventually having in-home shows and weekly yard sales.  Madeline was a member of the Wednesday Night Mixed Bowling League.  She enjoyed the great sounds of B.B. King, Aaron Neville, Smooth Jazz, and various Gospel artists.She leaves to cherish her memory three daughters; Joyce M. Bladen (Dennis) of Newark, DE, Joan M. Thomas and companion (Joe) of Parkesburg, PA, Joanne M. Carter at home; two sons, Robin J. “Bubby” (Robin) of Elkton, MD, Richard C. (Nydia) of Lincoln University, PA; four sisters, Mary Clayburn of Las Vegas, NV, Ernestine Garner of Gap, PA, Roberta Bowman of Avondale, PA, Harriett Shockley of Coatesville, PA; 10 grandchildren, two of whom she reared, Robert S. Brison (Jacqueline) of Kennett Square, PA, Michael J. Brison and partner (Jason) of Chestertown, MD, and 14 great-grandchildren who she adored.  In addition to her husband, she was predeceased by two sons, Robert J. and Ronald I. and her fur baby, Roxie.You are invited to visit with Madeline’s family and friends on Saturday, March 13, 2021 from 10-11AM at Calvary Baptist Church of Avondale, 218 Ellicott Road, Avondale, PA 19311.  Her funeral service will follow at 11AM.  Due to COVID, masks are required and social distancing will be followed.  Interment will be in Union Hill Cemetery, Kennett Square, PA.  Contributions in her memory may be made to Active Day of Kennett Square, 500 Old Forge Lane Suite 503, Kennett Square, PA 19348.Arrangements are by Matthew Grieco of Grieco Funeral Home & Crematory, Inc. (1-800-FUNERAL). To view her online tribute, please visit www.griecofunerals.com.

Ricky "Rick" Turner, 65, was born in Mooresville, NC on April 30, 1956. He was the son of the late Mayhew and Lolean Turner.Ricky was a fun loving person who lived to cherish and share laughter. Rarely did he meet a stranger. He was known by so many, most of which speak of his sense of humor and be personality. He had a way to make anyone he was around smile. He loved the Lord and didn't mind telling those who he came in contact with about his faith and the God he served.Ricky was an ordained Elder of Bibleway Church of the Living God, where he was a lifelong member. He grew up in the Bibleway Headquarters church in Statesville, NC where he served the church in many capacities. He served as a deacon and was a member of the Jubilee Gospel Singers, and he loved to sing the songs of the old. He served as the coordinator of the pastoral anniversaries for the late Bishop H.J. Daniels and Overseer G.A Daniels. Ricky also directed the Junior Jubilee Gospel Singers, second generation choir. He took great pride in showing off this talented group of young folk in the Mooresville Area.Simply put, Ricky loved life and love people. To know him, was to love him; which was an extension of his big and loving family, where he was the baby boy.He was preceeded in death by his parents, Mayhew and Lolean Turner, his sister; Gwendolyn Turner, brothers; John Garland and Allen Turner also preceeded him in death, and his brother-in-love Mack Tucker.To cherish his life, Ricky leaves precious memories to those he loved best; his sons, Pervis Gillion Sr. and Ricky Turner Jr. His grandchildren, Dezariah Blackwood, Pervis Gillion Jr., Tremell Gillion, Brielle Simons, Kahmaria Turner, and Kie Turner. One brother, Ivory (Doris) Turner of Statesville, NC; two sisters, Barbara (Allan) Lowery and Tawanna Tucker both of Mooresville, NC. A god sister, Carolyn (Hubert) Harris, and a host of nieces and nephews.To send flowers to the family or plant a tree in memory of Ricky Turner, please visit our floral store.

Linda K. Muensterman of Augusta, MO, went home to be with Jesus on Saturday, July 30, 2022. She was born on September 21, 1945 in Lincoln County Missouri to Duncan Alexander Luck and Hazel (Wilson) Luck. Linda married the love of her life, Bob (Robert)Muensterman, on October 1,1966. From this blessed union two sons, Douglas and and Dean, were born.Linda enjoyed working alongside Bob and the boys on their family farm. She was an avid gardener and the ultimate flower whisperer. Fall was her favorite season. Linda was a stylish farm girl at heart that could fashionably rock rubber farm boots or fur and rhinestones on any given day. Linda delighted in her grandchildren. Her favorite day was being out in the Missouri countryside, spending time with Bob, surrounded by her sons and their families. Linda loved Jesus most of all. And the genuine love that she had for Him made her sparkle from the inside out. Linda was a loving wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend. She will be greatly missed by all those who loved and knew her.Linda is survived by her beloved husband Bob of Augusta, Missouri, son, Douglas (Kristi) Muensterman, with granddaughters Elizabeth, Kaitlen, and Mackenzie, and grandson Benjamin Muensterman of Missouri, son, Dean (Anne) Muensterman with granddaughters: Lauren and Kaley Muensterman of Virginia, sister, JoAnn Schaper of Overland Park, Kansassister Barb (John) Norvel of Elsberry, Mo, sister-in-law Pam Muensterman of Troy, Mo, brother-in-law Phillip Burg of Lake St. Louis, Mo, along with nieces, nephews, and many other family and friends.A Celebration of Life Gathering, followed by a meal will be held on, Saturday, August 13, 2022, 12:30 p.m., at the, Mill Creek Baptist Church, 645 Millcreek Church Road, Silex, Mo, 63377. Inurnment will be private. Friends and family are invited to visit our website at mccoyblossomfh.com to sign the on-line guest register.

Pat Drescher was born in Longmont, Colorado on January 11, 1931 to Paul Lynn and Jessie Mae Drescher. Shortly after birth, Pat moved to Arizona where his parents farmed in Oak Creek Canyon near the town of Cottonwood. During grade school Pat attended Oak Creek School which was a two room country school near the ranch.At age sixteen, Pat moved to Reno, Nevada where he graduated from Reno High School in 1949. He attended the University of Nevada Reno for two years pursuing a pre-legal degree before entering the Air Force to become a fighter pilot on February 9, 1954. Upon completion of pilot training, he returned to the Nevada Air National Guard and served as a F-86 fighter pilot assigned to the Air Defense Command until his discharge on May 31, 1956.After separation from the military, he became owner/operator of a small antique and pawn shop until 1962 when he was employed by the City of Sparks Fire Department where he served for 28 years. Pat's primary assignment was fire prevention and investigation. He attended the Western Nevada Community College for two years and graduated with an Associate of Arts degree in Fire Science. After retiring from the fire service on April 15, 1990 at the rank of Fire Marshal / Battalion Chief, he spent approximately ten years as a private investigator specializing in Fire Investigation.In February of 2000, Pat moved to Amidon, North Dakota where he operated "Firehouse Antiques" for three years and then in 2003 moved to Sidney, Montana where he married Mavis Schledewitz and enjoyed total retirement.Pat was very active in scouting throughout his lifetime. He spent many years as a scoutmaster, serving on Woodbadge training staff while in Nevada. He was also active in Kiwanis for over thirty years and served as club president in Sparks, Nevada and Lt. Governor of Division 23 of the Nevada-California-Hawaii District. After serving his term as Kiwanis Lt. Governor, he received the Distinguished Lt. Governor Award for his exceptional leadership and devoted service.He brought his passion for serving children with him to Sidney where he has served as Lt. Governor of Division 5 of Montana District Commissioner for the Badlands District of the Boy Scouts of America. In 2013, Pat was awarded the Montana District Scouting Award of Merit.Pat and Mavis moved into the Lodge in September of 2018. In September of 2021, Pat and Mavis moved to Culbertson to live by family. He passed away on Saturday, July 30, 2022.Pat is survived by his wife, Mavis and their many family and friends.

Richard Herbert Miller (born on December 6, 1944) passed away on July 30th at home in the care of his wife and daughters after a long battle with Parkinson’s Disease. Rich was a music aficionado with, notably, an encyclopedic knowledge of music from the 1950s-60s. Doo-wops were a clear favorite; in fact, his favorite song in the world- by the Planotones- is about singing them. Singing doo-wops brought him such joy, and when he sang at his daughter Catherine’s wedding, he brought the house down. Rich’s passion for music extended to many genres and musicians, though. Miles Davis, the Beatles, and Mozart were favorites; he would have a list of his top ten works for each. Rich Miller was a list maker extraordinaire. He devoured movies; yes, there is a top ten list. His favorite short story was Melville’s His favorite Shakespeare play was He was a Yankees fan who had cheered for the Dodgers in his youth until the team left Brooklyn in 1957.Before his illness, he reveled in long drives on back roads without requiring maps, since in his view, he always knew the general direction and would get there eventually. Vacations were reached by car no matter the distance, and of course each journey required its own song list. He particularly loved the car rides to visit his cousins in Tennessee. Rich loved to tell stories, especially of his youth, of which at least half must have been true. He also regaled us with tales of his years as an instructor at Northern Telecom, where he worked for nearly thirty years. He was a staunch believer in standing up for justice even if you’re standing alone; he was generous and kind.Originally from Jersey City, he met the love of his life in Rutherford, NJ in 1965. He and Evelyn married in 1967 and raised their daughters in Rutherford, moving to Pequannock in later years. He is predeceased by his parents, Frank and Dorothy Miller. He is survived by Evelyn, his wife of 55 years; daughters Ruth Miller and Catherine Sisco (Alonzo); and beloved granddaughter Emma Garcia-Miller. He will also be missed by his extended family and friends, including everyone in the Community of God’s Love in Rutherford, of which he was a member for forty-seven years. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Parkinson’s Foundation or the Lewy Body Dementia Foundation would be greatly appreciated.There will be a mass to celebrate Rich’s life in the fall.

Susan Leigh Anderson, Ph.D, Professor Emerita of Philosophy at the University of Connecticut, passed away in her home in New Milford, CT on Saturday, July 30, 2022 of complications due to ALS.  Born November 13, 1944 in Portland, OR, the first child of Paul Lynge Smith and Viola Malm Smith,  she was 77 years old. Susan is survived by two siblings Peter Smith and Ann Duncan, as well as her husband Michael Anderson, her son Alexander Anderson, and her granddaughter Gwyneth Anderson. Susan will be interred beside her parents in Miner Cemetery,  Middletown, CT.Susan's formative years were spent in Fairfield, CT where she readily admitted her life mirrored the warm, safe world of the Dick and Jane books of mid-twentieth century America. Music was her first love.  She often recalled singing Ave Maria in a Christmas pageant at her church and she cherished an enchanting photograph of herself in full ballet costume, dancing the lead in a production of Swan Lake put on by her ballet class. Susan graduated from Fairfield's Rodger Ludlow High School in 1962 and went on to major in philosophy at Vassar College, earning her undergraduate degree in 1966.  After a year teaching mathematics at a girl's preparatory school, Susan pursued her doctorate at UCLA studying with (and receiving glowing letters from) such luminaires of philosophy and logic as Alonzo Church, Rudolf Carnap, and David Lewis. Susan's 1974 dissertation "A Philosophical Analysis of the Phenomenon of Multiple Personalities in Connection with the Problem of Personal Identity" was later noted, by her thesis chair John Perry, to presage Marvin Minsky's seminal Society of Mind (1986) by over a decade. A favorite professor at the University of Connecticut and member of the American Philosophical Association, Susan taught a wide variety of courses in philosophy and published extensively in the field.  She was especially pleased by a trio of volumes she wrote for the Wadsworth Philosophers Series: On Dostoyevsky, On Mill, and On Kierkegaard. These have been translated into many languages and read worldwide. She spent many summers on National Endowment for the Humanities Fellowship grants with Richard Rorty at Princeton University, Roderick Chisholm at Brown University, and others.   Notably, Susan won the "2002 Centennial Prize for Best Op-Ed Piece Published by a Philosopher," given by the American Philosophical Association. It draws a timely a lesson about the dangers of relativism, just after the 9/11 attacks. Susan spent the last two decades of her life championing machine ethics, a field of ethics and artificial intelligence she was instrumental in creating. Notable achievements of her National Science Foundation supported research in this field include the creation of the first machine to behave ethically- reported by Scientific American, Artificial Intelligence Journal, and the Proceedings of the IEEE- and co-editing the seminal collection of articles on the subject Machine Ethics, published by Cambridge University Press. Susan loved to travel and kept journals as well as photo books on each of the dozens of journeys she took around the globe. She was also an avid collector of beautiful things, her Victorian "mansionette" filled to the brim with treasures she found along the way.  And if there is any castle anywhere in the world that she did not visit, it was only because someone forgot to tell her about it. Later in life, she created her own dream tour of India, a romantic idyll of a sojourn to the precious stone inlayed Taj Mahal, an elephant ride up to Amir Fort in Jaipur, a barefoot pilgrimage to the Golden Temple of Amritsar, and an excursion to the Victorian Gothic splendors of Mumbai. It was a trip of a lifetime. On a wall of Susan's study, displayed in a place of prominence, is a letter received from yet another philosophical luminary concerning a talk that she had given:"I'm sorry I lost sight of you Saturday noon in Portland, as I wanted to say how much I appreciated your demonstration that sane & sober discussion of explosive topics is, after all, possible.  Your rationality shone like a good deed in a naughty world."  -Wallace MatsonSusan was an accomplished philosopher, a respected professor, a world traveler, and a beloved daughter, sister, wife, mother, and grandmother.  She once wrote that she had "a life that has been more wonderful than what I ever envisioned for myself."  The lives of those who knew and loved her have been far richer than they could have ever been without her. Susan died as she had lived, on her own terms.

Funeral services for Dennis Fischer, 78, of Mobridge will be at 11 AM, Saturday, August 6, 2022, at the UCC Church in Mobridge. Burial will be at the Fairview Cemetery under the direction of Kesling Funeral Home of Mobridge. Visitation will be one hour prior to services.Dennis Edwin Fischer peacefully passed away on Saturday, July 30, 2022 at Mobridge Regional Hospital after a long battle with cancer.Dennis Edwin Fischer was born May 24, 1944 in Eureka, SD to Edwin and Iola (Kusler) Fischer. Dennis grew up on a farm with his sister Lorie and brother Gary, near Herreid, SD. Dennis liked to be outside with his brother Gary both winter and summer! His mom would find small footprints in the snow and knew they were outside playing. Dennis attended a country school for eight years. In the winters Dennis drove his brother to country school in a Model A but wrecked hitting a rock pile, then had to use the tractor. He then went to high school in Herreid and graduated in 1962. Dennis joined the National Guard in 1961 at the age of 17 as a junior in high school.This is when he met Carol (Hardcastle) his future wife at the Mobridge A&W when they pulled up in a big National Guard truck. Carol had to climb up to take the orders and they would soon become a couple and married two years later in Seattle Washington where they lived for nine years. Their son Todd was born there in 1967. The family moved back to South Dakota where he took up a new position and moved to Mobridge where Casey, Bubba (Jesse), and Kelly were born. Dennis was a skilled tradesman and instructor in asbestos removal and insulation installation. Dennis was required to travel throughout the country and region for his employment and even worked on the Eisenhower tunnel in Colorado. Dennis finally retired after working for his brother’s company at the age of 72. But continued helping friends and family with yard work and other favors.Dennis loved to ride his motorcycle, spend time with his brother-in-law Jim Brockcamp, and taking out his family on his pontoon boat. He loved spending time with his friends especially Gigs Zeller, and always with his family and his brother Gary and his cousin Bill during their trips to Sturgis and other rides.Dennis is survived by his wife Carol, their four children Todd (Shari Claymore), Casey (Jennifer), Jesse (Kateri Hunter) and Kelly (Alan Malsam); his brother Gary and Becky (Naasz) Fischer and their four children, and Lorie and Aldeen Goehring and their four children. Also surviving are his beloved Grandchildren Trent Davis, Cody Stotz, Elizabeth Fischer, Beau Fischer, August and Greta Fischer, Nicholas Hunter, Alaya Fischer, Wesley and Braden Malsam, Shawn and Shane Hepper; four greatgrandchildren and many nieces and nephews, and his uncles and aunts Lloyd and Carol Kusler, and Jeanette and Marvin Winterberg.Preceded in death were his beloved Mother and Father, his in-laws Bill and Jean Hardcastle, his brothers-in-law Jon Hardcastle and Jim Brockamp and two greatgrandchildren.To plant Memorial Trees in memory of Dennis Fischer, please click here to visit our Sympathy Store.

William F. Flannery, age 82, a resident of the Village at Willow Crossings in Mansfield, passed away on Saturday, July 30, 2022 at the Sturdy Memorial Hospital in Attleboro. He was the beloved husband of the late Margaret E. (Freeman) Flannery, who died on January 10, 2013.Born in Boston, MA on July 24, 1940, he was a loving son of the late William F., Sr. and Estelle (Capozzi) Flannery.Bill grew up in the Roxbury neighborhood of Boston and was a graduate of Cathedral High School in Boston. During the time of the Vietnam War, he proudly served his country for four years as a member of the United States Air Force. Following his honorable discharge, he continued his education, receiving a bachelor's degree from Northeastern University and later a master's degree from Babson College. Prior to retiring, Mr. Flannery proudly worked as a Business Education Teacher at North Attleboro High School. He next worked for the Massachusetts Department of Youth Services as a math teacher and later in life, at H & R Block.A resident of Mansfield for the past forty-nine years, Bill was an actively involved communicant of Saint Mary's Church in Mansfield and formerly served on the Board of Education at Southeastern Regional Vocational Technical High School.Bill volunteered his assistance with Boy Scouts and was a former member of the Mansfield American Legion Post #198. He loved spending time with family and friends and was an avid New England sports enthusiast.He is survived by his devoted son Matthew F. Flannery and his wife Susan of Milford. He was the cherished grandfather of Caitlin E. Flannery and Ian C. Flannery, both of Milford. He was the dear brother of Joseph Flannery and his wife Carol of Missouri, Patricia Flannery and her husband Charles Gibson of Missouri and the late Margaret Flannery, Mary Caira, David Flannery and is also survived by his loving nieces and nephews.His Funeral Mass, to which relatives and friends are cordially invited to attend, will be celebrated on Wednesday, August 3rd at 11:00 A.M. in Saint Mary's Church, 330 Pratt Street (Route 106) Mansfield. Burial with military honors will follow at 1:30 P.M. at the Massachusetts Cemetery in Bourne.Visiting hours are omitted and due to the limitation of flowers allowed at the National Cemetery, William's family has requested that donations in his memory be made to the Wounded Warrior Project, P.O. BOX 758516, Topeka, Kansas 66675-8516.To send his family a message of condolence, please visit www.shermanjackson.com

John A. Lehman, age 80, of Apple Creek passed away peacefully on July 30, 2022, at Glendora Health Care Center following a period of declining health.John was born on April 4, 1942, in Apple Creek to the late Willis and Sarean (Amstutz) Lehman. He graduated from Eastern Mennonite School in Harrisonburg, Virginia, in 1960. In 1961 he went to Hannibal, Missouri, for Voluntary Service where he met Rozella Zook. The two were married on April 10, 1965. He is survived by Rozella.John was employed at Schantz Organ Company in Orrville as a pipe maker for 41 years, retiring in 2006.John was an active member of the Sonnenberg Mennonite Church where he served as the church treasurer for many years, mowed the church lawn, and developed many lifelong friendships. His love for his Savior was evident in all he did; he was a kind and gentle man, generous with his time, and concerned for the welfare of others. John was an avid golfer and could be found on the course several times a week! He enjoyed gardening, wood working, cheering on the Cleveland Indians, playing games, and camping. Spending time at his grandchildren’s sporting events, playing Euchre, traveling, and spending time with family brought him great joy.In addition to his wife, Rozella, he is survived by two children, Kevin (Geannette) Lehman of Red Deer, Alberta, and Roxie (Eric) Ramseyer of Dalton; grandchildren Nathan (Quinn) Lehman, Dillon (Lindsay) Lehman, Reece Lehman, Chenée Lehman, Josiah (Natalie) Ramseyer, Jacob Ramseyer, Isaac Ramseyer & Micah Ramseyer; one great granddaughter, Emerie Lehman. John’s siblings include his sister-in-law Twila Lehman, Maurice (Carol) Lehman, sister-in-law Ruby Lehman, Marjean Lehman, LuAnne (Dennis) Hatter, Steve (Elaine) Lehman, and brother-in-law Ron Geiser.In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his brothers, Kenneth, Donavan, James, Chester and Paul, and sister, Bonita.Services will be held at Sonnenberg Mennonite Church on Saturday, August 6, 2022. Calling hours will be at 3:00, with the Memorial Service beginning at 4:00 pm.The family wishes to express their deepest thanks to Glendora Health Care Center and LifeCare Hospice for their compassionate care. Memorial contributions may be made to Sonnenberg Mennonite Church or LifeCare Hospice of Wayne County.To send flowers to the family of John, please visit our floral store.

Walter J. Wawrejko, 81, of Turner Hill Rd., Corry, Pa., passed away on Thursday, June 20, 2013 after a prolonged illness.   He was born on March 12, 1932 on the family farm in Spring Creek, Pa., the youngest of 11 children, of the late John and Theresa Bednarz Wawrejko.   Upon graduating with honors from Corry High School, where he was described as "wise, jovial and wonderful", he served our country during the Korean Conflict as an Air Force Military Policeman, seeing tours in Northern Africa, England and Guam.  Walter returned to the Corry area and resumed employment at Raymond Manufacturing, retiring in 1987 after 37 years of dedicated service.    Walter attended St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church and was a member of the Polish National Alliance and a life member of the VFW Post #264, where he enjoyed the company of friends.  In earlier days, he was an avid bowler and played on the Raymond's team league and was a lifelong Cleveland Indians fan, attending several of their games.  Later, he followed that team and many others from the comfort of his home, where visitors would be greeted to the sounds of baseball or some other sporting event on TV. One of his favorite past times was cruising the side roads with his brother, Ted, enjoying the local scenery and wildlife.  Although Walter never married and remained private, family was important to him.    In addition to his parents, Walter was preceded in death by a sister, Eleanor Choma and six brothers, Walter, as a child, Joe, Frank, Ted, John and Steve Wawrejko.     Walter is survived by three sisters, Genevieve Thompson and Elizabeth Phelps, both of Florida and Helen Plevack of California; and many loving nieces and nephews over several generations.    Family and friends are invited to call at the Bracken Funeral Home, 315 N. Center St., Corry, Pa., on Tuesday from 4 to 7 pm, with a Parish Scripture Service at 6:30, and attend the Funeral Mass at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church, 203 W. Washington St., Corry, Pa., on Wednesday at 10 am.  Rev. Mark Hoffman will officiate.   Burial will be in St. Thomas Cemetery, Corry, Pa.

Glenn Gossage, age 93, of Greenwood, Indiana, went to be with his Lord & Savior, Jesus Christ, on Sunday July 31, 2022. Glenn was born in New Castle, Indiana, on March 4, 1929, to Leonard Gossage and Della (Eads) Gossage, both of whom preceded him in death.Glenn was married to Darlene (Fullmer) Gossage on February 17, 1950. He was an active member of various Baptist churches throughout his lifetime and was a member of First Baptist Church of Greenwood at the time of his death.He retired from Eli Lilly & Co. in 1991 after 39 years of service in various areas of the Financial and Accounting Departments. In addition to his work at Eli Lilly, Glenn and his wife, Darlene, were the owners and proprietors of Beech Grove Bowl from 1969 until 1975. During their ownership they were able to increase the bowling lineage by almost 50% above the previous years. Glenn also served as Chairman of the Greater Indianapolis Bowling Association during his last year of ownership. It was a “fun time” for both of them in meeting and getting to know many new friends through the bowling center.After 13 years of retirement, including 10 years of wintering in Florida, he and his wife returned to fulltime residency at Greenwood Village South. Then in June of 2004, life took a new turn when he joined as volunteer Board member (Treasurer) and assumed all the financial responsibilities as required for the non-profit food pantry for several years.The highlight of his later years was a golfing project to play in all 92 counties of Indiana. Along with golfing friends Paul Hammond, Bill Hurt, and Jim Pinegar, all from the same Sunday School Class at First Baptist Church of Greenwood, the project was started on September 22, 2008, by playing Antler Point in Rush County (Rushville). The project was completed when the foursome made a trip to play Hulman Links in Vigo County (Terre Haute) on July 18, 2011. The foursome became known as “Club 92” and Glenn got the nickname of “Dad” since he was the eldest member of the group. Even though Glenn was the statistician and “average keeper,” he could never quite keep up with the scores of the other three.He was preceded in death by his wife Darlene (Fullmer) Gossage in 2014. He is survived by their daughters, Paula S. Boone (William) of Indianapolis, Indiana and Peggy A. Votava (Glenn) of Goshen, Indiana. Grandchildren, all surviving, including Michael Boone (Jackie) of Indianapolis, Indiana, Jason Boone (Heidi) of Danvers, Massachusetts, Jonathan Boone (LoriAnne) of Whiteland, Indiana, Kristin Leasure of Chicago, Illinois and Gregory Leasure, also of Chicago, Illinois. He is also survived by seven great-grandchildren; Cody Boone and Cheyenne Boone of Indianapolis, Indiana. Joel Boone, Faith Boone, and Anna Joy Boone of Whiteland, Indiana and Parker Boone and Delaney Boone of Danvers, Massachusetts.Also surviving is a sister, Velma G. Strong of Huntsville, Alabama, and sister-in-law, Faye Templin of Baraboo, Wisconsin. He is preceded in death by his older sister, Lilian G. Greeson of Winston Salem, North Carolina.Funeral services will be held on Friday, August 5 at the First Baptist Church of Greenwood, 99 W. Main St. Greenwood, Indiana. Visitation will be held from 9:30 A.M. to 11:00 A.M. with the funeral service immediately following at 11:00 A.M. with Rev. Sean D. Holloway officiating. Final graveside prayers will be at Washington Park East, 10612 E. Washington Street, Indianapolis, Indiana. A luncheon at the church will follow the graveside service. Memorial contributions may be made to the First Baptist Church of Greenwood. Arrangements are entrusted to Singleton & St. Pierre Funeral Service and Crematory.To send flowers to the family or place a tree in memory of Mr. Glenn Gossage, please visit our Tribute Store.

Esperanza Silva passed away November 15, 2014. She was born in Martindale, Texas on June 5, 1921 to Santiago and Adela Sandoval. Esperanza grew up in Martindale, and then during WWII her family spent time in Houston, Texas. After the war was over her family moved back to San Marcos. She married Manuel Silva and they began their family. They owned a restaurant in San Marcos till 1965 when they moved to Dallas, Texas. Esperanza was a house wife, but she did work in a school cafeteria for 20 years. She enjoyed sewing, making paper mache flowers and being overall crafty. She had a strong faith that she passed on to her family. She was a joyous, strong willed woman. However, her main passion was her family. I'm FreeDon't grieve for me for now I'm free.  I'm following the path God has laid you see. I took His hand when I heard His call.  I turned my back and left it all. I could not stay another day to laugh, to love, to work, or play.  Tasks left undone must stay that way.  I found peace at the close of day. If my parting has left a void then fill it with remembered joys. A friendship shared, a laugh, a kiss. O yes, these things too, I will miss. Be not burdened with times of sorrow. I wish you the sunshine of tomorrow.  My life's been full I savored much, good friends, good times, a loved one's touch. Perhaps my time seemed all too brief.  Don't lengthen it now with undue grief.  Lift up your hearts and peace to thee . . God wanted me now.  He set me free.

Dennis Dionysios Agallianos of Urbana, formerly of Brattleboro, Vermont, passed away on Tuesday, January 29, 2019. He was 96. He was preceded in death by his wife, Georgia-Lee Virginia (Foden) Agallianos. He is survived by his brother, Platon Agallianos, of Athens, Greece; his daughter, Helen Penelope Agallianos (Eric Johnson) of Urbana; and his wife Georgia's children, Donald Melvin (Rodica) of Surrey, England, and Susan Cronin (Benjamin Burns) of Georgia, Vermont, as well as eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.Dennis was born on January 1, 1923, in Galati, Romania, to Dionysios and Eleni (Craciun) Agallianos. His father was born in Zakynthos, Greece, and his mother was born in Romania of Greek and Romanian heritage. After attending the Greek Lyceum of Galati, he graduated with a medical degree from Victor Babes University in Cluj, Romania. In 1951, after the installation of the communist dictatorship in Romania, Dennis fled Romania for Greece. After a stay in a refugee camp on the island of Lesvos, he settled in Athens, where he practiced urology for six years. In 1957, Dennis immigrated to the United States under a program for refugees of the Cold War. Dennis lived and worked first in New York City and then in Brattleboro, Vermont, where he met his future wife Georgia-Lee and her children, Donald and Susan.Dennis and Georgia were married in Baltimore, Maryland, in 1964, and their daughter Helen was born there in 1968. Dennis, who changed medical specialties when he moved to the United States, worked as a psychiatrist at Spring Grove State Hospital in Baltimore, and then, for more than thirty years at the Brattleboro Retreat in Vermont. While in Baltimore, Dennis conducted research at Johns Hopkins Hospital, and his research was published in a number of scientific and medical journals, including Nature. Later, Dennis became an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at Dartmouth Medical School. In 1994, Dennis was honored with an Exemplary Psychiatrist Award from the National Alliance on Mental Illness. After retiring from the Brattleboro Retreat, Dennis worked at community mental health centers in Vermont and Massachusetts; he prided himself on having worked until age 87. He and Georgia were active members of St. George Greek Orthodox Church in Keene, New Hampshire. Georgia passed away in 2004, and in 2010, after more than forty years in Brattleboro, Dennis moved to Urbana, Illinois, to be close to Helen, her husband Eric, and their children, Theodore and Zoe. In Urbana, Dennis made himself part of the warm and welcoming communities at Clark-Lindsey Village and at Three Hierarchs Greek Orthodox Church. He made many new friends, with whom he loved discussing news, politics, history, philosophy and language. Most days he could be found at Clark-Lindsey's library. He read several newspapers a day, including the New York Times, Wall Street Journal and a daily Greek-language paper, and he often had a newspaper clipping at the ready for a friend or relative who he thought might be interested in a particular topic. He was a warm and generous friend and a loving and doting father and Pappou. He will be sorely missed. Memorial contributions may be made to Three Hierarchs Greek Orthodox Church. Visitation for Dennis will be held on Thursday February, 7 2019 at Three Hierarchs Greek Orthodox Church on 2010 3 Hierarchs Ct, Champaign, IL. 61820 from 10am-11am with a service to follow at 11am. Burial will be at Dummerston Center Cemetery in Vermont at a later date.Please join his family in sharing memories, pictures and videos on our website at www.sunsetfuneralhome.com

Elsford “Ebb” Stricklin, 95, of Slaton, passed away Thursday, November 18, 2021.A private family graveside service will be Saturday, November 20, 2021 at Englewood Cemetery in Slaton. There will be no public viewing. Arrangements are by Englunds Funeral Service of Slaton.Ebb was born September 16, 1926 in Henderson County to Aud and Willie Mae Stricklin. He was raised in Canton and attended school in Cream Level. His family later moved to Abernathy where he attended high school before being drafted into the U.S. Army, serving in Korea. Ebb married Darlene McCullough on August 25, 1947 in Lubbock. They moved to Slaton in 1950 where he began his career as a master plumber and home builder while raising five children.Ebb was a gentle man with a servant heart who mentored many young men while coaching youth baseball teams. He was also an avid hunter in his younger days alongside his hunting dog, Kate. He loved history and after retiring spent many hours reading, gardening, watching football and keeping up with current events. However, he will be remembered best for his love and his heart for his family.Ebb is preceded in death by his parents; an infant son, Elsford Dale; his son, Claude; two brothers and three sisters.Ebb is survived by his wife Darlene of Slaton; his daughters, Donna Stricklin of Slaton, Gwenda Hurley and her husband, Greg of Lubbock and Gretta Kitten and her husband, Floyd of Blackwell; his son Geron and his wife, Carla of Slaton; twelve grandchildren and several great-grandchildren.To send flowers to the family or plant a tree in memory of Elsford "Ebb" Stricklin, please visit our floral store.

Rochester: On August 1, 2022 at age 94. With heartfelt sadness we share the passing of our loving and devoted Mom and friend. Predeceased by her sister, Marjorie Konopaska. Joyce has touched many people's lives around the neighborhood and around the world. Mom would always refer to herself as "bright-eyed and bushy-tailed" and wished everyone to "Have a good day."Left behind are her four loving children, Kathleen Lee Rood Quagliata (Terry), Cynthia Joyce Hardy (Marshall), Kimberly Jaye Mryglod (Kevin), Timothy John Collins (Jeannine); grandchildren, Scott (Kristi), Brandon, Ashley, Austin (Kristen), Jeremiah & Nick Mryglod; and three great-grandchildren; Joyce's loving brother, Ronald DeBellis (Margaret); several nieces and nephews.Joyce graduated from Jefferson High School. She started working at 16 at Rochester Telephone Company. She then worked at Strong Hospital, where she helped set up the internal pharmacy tube system, before working in administration on their River Campus. From there, Joyce worked for RD Products (Griffin Technology) as a Customer Service Internal Coordinator for their ID card systems for colleges and banks throughout the U.S.Joyce was very active in her community. She volunteered at Hillside Children's Center, The Simon School at RIT and the U of R, where she assisted students and their families coming to America for studies and research. She was known as their "American Mother" and was a celebrated guest in Japan.Joyce's children, home, gardens, neighbors, and friends were her life and happiness.Private arrangements have been made by the family.Our lives will never be the same without her, but to know she has no pain and is with God gives us peace.

Maureen M. Hunter, age 84, passed away peacefully on Friday, April 14, 2023. Maureen was born,raised, and spent most of her adult life in New Jersey. She graduated from North Plainfield High Schoolin 1956 and in 1960, married her high school sweetheart, Clayton Lee Hunter.In 2000, Maureen and Lee followed their dream to live in New England and moved to Exeter, NH. Theywere immediately surrounded by wonderful neighbors who became like family, the Christ Churchcommunity, and their daughter, son-in-law, and grandsons. Maureen loved spending time at theirfamily cabin in Jackson, NH. She looked forward to the Jackson Duck Race in May and seeing all thepumpkin people in October.Maureen treasured her friendships near and far. She was wonderful at writing letters, she never misseda birthday or anniversary, and would often bake for neighbors. She loved it when her dear friends in theVineyards would stop by to say hi and visit around the kitchen table.Anyone who walked into Maureen’s home immediately noticed the beautiful cross stitch. Maureenthoroughly enjoyed stitching for and with others. Over the years, she had many wonderful memories ofstitching or crafting while talking and laughing with friends. Many generations cherish her handmadecross stitched samplers, Christmas cards, and ornaments.Maureen loved all animals. While living in New Jersey, she had raccoons, birds, squirrels, chipmunks,and deer literally eating out of her hand. Maureen did not meet a dog, cat, or bird that she did notimmediately want to spoil with treats and toys. And her favorite creature of all may have been MickeyMouse. Boy did she love Disney World.Most of all, Maureen loved her family deeply. She was so proud of all the furniture and model boats herhusband made. She made sure Lee always had his favorite homemade cookies and muffins available.Maureen was her daughter’s biggest champion and often expressed her admiration for how she and herhusband were raising their two sons. Nothing made Grammy prouder than hearing about hergrandson’s milestones and accomplishments. Up until the end, she lit up when the boys visited.Maureen is survived by her husband of 63 years, Lee, her brother and his wife Paul and Ellen McCarthy,and her daughter, Karen, son-in-law Todd, and their two sons Ryley and Casey.If you would like to honor Maureen, please consider a memorial contribution to either the NH SPCA orNAMI NH.To plant a beautiful memorial tree in memory of Maureen, please visit our Tree Store or plant a tree.

Davis Anderson, age 97 of The Woodlands, passed away on Friday, April 14, 2023.Graveside services will be held at 2:30 PM, Friday, April 21, 2023, at Ater Cemetery with Pastor Kevin Brown officiating. The family will receive visitors from 1:00 PM to 2:00 PM at Scott’s Funeral Home.Davis Clinton Anderson was born September 18, 1925, to the late Henry Leslie and Johnnie Bessie Davis in Levita, Texas. He attended school in a one-room schoolhouse in Levita through the sixth grade and then began working on the family farm.In 1943 he joined the US Army and served during World War II. He was a decorated war veteran, receiving the Bronze Star and Purple Heart for actions during combat. In 1950, Davis married his first wife Bertie Lou McDonald who gave birth to their first child, Kelley Lynn Anderson in 1960. Davis met and married his second wife Chong Ja Kim while working as a civilian aviation contractor in Korea. They welcomed their first child David Leslie Anderson in 1967. After moving back to the states, they had their second child Dan Clinton Anderson 1972.Davis loved to fish and was an avid gardener and outdoorsman who enjoyed nature more than anything. He could often be found in his spare time helping others and looking out for those in need.He was preceded in death by his parents; wife, Kim; son, Dan Anderson; sisters, Edith Cox, and Syble Jones; and brothers, J.B. Anderson, Mack Vernon, and James Weldon.He is survived by daughter, Kelley Cates and husband, Steve; son David L. Anderson and wife, Kelly; grandchildren, Amber Jowers and husband, Josh; Brian Harp and wife, Melissa; Mark Anderson and wife, Victoria; Zoe Wells; Kaleigh Danann; Avery McCoy; great-grandchildren, Bryson Jowers; Braydon Jowers; Brody Jowers; Brynleigh Jowers; Bree Jowers; and Carter Harp.Psalm 23 1-2 The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want. He maketh me to lie down in green pastures: he leadeth me beside the still waters.To order memorial trees or send flowers to the family in memory of Davis Clinton Anderson, please visit our flower store.

Psalm 1:1-3Blessed is the man Who walks not in the counsel of the ungodly, Nor stands in the path of sinners, Nor sits in the seat of the scornful;Christopher Thomas Culpepper DC LPN, 51, of Maumelle, Arkansas, passed peacefully in the early morning hours of April 14, 2023. Chris was born September 9, 1971, to parents Charles and Mary Culpepper at Jefferson Regional Hospital in Pine Bluff, Arkansas.He was preceded in death by his father, Charles Culpepper, Grandparents, Rev. James and Mildred Beck of Monticello, AR, and the late Thomas Richard Culpepper and Nellie Mae Mann of Lincoln County, AR.Chris is survived by his two sons, Willem and Walden Culpepper of Little Rock, Arkansas; his mother, Mary Carolyn Beck Culpepper; his brother, Brian Culpepper and his wife Cristina Scarlat, and his niece, Clara Culpepper, of Fayetteville, Arkansas.Chris participated in many team sports such as football and baseball like many Gen X kids do and was a 1989 graduate of White Hall High School. From there, he carried the bulldog pride, fighting spirit and compassion for others into his career as a Doctor of Chiropractic (DC), serving as a compassionate caregiver to many throughout his life. He demonstrated his true bulldog grit, spirit, and determination when he battled cancer with grace and dignity over these past few years. During his lifetime, Chris helped many others regain their health and happiness with professionalism and passion. We’re grateful.After high school, Chris enrolled at the University of Arkansas, Fayetteville for two years covering pre-requisites before transferring into Cleveland Chiropractic College in Kansas City, MO to complete his Doctor of Chiropractic Degree in 1995. Chris was a life-long learner and resided in Little Rock, Arkansas practicing his craft. He also studied Psychology and Nutrition at the University of Central Arkansas and Pulaski Technical College and earned his Nursing LPN in December of 2014 from Baptist Health Schools in Little Rock, AR.Chris surrounded himself with good people who kept him smiling while attending music festivals and gatherings with his extended family. He lived and practiced within the Little Rock area and shared his love of sports and music with his two children early in their lives. He was quick to admit that both boys quickly surpassed his hobbyist/skill levels in both guitar playing and various team sports! Chris loved this and was so very proud of both for becoming fine, young leaders within their schools and at church.Chris was blessed with the best lifelong friends anyone could ask for and he played a starring role in many hilarious memories as they grew up in Jefferson County, Arkansas. A mid-eighties memory from White Hall’s Little League Baseball season comes up frequently. Chris was always a ‘little bit stronger’ than some peers and for his age so his pitching speeds were quite prolific in those days His control of the strike zone, however, lacked the precision he later developed in his chosen profession. His best friend Georgie tells this story often, “Back in one Little League baseball game, young Dr. Pep was on the pitcher’s mound; hurling three consecutive speedballs into the back, ankle and the shin of opposing team batters; a concerned baseball mom yells from the bleachers, “ take him out, He’s a killer!”. Times sure have changed since the 80’s, but Chris’ good friends will keep that comical story and countless others alive for all who knew and loved Dr. Christopher T. Culpepper DC. Here’s to being pain free, My Brother! We love you; miss you already and will keep you in our hearts and minds until we meet again. In lieu of flowers, the family would like to direct donations to: https://carti.ejoinme.org/donateMemorial service will be held 2:00 pm Saturday April 29, 2023 with the visitation a hour prior at Moore's Chapel, 206 West Center St., Fayetteville, AR 72701.

Elizabeth Smith of Phillipsburg, Missouri passed away in her home on Friday morning, April 14, 2023. She was born January 13, 1942 in Cincinnati, Ohio to Robert E. Gibson and Edith Greer Gibson. At the time of her passing she was eighty-one years, three months and one day.Elizabeth was raised in New Mexico, graduating from Highland High School. In 1960, she met Homer Smith while he was stationed at Kirkland Air Force Base in Albuquerque, New Mexico. They fell in love and were married September 22, 1961. They would celebrate just over sixty years together before Homer passed away on October 19, 2022.For the first twenty years of their married life, they lived in many different areas as Homer was in the military. During this time, they added four children to their family, Paul, Robert, Connie and Donnie. She was a great mother and “kept the home fires burning” while Homer protected the nation. She was not afraid to make herself known and she was quick and ready to be what she needed to be in the moment to protect her family. She enjoyed being a military wife. Her family was everything to her and she loved them deeply.Elizabeth was also very excited when she became a grandmother. She was proud of all nine of her grandchildren and enjoyed being with them, attending their events in sports and at school, as well as having sleepovers with them. She loved to cook and have big family gatherings.In her free time, she enjoyed reading, computer games, playing the piano, anything that would help in keeping her mind active.In addition to her parents and her husband, she was preceded in death by her brother, Donnie Gibson of Albuquerque, New Mexico.She is survived by her daughter, Connie Burns of Phillipsburg, Missouri; three sons, Donnie Smith and his wife, Beth, Paul Smith and Robert Smith and his wife, Cathy, all of Phillipsburg, Missouri; nine grandchildren, Kenny, Jessica, Sarah, Lynsey, Allison, Greyson, Logan, Leah and Luke; and her sister-in-law, Donna Gibson of Albuquerque, New Mexico.Elizabeth was a great role model for her children and grandchildren. The memories she made with them will be with them for years to come and her legacy is greatly appreciated.A memorial to the Vietnam Veterans of America, chapter 1014, has been established and donations may be made at the funeral home.

Wesley Duane Williams, 83, of Viola, Arkansas, departed this life on Friday, April 14, 2023, at his home. He was born on August 10, 1939, in Mitchell, Arkansas, to Samuel Audra and Ada Mae (Mitchell) Williams. During his working years, Duane worked as a carpenter. He was also a farmer and raised cows, which he very much enjoyed. Duane was a hunter and fisherman. He hunted deer and squirrel. Duane was a western man at heart. He loved watching, reading westerns, and dressing in western shirts and hats. His favorite western books were those by Louis L’Amour. Duane enjoyed traveling to the Bluff. He was of the Christian faith and belonged to Hebron Community Church in Mitchell. Left to cherish his memory are his son, Danny Williams of Viola, Arkansas; daughters, Lisa (Paul) Chesney of Paola, Kansas and Karen (Craig) Zehner of Kansas; brother, Max (Kaye) Williams; grandchildren, Shane Lynch, Karysa Johnson, Karah Steinke, Charley Provence and Joshua Cole and great grandchildren, Willow McNary, Luke McNary, Noah Blanchard, Levi Hill, Aiden Leftwich, Trenton Provence and Parker McNary. He was preceded in death by his parents; brothers, Rexal Williams and Devoe Williams and sisters, Lucille Wist and Sharon Kay Williams. Pallbearers include: Paul Chesney, James Fewins, Joshua Cole, Clint Vandergiff, Bryan Harris and James Newman Honorary Pallbearers include: Max Williams, Levi Hill, Brent Williams, Alex Harris, Nathan Harris and Aiden Leftwich Funeral services will be Thursday, April 20, 2023, at Doty Family Funeral Service Chapel in Salem, Arkansas beginning at 2:00 PM with Bro. Tom Doty officiating Burial will follow services at Hebron Cemetery in Viola. Visitation will be prior to the service beginning at 1:00 PM.

Milo W. Thompson, 92, of Rimersburg, died on Tuesday, October 9, 2012, after a specialweekend spent with many of his immediate family members at his home.He was born on August 11, 1920, to Harry and Anna (King) Thompson. Milo married GraceCrissman on May 30th, 1945, and they enjoyed 67 years of marriage together.Milo graduated from Union High School in 1938 and from Kittanning Business College in 1940.After serving in the United States Air Force from 1942 to 1946, he joined his father in working at thefamily-owned Clover Farm Store in Rimersburg. He was later employed by the Filetti Insurance Agencyfrom 1956-2002.Mr. Thompson lived his entire life in Rimersburg and was proud to do many things to benefit hiscommunity. He learned many life skills as a young Boy Scout in Troup #65, and later became a chartermember of the Rimersburg Lions Club and Community Club. His service extended to the Masons andthe Scottish Rite in New Castle. He was past President of the Clarion County United Way, and wasnamed volunteer of the year for his dedication. He joined the Jerusalem United Church of Christ inRimersburg 1934, and humbly served the Lord for entire life. He also served on the Board of Directorsof Lancaster Seminary, and was President of the Board of Directors at Clarview Nursing Home at thetime of his death. He also belonged to the Shearer-Shick American Legion and the VFW Post 7132both of Rimersburg.He loved spending time with his family and was known for growing beautiful flowers and abountiful vegetable garden. He lived simply and appreciated every minute of a well-lived life.Milo is survived by his wife, Grace, and three children Robert and wife, Mary, of Las Vegas,Nevada, Connie Traficante of Duncansville and Kim Daugherty and husband John of Knox, eightgrandchildren, two step-grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren. He was preceded in death by aspecial grandson, Logan Daugherty, in December of 2010.Friends will be received from 1 to 4 p.m. Saturday afternoon at the Varner Funeral Home ofRimersburg and Sunday at the Jerusalem United Church of Christ, Rimersburg from 1:30-2:30pm where Funeral Services will be held at 2:30pm, withThe Rev. Dr. John W. Gareis officiating. Interment will follow in the Rimersburg Cemetery with fullmilitary honors accorded by the ceremonial squads of the Rimersburg American Legion and VFW. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to theJerusalem UCC, Rimersburg, PA. and Charitable Deeds and Services, Knox. PA.

On Monday, April 11, 2016 God called home our beloved Frank Solomon Lewis. Solomon (Bubba) son of the Late Lottie M. Lewis and Frank S. Lewis was born in Suffolk, VA. on May 18, 1945. Even though Solomon was not educated through the Suffolk Public School system, he learned and performed many trades. He worked on houses, drove long distance trucks, auto mechani and also followed in his grandfathers footsteps and became a Logger. Logging was one of his first loves and he started his own company named Lewis Logging located in Suffolk, VA. He loved enjoying family and friends having backyard cookouts and barbecuing pigs. After knowing Gilda for many years he confessed his love when they married on May 4, 2013. Solomon also gave his life to Christ and became a member of Faith Fellowship CBC in 2013. He resided in Portsmouth, VA with his wife until he took ill and was transported to Autumn Care Nursing Home until his time of demise. Solomon leaves to cherish his memory, wife Gilda Lewis of Portsmouth, daughter Star Privott of Suffolk; step daughters, Synne Walker (Frankie)  and Lynnn Hamilton both of Porstmouth; sons, Scottie Boone (Suffolk), Mark Eley (Portsmouth) step son Lamont White (Portsmouth); sisters Mary Eley (Robert) of Suffolk Sarah Williams (Leon) ,Margie Lewis (Suffolk); brothers, Thomas Lewis (Nita) of Suffolk, William Lewis  of Suffolk, Willie Lewis of Suffolk. He was preceded in death by his parents Lottie M. and Frank S. Lewis and his sister, Lonabell Boone. Also left to cherish his memories 15 grandchildren, 4 great grandchildren and a host of nieces, nephew, cousins other relatives and friends.A celebration of life will be held 11:00 a.m. Tuesday, April 19, 2016 in the Melvin J. Blowe Memorial Chapel of Crocker Funeral Home, Inc. He will be laid to rest in Pleasant Hill Cemetery. Professional services with dignity have been entrusted to Crocker Funeral Home, Inc.

STOW - Cynthia “Cindy” A. Boyle, 62, passed peacefully on August 2, 2022.Born in Torrance, CA, she moved to Stow as an infant and had been a resident ever since. In her younger years, she enjoyed singing in the choir and dreamt of becoming a music teacher. After her daughters were born, she attended school to become a medical transcriptionist and graduated valedictorian of her class. Cindy went on to enjoy over 30 years of employment with Chase Transcriptions, Inc., retiring in 2022. In her free time, she could be found hiking, watching football (Go 49ers), reading, or fostering kittens for the Humane Society.Preceded in death by parents, John and Ruth Diroll; daughter, Rebecca "Becky" Lynn Weinberg, and brother, Greg Diroll.
