Audrey M. Bloechl, 85, of Gleason, passed away Saturday, April 15, 2023, at Woodland Court Elder Services, Merrill, WI. Audrey was born June 14, 1937, daughter of the late Clarence and Bertha (Hinz) Doering. Audrey married the love of her life, Frank ‘Sonny’ Bloechl on November 24, 1956.Audrey worked at Lincoln County Bank and had several seasonal jobs. She enjoyed working outside best of all. Audrey loved camping at Buffalo Lake with her family and taking long walks around the lake. Sonny and Audrey spent many hours fishing in the surrounding lakes.Audrey loved going to rummage sales every week in the summer. She enjoyed gardening and canned many vegetables every year. She was well known for her baking. She made the best bars and treats.Sonny and Audrey enjoyed traveling with family and friends. They visited almost all the states, including Alaska and Hawaii multiple times. Audrey also enjoyed going to family baseball games and snowmobiling with her family.Audrey is survived by her husband, Frank ‘Sonny’ Bloechl; children, Sherri (Tim) Diels, Brian Bloechl, and Debra (Russ) Jablonski; six grandchildren, Leah (Justin) Bloechl-Gruna, Sarah Jablonski (Tim Stahnke), Jenna (Matt) Loveless, Jacob Jablonski (Emily Hurley), Keith Diels, and Kristina (Zach) Patterman; and several great-grandchildren. Also, siblings, Robert Doering, Marion Kohnhorst, Marvin Doering, Joyce Olson, and Patty Geiss, along with many nieces and nephews. Audrey was preceded in death by her parents; and brothers, James Doering and Donald Doering.Audrey’s family would like to thank the staff at Aspirus Comfort Care & Hospice Services for their professional and personal care. They would also like to thank the staff at Woodland Court for making her feel at home and helping Audrey’s family during this difficult time.A celebration of life will be held on Sunday, April 30, 2023, at 2:00 P.M. at the Gleason Bowling Center. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Lincoln County Humane Society. Taylor-Stine Funeral Home & Cremation Services, Merrill is assisting the family.Online condolences may be made at www.taylorstinefuneralhome.com

Anne F. BreauxBossier City, LAAnne O'Rourke Breaux, 71, passed December 21, 2009,  away at Grace Home after a brief illness.  A mass to celebrate her life will be held at Wednesday, December 30, 2009 at Mary Queen of Peace at 10:00 a.m. with Father Joseph Ampatt and Monsignor Carson LaCaze officiating.  Visitation will be held Tuesday, December 29, 2009 at Hill Crest Funeral Home from 6 until 8:00 p.m.  Interment will be at Hill Crest Memorial Park in Haughton, LA.Anne was preceded in death by her parents Hugh and Kathleen O'Rourke, infant son, Pierre, and brother, Jim.  She is survived by her husband of 51 years, Joseph, son, Mark and wife Jeannine; daughters Rita and Agnes; grandchildren: Ashley, Ryan, Joseph, Deanna, Caleb and Claudia; great-grandchildren: Billie and Mat; brothers: Bob and wife Pat, John and wife Margie; sisters: Jean Eady and husband Bill, Rita O'Rourke SSND, and Mary Keller; and many nieces, nephews, and cousins. Much of Anne's adult life was spent traveling with her husband and family to Various Air Force Bases overseas and throughout the USA.  She spent 27 years as an LPN at Christus Schumpert caring for and loving babies in the NICU.  Anne was a devoted Catholic and member of Mary Queen of Peace parish.  Over the years Anne enjoyed league bowling, playing bingo and various arts and crafts.  Later in life her weekends were spent rooting for Notre Dame Football and watching professional golf.  Pallbearers will be her grandsons; Ryan Laux, Joseph, and Caleb Breaux and good friends Gary Price, Jack Fesmire and Walt Siedlecki, Sr.  Honorary pallbearers are her cousin Steve Higgins and the 4th degree Knights of Columbus.In Lieu of flowers donations can be made to the charity of your choice.  The family would like to thank Christus Schumpert Hospice, especially Chris, and special friends Joan, Louise, Mary Z. and Mary P.Words of Comfort may be shared with the family by visiting www.hillcrestmemorialfh.com

Beatrice G. McGee, 87, passed away peacefully of natural causes on June 23, 2013. She was the wife of the late Capt. Morris L. McGee (USA Ret). Beatrice was born in White Deer, Texas on March 12, 1926, the fourth daughter of John E. and Bessie M. (Pryor) Latta. She was raised in Delta, Colorado. She was working as the personal assistant to Col. Clyde G. Young at Camp Roberts in California in 1951 when she met Morris. Beatrice loved to travel and her travels with the Army took her through Europe and to Okinawa, as well as all over the United States and in later years she traveled to Alaska and the British Isles with her children.    Upon retirement from the Army, Morris and Beatrice settled on the Monterey Peninsula where they raised their five children. She was active in Cub Scouts with her sons and Brownies with her daughters, as well as her children's numerous school activities. She created many, many wonderful memories for her children of camping trips, road trips, and just playing kick-the-can outside with them or picking huckleberries in Deer Flats with them. She always allowed her children to have a menagerie of animals from dogs and cats to geese and chickens to hamsters, rabbits, and rats.   Bea worked for the Scotch Bakery in Pacific Grove for a short time and then went to work for the Monterey Peninsula Unified School District as Registrar at Seaside High School and Monterey High School until her retirement. Bea was also a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution. She was an animal lover and will be greatly missed by her little dog, Sam.   She is survived by her five children: daughter, Cynthia Alynne Wright (John) of Marina, CA; son William Latta McGee (Sam Sutrino) of Alturas, CA; daughter, Susan Beatrice Clark (Richard) of Litchfield, CT; son, Robert Bryant McGee (Marsha Mullins) of Capitola, CA; and son, Morris McGee, Jr. of Elk Grove, CA; granddaughters, Pamela Van Valkenburg (Michael) of Del Rey Oaks, CA; Jennifer Clark of El Dorado Hills, CA; grandson, Jeffrey Clark of El Dorado Hills; and great-grandson, Ethan Van Valkenburg of Del Rey Oaks, CA. She was the fifth of nine children and is also survived by two brothers, James P. and Larry D. Latta; one sister, Ernestine Startup and many nieces and nephews.   Visitation will be on Friday, July 5, 2013 from 4:00-8:00pm at Mission Mortuary, 450 Camino El Estero, Monterey, CA. Graveside service will be held on Saturday, July 6, 2013 at 10:00am at Monterey City Cemetery.   In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the SPCA for Monterey County, or just do something nice for someone.   Visit www.missionmortuary.com to offer online condolences.

Mother's Heart                                                        Author Unknown                                     I loved you from the very start,                                     You stole my breath, embraced my heart,                                     Our life together has just begun                                     You're part of me my little one.                                     As mother with child, each day I grew,                                    My mind was filled with thoughts of you.                                     I'd daydream of the things we'd share,                                    Like late-night bottles and Teddy bears.                                    Like first steps and skinned knees,                                    Like bedtime stories and ABC's.                                    I thought of things you'd want to know,                                    Like how birds fly and flowers grow.                                    I thought of lessons I'd need to share,                                    Like standing tall and playing fair.                                    When I first saw your precious face,                                    I prayed your life be touched with grace.                                    I thanked the angels from above,                                   And promised you unending love.                                   Each night I lay you down to sleep.                                    I gently kiss your head and cheek.                                    I count your little fingers and toes;                                    I memorize your eyes and nose.                                    I linger at your nursery door,                                   Awed each day I love you more.                                   Through misty eyes, I dim the light,                                    I whisper, ' I love you" every night.                                    I loved you from the very start,                                    You stole my breath, embraced my heart.                                    As mother and child our journeys  begin,                                    My heart's your forever little one.

Kevin Guy Evanto, age 51, of Pittsburgh, PA, passed away at Shadyside Hospital on Tuesday, March 9, 2021, after a brief illness. His parents were at his side. Kevin was born on July 11, 1969, in Clarksburg, WV, and grew up in Shinnston, WV. He graduated from Lincoln High School where he was Valedictorian of his class in 1987. Kevin received his Bachelor of Arts Degree in Political Science and Government from the University of Pittsburgh in 1991; and his Master's Degree in Public Administration – Public Management and Policy in 1996 also from the University of Pittsburgh. His career included serving as the Assistant Director of Commonwealth Relations at the University of Pittsburgh 1992-1996; Associate Director of Government Relations at the University of Washington 1997-1999; Senior Associate at Cocker Fennessy Consulting Firm in Seattle, WA 1999-2004; and Director/Deputy Director of Communications for Allegheny County 2005-2014. At the time of death, Kevin held the position of Chief Marketing Officer for Allegheny County, Pittsburgh, PA. Kevin is survived by his parents Larry and Sandy Evanto; brothers Kristopher (Michelle) Evanto and Larry (Meagan) Evanto; nieces and nephews Nora, Alece, Maren, Lilly, Hunter and Cooper Evanto; and, beloved Aunt Diana Wright. He was preceded in death by his maternal grandparents Howard and Jean Rutter, and by his paternal grandparents George and Irene Evanto. The family would like to extend a special thank you to the doctors and nurses at Shadyside Hospital and to Kevin's friends and co-workers at Allegheny County for their kindness during this time. A private memorial will be held at a later date. Professional services trusted to D'ALESSANDRO FUNERAL HOME and CREMATORY LTD., Lawrenceville. .

Dearl was born on May 30, 1948 and entered into eternal rest on November 20, 2021 with his loved ones by his side.Dearl was a loving husband to the late Karen Holt, and beloved father to Stephanie (Richard) Blankenship, Pamela (Ronald) Coleman, Rodney Gardner, and Scott Holt; grandfather to Heather (Floy) Stevens, Dawn (Josh) Wilder, Taylor Coleman (Jonathan Jennemann), Kayla Coleman (Tyler Kofron), Morgan Holt (Logan Shields), Rodney Gardner III, Scott Holt Jr., and Karissa Concialdi; great-grandfather to Alexa, Brayden, Elijah, Kinsey, Floy Jr., Oliver, Skylar, and Barrett.Dearl was a loving son to the late Alta Ramsey and Eugene Holt, and beloved brother to Brenda Garavaglia, Peggy Holt, Randy (Shirley) Holt, Robert (Robin) Dismang, Mike Holt, Regina Conley (Steve Roberts), Joyce (Fernandez) Smith, Jimmy (Jessie) Holt, and Cherie (Clyde) Montgomery.He was met by those who preceded his death; mother Alta Ramsey, father Eugene Holt, step-mother Doris Holt, son-in-law Richard Blankenship, wife Karen Holt, sister Cherie Montgomery, and brother-in-law Clyde Montgomery.Dearl served in the United States Army during the Vietnam War, where he received two Purple Heart Awards. He was the true definition of a soldier. He was determined to fight through every single battle life ever threw his way. There was not a single person he met that he did not befriend. His loyalty, strength, and love for his family, friends, and country was completely admirable. There are many wonderful memories that will always be treasured with our dearest son, brother, husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, uncle, brother-in-law, father-in-law, cousin, and friend.The burial at Jefferson Barracks will be held at a later date, as well as a "Celebration of Life" in lieu of a Memorial Service… per Dearl's requests. The family will keep everyone posted of this date.

Mrs. Irma Jean Hill-Gibson was born on July 5, 1944, in the city of Jacksonville, Florida. She was the youngest daughter of the late Deacon Daniel Hill and Mrs. Thelma Curry-Hill. She was the devoted wife of Eddie Lee Gibson, Esquire, for 41 years. She was the beloved sister of Brenda Joyce Kohn.Mrs. Gibson, affectionally known as Jean and Aunt Jean, was a faithful member of Greater Zion Grove Missionary Baptist Church, where she served in many capacities. Jean was a Sunday School Teacher, an active member of Usher’s Board #2 and the Pastor’s Aide Board.She enjoyed traveling. Major highlights included: a trip to Italy and Spain, a weekend girls trip with her sister and nieces to Palm Coast, Hammock Beach Resort, spending time with family for birthdays, holidays and other occasions. Her other favorite past times included baking cakes — she was famous for her carrot cakes and pound cakes. She loved studying the word of God and loved her church family. Her favorite TV show was PBS’ Downton Abbey. Mrs. Gibson will be remembered and greatly missed for her sincere kindness and her caring nature.Jean was a graduate of New Stanton High School, class of 1962; Florida Memorial College in St. Augustine, Florida, on May 30, 1967; and obtained her master’s from Florida A & M University. After graduating, she taught Elementary School in Haines City, Florida; Duval County, and Houston, Texas, before retiring from Duval County. Professor Gibson was nominated for Duval County Public Schools’ Teacher of the Year on two occasions. Mrs. Gibson was a kind, loving teacher and mentor, who was loved by her co-workers, parents and students. She was a member of Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, the National Sorority of Phi Delta Kappa, as well as the National Education Association and Duval Teachers United.Mrs. Gibson leaves to cherish her memory, her husband, Eddie Gibson, Esq.; devoted loving sister, Brenda Kohn; four nieces, Olivia Kohn-House (Paul), Judy Kohn, Natalie Kohn-Spikes (Derrick) and Nicole Kohn-Coronado; two nephews, Mark Kohn, Sr. (Staci) and William Kohn, III (Yolanda); cousins, Bernice Scott Kohn, James Scott (Gloria), Betty Young (Alfred), Beverly Williams, and Diane White; brothers-in-law, Clarence Gibson, Randy Gibson and Charles Gibson, Jr.; grandnieces, Franchesca Kohn, Alexis Kohn, Arrington Kohn, Madison Kohn, Nikayla Coronado, Jaelyn Benyard, Joslyn Benyard Graham (Ronnie) and Sydney Roundtree; grandnephews, Mark Kohn Jr., Myles Kohn, Malachi Kohn, Morgan Drew Kohn, Santiago Coronado, Jr. and William Coronado; great-niece, Isabella Kohn; great-nephew, Ronnie Graham, Jr.; niece and nephew, Veronica Brown (Larry) and Carl Kohn, Jr.; goddaughters, Gail Hayes and Tiffany Williams, along with a host of sorrowing relatives and friends.A visitation will be held on Monday, November 29, 2021 from 5:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. and Funeral Service on Tuesday, November 30, 2021 at 11:00 a.m. both at Aaron and Burney Bivens Funeral Home, 529 Kingsley Avenue, Orange Park, Florida 32073.To send flowers to the family or plant a tree in memory of Irma Jean Gibson, please visit our floral store.

RICHMOND, Ind. – Jerry Carl “Jet” Jensen, age 82, of Richmond, Indiana, slipped the surly bonds of Earth on Saturday, November 20, 2021, at home surrounded by his family.Jerry was born at home on May 25, 1939, near Meriden, Iowa, to Otto and Lilly Johnson Jensen. His youth was spent on his family’s farm, where he learned to do everything from milking cows and castrating piglets to plowing the fields and repairing tractors (always John Deere). Jerry grew up being very close with his many aunts, uncles, and cousins, as well as many neighbors and friends, most of who attended the local Lutheran church that was founded by his grandfather after immigrating to Iowa from Sweden. Considered tall by most, at home Jerry was the shortest man in his family at 6’3”. After being a great student and graduating high school, he attended Buena Vista College in Storm Lake, Iowa. Although Jerry was a state champion plowman and liked farming and animals, he had a passion for aviation. As a boy, Jerry would look up at the sky when a plane flew by and comment, “I’ll be up there someday.” Finally, deciding that a career as a pilot was the best path for him, he transferred to Spartan School of Aeronautics in Tulsa, Oklahoma.Jerry’s work took him to Kettering, Ohio, where he met his future wife, LaDonna. After they married, they moved to Ypsilanti, Michigan, where their daughter, Julia, was born. They relocated to Livermore, California, in 1971. Their second daughter, Sarah, was born in 1972, but sadly only lived for a few weeks. Their third daughter, Janell, was born in 1975. In 1976, the family moved to Richmond to be near LaDonna’s mother and aunts. They joined First English Lutheran Church at that time, as well. Jerry had been a highly valued member of his community in Richmond ever since.Jerry began his career flying for various cargo and then charter carriers, including Universal, Zantop, and Saturn Airways. He then flew many years with Transamerica Airlines, before becoming one of the first pilots hired by UPS as they developed their air fleet. Jerry had piloted many types of commercial aircraft, including the AW Argosy in the beginning, and flew as Captain of Douglas DC-8 and later as Captain of his favorite commercial jet to fly, the Boeing 747. He flew all over the United States, as well as to every continent in the world except Antarctica. From student to Co-Pilot to Captain, Jerry’s attention to detail, intuition for the physics of flight, deep knowledge of the machinery of the aircraft, as well as his commitment to integrity and safety meant that anyone who flew with him was absolutely impressed. His careful handling meant Jerry was requested specifically to fly the champion racehorse, Secretariat, three times. He also was the right pilot to spend a month transporting devout Muslim pilgrims, who had never flown before, from rural parts of Ghana and the Ivory Coast to Mecca for the Hajj. Jerry especially enjoyed flying to Alaska, Hawaii, Germany, Hong Kong, and Japan.Additionally, Jerry flew and restored WWII-era Stearman biplanes — WWII open cockpit trainer planes—with his best buddy, Jeff Jordan. He also enjoyed rebuilding them, but especially loved going to fly-ins and giving rides. Jerry was always sharing the skies with family and friends, as well as taking the planes to Hagerstown, Indiana; Oshkosh, Wisconsin; Galesburg, Illinois; or even back to Iowa. He and Jeff donated rides to many charitable organizations’ fundraisers. Jerry also took many veterans for rides, including a WWII veteran who trained in a Stearman in 1942. He enjoyed meeting with his “Richmond Air Force” friends and was a member of Stearman Restorers Association and the EAA (Experimental Aircraft Association) Chapter 373.Jerry was a gifted mechanic. He grew up on John Deere tractors and always had at least one green-and-yellow implement on hand—and had kept them all running for decades. Jerry also maintained and operated the antique cars at the Wayne County Historical Museum for years. For countless family, neighbors, and friends, he could repair any mower, tractor, car, appliance, or machine anything with a motor. Jerry enjoyed removing snow from the neighborhood every winter with his snowblower, as well.Jerry would do anything for anyone and almost never said no. He had a kind heart. Jerry always enjoyed the company of animals, much to the delight of his daughters, and welcomed a motley succession of cats, dogs, mice, ferrets, hamsters, horses, and even goldfish into the family. He was an amazing horse show dad and then a horse show grandpa. Jerry was an absolutely devoted grandpa for all his grandchildren. He was also an amazing father, excellent husband, and a valuable relative or friend to many, many people. Jerry had the most generous spirit. Shaheed (Heedy) Omar Smith was born on March 7, 1992, to the late Muriel Smith in Chester, PA. He was raised in Wilmington, DE, where he attended Wilmington public schools. He then went on to receive his certification at Job Corp for Facility Maintenance.Shaheed (Heedy) was more than just a man. He was a loving man, father, son, brother, uncle, nephew, cousin and friend. He had a fun spirited soul who had many passions in life. Heedy had such a welcoming spirit. As a child, he would make friends at the park and then bring them home, not even knowing their names to have them stay for dinner or spend the night. He got this welcoming spirit from his mom, who never turned a kid away and, after learning their situations, would accept them in her home. Heedy wanted so much more out of life and devoted much time to his family to create a strong foundation for them. Heedy also enjoyed getting together with family at gatherings, eating, joking, playing games, and just having a good time creating memories. Heedy was an intelligent math whiz. He encouraged people to have a positive mindset, eat healthy, and taking care of themselves. He also loved his dogs. Before he had kids, his dogs were his kids. He was just getting into the business of breeding and training his dogs, which was successful. He had everything to live for and was looking forward to watching his family and business grow. He loved to travel seeing and learning new things. He recently just came back from Jamaica where you could see his light shining through. He also had a love for fashion always sharp with a fresh cut. Anytime a person was in need, he was always willing to help. He would say, "I gotch you cuz" and always fulfilled his vow. His smile and laughter could light up a room. He was genuinely a beautiful person inside and out. In his 31 years of life, Heedy has made such an impact on many lives. He will be forever missed.He is survived by his two beautiful sisters, Sherreda Johnson (Aaron Johnson), and Shakina Smith; the love of his life, Armani Harley; children, Samir Smith, Semaje' Smith, and Brooklynn Judson, whom he cared for as his own; three nieces; two nephews, and a host of relatives.He is preceded in death by his mother Muriel Smith, sister Shakira Smith, and grandmother Josephine Smith.To send flowers to the family or plant a tree in memory of Shaheed, please visit our floral store.

Kenneth R. Peura, age 55 of 3725 County Road 456, Skandia, died Tuesday evening, January 25, 2005 at his home after a courageous three-year battle with cancer.    Mr. Peura was born on April 21, 1949 in Marquette to the late William and Irene Henriksen Peura.  After graduating from Munising High School in 1967, Ken began working with the L.W. Brumm Construction Company at the age of 18.  He later worked for the O'Dovero Construction Company for 21 years as a heavy equipment operator.  His most recent employment was with A. Lindberg and Sons Construction Company where he worked until becoming ill, retiring in March of 2002.  Ken was a highly skilled heavy equipment operator and was an active member of the Operating Engineers Local 324.  He was well known throughout the construction industry and was respected by everyone he worked with.    Nothing was more important to Ken than his wife and children who he constantly nurtured and showed immeasurable affection toward.  His other interests included his being an avid outdoorsman, particularly enjoying ice fishing for Pike.  He also enjoyed trips to Stannard Rock with his son, Dave and spending countless hours trolling on Lake Superior visiting remote beaches.  Ken especially enjoyed the beach at the mouth of the Laughing White Fish River.  An avid deer hunter, Ken had numerous successful deer hunts.  In his free time, he loved spending time in his garage working on anything with a motor, especially Fords.  Throughout his life, Ken owned and enjoyed hot rods including Ford Thunderbirds and V-8 Ford Rangers.     Survivors include his loving wife of 32 years, Linda; three cherished children, Alison Kevin Thomma of Munising, Amy Brandon Koenig of Marquette and Dave Peura of Skandia; one grandson, Clayton Hendrickson as well as an expected granddaughter; a sister, Audrey Francis DesArmo of Sand River; also three nieces, two nephews and his faithful dog, Layla.  Visitation will be on Friday from 4 to 7 p.m. at Victory Lutheran Church at Sawyer.  Funeral services will be held in the church on Saturday at 12:00 noon with Rev. Mark Sippola officiating.  Spring burial will take place in the Deerton Cemetery.  Pallbearers will be Ken's family members, Alison Thomma, Kevin Thomma, Amy Koenig, Brandon Koenig, Dave Peura, and Clayton Hendrickson.  Honorary bearers are Darwin Britton, Dan Lindberg, Kurt Janofski, Del Dravland, Ed Wolfe and Nathan Todd.

Stephen Hnath, 89, passed away Thursday October 11, 2012 surrounded by his loving family at home. He entered the Army in 1943 as a Machine Gunner. Stephen was a member of the Elks Club in East Stroudsburg, and the VFW. He enjoyed playing cards with his loving wife Helen of 65 years. He loved to sell tickets for BINGO night. Stephen enjoyed spending time with his loving family and will be greatly missed by many. ALICE RUTH HUNTBATCH SANDERS passed away with her family around her on Tuesday, November 18.  She is survived by her children Steven Sanders, Sandra and Doug Hamilton and Debra and Jim Cupp, her grandchildren Doug and Pam Hamilton, Jr., Mathew and Liz Hamilton, Mitch Hamilton, John Cupp and Michael Cupp, her great-granddaughters Fiona and Ariana Hamilton.Alice was born on March 19, 1924 to John and Pauline Huntbatch in Geneva, Iowa.  She lived with her older brothers and sister, Carl, Fred, Edward and Helen on the farm outside of Geneva.  She attended and graduated at the age of 17 from Geneva school where she was in glee club and theater and continued her education at beauty school in Waterloo, Iowa.  She had a beauty shop next to her brother Ed's auto shop in Geneva, Iowa.In 1947, she met Robert C. Sanders at the Electric Dance Hall in Waterloo, Iowa.  They were married in Geneva, Iowa at the Methodist Church on July 11, 1948.  They traveled to Niagara Falls for their honeymoon the first trip of many that took them both to all United States states except New Jersey.  They lived on a small acreage near Chapin, Iowa and were active in the Salem Methodist Church in Chapin, Iowa.Alice loved to garden, can, cook and craft.  She quilted many quilts and taught others how to hand quilt and her pies and chocolate angel food cakes were legendary.  She and Bob raised their three children on the farm.  In their retirement they traveled to Arizona during the winters and finally in 1990, they moved to Castle Rock, Colorado to be closer to family.  They were members of the Methodist Church in Castle Rock, Senior Center and the American Legion.  In 2006, they moved into an assisted living community, Valley House in Castle Rock.  Alice then moved to Brookside Inn in 2012.Alice was preceded in death by her husband of 62 years, Robert and her siblings and parents.  She taught us to keep on smiling and always keep on keeping on.  We will miss her dearly.  She asked to be cremated and we will have an interment ceremony in the spring of 2015.  In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to First United Methodist Church, 1200 South Street, Castle Rock, Colorado, 80104.

Wendy Anne Wallace, age 51 of Bronston, Kentucky died on September 7, 2017. Obituary for Mary Thede Mary Louise Hilsenbeck Thede was born October 18, 1948, in Jefferson, Iowa, the daughter of Charles Hilsenbeck and Gertrude Mehman Hilsenbeck. She died with her family by her side on May 21, 2018 at Iowa Methodist Medical Center in Des Moines, Iowa at the age of 69 years. Mary grew up in the Bagley, Iowa area and graduated from YJB High School in 1966. Mary lived most of her adult life in Jefferson. Mary and Dennis Thede were the parents of four children: Sarah, Chad, Jason, and John. Mary worked as a Dietician at the Greene County Medical Center in Jefferson. She also volunteered working with older women and their families helping them at home. She later stayed busy volunteering her time at Congregate Meals. Mary was an avid reader. She also enjoyed crocheting, camping, westerns, and a good fish fry. She loved to spend time with her family. Mary was preceded in death by her infant daughter Sarah, and her father Charles Hilsenbeck. She is survived by her mother Gertrude Hilsenbeck of Jefferson, IA; her three children: Chad (Megan) Thede of Davenport, IA, John (Shara) Thede of Clarksville, TN, and Jason (Diana) Thede of Bouton, IA; her long-time companion, Jim Taylor of Jefferson, IA; 8 grandchildren; numerous great grandchildren; six siblings: Beverly, Chuck, Donna, Duane, Shirley, and Linda; nieces; nephews; other relatives; and many friends. Roland (Rollie) Carlson, 84 of Buchanan MI passed away on Wednesday, March 10, 2021 in Sebring FL. Rollie was born on June 20, 1936 to the late Arthur and Marie Carlson.  He was the oldest of 5 children.  On January 14, 1956 he married the love of his life, Arlyne Norton. Rollie was a member of Local #1 Structural Ironworkers Union, Chicago IL.  He was proud to have worked on many buildings and bridges in the City of Chicago.  Most memorable were the Sears Tower, McCormick Place, John Hancock and the Cook County Jail.   Rollie and his family spent the summers at their cottage on Clear Lake.  He enjoyed boating, hunting, fishing and taking his girls water skiing.  He would circle the lake with them in tow until they were tired out.  He eventually moved his family to Buchanan in 1970 after renovation and winterizing their cottage. He loved his motorcycles, Honda Red Wings and Harley Davidsons.  He took many road trips.  The longest was a 5 week trip out west he and Arlyne took with several of their close friends.  He rode until he couldn't ride anymore. He leaves behind his daughters, Kim Kamealoha and Kelly (Scott) Freeze; his grandchildren Larry (Melissa) Ferris, Jeremy (Genesia) Ferris, Natalie Ferris and Nicole Miller; also, his great-grandchildren Addisyn, Collette, Jaxon Ferris and Makayla Miller. Rollie loved spending time with his grandchildren and great grandchildren.  He was a coach for Indoor Floor Hockey, took them for motorcycle rides, and loved camping and fishing with them. They have many memories to cherish.  Visitation will be held on Monday, March 15 from 6-8 EST at Hoven Funeral Home, 414 Front St, Buchanan, Michigan.  A private burial service will be held on Tuesday.To send a flower arrangement or to plant trees in memory ofRoland "Rollie" Carlson, please click here to visit our Sympathy Store.

James Patrick Cosgrove Dearest husband, father and grandfather, 'a strong, understated man,' and proud 2nd-generation Irish-American A giant of a man died Tuesday, May 22, 2018, in Bloomfield, N.J., as he had lived his 84 years - at home, surrounded by a loving and adoring family. James Patrick Cosgrove, born in Newark, N.J., on May 14, 1935, to Irish immigrants James Joseph and Mary (Lydon) Cosgrove, was a proud son of the ould sod. Jim was a tough, hard-working Teamster (Local 575); a strong, understated man who never felt he needed to be heard, yet commanded the room with his stories of Newark in the '50s and his many adventures. Similarly, he quietly guided his family, through tough times and in good ones, using his example rather than his commands. With love, kindness, patience, and faith, he taught his children, his grandchildren, and those who came to know and love him, how to live a life with meaning. He loved and adored his bride, Frances (Stalma) Cosgrove, throughout their 59 years of marriage; Jim was a strong, loving, and patient father to Maureen (Tom), James Jr. (Darlene), John (Kim), Frances Ann, and Kerry Ann Andrek (Adam). He is survived by 13 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. A member of the Holy Name Society of the Sacred Heart, he proudly accepted their "Man of the Year" honors in 2001. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from the O'Boyle Funeral Home, 309 Broad St., Bloomfield, on Friday at 9:30 a.m. The Funeral Mass will be offered at Sacred Heart Church in Bloomfield at 10:30 a.m. Interment is at Sky View Memorial Park in Tamaqua, Pa. Visiting will take place on Thursday, May 24, from 4 to 8 p.m. at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Sacred Heart Church or St. Jude Children's Research Hospital.

DeFEO, Shirley (Smith) Age 93, of Westwood, MA, died peacefully on March 11, 2021. She was born on November 3, 1927 in Medford, MA to A. Dudley and Doris (Hurlburt) Smith. She was raised in Lexington, MA. After graduating from Lexington High School, she graduated from Chandler Secretarial School in Boston. She worked as a legal secretary in Dedham then worked at Record Data in Dedham and Westwood. Her favorite job was her part-time job for 21 years at the Westwood Public Library until she retired in Feb. 2020. She was a longtime resident of Westwood. She is fondly remembered for her strong independence. She always wanted to find new places throughout New England to visit. She spent many vacations on Cape Cod with family and loved the beach. She was always found in her yard gardening and talking with neighbors and friends. She was a member of First Parish Church for 60 years and volunteered many hours on several committees. She was an avid reader. Shirley is survived by her two daughters, Susan Bourdon and husband Kevin of Waltham, VT and Cynthia Dowling and husband Mark of North Attleborough, MA, six grandchildren, Christopher and wife Miranda Rampone, Mark Bourdon, Scott Bourdon, Alison and husband Luke Russett, Harrison Dowling, and Jennifer Dowling, and one great-grandchild, Genevieve Rampone. There will be no Visiting Hours and Burial will be private. A Memorial Service in celebration of Shirley's life will be held in late Spring and will be announced. Funeral arrangements are provided by the Holden, Dunn and Lawler Funeral Home, WESTWOOD. Gifts in her memory can be made to VNA Hospice & Palliative Care in memory of Shirley DeFeo to support patient care at VNA Care, 120 Thomas St.,Worcester, MA 01608 or viawww.vnacare.org

Margie Phyllis Stengle was born on May 19, 1923 to Roy and Mary (Nelson) Piersol in Vermillion, SD. She passed away at Avera Sacred Heart Hospital in Yankton on August 5, 2022, at 99 years young.A celebration of her life will be held at a future date.  Arrangements are under the direction of the Wintz & Ray Funeral Home and Cremation Service in Yankton.Margie grew up on the Piersol family farm with her seven siblings and joined a large extended family of Clay County relatives. Margie attended grade school at the nearby Spirit Mound School. She graduated from the University High School on the campus of the University of South Dakota in 1941.She married that handsome US Navy pilot, Robert M. Stengle, from Yankton at the Memphis Naval Air Station on September 9, 1945. The couple moved to Vermillion where Rob attended the University under the GI Bill. Sons Robert, Jr. (1946) and Thomas (1949) were born in Vermillion. After Rob graduated from USD, the family moved to Yankton as Rob began his career with the US Department of the Treasury, Internal Revenue Service. Son James was born in Yankton in 1951.Margie was a truly lovely person, and she made the world a little better place for many in her own quiet way. She was always willing to help and rarely needed to be asked. During World War II with the blessings of their parents, she and three of her best friends from high school moved to Kansas City and worked in the defense industry building B-25 bombers. Those "Rosie the Riveter" gals supported the war efforts and became unsung heroes to many. They are true icons of the women's movement.Family and faith were Margie's focus. With the move to Yankton, she joined the First United Methodist Church which was Rob's childhood church. That relationship with her Church lasted for over 70 years. When her sons were small, she helped with Sunday School. She was involved in many church functions and activities from bible study, UMW, choir, bell choir, annual bazaar, funerals, weddings, memorials, kitchen duties, the Methodist bowling league, Habitat for Humanity, and more. She delivered Meals on Wheels well into her 90s. She was the consummate volunteer, and it gave her strength and enjoyment.Margie is survived by sons, Robert and James of Yankton, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, numerous nieces and nephews, and many friends.She was preceded in death by her husband, Robert; son, Thomas; her parents, Roy and Mary Piersol; brother, Ralph Piersol; sisters, Florence Piersol, Elsie Piersol, Dorothy Christensen, Ruth Neer, Corrine Callahan, and Arlene Larson.

Jerry Brooks, 56 of Detroit, passed away peacefully on Friday, August 5, 2022 with his sister by his side.A funeral service has been set for Wednesday, August 10, 2022 at 10:00 AM at New Hope Baptist Church in Detroit with Rev. Robert (Bob) Endress, SrDecember 22, 1935 - April 18, 2023Robert (Bob) Endress, Sr., 87, passed away on April 18, 2023, in Mission Hills, CA. He was born on December 22, 1935, in Joliet, Illinois. Bob was a loving husband to his wife of 45 years, Sue, and a proud father of four children, Bob (Melinda) Endress, Jr., Belinda (Steve) Carvajal, Casandra (Matthew) Iglitz, and Nicole (David) Centrone. He was also a cherished grandfather to Jacob, Avery, Ryann, and Dillon. Bob is survived by his wife, children, grandchildren, and his many friends and acquaintances.Bob was an accomplished man and athlete who lived a very full life. He attended Joilet High School, where he lettered in football and baseball. He then went on to graduate with a BA in Education from Michigan State University, where he played football. One of the highlights of his college years was playing against UCLA in the Rose Bowl in 1956, beating UCLA.Bob served in the US Marine Corps from 1957 to 1959, and then serving six years in the reserves. After his military service, he worked for Trans America Corporation before venturing out on his own in the communications world. Bob settled in the Santa Clarita Valley where he was a businessman for several decades. He and Sue owned a communication company in Newhall, Unicom Electronics, and was very generous with his time and expertise, especially during our devastating earthquake in 1994.He enjoyed hunting, and fishing and was very active in the community as a member of the Newhall/Saugus Kiwanis for over 30 years. Bob also served for 35 years on the Board of Directors for the Committee on Aging that oversees the Santa Clarita Valley Senior Center. He was always trying to make the world a better place for our seniors.Over the years, you could always find Bob at his children's and grandchildren's football, baseball and soccer games, car and motorcycle races, concerts, band competitions, track meets, dance recitals and activities. They were the joy of his life.He chose not to have a memorial service, so the family is having A Celebration of Life which will be held on June 24, 2023, from 2:00 – 4:00, at the SCV Senior Center, 27180 Golden Valley Road, Santa Clarita. This will be a very casual event, but please bring stories and memories of Bob and enjoy his favorite sweet treats. Instead of flowers, please consider donating to the SCV Senior Center in Bob's name.Bob will be dearly missed by all who knew him. May he rest in peace.

Born on November 26th 1958Died on April 18th 2023Judy was preceded in death by her Mother Gladys Green, Father James Green, Stepfather VanceCrocker, Brother Rick Green, and son Micheal Shane Reed.Judy was survived by her Children. Sons Audie Wayne Reed JR. and wife Sherri of Winona TX, JeremiahHartsfield and Wife Morgan of Bullard TX, and Daughters Kristi Kaye Reed of Tyler TX, Sunni Green andhusband Darrell Sargent of Bullard TX. Wayne T. Goldsberry, 92 of Lufkin, was born February 9, 1931, in Nat, Texas, to the late Clarence Goldsberry and Ammie Greene, and died Tuesday, April 18, 2023, in Lufkin.Mr. Goldsberry was a jack of all trades. If it was broken he could fix it. He loved the beach and looked forward to the annual family trip. Mr. Goldsberry was a member of the U.S. Army and served in the Korean War, where he was awarded a purple heart for his service in the Korean War. Mr. Goldsberry retired after 35 years as a maintenance supervisor at the Texas Highway Department. What we will remember most about him is that he was a loving father. He joined Forest Level Baptist Church at an early age and was a devoted member until he took ill. She was a social butterfly and loved to travel, especially to Europe, Hawaii, Mexico, Idaho, and the west coast. Graveside services for Inez Faye Terry, 81, of Buffalo will be held Tuesday, November 30, 2021, at Keechi Cemetery followed by a celebration of life at Stewart Memorial United Methodist Church, Buffalo, Texas.Inez Terry was born January 11, 1940, in Houston, Texas to Fredrick and Nora (Selman) Courtney. Inez was known as a people person; who never met a stranger. This combined with her creativeness took her down a career path which allowed her to enjoy socializing and using her creativity in the business of interior decorating. When she wasn’t working she also loved to cook and travel. She and her late husband, Arnold were fortunate to have the opportunity to visit most of the countries in Europe and all of the fifty states during their life. When at home she was always in the kitchen, cooking for the family, the church, or anyone that was in need. She lived in Houston for most of her life, where along with her husband, owned a freight delivery business. She had also spent many years as a senior manager with interior decorating company Home Interiors and Gifts.For the past thirty-nine years, she had lived in Buffalo and was a member of the Stewart Memorial United Methodist Church. Inez passed away in Tomball, Texas on November 23, 2021.Inez was preceded in death by both of her parents; her brother, Fred Courtney; her husband, Harold Arnold Terry and by her sons, Mark Randall Terry and John Arnold Terry.Surviving family includes her son, Paul Terry (wife, Tara) of Houston; and four grandchildren, Brooke Terry, Amber Terry, Jordan Terry-Kraemer and Kailey Hessel (husband, Michael).Arrangements are under the direction of Walters' Buffalo Funeral Home, Buffalo, Texas.

Harold “Butch” Struble Sr.May 14, 1943 – November 23, 2021Slate Hill, NYHarold “Butch” Struble Sr. of Slate Hill went home to the Lord Tuesday, November 23, 2021. He was 78 years old.First born son of the late Clarence and Rose Ann Struble. Butch was born on May 14, 1943, in Port Jervis, New York. Butch graduated from Minisink Valley High School and proudly served 2 years in the U.S. Army. Butch worked doing Plumping, heating and A.C. work for Orange Heating, Jones Service & Appolo Heating. He was a jack of all trades who helped many. In retirement Butch worked for the Times Herald Record.Church was a very important part of Dad’s life, and he gave many years of devotion to Grace United Methodist Church of Ridgebury & Slate Hill as the handyman, cook and Trustee welcoming all who came. He enjoyed fishing when he had time and took up coloring in the last few years of his life. He took great pride in his pictures he colored and would give them out to the wonderful medical staff that helped him during his many medical visits. But most of all his family came first. He found joy with his wife, children, and especially his grandchildren who he loved with all his heart.Butch is survived by his loving wife Margy (Knibbs) Struble of 55 years. His son H. Joseph Struble Jr. of Slate Hill NY, Daughter Laura Slowik and Husband David of Greenville NY and his four wonderful Grandchildren Karly, Miles, Ethan and Cailin. Also, his siblings Dolores Liebler, Rose Mary (Paul) Capobianco, Lyn (Carol) Struble, Burton (Bertha) Struble, Ken (Annie) Struble, Tom (Debbie) Struble along with numerous cousins, nieces, and nephews. In addition to his parents, Butch was predeceased by his daughter Lori Struble and brother Bob Struble.Visitation will be held at the Grace United Methodist Church 12 Ridgebury Hill Rd, Slate Hill on Saturday, December 11, 2021, from 11:30 -1, Funeral service at the church will follow immediately after with a burial of his ashes in the family plot. Zoom and Facebook information will be posted when available for those unable to attend.Memorial contributions may be made to the Grace United Methodist Church of Ridgebury and Slate Hill.To plant a tree in memory of Harold "Butch" Struble, Sr., visit the Tribute Store.Read More »

Carol Lee Del Signore, 87, left her earthly home in New Creek, WV, to enter the glorious kingdom of God on August 6, 2022. Carol was born June 8, 1935, to Edward Thomas and Elsie Mae Klipstein at their home in Lonaconing, MD. Her parents raised Carol according to Biblical principles and imparted the values of family, hard work, perseverance, and humility.Carol loved growing up in the small coal town of “Coney” and remained active in her church, community, and school. After graduating from Central High School in 1953, she held several jobs; however, Carol’s true desire was to marry and start a family. In 1960, she married Robert P. Del Signore from New Creek, and together they raised six children and operated a dairy farm there.Carol created a humble home filled with both discipline and laughter. Carol easily made others laugh with her dry perspectives, but she could laugh at herself, too. In addition to all of the chores, she gathered the children around the piano to sing or read stories to them, as she herself was a voracious reader who visited the library regularly. Carol also loved nature. From her armchair, she watched programs about exotic wildlife. In her own yard, she enjoyed caring for the fish in the fishpond and calling to the many birds at their feeders. Carol could grow almost anything, and she was often seen in her yard or on her front porch tending to her abundant flowers.Carol also worked outside the home in various service jobs in Keyser, WV, including at the Potomac Motel and Heartland Nursing Home. In all positions, Carol became a leader because of her work ethic, integrity, and consideration for others. Never did her family hear an unkind word about their mother.Retirement in 1999 left Carol more time to spend with her growing family. She showed her grand- and great-grandchildren unconditional love and always offered encouragement and wisdom. Carol also felt blessed to have loving daughters- and sons-in-law.Devotion to her family came naturally and they adored her. Carol always put others first, and with such a modest and self-less soul, she never realized what an extraordinary person she was or how her warm - but strong - spirit would leave an indelible imprint on the hearts of all who knew her.Carol was predeceased by her husband of 53 years, Robert; her parents; an infant sister Lois, and two brothers, John E. and James Klipstein.Surviving are her children Robert Mark Del Signore (Vickie), New Creek, WV; Denise Holmes (John), Inwood, WV; Lorie Del Signore, Moorefield, WV; Anthony Del Signore (Marie), Keyser, WV; Karen Whitlock (Brent), Louisa, VA; and John Del Signore (Amy), Keyser, WV. Also missing her greatly are 14 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren; a younger brother Melvin Klipstein (Anna) of Frostburg, MD; six special nieces and nephews on her family’s side; a caring, extended family on her husband’s side, and many friends.Carol will be buried next to her husband at St. Thomas Cemetery, Keyser, August 16, 2022, in a private service by Smith Funeral Homes and Crematory.In lieu of flowers, please donate to New Creek Volunteer Fire Department, 3628 New Creek Highway, New Creek, WV, 26743. Carol’s family also would like to express gratitude for the angelic nurses and aides from WVU Medicine Hospice, Keyser.To plant Memorial Trees in memory of Carol Lee Del Signore, please click here to visit our Sympathy Store.

Charles Eugene Arbuckle, Sr., 92, of Pittsburg, passed away at 10:30 p.m., Saturday, August 6, 2022 at Medicalodge of Frontenac.He was born June 20, 1930 at Pittsburg, the son of David Earl and Nora Frances (Rasnic) Arbuckle. After his mother passed away, Charles was raised by his grandparents, Charlie and Mary Rasnic. He graduated from Pittsburg High School and later received a woodworking degree.On August 12, 1950, he was united in marriage to Leola May Swift in Pittsburg. She survives at the family home.Mr. Arbuckle served in the United States Army during the Korean War for 18 months.He worked for Town Talk Bread in Joplin, Faddlers Produce, Monsour’s Produce and then Marrone’s Produce until he retired on June 20, 1991.After retirement, they moved to Grand Lake where he went to work at Shangri La golf resort and took up playing golf. He also loved to bowl and was on several bowling leagues.Membership was held in the Pittsburg American Legion Post #64 for 64 years.In addition to his wife, Leola, he is survived by a daughter, Cheryl Ann Shipman of Frontenac; a sister-in-law, Alice Arbuckle of Pittsburg; two grandchildren, Justin Michael Shipman (Sarah) and Michelle Ann Shipman (Austin); and 5 great-grandchildren, Maddison Michelle Jones, Sophia Rosanne Bell, Cameron Michael Raider, Noah Michael Shipman and Isaac Raider.He was preceded in death by his parents, a daughter, Pamela Sue Arbuckle, a son, Charles Eugene Arbuckle, Jr, a brother, Robert Earl Arbuckle, a sister, Betty Irene Swartz, and a half-sister, Daveita Kay Findley.A Graveside Service will be held at 10:00 a.m. Wednesday (August 10) at the Mt. Olive Cemetery with Pastor Daryl Gaddy officiating. Friends may call from 1:00 p.m. to 4:30 to sign the register book at the Brenner Mortuary. The family suggests memorials to the College Education Fund for the great-grandchildren. These may be left at or mailed to the Brenner Mortuary, 114 E. 4th St., Pittsburg, KS 66762. Online condolences may be left at www.brennermortuary.com. Arrangements are under the direction of the Brenner Mortuary, 114 E. 4th St., Pittsburg, KS.To send flowersto the family or plant a treein memory of Charles Eugene Arbuckle, Sr., please visit our floral store.

Pamela Francis Dotson was a caring wife, mother, grandmother, great grandmother, sister, and friend. She was preceded in death by her husband; Robbie Dotson; her daughter; Vanessa Dotson; her parents; Daniel Boone & Maggie Francis; her brothers; Jerry and Dan Francis.Family, friends, and others whose lives were touched by Pam are invited to attend her Celebration of Life at the Phelps, KY Fire Department from 1pm-3pm on April 30, 2023.Care Cremation and Funeral Service is honored to be entrusted with final care.To plant a beautiful memorial tree in memory of Pamela, please visit ourTree Store or plant a tree.

Rose Marie Sangirardi  was born April 4, 1927, in Brooklyn New York, to Frank and Angelina Colaianni. She had one younger brother Michael Colaianni, of Centerich  Long Island.Rose attended Franklin K Lane High School in Brooklyn. She was the first in the family to attend college and received Bachelor of Science Degree in Home Economics / Dietetics from Pratt Institute. Rose married the love of her life Lazurus Sangirardi June 12, 1948. She and "LAZ" have been married for more than 62 glorious years and had  two children, Angela Smith and Peter Sangirardi.In 1970 Rose began teaching at Saint Angela Hall Academy in Brooklyn, where her children had previously attended school. She taught there for nine years. There after she taught at The Mary Lewis Academy (TMLA) in Jamaica New York, where she taught for 15 years, until her retirement. While teaching at TMLA she earned her Masters Degree in Home Economics / Dietetics from St. Johns University.While at TMLA Rose  received  many honors, including the following:-Volunteer Nutritional Consultant to Head Start in 1986.-Became a Certified Home Economist in 1990.-Named "Outstanding Catholic School Teacher" by the Brooklyn/Queens Federation of Catholic Secondary Schools.-Publically recognized by The Mary Lewis Academy for exemplifying the Charism of the Sisters of Saint Joseph and the Philosophy of The Mary Lewis Academy.Following a successful teaching career, she and Laz retired to Oklahoma to be near their children and grand children. Rose was and avid reader, played the piano, loved the Brooklyn Dodgers and "Sooner Football". She was a cancer survivor and battled with Diabetes for 40 years. She was a Devoted Catholic and prayed daily, or more, usually on someone else's behalf, to Saint Anthony of Padua.Rose was preceded in death by her parents and lifelong friend Maggie Pescatore.Rose is survived by her loving and devoted husband,  Lazarus  Sangirardi, her daughter Angela Smith and husband John Michael Smith, son Peter Sangirardi and wife Nancy , grandchildren Robert Anthony Robinson, Kristin Rose Sangirardi, Joseph Anthony Sangirardi, and great grandson Cameron Anthony, a brother Michael Colaianni, cousin Rosalie Mazzalupo, and Maggie's sons Michael, Chris, and William Pescatore.The family would like to thank all of her wonderful care givers, especially Tina, and  to thank you for celebrating her life and inspiration with us. She will be dearly missed,  forever cherished and never far from us.
Burial arrangements under the direction of Moore Memorial Gardens.

Michael Callaghan, age 82, of Spring Hill, FL., died at the Hernando Pasco Hospice Care Center in Brooksville, FL., on Friday, November 21, 2014. Born on December 5, 1931, in Philadelphia, PA., Mike moved to Spring Hill in 1991, from Northeast Philadelphia.Michael was the owner of the Callaghan Marble Shop in Philadelphia, PA. and he later worked for the Ferag Machinery Company, in Levittown, PA. Michael was a veteran of the US Army serving active duty in Korea from 1952-1954, and was a reservist until 1960. Mike was a life member of the VFW Spring Hill Post # 10209, in Spring Hill, FL., and as a member from 1992 to present; he also served as the long time Honor Guard Captain. Michael was Catholic and a member of St. Joan of Arc Catholic Church.Michael is preceded in death by his beloved wife of 47 years, Sophie Callaghan, and by his daughter, Cynthia Callaghan.  Michael is survived by his loving daughter, Andrea J. Hennessey and her husband John Dziegielewski, of Spring Hill, FL.  Along with his membership at the church and the VFW Post, Mike was also a life member of the Hernando Sportsman’s Club, Brooksville, FL, serving as a Trustee on the Board of Directors and a NRA Instructor. A Memorial Gathering will be held at the VFW Post Spring Hill #10209, on  December 8, 2014 at 11:30 AM with lunch to follow. The Memorial Service and Military Honors will be performed by the Honor Guard of VFW Post 10209.  Mike will be laid to rest with his beloved Sophie, at the Florida National Cemetery, in Bushnell, FL., at a later date. Services and Cremation entrusted to the Turner Funeral Homes, 14360 Spring Hill Drive, Spring Hill, Florida 34609, 352-796-9661.Condolences may be sent to www.turnerfuneralandcremation.com, in lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Michael’s memory to the Hernando-Pasco Hospice Foundation, 12107 Majestic Blvd. Hudson, FL. 34667 Turner Funeral Homes Spring Hill Chapel 14360 Spring Hill Drive Spring Hill FL

Enrique Rivera; 92February 12, 1924 - December 28, 2016 LEOMINSTER -- Enrique Rivera, 92, died peacefully at home on Wednesday, after an illness with his family at his bedside. Born in Ciales, P.R. son of Juan Rivera and Maria Vazquez.He had been a farmer and lumberjack in his earlier years in Puerto Rico. He also worked in food service in Puerto Rico and was part of a restaurant staff that served Luis Munoz Marin who was then governor of Puerto Rico.His hobbies included making model airplanes out of scrap metals. He also loved ceramics and art. He was a nature lover. He was an excellent swimmer and had dived into a Taino Indian underwater cave and found an old artifact bow and arrow used by the Indians.Enrique is survived by his daughters, Elsie, Raquel, Rebecca, Maria and son Elias; seven grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren; and two great-great-grandchildren.No funeral services are planned at this time.Bosk Funeral Home, 85 Blossom St., Fitchburg, boskfuneralhome.com

Juanita Bonnie Brandon Matherne was born on March 6, 1926, in the small town of Desloge, Missouri. In 1933, Bonnie’s father took a new job with Freeport Sulphur Company in Port Sulphur, La. Bonnie was only seven years old when she took a train with her mother and younger sister to Port Sulphur to meet. Bonnie attended the local schools and graduated from Port Sulphur High School. After high school, Bonnie studied for a year at University of Southwestern Louisiana. She returned to Port Sulphur after college and worked in the pay-roll office at the Freeport Sulphur Company’s mines at Grand Ecaille. This is where she met her husband, Hector.Bonnie and Hector were married on January 9, 1949, in Port Sulphur. The two of them moved to New Orleans in the 1950’s and raised three children. Bonnie was very dedicated to her family, and she took great pride in everyone’s accomplishments.Juanita Bonnie Brandon Matherne is preceded in death by her husband of 56 years, Hector H. Matherne Sr., her daughter, Brenda Matherne Klibert (Allen); her parents, Frank Aaron Brandon and Bonnie Lee Rentfro Brandon; and her grandchild, Tressie E Klibert.Bonnie is survived by her children, Hector “Bert” H Matherne Jr (Lana) and Brandon B Matherne (Diana); her sister, JoAnn Brandon Schoenberger (Late Barney); her grandchildren, Dale A Klibert Sr (Penny), Hector “Matt” H Matherne III, Shane M Matherne (Brynn), Sheena M Chlebowski (Brian), Carmann M. Hoover (Dillon), Marguerite E Matherne (David), and Marshall B Matherne. Bonnie is also survived by her great grandchildren, Dale A Klibert Jr, Stella Cohravey, Roman Chlebowski, and Ember Matherne; as well as her niece, Bonnie Jo S. Thomas (Bobby) and many Rentfro family relatives from Missouri.Relatives and friends are invited to attend a funeral service on Saturday, December 4, 2021, with visitation beginning at 11am, and a service at 1pm located at Mothe Funeral Home, 2100 Westbank Expressway, Harvey, La 70058. Interment will immediately follow the service in Westlawn Cemetery in Gretna.

Francis Edward Kenneth Halagan, 92, entered peacefully into eternal rest on April 20th, 2023. He was born January 2, 1931 in Cleveland Ohio, later moving to the family farm in North Ridgeville Ohio in 1940.After graduating from high school, he worked for the Chronicle Telegram until he enlisted in the Air Force in 1951. He proudly served from 1951 -1952 in the Korean War crash crew, then returned stateside to serve in the Air Force Medical Corp finishing in the pharmacy department until 1954.He then returned to the Chronicle for 2 more years before determining his life's work to be a pharmacist and entered the University of Toledo for 4 years to graduate in 1962 with a pharmacy degree. He then served as a local pharmacist for 33 years before retiring.Francis loved to be golfing, bowling, gardening, hunting and traveling visiting most of the 50 states. He was a lifelong fan of the Brown's football and Indian's baseball teams.He was a lifelong member of St. Peter's Catholic Church, where he later served as an usher, and a proud member of the Holy Name Society, a charter member of the American Pharmaceutical Association, the West Shore Pharmaceutical Association, member of the Lorain County Pharmaceutical Association and former member of the Ohio Pharmaceutical Association. From 1971 to 1975 he was a Board member of the North Ridgeville City schools.He was a charter member of the VFW Post 9871 for 57 years, Quartermaster for 24 years and Trustee for 6 years.Francis is survived by his beloved wife of 66 years, Marian, his sons Robert, (Jodi), Kenneth (Nancy) and Gregory (Robin) Halagan. His daughters Michele and Catherine Halagan. Nine grandchildren, Joshua (Kim), Jennifer, Makayla (Matt), Alicia (Matt), Meghan, Alexander, Emily, Madelyne and Madison. And 3 great grandchildren, Laney, Riley and Colton. His sister-in-law Mary Jane (Larry) Horn and many nieces and nephews, and loyal granddog and companion, Lucy.He is preceded in death by his parents Michael and Anna Halagan, brother Rudolph (Rita) Halagan and granddaughter, Sara.Friends may call Monday from 4-7PM at the Bogner Family Funeral Home, 36625 Center Ridge Rd., North Ridgeville, where a prayer service will be held on Tuesday at 10AM followed by a 10:30AM Mass at St. Peter Church, 35777 Center Ridge Road. Fr. Bob Franco, Pastor will be the celebrant. Burial will follow at Resthaven Memory Gardens in Avon with full military honors conducted by VFW Post 9871, North Ridgeville.Memorial contributions are suggested to the Hospice of the Western Reserve at www.hospicewr.org

Mary Lou Hummer of Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, formerly of Booker, Tx went to be with her heavenly father on April 20, 2023 at the age of 88, peacefully surrounded by her loving family. A funeral service is scheduled for 2:00 p.m., Tuesday, April 25, 2023 at the First Christian Church of Perryton, Texas with Ralph Maxfield officiating. Burial will follow in Ochiltree Cemetery. Viewing/visitation will be held Monday, April 24, 2023, 10:00 a.m. - 9:00 p.m. and Tuesday, April 25, 2023 9:00 a.m. - 12:30 p.m. at Boxwell Brothers Funeral Home in Perryton, Texas.  Arrangements are under the direction of Boxwell Brothers Funeral Home of Perryton.Mary Lou Smith was born January 26, 1935 in Booneville, Arkansas to Hedrick and Sylvia (Glass) Smith. She grew up along with her sister, Laverne, on a small farm located in the Arkansas River Valley between the Ouachita and Ozark Mountains. She was a loving daughter, sister, wife, mother, mother-in-law, aunt, friend, grandmother, and great grandmother.After graduating from William Carey University in Hattiesburg, Mississippi, she moved to Perryton, Texas to teach school. While in Perryton, Mary met the love of her life David Hummer where they shared 39 years together. David and Mary moved to the family farm north of Huntoon where they farmed, ranched, and raised three daughters.Mary had a love for nature and enjoyed spending time outdoors. She was an artist and avid reader. She enjoyed cooking, music, and spending time with her family and friends. Mary’s carefree and loving spirit will be missed dearly.She is survived by her three daughters, Malinda Hummer of Ft. Worth, TX, Susan Randall and husband, Ben, of Oklahoma City, OK and Stacey Herring and husband, Rick, of Ft. Worth, TX; nine grandchildren, Maggie Row and husband Jason, Aaron Martinez, Caleb Randall, Kelsey Slater and husband Weston, Keaton Randall, Canon Randall, Kristen Brock and husband Peter, Rachel Hawthorne and husband Jarad, and Allie Herring; four great-grandchildren, Harry and Maddie Row, Karsyn and Baylor Slater; brother-in-law Talmadge Nelson; and sister-in-law, Mary F. Hummer. She also leaves behind many nieces, nephews, and friends.She was preceded in death by her parents Hedrick and Sylvia Smith, husband David Hummer, sister Laverne Nelson, and father and mother-in-law David D. and Mary Hummer.Family requests memorial be in her honor to Perry Memorial Library, 22 SE 5th Ave, Perryton, TX 79070 or to OGH Hospice Volunteers, 3019 Main, Perryton, TX 79070.

Mr. Charles Leonard Danley, 84, of Mount Airy, passed away early Thursday morning, April 20, 2023, at his home. Mr. Danley was born September 24, 1938, in Surry County, the son of the late Charlie Posey and Alma Key Danley. Charles served our country honorably in the United States Air Force from 1956 until 1960. Upon his discharge from the Air Force, he worked as a farmer and truck driver, retiring from Ryder Logistics after many years of service. Charles was a founding member of Jesus’ Church of Corinth in Ararat. He helped build the church building and later the fellowship hall. Charles served as a member of the church’s board of trustees for more than 40 years and was a Sunday school teacher for many, many years. Ultimately, he was a faithful servant of God. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Selva Jean Key Danley of the home; two daughters and a son-in-law, Lorri Danley Bowman of Mount Airy and Melissa and Tony Hamlin of Dobson; two sons and daughters-in-law, Chris and Tara Danley of Mount Airy and Kip and Kim Danley of Ararat; his grandchildren, Lindsay and Hal Epperson, Nicole and Aaron Moser, Trey Hamlin, and Molly Hamlin, all of Dobson, Zach Bowman, Reid Danley, and Maddie Danley, all of Mount Airy, and Hunter Danley and Heath Danley, both of Ararat; two great-grandchildren, Essie Raye Moser and River Kate Moser, both of Dobson; a sister, Patty Danley Marion of Ararat; and numerous nieces and nephews. In addition to his parents, Mr. Danley was preceded in death by a son-in-law, The Honorable Clifford Ricky Bowman; a brother and sister-in-law, Oliver J. and Jane C. Danley; a brother-in-law, Jack Marion; his father-in-law and mother-in-law, Dock and Mollie Reid Key; and his sisters-in-law and brothers-in-law, Ruby T. Key, Fred and Jettie Key, Hassell and Mary C. Key, Barley and Mattie H. Key, Dorothy and Sam Moore, and Melva and J.B. Greene, Jr. A private graveside service will be held at Jesus’ Church of Corinth Cemetery, with the Rev. Dale Pack and Lindsay Epperson officiating. Military honors will be conducted at the conclusion of the service by the VFW Memorial Honor Guard. No formal visitation will be held. The family wishes to express their gratitude for the love and compassion shown by the staff at Mountain Valley Hospice and Palliative Care, as well as his special caregivers, Kathy Whitener, Deborah Creed, Dixie Atkins, and Dee Hughes. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Mountain Valley Hospice and Palliative Care, 1427 Edgewood Drive, Suite 101, Mount Airy, NC 27030; or The Honorable Clifford Ricky Bowman Memorial Scholarship Fund, c/o Surry Community College Foundation, 630 South Main Street, Dobson, NC 27017. Moody Funeral Services in Mount Airy is serving the family.

Kent Palmroth Peach October 16, 1930 - December 29, 2016 Kent Palmroth Peach, Grand Forks, ND died peacefully December 29, 2016 at Banner Desert Hospital, Mesa, AZ from complications due to a sudden massive hemorrhagic stroke suffered on December 20, 2016.  Kent was born on October 16, 1930 in Fargo, North Dakota to Fred and Charlotte (Palmroth) Peach. Kent was raised on the family farm, near Erie, ND aka "Twin Birch Farm".  He graduated from Erie High School in 1948 but due to childhood polio he was unable to serve in the military. He went to NDSSS/Whapeton to attain his Plumbing and Heating degree.  He jokingly told people he had received his "PHD".   Kent met Karen Haug on a blind date in 1951 and they were married in Langdon, ND in 1953.  Later that year he joined the Plumbers and PipeFitters Union Local 300.  He worked as journeyman pipefitter for several years and later became a Master Plumber.  His first business, Opp & Peach, Inc., received the North Dakota Small Business of the Year Award in 1977.  In 1982, he started his own mechanical contracting business, Kent Peach, Inc. "Peach" was held in high regard in the construction business as he was known for doing the job right the first time.  Kent was a collector of many things, particularly cub cadets and antique tractors. He never threw anything away, preferring to store things at "the farm". He was an avid fisherman and hunter, flying back yearly to ND from AZ for deer season until he was 85.  Kent loved golfing every morning & evening at Lincoln Golf Course and being part of the seniors league. He treasured his friendships with his golf friends and McDonalds coffee buddies every morning in the summer months. One of Kent's hobbies was wood working and he was known for making stools with wood from Twin Birch Farm.  He made hundreds of them, gifting them to family and friends, as well as friends of friends, never asking for anything in return but a smile.   Kent lived a humble life to the absolute fullest. He was physically active from sunup to sundown, until December 20, 2016. His favorite saying was, "Come on, we're burning daylight!"  Kent viewed life with a "glass half full" attitude - he was always positive and had a dry sense of humor that made everyone laugh. Kent is survived by his loving wife Karen of 63 years; his children: Konnie (Tom) Middleton of Fountain Hills, AZ; Kim Peach (Kristy) of  Choteau, MT and Kay (Art) Culver of Grand Forks.  He is also survived by six granddaughters that thought their Grandpa Peach was bigger than life itself:  Nicole Middleton, Lindsay Middleton, Adair Peach, Ella Peach, Kourtney Culver and Kaitlan Culver.  He is also survived by his sister, Mary Ellen Cabral of Mesa, AZ. He was preceded in death by his parents, Fred and Charlotte Peach, and his brother, Jack Peach. Kent and Karen wintered in Mesa, Arizona for the past 30 years.  A memorial was held in Arizona on January 3rd at the Mesa Village clubhouse where Kent was very active and in charge of many activities.  Funeral services are planned for June 9th 2017 at Calvary Lutheran Church in Grand Forks, ND with burial in Erie, ND cemetery.  In place of flowers the family requests donations kindly to Calvary Lutheran Church or favorite charity. Arrangements under the direction of Melcher Mortuary Mission Chapel & Crematory, Mesa, AZ.

Mary Sandra Geeslin Pruitt, 86, of Lynchburg, VA, passed away at home, with her family, on August 8, from complications of dementia.She was born on September 7, 1935, to Wilma Rose Box Geeslin and Joseph David Geeslin in Jasper, Alabama. She was preceded in death by her parents, husband, Warner, sister, Murrine, and nephew, Carl Brown. She is survived by her daughter, Jeanell Smith (Randy), brother, Joe (Liz), and the light of her life, granddaughter, Sophie.She graduated in 1954 from Shades Valley High School in Birmingham, Alabama, and after many years of part-time work/volunteering and full-time Mothering, at 40 she enrolled at the University of Alabama in Huntsville and graduated in 1986. Throughout her life, she moved many times as her Father followed work and with her Air Force husband. Upon Warner’s retirement from the Air Force they settled in Huntsville, Alabama. She worked for many years as a Government Contract Specialist for the Department of the Army at Redstone Arsenal. Upon their retirement, they moved to Virginia to be close to family.She loved people, all people, and spent much of her life in the service of others. Throughout her life, she volunteered wearing many hats, including Girl Scout Leader, PTA school President, classroom Mom, scorekeeper, team chauffer, and community and church volunteer at First Christian Church. She served as President of the PTA of Huntsville and the State PTA Board of Alabama. She also served as the Secretary of the National Contract Management Association. Her life of service and love for people set the example for her family to follow. She was amazing. Sandra was a lifelong college football fan with a deep love for the Alabama Crimson Tide. Roll Tide!Our family would like to thank her dedicated aides over the years, Aletha, Karen, Tanya, Ella, Pam, and Janet. Your presence in our lives allowed her to live her best life and we are so very grateful to you. We thank Centra Hospice for their support and care. Thank you to Cheryl Metz, her dear friend, for her love and friendship. Thank you also to Carole Friend for her unwavering support, guidance, and love. To Randy, thank you for working so hard to keep us all together. We would also like to thank our friends for their love and support over the years.In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Miriam’s House, 409 Magnolia St, Lynchburg, VA 24503, https://www.miriamshouseprogram.org/, to support their continuing work housing individuals and families. Her love for her sister led her to support this organization for many years in her memory.Heritage Funeral Service and Crematory 427 Graves Mill Road Lynchburg is assisting the family. Memories and thoughts may be shared with the family at www.heritagefuneralandcremation.comTo plant a beautiful memorial tree in memory of Mary, please visit ourTree Store or plant a tree.

James Johnson Hall, born July 28, 1934, the first dog day of summer, with a mind like a steel trap, passed away August 8, 2022 after a decades long battle with Parkinson’s disease. He was preceded in death by three infant daughters and by his beloved wife, Annette Conner Hall. Mr. Hall was survived by three sons, Clayton A. Hall (Sara), Jay A. Hall (Melissa) and Christopher C. Hall. Mr. Hall was also survived by four grandchildren, James A. Hall, II, Preston J. Hall, Taylor A. Hall and Annslin S. Hall.Funeral services will be at 2:00 pm on Wednesday, August 10, 2022 at Clark Funeral Home with Rev. Maggie Bloodworth, Ernest Mashburn and Marvin Peavy officiating, with a visitation held prior to the service at 1:00 pm. Burial will be in the family plot at Orange Hill Cemetery and will be private.Mr. Hall was born in and lived all of his life in Pulaski County, Georgia, having been born to James Ashley Hall and Lucille Johnson Hall, whom preceded him in death. He graduated from Hawkinsville High School, with the classmates he loved and adored, in 1952 and later from the University of Georgia and Mercer University School of Law. Mr. Hall drove daily from Hawkinsville to Macon to attend law school all the while raising his sons and serving the City of Hawkinsville as a Commissioner for what would become 16 years. He began law practice in 1970 in Hawkinsville and remained an active member of the State Bar of Georgia until his death. He was widely known and admired for his encyclopedic knowledge of real estate law and real estate of Pulaski County. He will be missed and remembered by his peers.Always civic minded, in addition to his service as a Hawkinsville City Commissioner, he served decades as Pulaski County Attorney and many years as the attorney for the Pulaski County Board of Education. Among his many efforts on behalf of the citizens of Hawkinsville and Pulaski County, he served as chairman of the Heart of Georgia Area Planning and Development Commission and the Jointly Owned Natural Gas Transmission Line.When not caring for his many friends and clients, he enjoyed taking trips with his family to St. Petersburg Beach and to Lake Blackshear. He drove his Volkswagen “The Thing” with his dogs King and Queen. An accomplished boat driver, he enjoyed pulling his sons and their friends water skiing. Later, he enjoyed trips to The Gibson Inn in Apalachicola, Florida, where he and his wife Annette, were on the cover of the brochure.Mr. Hall believed you must be a friend to have a friend and he leaves behind his great friends, to whom he was closer to than any brother, Ronnie Fleeman and Ernest Mashburn, Jr. He was predeceased by his college classmate and great friend Andrew Cabero.The family wishes to thank their father’s dedicated and loving sitters Angie Bryant and Tomeka “BayBay” Jenkins for their loving devotion, care and kindness and his favorite secretary Amy. Also, the family wishes to thank Brenda Wright and Jamie Chamberlain, of Agape Hospice, for their loving care especially over the last few months.Last but certainly not least, the family wishes to thank Ms. Vera Roberts for being the most special friend our father could have had. Her care and affection will forever be remembered.Clark Funeral Home of Hawkinsville, Ga. is in charge of the arrangements.Please sign the online register at www.clarkfuneralhawkinsville.com
