Bernice L. Mahanof BremertonJuly 26, 1913to Sept. 9, 2010Bernice L. Mahan left this world peacefully, in the arms of her daughter, the morning of Sept. 9, 2010, after 97 wonderful years.She was born July 26, 1913, to David and Delia (Kammerzell) Oakes, on a small Palouse farm near Dusty, WA. Bee lived her early years in Portland, OR, during the Great War, while her father worked the grain silos for the war effort. After WWI, Bee's family returned to the family wheat farm in Farmington, WA. It was there that fate would introduce her to her future husband, Bill. He came from Bremerton to spend a year on his Uncle's farm and would catch a ride to school with Bee on the back of her horse. He was 7, she was 10.Bee and her sister, Erville, were very close and grew up working hard together on the family farm. Bee was a good student and liked barn dances, sleigh rides, and silent movies. In high school she was awarded a ride in the first bi-wing airplane to land in Farmington & remembered the thrill of the spins and loop-de-loops. She graduated from Farmington High School in 1932 and attended Sacred Heart School of Nursing in Spokane. After graduating as a Registered Nurse in 1935, she worked at Eastern State Hospital, was married briefly and had a son, Thomas Goddard.During WWII, answering a call for nurses to care for injured servicemen, Bee moved to Bremerton with her son Tommy. She attended a local USO Social and was asked to dance by a handsome young Sergeant. During the dance Bee and Bill realized they knew each other from earlier days. Their angels congratulated each other, and Bee and Bill Mahan were married in 1946. In 1950 their daughter, Kathy, was born. Bee and Bill shared 60 loving years together before Bill's death in 2006.After the war, Bee worked at the Jackson Clinic in Bremerton. When the Doctor's Clinic was first started she continued her career as Dr. Rosendale's nurse/midwife. In 1962, Bee was offered the job of Nursing Supervisor of labor & delivery at Harrison Hospital; she retired in 1979. During her career years, she also received a Golden Acorn award for PTA work, volunteered with the Lady Elks and Lionesses and attended Olympic College evenings. Bee was a devoted mother, enjoyed sewing and gardening, cared for her elderly parents and supported Bill in countless philanthropic endeavors. But nursing was always her passion. One of the great joys of her life was assisting new mothers in the birth of their babies.After retirement, Bee & Bill enjoyed travelling, especially to Mexico. She celebrated her 80th birthday by climbing 5 major pyramids in the Yucatan. Bee attended aerobics class nearly every day at the YMCA and finished up with a mile walk. She gave up aerobics at age 90, but still enjoyed daily walks and exercising until age 96. Her body slowed down, but her spirit remained a bright and shining light.Bee lived her last 4½ years with her daughter and loving caregivers at Miami Beach, Seabeck, where she and Bill had their summer home. Hospice caregivers provided an abundance of TLC in her last few months of life and son-in-law, Don, could always elicit a big smile.She is survived by her son and daughter-in-law Tom and Carol Goddard of Dayton, WA; her daughter Kathy Mahan and son-in-law Don Paulson of Seabeck, WA; sister Ervie Johnson (96) of Spokane; niece Judy (Gordon) Warren; nephew Mike (Debbie) Johnson.A celebration of Bee's life will be held at the Miller Woodlawn Chapel in Bremerton on Friday, Oct. 22nd at 1 p.m. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Kitsap County or to the Bremerton Food Line.

An extraordinary life of service to family, country, and community came to a peaceful end for Ethel Elizabeth Stiles Kampf on Monday, May 23, 2011.  After suffering a debilitating stroke in June of 2010, Ethel spent her remaining days at the Kittitas Valley Rehabilitation Center. Ethel was born in North Adams, MA to Elizabeth Hodge MacAdoo Stiles and Floyd Lent Stiles on Nov 4, 1921.  She graduated from Dalton High School and went on to graduate as a registered nurse from the Bishop School of Nursing in 1942.  Heeding to the call for nurses needed in WWII, she enlisted in May of 1943 and served in England as a member of the US Army Nurse Corp for three years.  She nursed troops through some of the bloodiest battles in Europe.  And, as so many of our "Greatest Generation" she rarely spoke of her wartime experiences.  She flew as a United Airlines flight attendant (they had to be registered nurses then) until her marriage to J. Edward Kampf in 1947. They made their home in the San Francisco Bay area where she continued her career as a registered nurse. She and her husband traveled extensively around the world after they retired, making many friends along the way.  They were married for 51 years. Edward preceded Ethel's death in July, 1998.She is the mother of two children: Deborah Essman (husband Bill) of Ellensburg and a son, Michael, of Erie, CO.  She has three grandchildren:  Sarah Kampf Jordan (Erie, CO), Ryan Kampf (Prince Frederick, MD), and Scott Essman (Ellensburg), plus one Great-Grandson, William Ridge Essman of Ellensburg.  She leaves behind many, many dear friends including her best buddy, and fellow WWII veteran, Helen Bennett. Ethel came from a large family of two brothers: Floyd and William, plus three sisters: Alice, Mary, and Judy (Dave) of Santa Clara, CA.  Judy is her only surviving sibling.After Edward's death, Ethel moved to Ellensburg in 1998 to live near her daughter and son-in-law. She quickly became involved with the community as a proud member of the American Legion and VFW.  She volunteered for the Meals on Wheels program, the Senior Center,  and at Kittitas Valley Community Hospital where she put her nursing knowledge to good use helping limited-income seniors to qualify for drug subsidies offered by pharmaceutical companies.  At the Legion and VFW, she volunteered tirelessly to support currently deployed  troops.  After volunteering for more than 4,000 hours in 10 years to a variety of county organizations, she was honored in 2010 as a Presidential Volunteer and received a personal citation from President Obama.  A graveside service will be at the High Cemetery off Robinson Canyon Road at 12 noon on Friday, June 24th. A memorial potluck and gathering of friends for Ethel will follow at 1 PM at the American Legion Hall.  All are invited to attend.Arrangements under the direction of Steward & Williams Tribute Center, Ellensburg, WA.

Joyce G. Hershey, 79, of Lancaster, died peacefully and went home to be with her Lord on Tuesday, September 12, 2017 at Homestead Village Retirement Community. Born in Big Spring, Maryland, she was the daughter of the late Joseph and Ruth Horst Clugston. Joyce was the loving wife of Donald C. Hershey and they observed their 60th wedding anniversary in June of this year. For 53 years Joyce was the Corporate Secretary for the Hershey Equipment Company, Lancaster. With experience in Interior Design Joyce was the owner and operator of Gehman's Furniture, Mount Joy from 1990 to 2000.  Joyce had a life-long passion for ministry, and was a leader of Stone Croft Ministries during the 1970's and 80's which focused on Women's Ministry nationally. Joyce and her husband Don along with others helped to start LCBC ministries in their home as a way to reach out to others in helping to share the love of Christ. Joyce is a partner with LCBC and served on the board for Lancaster Bible College. Joyce could fill up a room with her engaging personality; people were drawn to her because of her kind spirit of always wanting to help others. She truly had a servant's heart and provided hope and joy to so many friends and to strangers alike. Joyce was adored by her husband, children, grandchildren, and extended family.  Surviving in addition to her husband Don, are two daughters: Doreen L. wife of Michael D. Dickson, of Marietta, Donita L. wife of Pastor Dwayne E. Carson of Lewis Center, OH., six grandchildren: Bradley M. Dickson, Jeffrey D. husband of Laurin Dickson, Kristen A. wife of Josh Peterson, Kaitlyn A. Carson, Kirk A. Carson, Klayton A. Carson, and two sisters: Miriam wife of Jacob Ober of Conestoga, E. Ruth wife of Galen Miller of Lancaster. Preceding her in death is a son, Daryl L. Hershey, and three brothers: Paul, Merle, and Leon Clugston.  Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend Joyce's Service of Remembrance and Thanksgiving at LCBC Church, Manheim Campus, 2392 Mount Joy Road, Manheim, on Monday, September 18, 2017 at 4:00 PM, please use the South Auditorium Entrance. Friends may visit with the family at the church on Monday afternoon from 2:00 PM to 3:30 PM. Interment will be private and at the convenience of the family in Laurel Hill Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent in Joyce's memory to LCBC Outreach, 2392 Mount Joy Road, Manheim, PA 17545. Buch Funeral Home, Manheim, in charge of arrangements. To send the family on-line condolences, please visit: www.BuchFuneral.com www.pennlive.com/obits

Rector, David 1/2/1930 - 5/26/2018 Cedar Springs David Lee Rector, age 88, of Cedar Springs, Michigan passed away on Saturday, May 26, 2018 at Spectrum Health Butterworth Campus. He was born in Grand Rapids, Michigan on January 2, 1930 to Edwin D. and Myrtle (Brower) Rector. David graduated from South Union High School in 1948. He continued his education at Western Michigan University where he obtained a bachelor's degree and then obtained 2 Master's Degrees, one from University of Michigan in 1958 and one from Western Michigan in 1974. David spent over 35 years as an educator, teaching for 25 plus years in Benton Harbor Public Schools. After leaving Benton Harbor he continued as a substitute teacher in the Grant, Fremont and Rockford school systems. David married Ada Dexter in 1956 and they enjoyed 47 years of marriage before she preceded him in death in 2003. David was an avid sportsman and loved to fish and hunt. He never met a lake or river that he didn't like! Everyone who knew them would agree that Dave and Ada were kind, humble and generous with their resources. David is survived by his brothers, Tom Rector and Bob (Marilyn) Rector and seven nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his parents, his wife, and his brother, John. Services for David will be held on Monday, June 4, 2018 at Hessel-Cheslek Funeral Home in Sparta, Michigan at 11:00 AM with Reverend Tim Tuthill officiating. Family will meet visitors for one hour prior to the service starting at 10:00 AM. Interment will be in Garfield Park Cemetery in Grand Rapids. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations in David's memory may be made to Lean On Me @ rockfordres.org, or the Alzheimer's Association in remembrance of how he and Ada helped so many in need. www.hessel-cheslek.com

Obituary for Mr. Cleveland "Nu Nu" Chouest, Jr. Cleveland "Nu Nu" Anthony Chouest, Jr. a native of Golden Meadow and resident of Galliano passed away on Sunday, October 20, 2019. A visitation will be held at First Baptist Church of Golden Meadow on Tuesday, October 22, 2019 from 6:00 pm until 8:00 pm and on Wednesday, October 23, 2019 from 9:00 am until service time. Funeral Services will begin at 11:00 am with procession following to his burial in Cheramie Cemetery. Mr. Cleveland is survived by his wife of 57 years; Jean Dubois Chouest, children; Anthony Chouest (Michelle), Annette Chouest, Matthew Chouest, Sr. (Bernadette), Crystal Chouest, and Christian Chouest (Ranada), grandchildren; Kayla (Ron), Ben (Maggie), Devin, Seth, Jacob, T-Matt, Destinie, Ryan, Ava, Asher and Eden, great grandchildren; Brandon, Emily, Jacie, Susie, Natalie, and Georgia, brothers; Gilmay and Jeffery Chouest, and sister Patricia Louviere. Mr. Chouest was preceded in death by parents; Cleveland Sr. and Dorothy B. Cheramie, step father; Joseph L. Cheramie, brother; Johnny Chouest, and sister; Arlene Chouest. Nu Nu loved the Lord, and was a loving husband, father, and grandfather who enjoyed spending time with his family, trawling and loved to laugh. He will be greatly missed by his family and all who knew him. And he would like to leave you with two of his favorite sayings: "For the Child of God, dying is easy; living is hard." and "Politicians shake hands; Brother's hug." Joy Elaine White, 77, of Robinson, IL, died on October 20, 2019, at Casey Health Care Center in Casey, IL. She was born on January 26, 1942, in Hutsonville, IL, the daughter of Ovie Adams & Charlotte (Butler) Adams, both of whom preceded her in death. She married Kenneth White on July 23,1983, and he preceded her in death on October 19, 2004. She was also preceded in death by her sisters, Peg Boyll, Betty Lou Anderson, Wanda Arbuckle; and by her brother, Bob Adams. She is survived by her sisters, Jodi Jackson (Marshall, IL) and Virginia Nole (Roosevelt, AZ); by her sister-in-law, Doris Adams; as well as several nieces and nephews.  Joy grew up in both the Hutsonville and West York areas. She would go on to work for TRW for a number of years, but her heart was for her home, where she lived with and loved on her cats! Anyone who knew her could attest to the love she had for her four-legged companions as well as her inherent sense of happiness, no matter what life threw her way. She was also known to collect dolls and spent countless hours crocheting afghans for them and for her loved ones. She and Ken were longtime members of the New Hope Baptist Church, where they worshipped the same Savior who made a way to the eternal life they are both experiencing today and forevermore.  A time of visitation will be held from 9:00-10:00 a.m. on Thursday, October 24th at the Goodwine Funeral Home in Robinson. Funeral services will be held at 10:00 a.m. with burial following in the Palestine Cemetery. Pastor George Meese will be officiating the service. In honor of her love of cats, memorial contributions may be made to the "Crawford County Humane Society", with envelopes available at the funeral home.

In Bradley, Arkansas, on October 21, 1976, a beautiful baby girl was born, Emma Mae Walker Horton. Emma was a member of Pentecostal Church of Stamps under the leadership of Pastor Lee Moss. In 2001, Emma was involved in a life changing bicycle accident that left her to be cared for by her loving parents. With many laughs shared by friends and family she was able to do so.Emma was preceded in death by her brother, Berlin Walker. Terry Adams, age 65, gained his angel wings and passed away peacefully on November 26, 2021. Terry was born in Chicago, Illinois, and moved to the copper corridor in 1971. In 1974 he met the love of his life, Cathy, and in 1976 they were married. Together they made their home in Mammoth.Terry was truly a people person. He loved talking to and helping anyone he came across. Terry started his career working at Napa (Slaters) Auto Parts in Hayden. Terry never met a person or a car he couldn’t fix. Terry spent the better part of thirty years helping people in the Copper Corridor find parts and fix their vehicles.Terry loved giving back to the community. In 2018, Terry signed up to be the vice president/secretary for Mammoth Little League. Terry loved making snow cones and other treats for the kiddos and their families. When a child would come up to the concession stand to get a treat and didn’t have any money, Terry would use his own money to purchase the treat. He loved bringing joy to others. In 2020, Terry took his community service a step further and ran for and won a seat on the Mammoth Town Council. A position he took great pride in.Terry loved spending time outdoors camping with his beautiful bride and other family members. Family was at the top of Terry’s list of favorite things. Terry was always up for any BBQ or family get-togethers that were suggested.Terry had many hobbies beyond spending time with his family. Terry loved to collect model trains. He enjoyed watching TV specials on how certain trains were upgraded or how engineers solved problems with weight and speed. Terry also loved to build things or fix broken items. If you needed home improvements done, Terry couldn’t wait to get started. Terry also enjoyed listening to music. His favorite genre was music from the 50s and 60s, or as the grandkids like to call it, “old people’s music.”Terry was a long-time devout Christian. He spent many hours talking to his family and friends about Jesus. He served on the Board of Directors for the San Manuel Assembly of God for many years.Terry was a loving, caring, funny man who would light up the darkest of rooms. He would give the shirt off his back to help anyone in need. Terry always had a joke or a hug if you were sad or down. He always knew how to make you feel better. He was always the biggest presence in the room.Terry is preceded in death by his brother Gary White and in-laws Gerald and Aurelia Seevers. He leaves behind his wife Cathy; parents Frank and Wilma Adams; brother Frank Adams Jr.; children Annie (Albert) Martinez, Terry Jr (Amber) Adams, and Gina Medina (Bret Snelgrove); Grandchildren: Tori, Bella, Archer, Lexie, Zeke, Riley, and Addison; many brothers and sisters-in-law’s, and a multitude of nieces, nephews, and close friends. Terry will forever be missed by all who knew him.To plant Memorial Trees in memory of Terry Lee Adams, please click here to visit our Sympathy Store.

Karen “Katrina” Maxwell, 62 of Howell, Michigan, passed away on November 26, 2021. The daughter of Robert and Carol Stapula, she was born on June 1, 1959, in Detroit, Michigan. She was the youngest of three daughters. She graduated from Fowlerville High School. When she was 17, Ron, “the redneck farm boy from next door,” gave her a diamond ring. On September 3, 1977, she married him, and he became her best friend for life. The following year, their daughter Melisa was born who was dear to their hearts.Katrina was a beloved and caring wife, mother, grandmother, aunt, family member, and friend. She was a charismatic and cherished light in the lives of countless people. She was proudly 100% Finnish and undeniably had Sisu. She was a gifted leader in all aspects of her life. She radiated warmth and had a passion for caring for children and serving others. She loved her pets and animals, gardening, baking, sharing time with friends and being involved in her community. She enjoyed traveling and spending time in northern Michigan and in Florida.Katrina served as the President of the Howell Jaycees where she received numerous recognitions from the state including Family of the Year and grew the Howell chapter to the largest in Michigan. She was employed with L.E.T.S. Transportation for nearly thirty years in Livingston County. During her tenure, she worked as a drug and alcohol testing trainer locally and nationally and was also promoted to Operations Manager. She attended conventions and served on a board for the FDA where she wrote policies for OTC medications that were adopted nationwide. She was also honored as The Grand Marshall of Howell Melon Festival.Katrina is survived by her treasured husband, Ronald G. Maxwell; her loving daughter, Melisa A. Maxwell; her beloved granddaughter, Caelynn Roy; her sisters, Sharon (Roger) Younce and Debbie (Brian) Tyler; her many cousins, nieces, and nephews. She was preceded in death by her parents Robert and Carol and her dear friend Cheryl Bettis.Visitation will be on Wednesday, December 1, 2021 beginning at 3:00 P.M. until 7:00 P.M. at Watkins Brothers Funeral Home-MacDonald’s Chapel, Howell, MI (517-546-2800). A funeral service will be held on Thursday, December 2, 2021 at 11:00 A.M. also at the funeral home. Friends may visit beginning at 10:00 A.M. Interment will then follow at Howell Memorial Cemetery, Howell, MI.Memorial contributions are suggested to the National Kidney Foundation and St. John’s Lutheran Church in Fowlerville, MI.To send flowers to the family of Karen "Katrina" Maxwell please visit our Tribute Store.

It is with tremendous sadness that the family of Charles Vincent Suphan must announce his passing. Charles passed away August 9, 2022, at Baptist Hospital in Little Rock, Arkansas. Charles leaves behind two children, Alicia Suphan, and Jesse Suphan; five grandchildren; his brother, William Suphan; his sister, Clara Wright-Sloan; and his ex-wife, Neema Suphan.He is preceded in death by his parents William Suphan (Fireman) and Ruth Suphan (Nurse); his daughter, Charlene Suphan; and his older brothers, Donald Boyer and James Boyer.Charles was born in Brooklyn, NY June 25, 1948. He grew up back and forth between Arkansas and New York. Charles had a big personality and led an even bigger life. He would often regale his kids with stories from his youth of traveling the country, the friends he met, and the trouble he got into. And there was a lot of trouble.Charles held many careers including but not limited to deep sea fisherman, carpenter, line cook, mill worker, unemployment hearing judge, and lastly attorney.Charles graduated from Berkshire Community College in Pittsfield, MA. He then went on to get his B.A. in Political Science at Amherst College, Amherst, MA class of 1986. He returned to Arkansas to study law at University of Arkansas at Little Rock School of Law and graduated in 1989. Charles passed his bar exam on the first try, which he would remind his kids frequently.Charles has been an Attorney for over 30 years in Arkansas with a long history of standing up for the little guy. One of his past paralegals quoted him as saying “lives are in the balance here” regularly around the office. He advocated for those who needed a voice through his law practice. He represented clients pro-bono under RAINN- Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network, the nation's largest anti-sexual violence organization. Before apps like “23 and me” or “Ancestry,” Charles volunteered his time to help reunite families. Some of his proudest moments were reuniting parents with kids, siblings, and long-lost friends.Charles’ hobbies included country music and history. Charles was major fan of Elvis Presly. On many occasions, he took his kids to Graceland to be in the presence of “The King.” Charles also held a deep passion for investigating US history, especially the JFK assassination. He took his family yearly to Dallas to the grassy knoll to do his own research on the matter. He did eventually get to the bottom of it, of course.Charles’ most wonderful traits were his nonjudgmental disposition, gentle demeanor, and high-spirited humor. As a person with “above average intelligence” (he would want this put in), he was able to find the humor in everything. One of his most revered comedy idols was 50s comedian Lenny Bruce. Lenny Bruce once said, “without the human condition there is no struggle, no pain, and also no laughter.” Right now his family is feeling that pain and struggle. However, his family wants to thank him for his gift of laughter that helps bring them some comfort. Lenny Bruce also said, “there are never enough I love you’s,” and nothing is more true today. Charles always ended every phone call saying “I love you” because in case anything happened, those would be the last words he said to you. There are never enough opportunities to say another “I love you”. We love you Charles, and we will take all your lessons to heart and pass them along to those we love.Arrangements by Arkansas Cremation, 10515 W Markham St, Ste B1, Little Rock, AR 72205.Online Guestbook: www.arkansascremation.comTo send flowersto the family or plant a treein memory of Charles Vincent Suphan, please visit our floral store.

Theresa L. Larsh, 95, of Beaver Grove, was called home by the Lord on August 9, 2022. She had been residing at Trillium Hospice House since June 2021.Theresa was born in New Swanzy to Silas and Louise (Tousignant) Moquin on June 24, 1927, which was their 15th wedding anniversary. She graduated from Gwinn High School in 1945. She spent a summer working in Detroit while still in high school.She was united in marriage to the late William J. "Bill" Larsh Sr. in Gwinn on September 23, 1946 while he was home on leave from the Army. Together they raised their four sons in a supportive neighborhood in Beaver Grove with families that became lifelong friends. When Bill became ill in 1981, she became his loving caretaker until his death in July of 1983.Theresa was a founding member of the St. Louis the King Catholic Church and loved her Church family. She belonged to the Altar Society for many years. She enjoyed spending as much time as she could with her family and the Beaver Grove "Grovers" families, including the Youngs, Baldwins, Goodwins, Georgiannis and Gorieskys. She enjoyed her Debbie Tour Bus trips with her friend, Joanne. She was so thankful for the friendship and help from the Carlsons, Hamaris and as she called them, "her three special angels" Paulita, Polly and Pat. She will be remembered for her quirky sense of humor, teasing her grandchildren, kind heartedness and always more concerned about others before herself. Her boys will remember her as "short and sassy." She had a tremendous memory for her 95 years.Theresa is survived by her loving sons, Bill (JoDee) Larsh of Marquette, Al (June) Larsh of Ishpeming, Larry (Kim) Larsh of Three Rivers, MI and Dave (Stacey) Larsh of Emmitt, MI; 14 grandchildren, 10 great-grandchildren and 1 great-great-grandchild; and numerous nieces and nephews.Theresa was preceded in death by her husband of 37 years; her parents; brother, Silas Moquin and his former wives, Kay and Anne; brother, Bert and his wife, Avila; her father-in-law and mother-in-law; and her Aunt Mary and Uncle Ted.A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Louis the King Catholic Church on Tuesday, August 16th at 11:00 a.m. with Rev. Glenn Theoret officiating. Visitation will begin at 9:30 a.m. until the time of the Mass. A reception will immediately follow in the Father Gauthier Hall. Burial will take place in the Gwinn Cemetery later in the week. Pallbearers will be her loving grandchildren.The Larsh family would like to thank the Trillium Hospice House and U.P. Home Health & Hospice staff and volunteers. A special thank you to FNP, Erika Kielhorn and Dr. Catherine Kroll for their exceptional care and friendship they provided.In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made in Theresa's name to the Trillium Hospice House, 1144 Northland Drive, Marquette, MI 49855.Canale-Tonella Funeral Home and Cremation Services is assisting Theresa's family where memories and condolences may be shared at canalefuneral.comTo send flowers to the family or plant a memorial tree in memory of THERESA L. LARSH, please visit our Tribute Store

Gerald L. Jacksonof Westford; 82 WESTFORD - Gerald L. Jackson a resident of Westford and beloved husband of Doris A. (Beskalo) Jackson passed away on Monday, October 21, 2019 at the Life Care Center of the Merrimack Valley following a period of declining health. He was 82.Born in Medford on December 14, 1936, he was a son of the late Gordon and Barbara (Wilder) Jackson.Gerald grew up in Tewksbury and graduated from Tewksbury High School. He enlisted in the Army and served during the Korean War.Prior to his retirement Gerald was employed as an inspector for General Tire. Following his retirement, he worked for the Dee Bus Company as a bus driver for 8 years.Gerald was a sports fan. He enjoyed watching the Bruins, Red Sox, and Patriots. He was an avid college hockey fan, especially the UMASS Lowell River Hawks where he has been a season ticket holder since 1975.When his children were younger, he was a volunteer coach, coaching his children in Westford Youth Hockey and Westford Little League Baseball.Gerald enjoyed the outdoors. He looked forward to hunting and snowmobile trips to Pittsburg, NH. He was also worked for the Ski Patrol at Killington Resort in Vermont where he would ski with his boys.Gerald had an extensive vegetable garden that he would share with family and friends. In his spare time relaxing he liked to listen to country music.In addition to his wife Doris with whom he would have celebrated 58 years on October 28th of this year are two sons and daughters-in-law, Steven and Andrea Jackson of Lowell, Jeff and Anne Jackson of Westford; three grandchildren, Nicholas Jackson, Zoe Jackson, John Kane; a sister and brother-in-law, Joyce and Robert Smith of Hollis, NH; and several nieces and nephews. He was also the brother of the late Diane Driscoll.JACKSON - Relatives and friends are invited to Gerald's celebration of life from 6 until 8 PM on Thursday at the HEALY FUNERAL HOME, 57 North Main Street, Westford. His funeral Service will be in the funeral home on Friday at 11:00 AM Burial will follow at the Russian Brotherhood Cemetery. For directions and condolences, please visit www.healyfuneralhome.com.

John P. Lovejoy, age 56, of Archbold passed away on November 27, 2021, at home. John spent 34 years married to the love of his life, Ronda (Rupp) Lovejoy, who survives.John was born on June 19, 1965, to Paul and Joan Lovejoy in Ft. Hood, Texas. John started working in seventh grade with his cousin, David, now brother-in-law, cleaning the Archbold Dairy Freeze in the evenings. He later graduated from Archbold High School in 1983. After high school, John worked for Sauder Forecraft for around 10 months. After Forecraft, John worked for his Uncle Ted at the Wastewater plant until he decided to manage the Dairy Freeze for a couple years. He returned to the Wastewater plant where he worked until he retired in 2019 after 32 years while also retiring from working with the Archbold Cemetery. After retirement he enjoyed driving part time for AMC transportation.John was a member of the Archbold Fire Department from 1983-2001, was a Lions Club Member, and fulfilled his dream of living in the country and owning a farm in 2001, where he raised cattle and sheep. John was also on the Fulton County Fair Board from 2011-2021, with three years serving as the Vice President. John was a member of Archbold Evangelical Church, where he served in roles of usher, trustee, and café server. John enjoyed spending time in his shop working on his Farmall Tractors (one of them being his Grandpa Schultz’s Farmall H). Everyone knew him for his love of his family, and how he loved to have fun and pick on his family and friends. He will also be remembered for his Facebook quotes, and most importantly, helping his kids with projects and just spending time with them.Surviving John is his wife, Ronda; children, Brad Lovejoy, Mike Lovejoy, Mandy Lovejoy, and Justin Lovejoy, all of Archbold; parents, Paul and Joan Lovejoy; and siblings, Mary (Kent) Sauder and Jason Lovejoy.Visitation for John will take place at the Archbold Evangelical Church on Thursday, December 2, 2021, from 2pm – 8pm. A memorial service for John will take place on Friday, December 3, 2021, at the church at 11am, with burial taking place at the Archbold Cemetery prior to the service at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that memorial contributions be made to Center for Biblical Living or the Fulton Co. Fairground Foundation. Online condolences may be offered to the family at www.grisierfh.com. The Grisier Funeral Home in Archbold is honored to serve the Lovejoy family.To send flowers to the family or plant a tree in memory of John P. Lovejoy, please visit our floral store.

Bill Zamzow, age 97, of Glenview, passed away peacefully on August 10, 2022. Loving husband of the late Ruth M. Zamzow. Beloved father of Kathy (Mike) Benolken, Lori (Ray) Lalowski, Lynn (Terry) McCarthy, Jim (Mary) Zamzow, Jan (Gary) Batz and the Late Nancy (Gregg) Meagher. Proud grandfather of Jen (Todd), Michele (Matt), Amanda (Dave), Kate, David (Gina), Amy (Phil), Kevin, Patrick (Nancy), Kristin (Everett), Megan (Eric), Brian (Amy), Kasey, Danny (Jenny), Kelsey, and Corey. Fond great-grandfather of 18. Loving companion of Mary Ellen Olcott.Bill was born in Madison, WI and graduated from the University of Wisconsin with a Masters in Chemical Engineering in 1948 after serving in the Army Chemical Warfare Service in WWII from 1944-1946 in New Guinea, the Philippines and Japan.He married Ruth in 1950 and together they started this incredible family listed above and were happily married for 61 years.He worked for Kraft Foods for 32 years and contributed to the development of several continuous cook processes for dressings and process cheese that are still utilized today. He was awarded the prestigious JL Kraft Jade ring for his many contributions & patents.Bill had many hobbies he was passionate about including Sailing (Lightnings in the summer on “Z-Boat” and Frostbiting in the winter on “Z Other Boat”). He was an avid Bridge and Duplicate player and directed the Glenview Senior Center Duplicate Bridge club for 35 years. Another passion was Jazz music which was always playing in his home and he & Ruth traveled all over the world to catch the best jazz shows.He was a continuous learner who embraced new technology from computers to iPhones, and even Facebook & Instagram. His grandchildren were amazed & proud with how tech savvy he was!After losing Ruth, Bill was lucky to find a new loving companion, Mary Ellen Olcott at Chestnut Square. They met over their mutual interest for Duplicate Bridge. She is one of the main reasons his life was so happy & full these past ~9 years.Visitation Wednesday, August 17, 2022 from 9:15am until time of the Mass at 10 am at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, 1775 Grove St., Glenview. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, C/O Sr. Paulanne’s Needy Family Fund, 1775 Grove St., Glenview, IL 60025.To send flowers to the family or plant a tree in memory of William, please visit our floral store.

HEITMAN, Charles A. "Chip" Charles A. (Chip) Heitman was born July 3, 1929, in Chicago, IL. Parents were Dr. Marjorie M. Heitman and John Andrews of Chicago. Parents later divorced and Chip was re-named for his mother's family. At age one, Chip moved to Spokane where Marjorie established a medical practice and reared her two sons.Chip attended Lewis & Clark High School where he was an outstanding track and cross-country athlete. He graduated from Whitman College in 1951 and spent two years in the U.S. Army, mostly in France and post-war Germany.Chip worked for GMAC in Spokane, the Dept. of Commerce in Washington DC and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in Jacksonville, FL. In later years he lived in Spokane where he enjoyed running in Bloomsday races. He also enjoyed spending time at his cabin at Glengary on Lake Pend Oreille, ID, with members of his extended family.He is survived by his older brother, Dr. Richard A. Heitman of Colorado Springs and Richard's four children: Jeffrey L. Heitman of Petaluma, CA, Dr. Gregory J. Heitman of Mesa, AZ, John R. Heitman of Spokane and Lisa Schmaling of Seattle. Other survivors include numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. He passed away at Riverview Retirement Community on April 20, 2016. The family is planning an inurnment this summer at the family plot in Rathdrum, ID. His favorite salutation was "Cheers!"

Lokken, GeraldGerald Lee Lokken, 75, of Sturgeon Bay, passed away on Sept. 14, 2017. He was born Sept. 3, 1942 in Madison to Glen and Lillian Lokken. On Aug. 13, 1966, he married Susan Morgan. She preceded him in death on Aug. 5, 2015. His given name was Jerry, but he was called by many names: son, brother, husband, dad, uncle, Bud, Crab Cakes, Jer Bear and friend. The name he was most often called in his life was "Coach". Gerald spent countless years of his life unselfishly volunteering his time and knowledge to others. His impressive tenure spanned for most of his life including a director with the Madison Drum and Bugle Corps Jr scouts, as a middle school basketball coach, high school basketball coach, high school softball coach, and Little League coach. He also coached 6 teams to the Badger State games and countless Sturgeon Bay city league teams. Jerry taught discipline, sportsmanship, and most of all a passion for what you do. He passed these ideals on to hundreds of players and gave his unique understanding to the next generation. He will be dearly missed, but his teachings will always survive. Rest now, your lessons have been learned and like you they will never be forgotten. Gerald is survived by his sons: Eric Lokken, and wife Jamie; Jeff Lokken, and friend Stacy Reinhart. Grandchildren: Elaina Lokken, Isabella Lesko and Terryk Lesko. Sisters: Gayle (Hank) Straw, and Glennys Kirkeeng. Along with many other nieces, nephews and cousins.The family would like to thank the friends and extended family who spent so much time visiting and supporting Jerry during his final journey.At Jerry's request there will not be a funeral service. There will be a celebration of life held at Beach Harbor Resort (3662 N. Duluth Ave. Sturgeon Bay WI 54235) October 28th from 11am-3pm.Online condolences may be offered at www.forbesfuneralhome.com
Burial arrangements under the direction of Elmwood Cemetery & Mausoleum.

John E. Willenbrock, a resident of Hayden, Alabama was born in Cranbury, New Jersey on January 25, 1928 and passed away peacefully on February 8, 2019 at the age of 91.John was preceded in death by his parents, C.A. Willenbrock, Sr. and Carrie Elmyra Willenbrock and two brothers, Charles Willenbrock and Mike Willenbrock.John is survived by his loving wife of 68 years, Edie Willenbrock; two sons, Jack Willenbrock and his wife Cheryl, and Scott Willenbrock and his wife Vickie; four daughters, Linda Jones and her husband David, Margie Lewis and her husband Richard, Jo Ann Cary and her husband Gregg, and Cindy Parker and her husband Ken; three sisters, Kathryn Roberts, Meta Hinze, and Myra Tesbir and her husband Bill; thirteen grandchildren; eighteen great grandchildren; many other family members and a host of friends.Celebration of life services will be held at Ridout's Gardendale Chapel on Wednesday, February 13, 2019 with a time of visitation to begin at 2:00pm followed by a memorial service at 4:30pm.The family request in lieu of flowers donations be made to the St. Jude Children's Research Hospital.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -John Willenbrock was born in 1928, Life was hard, but Edie made it great. 1950 was the year they started together, All John's farming depended on the weather.Soon along three children came- Linda, Margie, and Jack were their names.In Connecticut, he started with plows, He got the fields ready and then milked the cows.Farming in the snow was terribly cold, It wasn't long until it got very old.They loaded up the cows; and children too, Moved them all to Virginia, oh what a zoo!Holstein cows were what John would choose, All black and white, he loved the moos.The three years they were there went by fast,But still, Jo Ann came along to add to the cast.In 1958, on to Mississippi they decided to go, A 456 acre farm, where cows and kids could grow.Here they continued to add to the crew, With Cindy and Scott, the family grew. Farming and milking cows were hard on the knees, So they moved to Alabama and traded it all for an 18-wheeler's keys.John still loved the farming; he couldn't get it out of his blood, He continued to drive the tractor and plow in the mud! He planted tomatoes, red on the vine, Just so Edie could pick all the time!91 years of a long wonderful life,68 of those spent with his wife.John and Edie is what most know them byBut if you called them Ma and Pa they would always answer HiDavid, Richard, Gregg, and Ken all became a partAs well as Cheryl and Vickie all filled up their heart13 grandchildren, 18 great-grandchildren- John loved them all, Together, the family always had a ball.

Mary Lou (Manning) Garraway, 82, of Vero Beach, FL passed away on July 4, 2020. Mary Lou was born February 12, 1938 in Reading, PA.  She was a graduate of Reading Hospital School of Nursing in 1958. She served as an OR + OB Nurse as well as acting director of nursing at Monroe General Hospital in Key West, FL. She was an active member of the Lutheran Church, and volunteered with hospice wherever she lived as a Navy wife. Mary Lou was a talented painter in all mediums, stained glass and quilting, she volunteered as Guardian Ad Litem in Citrus County, FL, she loved teaching and sharing her love of art and reading with children, she also loved to play Solitaire. Survivors include Mary Lou's husband David G. Garraway of Vero Beach, FL, One Son, David S. Garraway of Madison, GA. Two Daughters, Patricia A (Garraway) Singewald of Sebastian, FL and Kelly L. (Garraway) Jones of Savannah, GA. 8 Grandchildren and 9 Great-Grandchildren.Memorial Services for Mary Lou will be determined at a later date, In Lou of Flowers, Memorial Contributions may be made to St. Jude's Children's Hospital.

Ja’Tavion D. Alexander “Hershey” was the first baby born in Hugo, OK on January 1, 1993. He was tragically taken from his beloved family on the night of July 4, 2020 at the age of 27.Ja’Tavion lived in Hugo until the age of five. In the summer of 1998 Ja’Tavion’s mother relocated the family to the Oklahoma City Metropolitan area. Ja’Tavion attended school and church while there and developed a host of friendships.Ja’Tavion was a member of Rising Star Baptist Church where he was baptized and accepted Christ at a young, tender age. He graduated from Oklahoma City Centennial High School in 2012. At OKC Centennial he was known for his football talent and it is also where he earned his nickname “Hershey”. He loved his family and children and took pride in being a great father and guidefather. Ja’Tavion also loved playing cards, football, basketball, dominoes, board games, video games, music, old school cars, dressing well, smelling great, laughing hard and helping everyone that he could. Ja’Tavion had the biggest heart and gave to anyone in need. Ja’Tavion loved the country life and enjoyed helping the city of Hugo by delivering meals to feed the elderly. He had the brightest smile and touched so many lives and will truly be missed, but never forgotten.Ja’Tavion was preceded in death by his sister, Jamie Freeman; grandfather, Ezekiel Johnson; 1st great grandparents, Eddie and Virginia Bills, Parthenia Johnson and Rosco Tucker;2nd great grandparents, Joe and Nellie Johnson; 3rd great grandparents, Sandford & Cornelious Guess Draper; 4th great grandparents, John Guess and Dicy Hunter; 5th great grandparents, Martin Guess, Polly Colbert, MaryAnn McCoy and William B. Hunter.Hershey is survived by his parents, Bridgett Bills-Rhodes of Oklahoma City, OK and  Jamey Alexander of Hugo, OK; four sons, Joaquin Breshears, Kingston Alexander, Maverick Ives, and Kashton Alexander;  brothers, Rah’Jay Jeffery of Oklahoma City, OK, Jishon Alexander of Valliant, OK, Javonte Alexander of Valliant, OK and Kyon Freeman of Hugo, OK;  sisters, Bre’Yell Thompson of Oklahoma City, OK and Jameisha Carter of Valliant, OK; grandparents, Van and Sandra Reynolds of Hugo, OK and Wilma Alexander and James Perry of Hugo, OK along with a host of other family, friends and loved ones.

Dr. James Lynn Daniel age 84 of Jonesborough, TN went home to be with Jesus on August 11, 2022. He was lovingly known by his family as Dad, Granddaddy and Uncle Jim.He was born July 9, 1938, the son of Harold Thomas (Fritz) and Iris Blanche (Jones) Daniel in Erwin, TN. He was an ordained Southern Baptist Minister and loved sharing the gospel of Jesus with others. He was a member of Bible Baptist Church, Kingsport, TN. James’ family moved from Erwin to Kingsport at age 7 and later Daytona Beach, FL at age 17. James graduated from Mainland High School (Daytona Beach, FL) in 1957. He was a veteran of the U.S. Army. He worked at Mason & Dixon Trucking in Kingsport, TN for 21 years as a Middle Manager in the Marketing Division. After leaving M&D he attended ETSU where he graduated with a B.S. in Psychology (1984) as well as a Masters in Psychology (1986) and a Doctorate degree in Post-Secondary Educational Administration (1992). He is a retired Senior Psychological Examiner and Mental Health Professional (in FL & TN) as well as Psychology Professor. After retirement, James busied himself by volunteering for Meals on Wheels, answering the phone for Billy Graham reruns, Contact 211 and My Ride TN. He had a very big heart and enjoyed his opportunity to give.Preceded in death by his parents; his brothers, William (Bill) Daniel and Jack Daniel and sisters, Dorothy (Dot) Page, Betty Armstrong, Doris Ann (Dodie) Rutherford, and Sue Hendrickson.He is survived by his son, Dr. John Daniel and Jennifer Yelton of Gray and daughter, Kim and husband Gary Carberry of Jonesborough. Grandson, Cody and wife Lindsay Carberry of Greeneville and great granddaughter Josie Carberry; Grandson, Jonathan and wife Angela Daniel of Johnson City and great granddaughter Harper Daniel; Granddaughter, Megan Daniel of Kingsport; Granddaughter, Chelsea Booher and Husband TJ of Kingsport and great grandson Ty Booher and many nieces and nephews.The family would like to extend a heartfelt thank you to the staff of Caris Hospice in Johnson City and the staff of Holston Rehabilitation and Care Center in Kingsport for their care and compassion as well as Dad’s church family at Bible Baptist church for all their love and prayers.There will be a private family celebration of life.East Tennessee Funeral Home and Cremation is honored to serve the family of Dr. James Lynn Daniel.

Sharon Kay Mehl, 66, of Galesburg, Michigan, died peacefully on Thursday, August 11, 2022, at Rose Arbor Hospice in Kalamazoo with her family in attendance.Sharon was born on January 2, 1956, in Saginaw, Michigan, to John G. Mehl (stepmother, Ollie Mae Thompson Clift) and Betty L. (Christensen) Mehl. Her parents are deceased. She was the fourth of six children: John A. Mehl (deceased); Gary L. Mehl (Pamela Serbantez); Timothy L. Mehl (Patricia Barrett); Linda L. Mehl; and Susan E. Mehl. She is also survived by her nieces Corrie Mehl and Kelly Mehl (Demetrius Bright), and her nephews Aaron (Heather) Mehl and their children Jordan and Reagan, and Andrew (Rebekka) Mehl and their children Jakob and Hanna. Her extended family was large: 17 aunts and uncles between her mother and father’s sides of the family, and all the cousins, too numerous to count.Sharon loved her roles as daughter, sister, aunt and great-aunt. She was an animal lover, particularly her beloved collies. She and sister Linda took great joy in the breed, raising many litters, and training them and their adoptive owners in obedience. Her last companions were Ginny, a sable, and Kenzie, a blue merle; her favorite collie was Jamie, a beautiful tri-color male, who was her devoted companion for many years. She could name every one of the collies they bred and raised, which numbered over 60.Sharon was a 25-year member of the Collie Club of America. She also achieved the equivalent of a B.S. degree with all her training in canine sciences, including genetics, behavior, grooming, obedience and confirmation. Sharon was a 1974 graduate of Lakeview High School in Battle Creek.Sharon loved to read, particularly romances and fantasy, and was an avid collector of books, including rare and first editions.Sharon was always interested in the lives of others, insisting on hearing all the details of someone’s latest travel journey, their gardening successes and failures, and of course, the dog stories. She relished being able to see photos from her friends and family, especially in her later years when travel became difficult.Interment at St. Mary’s Cemetery in Paw Paw will be private. A memorial Celebration of Life will be held Thursday, August 25, at 6:30 p.m. at the home of Gary and Pam Mehl, 11431 4 Mile Road, Battle Creek, MI, with light refreshments afterward. Please bring a lawn chair with to help with seating. Arrangements are being handled by Adams Funeral Home in Paw Paw, Michigan. The family requests no flowers, but donations can be made to Centrica Care Navigators (Formerly Hospice Care of Southwest Michigan) or the Collie Club of America.To send flowersto the family or plant a treein memory of Sharon Kay Mehl, please visit our floral store.

Cynthia Louise Kitchen Dye passed away peacefully in her home in Mountain Green, Utah, on August 11, 2022 due to the effects of glioblastoma brain cancer. She was cared for throughout her illness by her loving husband James, with help from many family members and neighbors who were angels in their service.Cynthia was born on January 1, 1961 in Nampa Idaho. She was the tenth of eleven children born to Arlo Asay Kitchen and Fern Chase. The family moved to Utah when she was one year old. She was raised in Cache Valley in the beautiful town of Providence where she made many cherished friends and memories. She graduated from Sky View High School and Utah State University with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Portrait Design.While working to establish her own business as a portrait photographer in Salt Lake, she met her eternal companion and sweetheart, James Leon Dye. They were married in the Salt Lake Temple on October 26, 1990. Cynthia designed a beautiful home for their family in South Jordan, Utah, where they lived for almost 30 years in the South Jordan Parkway 1st Ward. After five years of marriage, they were blessed to begin their adventure with adoption, eventually adopting six beautiful children.The gospel of Jesus Christ was always an important part of Cynthia’s life. She served as a missionary for The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Kobe Japan where she spent most of her time on the island of Okinawa. As a devoted member of the Church, she served in many callings throughout her life. Most of her church callings were in the Primary organization. She loved being with and teaching children.When Cynthia became a mother, she quit her successful photography business to focus on her children. She welcomed several additional foster children into her home, and also some young expectant mothers. As her children grew, she authored and published books, wrote poetry and songs. She ran 14 marathons and organized an annual five mile run between the Oquirrh Mountain Temple and the Jordan River Temple which raised money for the Church’s Temple Patron Fund.Cynthia always loved the arts and founded a non-profit art organization, the Alliance of Covenant Artists, to promote reverential and devotional art. She developed close friendships with many of the artists she had an opportunity to work with. She created web sites and hosted art exhibits and workshops for this cause.She is survived by her husband, James; her children: Christina (Justin) Evenson, Samuel Dye, Joseph (Madi) Dye, Julia (William) Steed, Jacob Dye, and Lydia Dye; her granddaughters: Hollie, Harvie, Ellie, and Kiara; and her siblings: Margaret (LaRell) Van Dyke, Darlene Hansen, Jean Lind, Shirley Miller, Kenneth (Molly) Kitchen, Thomas (Janice) Kitchen, Barbara (Keith) Anderson, Sara Kitchen, Darwin (Laurie) Kitchen. She was preceded in death by her parents and her sister, Francie (William) Fiedler.Funeral services will be held on Saturday, August 20, 2022 at 11:00 a.m. at Mountain Green Ward, located at 5378 West Old Highway Road, Mountain Green, Utah. A viewing will be held at the same address on Friday, August 19, 6:00 to 8:00 pm, and prior to the service on Saturday, 9:30 to10:30 a.m.Interment will be in the Mountain Green Cemetery located behind the church.The funeral service will be broadcast on the internet at https://zoom.us/j/93667433459 for those not able to attend in person.In lieu of flowers, please donate to The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints Humanitarian Fund in Cynthia's name at https://philanthropies.churchofjesuschrist.org/humanitarian-services or call 1 (800) 525-8074

Donald E. Betts, 78, passed away after a lengthy illness on April 24, 2023. He was born on June 9, 1944, in Waterloo, IA, the son of Clarence and Kathryn (Smith) Betts. Don graduated from St. Thomas High School, class of 1962. He attended one year at Loyola University, Chicago campus. Joining the work force, Don discovered the magic of the computer world at a time when a computer would occupy a space roughly the size of a small gymnasium. Getting in on the ground floor of computerization, Don learned to program these punch card eating beasts eventually creating the program that was utilized by Loyola University Hospital in Maywood, IL. As computers came of age, and to keep ahead of the young programmers entering the field, Don obtained both his bachelor’s and master’s degrees. Always interested in airplanes, Don acquired his private pilots license in 1971, flying small craft out of Hinsdale Airport. Don also had a lifelong interest in trains, especially the Illinois Central. He collected many HO scale replicas of this railroad. Later in life, Don co-founded a K-9 rescue and adoption operation.Survived by his brothers, Barry (Nancy Lindquist) Betts and Pat (Nancy) Betts and his sister, Carole (Mike) Lester and several nieces and nephews. Predeceased by his parents and his sister, Mary.Memorial services will be held at 7:00 P.M. on Tuesday, May 2, 2023, at Fitzgerald Funeral Home and Crematory, Mulford Chapel, 1860 S. Mulford Rd. Rockford, with Reverend William R. Wentink officiating. Burial in Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Waterloo, IA. Memorial visitation will be held from 5:00 P.M. until 7:00 P.M. on Tuesday at the funeral home. Share online condolences at www.fitzgeraldfh.com.To send flowers to the family of Donald, please visit our floral store.

Robert A. Ainey, 73, of New Hope, Pennsylvania, died at his home on Friday, August 12, 2022.Robert was born on July 30,1949 in Northeastern, PA, where he grew up. He received a full Senatorial Scholarship to the University of Pennsylvania where he graduated “magna cum laude” in May 1971.After graduation, Robert moved to Ohio and had several jobs in the early computer world. He received an offer to go to Kuwait for a 2 year assignment during which time he intended to save all his income so he could put a good down payment on a home in the US. After two years, he received an even better job opportunity in Saudi Arabia. He then returned to the US, only to be offered a job with ACI in London. He worked there a couple of years until he moved to Bahrain to open a branch in the Middle East. In Bahrain Robert was the General Manager for ACI for the Middle East for almost 20 years. He was especially proud of his involvement in Rotary and the good work they did in Bahrain for the poor.His last position was as President of the Bahrain Association of Banks. He totally turned around the organization, even having it renamed. He started the magazine “The Bahrain Banker” that had prominent bankers from all over the world offer pieces of knowledge useful to their membership.Upon returning to the US for retirement, he worked in the real estate industry before relocating to Arizona to care for his elderly father for more than a year. After his father’s death in 2021, he stayed to get the estate in order and returned to New Hope.Robert is survived by his spouse, A. Khalifa; three brothers, Jack, Jerry and Michael; his best friend, Thomas E. Hora and many friends both in the US and abroad.Funeral services will be private.Donations in Robert’s memory may be made to Fisherman’s Mark, 60 Wilson Street, Lambertville, NJ 08530.
