The year was 1926. Calvin Coolidge was the President of the United States, and the cost of a first-class postage stamp was all of two cents. The introduction of antifreeze had enabled people to drive their automobiles year-round.  In entertainment, RCA, GE and Westinghouse joined forces to establish NBC, which operated two national radio networks.  A new concept called "Book of The Month Club" was established, allowing avid readers to purchase books at a discount prices through mail order.  The St. Louis Cardinals defeated the New York Yankees to capture the World Series pennant, and a team called the Montreal Maroons were Stanley Cup Champions.  In rural Southwestern Michigan, Fred W. and his wife, Heldina (Summerfeldt) Piedt raised fruits and vegetables on their 80-acre farm near the community of Pearl Grange. Growing up, Fred W. Piedt came from North Dakota. His parents were considered to be rather wealthy, but they had somehow lost their riches in California. Eventually, the family settled in the Benton Harbor area, where soil conditions and climate were conducive to farming. Fred W. attended school only during the winter months, as his help was needed on the family farm in the spring and fall. He aided in the planting and harvesting of the family's wheat crops. Fred W. was able to complete the sixth grade before he was needed on the farm full-time. Although Heldina came to America from Volina, Russia, she was said to be as German as could be. Germans made up a majority of the residents in the Pearl Grange area. Heldina could neither read nor write, but she was a good, kind, Christian woman, a marvelous wife and mother. She loved flowers, especially gladiolas. Every fall, she insisted that her rows and rows of glad bulbs be harvested and carefully stored in the basement until the following spring, when they would once again be planted. Every week, the dear lady provided her church with a lovely, fresh floral centerpiece from her garden.Fred and Heldina were kind, generous and hard-working. Each Saturday, Heldina would butcher, dress and prepare two chickens. After church services on Sunday, they would deliver one of the chickens to Grandpa and Grandma Piedt, before going home to cook the second bird for themselves.July of 1926 was a particularly hot and humid month in much of the country.  Record temperatures of up to 108 degrees were set in Connecticut and New York.  On a steamy July 12th of that year, 38-year old Fred and his wife Heldina gave birth to little Fred.  He was a late-in-life baby for the Piedts, and his birth was eagerly anticipated by 9-year old sister Marion, the former baby of the family.  Along with Marion, Fred joined twins Florence and Lawrence (Larry), who were born in 1913; and Esther, born in 1914.  While Fred was still an infant, his parents decided that he should have a sibling that he could play and grow up with.  Ruth was born 18 months later in 1928.  Thus, the Piedt family was complete.Life in the small town of Pearl Grange was similar to many other farming communities throughout the Midwest region; the type of place where children could play the hours away in the summer sun, where neighbors all knew each other by name, and where faith, family, and hard work were all that were needed to make life complete.  Fred's family was very close-knit.  They worked hard and lived humbly.  The children learned that play involved a vivid imagination and the creek adjacent to their house, instead of fancy toys and the type of material trappings found at the local merchant.  Although they did not have much money, their lives were full of richness. One particular "treasure" that Fred came across was an old bike that he found in a junk yard.  He and his brother promptly set to work to try to render it road-worthy, in spite of a missing pedal.  They managed to rig it up so that it would still work, although it proved to not be as reliable as they had hoped.  One day, as he was riding the new-found bike down a hill, a mechanical failure of some sort occurred caused the front wheel to come off the bike driving the forks into the ground, and Fred went tumbling over the handlebars, landing in a heap near the bike.  Although slightly injured, Fred's childhood temper overcame him, and he arose, picked up the bike, and mustering all of his strength, threw it in the creek.  Later, after his cuts and scratches healed and his anger over the failed two-wheeler had subsided, he returned to the creek to retrieve the bike.Little Fred never knew the concept of being left with a babysitter.  He was always with his mother, or one of his older sisters if his mom was working in the fields.  He became particularly close to Marion, who was most often the sibling that took care of him when needed.  In his early years, he came to think of Marion as his mother.  When it was time for play, however, he often turned to younger sister Ruth for companionship.  He came to depend on Ruth to help him with his extreme bashfulness, even delaying the start of school for a year and a half until Ruth was ready to begin, just to avoid having to go to school alone.When Fred was a young lad of about ten years, a tragedy struck the family on Christmas Day.  The family home had caught on fire, and promptly burned to the ground.  Everyone was able to emerge from the home safely, but all of their material possessions were a total loss.  The only Christmas present that was able to survive was the family's new puppy, a present from their parents.  Thankful for their safety, and reminded that the true meaning of Christmas was not about presents and material belongings, the family gathered themselves together and thanked God for what they did have... each other.  The family went to live with various relatives in the area until their home was able to be rebuilt.Because his shy demeanor had delayed his start of school, Fred was grateful to a caring elementary teacher named Mrs. Burr who helped him catch up two grades in one year.  He made the 1-1/2 mile trek to Pearl Grange Elementary school every day, in all types of weather.  As a young man, school and life on the farm didn't allow Fred much free time. He was able, however, to manage some extracurricular activities during his career at Benton Harbor High School.  Not the best of students, Fred's report cards often reflected D's.  He particularly struggled in History and English, and failing tests in those subjects became a common occurrence.  The one subject where he did excel was German, since it was spoken fluently by his parents at home.  He also enjoyed typing, although he was only one of two boys in a class of 32 girls.  Popular with his female classmates, he reveled in the extra attention he received as being one of a minority.  The girls often flocked around him in order to help him with his homework.  Perhaps it was then that this painfully bashful young man blossomed; he was later described in his high school yearbook as being "a ladies' man".  The new, confident Fred went on to join the Camera Club, the Rifle Club, and the Future Farmers of America.  His athletic talents honed by years of working on the farm and rugged play, he was able to join the track team.  He often bragged about his star achievement: running the 100-yard dash in ten seconds flat.The start of his senior year was delayed until November, because he had to help with that fall's apple harvest.  World War II had taken most of the able-bodied men off to war, often leaving women and children to do their work at home. After his dear mother, Heldina passed away from an enlarged heart in 1941, Fred's obligation to the family was intensified, and he stepped up to the task by helping out on the farm.  In spite of this delay, along with his academic struggles, much to his relief and delight, he accepted his diploma from Benton Harbor High School in 1944.   Tragedy once again struck the family on July 1, 1944, when Fred's father was involved in a head-on collision, breaking every rib, and puncturing his lungs in two places.  Fred briefly attended Michigan State University in 1945, but once again felt the calling of family, and returned home to tend to the family farm and nurse his dad back to health.  The senior Fred's recovery went remarkably well under his son's care.  Once he was assured that his father was on his way to good health, the young man went to the draft board on a fateful day in October 1945 and was put on 1-A.  On October 18, 1945, he received a letter from Franklin D. Roosevelt, welcoming him to the Armed Services.  He was proud to be a World War II Veteran, serving in the Pacific Theater of Operations, ending up in the Tachikawa Army Air Force Base near Tokyo, Japan in 1946.  He served his country until his honorable discharge in January 1947.  Once back in the United States, a chance meeting at his cousin Ruth Prillwitz' wedding in June 1949 caused him to cross paths with a young woman named Dorothy Michael.  The two were both in the wedding party; Fred was an usher, and "Dot", as her friends lovingly called her, was the Maid of Honor.  Although he was smitten with her immediately, Dot barely noticed him.  During the reception, however, she was forced to take notice: Fred repeatedly flung wads of paper at her until she paid attention to him.  Shortly after their first meeting, the pair picked berries together on her parents' farm, which provided them the ability to spend much more time together.  On a fishing trip that August with his sister Marion and her husband, Fred mustered up his strength and anxiously asked Dorothy, "If I were to give you a ring, would you take it?"  Dorothy replied, "Sure".  Achieving the desired response, the resourceful young man was prepared.  He immediately slammed on the brakes, pulled to the side of the road, and opened the trunk to retrieve the engagement ring he had stashed there.  Not wanting to wait much longer to become man and wife, the young couple were joined in marriage on October 1, 1949 at the Clay Street Baptist Church, which was later renamed Napier Parkview Baptist Church.Fred continued to enjoy fishing long after that engagement afternoon in 1949.  The Piedts owned a camper, which they left at the Sandy Pines Campground in Burnips, Michigan.  This became their summer getaway, and they enjoyed meeting with many of their lifelong friends at this lovely spot.  It was a place where many happy family memories were made.  The bass fishing made the spot especially alluring for Fred.  This oasis was often the goal destination in the summer; they would work extra hard on the farm all week, just to be rewarded with the ability to sneak away to Sandy Pines on the weekend.  Never one to completely abandon his work responsibilities, Fred would call back home to the spray consultant to check on weather conditions.  If needed, he sometimes would have to reluctantly return home to spray.  As much as Sandy Pines was their summer getaway, he and Dot found winter solace in Florida.  Fred was especially proud of his coveted "ultimate fishing boat", and spent many a winter day in the Florida sun, casting his line upon the water.  While in Florida, they usually would rent a house for the winter months, and enjoyed inviting Mike, his wife Deb, and the grandchildren down for a visit. Perhaps because of his experience in the Army Air Force, aviation was in Fred's blood.  Although he was never able to fly during his tour in World War II, he always had a passion for it.  In 1960, he took it up as a long-desired hobby in the hopes of being able to crop dust his own farm.  After taking lessons in Benton Harbor, he was devastated to learn that the J-3 Cub in which he had learned to fly had been destroyed in a hangar fire.  He thought that his flying days were over.  Fortunately, he was mistaken.  He went to Dowagiac, where he met Grady O'Diton, a fellow that had a 1946 7-AC Aeronca for sale.  Fred was delighted to find that Grady would sell him the plane for $1,000, and even more so when Grady took over as his new flying instructor.  It was July, 1960, and the start of a new passion that lasted for the rest of Fred's life.  It took him a while to get his student pilot's license because he would spend so much of his time looking instead of learning.Not to be outdone by her newly-adventurous husband, Dorothy obtained her student pilot's license.  A larger plane was now in order, and later in 1960, Fred obtained a five-year-old Cessna 170-B, for which he paid $5,000.  Fueled by the desire to pilot his new aircraft, Fred studied in earnest, and was able to pass the written test and receive his FAA Private Pilot's License in August, 1961. New pilots Fred and Dorothy enjoyed taking many short trips to Grand Rapids, Fort Wayne, and Chicago's Meigs Field.  Their most adventurous flight was a trip to see Dot's parents in St. Petersburg, Florida.  The flight took a total of ten hours.  On the way home, after encountering bad weather, the couple took an unexpected stopover in Atlanta, which ended up lasting for several days.Another interesting experience, about which the two look back and laugh, occurred when Dorothy dropped Fred off at the hangar to take the plane up for a short flight.  After getting up in the air, Fred realized that he had the keys to the house in his pocket so Dorothy wouldn't be able to get in!  With no way of communicating with her, Fred proceeded to locate his wife on the road and followed her home.  After arriving home, Dorothy discovered their mistake and noticed Fred circling the house in the plane.  Fred used some of his considerable ingenuity and, after several passes, was able to get the plane low enough – without stalling the plane – to pass over their garage, drop the keys onto its metal roof, and watch as the keys slid off the roof to his stranded wife.Theirs was a joyful marriage, and Fred and Dorothy relished being with each other and serving the Lord together as husband and wife.  After 14-1/2 years, they were blessed with a son that they named Michael David, brought into this world on April 4, 1964.  He was the joy of their lives, and they loved being parents, teaching young Michael the value of hard work, vigorous play, and reverent worship.  He was showered with an abundance of love.  While young Michael had flown in five different planes before even reaching his first birthday, Dorothy felt it more important to spend time with her new son with feet planted firmly on the ground.  Realizing that flight without his wife and son in the plane would be less enjoyable, Fred resigned himself to the fact that his flying days may be over.  He sold the Cessna 170-B, resorting to renting a plane for future flights.  It seemed to be a minor sacrifice when he considered the blessings that Michael had brought into their lives.In addition to being an accomplished pilot, Fred was a great bookkeeper and a clever inventor.  He was very meticulous about his accounting practices, working sometimes for hours to assure that every penny was accounted for.  He patiently taught Deb, his beloved daughter-in-law, to take over the books.  He had a knack for miraculously fixing machinery that seemed beyond repair, or conjuring up ingenious ways to operate the farm more efficiently.  One of his crowning achievements was the tractor cab that he fashioned out of Plexiglass.Mike was the envy of all of his classmates because of one of his father's crafty inventions.  He fashioned a "Batman Pole" that allowed young Mike and his friends to slide from his bedroom closet, clear down to the basement toy room.  His friends thought he just might have the coolest dad on the planet earth!Still involved in aviation, Fred served on the aviation committee of the Grand Rapids School of the Bible and Music (GRSBM).  The school wanted to update their fleet of aircraft, so Fred acquired a 1946 Taylor Craft from them for $1,500, and his dream of aircraft ownership was revived.  Fred would use the plane in the summer months to teach Michael and would return the plane back to the school during the school year to teach the new students how to fly.  As the plane didn't have a starter, Fred had Michael prop the plane to start it.  Because this particular aircraft could land in short distance, he built his own runways and hangar.  He would park the plane in the hangar, and in an effort to also be practical, would store his farm implements and tools under its wings.In February 1979, he donated the aircraft back to the school and bought a Cessna 140.  In order to be able to fly it in the winter as well, he installed some skis on the plane.  Young Mike was now 15 years old, and was sometimes called upon to use his youthful brawn to push the plane when it would get stuck in the deep snow.  Once it was underway, he would run alongside the plane and jump in just prior to takeoff, face flushed and heart pounding.  Their adventures with this aircraft culminated in an incident where the plane had run out of gas during takeoff, causing Fred and Mike to crash land in the rye field on the Carl farm.  The father and son had evidence of their Father's eternal protective hand on that day.In June, 1979, he bought an F-19 Taylor Craft after selling the Cessna 140.  When Mike turned 16 the following year, while most of his classmates were receiving their driver's licenses, Mike received his student pilot's license first, obtaining this accomplishment on April 4, 1980.  Mike took advantage of this new-found freedom and dive-bombed his best friend's home during his graduation open house, startling all of his guests!When Mike and Deb's children were small, Poppy Fred bolted child-sized seats in the tractor cabs so they would be able to accompany him when he was spraying or plowing.  As often the case with children and moving vehicles, however, the movement of the tractor would cause the children to drift off, and their little heads would bang against the window.  This became the favorite way to lull restless children off to sleep, although this practice could not be employed regularly, lest the children's little heads become permanently bruised.  He loved his grandchildren, and enjoyed teaching little Ryan how to become a future mechanic.True to being a stickler with the finances, Fred was also determined to teach the youngsters fiscal responsibility.  He was a good role model, and practiced what he preached.  He taught the value of hard work and to be a cheerful giver, admonishing Mike and the grandchildren to give generously, since "you can't outgive the Lord".  He had also learned that it is best to live beneath your means, save for a rainy day, and not to put all of your eggs in one basket; sage wisdom from a humble man.  One of Mike's favorites that he heard often from his father was:  "A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush".A tribute to Fred's life cannot be complete without mention of his greatest joy in life: accepting the Lord Jesus as his own personal Savior.  He was honored that he was given a wife that also loved and served the Lord.  He had the distinct pleasure of traveling to Israel in 1974 and 1976.  He found great peace and joy in the fact that his children and grandchildren also grew to walk with The Lord.  Some of his favorite verses were II Corinthians 8:9, Psalm 16:16, II Timothy 1:12, Ephesians Chapter 1, and John 20:29.  While Fred was returning from Tokyo at the end of World War II on their vessel "The Marshall Victory", the ship encountered storms and 70-foot swells that lasted more than a week.  The crew worked feverishly to weld the ship day and night to keep it afloat.  When they thought the boat would sink, Fred sought comfort in recalling scripture and singing some of his favorite hymns, such as "A Wonderful Savior in Jesus My Lord", "A Shelter in the Time of Storm", and "He is So Precious to Me".  Fortunately, Fred had dozens more favorite hymns that helped him to know that the Lord was with him.His dear wife of 57 years remembers that Fred was always faithful to his word.  He counted his daughter-in-law, Deb, as "his child" along with her husband Mike, and he loved them dearly.  He would brag about his "kids" to everyone and anyone who would listen.  He was ever interested in Mike's activities and was eager to offer his advice and mechanical expertise on the farm.  He loved to recall the "good old days" when he spent time with Mike, passing along stories that will be repeated for generations to come.  He is remembered by all as a loving, helpful man that thought of others first and himself last.  He enjoyed fixing things and using his inventions to improve the quality of life.  He was a loving example not only in his life, but in his passing as well.  When he was first diagnosed with cancer, he was the one that consoled his family, taking comfort in knowing that he was one day closer to being forever united with his Lord and Savior.  He quoted II Timothy 1:12 to them, saying: "I know whom I have believed and am persuaded that He is able to keep that which I have committed unto Him against that day". His family now takes comfort in knowing that one day, they, too, will be united with Dad in the Master's presence.  He did not fear death, for he knew that to be absent from the body was to be present with the Lord, and he was at peace, although parting with his loved ones here on earth was a sweet sorrow.Fred led an active and full life, serving not only the Lord, but his community as well.  He served on several boards, including Berrien Center Bible Church, Grace Christian School, American Messianic Fellowship in Chicago.  He also served on the Aviation committee of Grand Rapids School of the Bible and Music, the Berrien County Youth for Christ, the Eau Claire Fruit Exchange, and the Michigan Flying Farmers.Fred J. Piedt left this earth to be with his Father on March 13, 2007, at the age of 80, after a courageous battle with esophageal cancer.  Services celebrating his life will be held on Friday, March 16, 2007 at 11:00 am, at the Berrien Center Bible Church.  Burial will follow at Caldwell Cemetery, Eau Claire, which adjoins the Piedt Farms apple orchard. Those wishing to sign the guest book or share an encouraging thought with the family may do so at www.legacyfuneral.com.  Friends are invited to visit with the family from 5-8 pm on Thursday, March 15, 2007 at the Legacy Funeral Services – Matthew R. Purchase Chapel, Berrien Springs.  Fred leaves behind his loving wife, Dorothy (Michael) Piedt, his precious son, Michael (Deborah) Piedt, and three grandchildren, Ryan, Mandy and Gregory Piedt of Eau Claire, Michigan.  They will miss their Poppy Fred very much.  He is also survived by sister Ruth (Fred) Holden of Baroda, and Marion Taylor of Saginaw, Michigan.  He was preceded in death by his parents; brother Larry F. Piedt, and sisters Florence Johansen and Esther Hards.  Memorial contributions may be made to Berrien Center Bible Church or to Hospice at Home from Kalamazoo.  What was most important to Fred was that those he came in contact with came to know the Lord Jesus Christ as their Lord and Savior.  He will be greatly missed by his friends and family until they meet again.
Arrangements under the direction of Greenwood  Funeral Home, Renton, WA.

ROBERT  CUNNINGHAM Robert James Cunningham age 88 of Pickerington formerly of Lancaster passed away Monday, September 13, 2010 at his daughters residence.  He was born Jan. 22, 1922 in Newark, Ohio to W.D. and E. Pearl Cunningham.Survived by a daughter Barbara S. Withem and two grandchildren:  Jennifer and Shawn Withem.  He was a 1939 Graduate of Newark High School and a 1943 graduate of Miami University.  U.S. Army Veteran of W.W.II 1943-1946 serving 22 months in Europe, and was awarded 3 campaign stars and the Purple Heart for a wound suffered in the Battle of the Bulge on Dec. 24, 1944.He worked at Owens Corning Fiberglass after discharge until Oct. 15, 1957.  Worked at Anchor Hocking in Lancaster from Oct. 1957 until Nov. 1984.  His final position was Director of Materials Research and Development.Bob was an avid photographer, golfer and traveler.  He visited all 50 states and several foreign countries and enjoyed sharing his slides to various groups.  He was a member of the First United Methodist Church , Lancaster, Olivedale Senior Citizens,  Mt. Pleasant Kiwanis, American Legion Post 11, past President of Friends of the Park, and 60 year member of Acme Lodge #554 F. & A.M., Newark. He is preceded in death by his wife Dorothy Jean (Young) Cunningham (2002), a sister Agetha Farmer and a brother C. W. Cunningham. Funeral services will be held 10:30 A.M. Friday at the Halteman-Fett & Dyer Funeral Home, Lancaster with Rev. Robert McDowell officiating,   Burial will be at Maple Grove Cemetery where the Lancaster Veterans Burial Detail with conduct military graveside rites.  Friends may call 6-8 P.M. Thursday at the funeral home.

TAYLOR, Glen EarlGlen Earl Taylor passed away peacefully on Monday, August 10th, 2015. He was born July 1st, 1931 in Amarillo, Texas, to Earl Sloan Taylor and Loma Gladys Wheat. He grew up in Sweetwater, Texas. After graduating from Sweetwater High School in 1948, he attended the University of Texas. While there, he joined the Marine Reserves and was called to active duty during the Korean War as part of the Special Services, specializing in underwater demolition. During this time, he met and married his wife of nearly 64 years, Barbara Wilks. After leaving the Marines, he returned to Austin, Texas where he completed degrees in Geophysics and Law at the University of Texas, later teaching Law at the University of Colorado-Boulder. He then moved to Washington, DC, serving in the Justice Department as Head of the Lands and Minerals Division during the Johnson administration. He then went to work for British Petroleum and was instrumental in opening up the Alaskan Pipeline. He later moved from New York to the San Francisco area. While there, he worked for Natomas, staying with the company until moving to Houston in order to work with Tenneco. Moving to Austin in 1989, he became Chief Legal Counsel of Lower Colorado River Authority, helping to reorganize the company. He worked there until retiring in 1997. He and Barbara were able to travel to many places, including Russia, Switzerland, France, Morocco, The Netherlands, and more. He is survived by his wife, Barbara, his daughters Jessica Taylor, Jennifer Bridges, and Hillary Branda, as well as his sisters Linda Duncan and Patty Walker. Glen also had four grandchildren: Katie, Vicky and Emily Bridges, and Harrison Taylor-Zimmerman and many nieces and nephews. His intelligence and dry sense of humor will be deeply missed by family and friends. Funeral services are pending with The Neptune Society In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Southern Poverty Law Center, Safe Place Austin, The Alzheimer's Society and Hospice Austin or a charity of your choice. Alzheimer's Association www.Alz.orgSafeplace www.Saveplace.orgSouthern Poverty Law www.splcenter.orgHospice Austin www.hospiceaustin.org

John Clarence Medema (84) of Holland, Michigan returned to his heavenly home on January 3, 2017.  Beloved husband of 62 years, he is survived by his only sibling, Gertrude Kloese, his loving wife, Dolores A. Medema (Natelborg) and their five children: Diane (George) Huisman; Janet (Ed) Kotynski; Paul (Betty) Medema; Daniel Medema and Connie Huizenga. John was blessed to be Grandpa to Wendi (John) Kitsteiner  and Keith (Adrienne) Huisman; Cara (Brian) Hurley  and Eddie (Hannah) Kotynski; Hope (Tom) Acker; Dolores Medema; Casey Huizenga and Colin Huizenga.  He was preceded in death by granddaughter, Faye Medema.  John was a fond Uncle, and happy and proud great-grandpa, as well.He lived his life devoted to his family and his faith in Jesus Christ. As his earthly body was failing him and he prepared to say good bye, he expressed both his wish to remain to experience the growing up of his grandchildren and great-grandchildren, (including the expected birth of another great-grandchild near his birthday), and his longing to meet Jesus and feel his touch.John was born to the late Cornelius Medema (Chicago, Illinois) and Margaret Plantenga (Lafayette, Indiana) on March 26, 1932. After graduating from high school, he served in the U.S. Army from 1952-1954 as a Corporal in the Korean Conflict.  He was honorably discharged on April 30, 1954, and married Dolores just a few days later on May 7, 1954.John was employed at Jewel Foods from 1950-1970, twelve of those years as store manager. He then learned the tile business in order to switch careers to something that would allow him more time with his wife and family.John was known for being a man who loved life, people, and Oreo cookies! He deeply enjoyed his family, friends and his daily relationship with God. Spending time with those he loved, traveling with friends and family (especially his wife), and sports were some of his favorite pastimes. He was a larger than life presence, and will be sorely missed by those who loved him.John said of his accomplishments, that he felt happy he could help many people in many different ways and that his life showed that God does care about us and will help us in times of trouble. The final message he wrote to family and friends was this:"Make God an important part of your life. Enjoy Life. Have Fun. Don't be afraid to laugh at yourself. Remember as you serve others, you serve God. Love people – not everyone is loveable, but everyone needs love."He loved his church and was always involved, whether it was teaching Sunday School, working with the youth, or serving as a deacon or elder. Even in his 80's John served as an usher, was involved in the prayer partner ministry, the food pantry, and benevolent and mission committees. It was important to John that his children knew that his involvement with church and serving others did not guarantee him a place in a heaven. These activities helped him express his gratitude for Christ's sacrifice on the cross for his salvation. And he wanted all of his children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren to share his faith in Christ's death, burial and resurrection and to know Him in a personal relationship.A military burial (family only) will take place on May 5, 2017 at Fort Custer National Cemetery in Battlecreek, MI, 2:30 pm. (Please meet there 15 minutes early at the gate).  On Saturday, May 6, 2017 a Memorial service and celebration of his life will be held  at Thorn Creek Reformed Church in South Holland, Illinois.  The service begins at 11 am, followed by a luncheon in the fellowship hall.  A small service was be held with John and Dolores' church family and local friends on Saturday January 21 at 2:30 pm at Bethany Christian Reformed Church in Holland MI. It is the family's hope that many who loved him will be able to come together at that time in celebration of John's life and the blessing he was to us all.The family asks tha tIn lieu of flowers, please send Cards &/or donations towards his Rest Haven bill and memorial: to Dolores Medema, The Village Appledorn, #224, Holland MI

Obituary of Shirley Benedict | Christopher Mitchell Funeral Home - Albion Proudly serving all of Orleans county Friday 15 February 11:00 am - 11:30 am Friday, February 15, 2019 Christopher Mitchell Funeral Home - Albion 21 West Avenue Albion, New York, United States (585) 589-4471 Friday 15 February 11:00 am - 11:30 am Friday, February 15, 2019 Christopher Mitchell Funeral Home - Albion 21 West Avenue Albion, New York, United States (585) 589-4471 Obituary of Shirley Benedict Kendall: Shirley M. Benedict, 70, passed away February 10, 2019 at Elderwood at Lakeside in Brockport. She was born November 29, 1948 in Albion, a daughter of the late John D. Jett Sr. and Glenna M. (Baker) Jett. Shirley was an avid bird watcher and enjoyed feeding them. She loved her cat and could make awesome sausage gravy. Shirley will be remembered as a loving mother, grandmother, sister and a devoted wife. She was predeceased by her brothers, Harold Jett Sr. and Richard "Rick" Jett. She is survived by her husband of 42 years, Richard; sons, Orin (Rachel Renko) Benedict and Richard (Sarah Bohn) Benedict; grandsons, Brenden, Caleb and Patrick; great-granddaughter, Coraline; siblings, Jim (Ardith) Jett, John (Pat) Jett, Rose Hall, Sue (Steve) Fearing, Ed (Jacquie) Jett; sister-in-law, Virginia Jett; several nieces, nephews, cousins. Shirley's Celebration of Life will be held at the Christopher Mitchell Funeral Homes, Inc. 21 W. Avenue, Albion, Friday February 15, at 11:00am. Memorials may be made to the American Cancer Society. Through meaningful memorialization - that is, taking time to reflect on the unique life of a loved one and remember the difference they made - families and friends take an important step in the journey toward healing after death. The death of a family member is a very difficult time in anyone's life. These articles will help you understand the grief you are feeling when someone in your family has died, and how you can honor the life of your departed family member.

Nuestra querida hija, madre, hermana, abuela, bisabuela y amiga. Alma Delia Garcia Lopez de 60 años de edad, fue llamada al cielo, el domingo 10 de febrero del 2018, en la cuidad de Phoenix, Arizona. Alma nació el 10 de agosto de 1958, en San Luis Rio Colorado, Sonora, México de sus padres Benito Garcia y Dominga Coronel Lopez. Alma era una persona muy social, amigable, amorosa, servicial, alegre y noble, le gustaba pasar tiempo con sus hijos y nietos también y cocinar para su familia.  El espíritu de Alma seguirá brillando, pues ella deja como sobrevivientes a sus hijos e hija; Edgar Alan Vásquez, Carlo Fabián Vásquez y Daniela Alexandra Garcia, nietos; Vanessa, Jazmine, Adam, Damian, Teresita, Abel, Olivia, Aylin, Janyn, Abner y Zoe, bisnietos; Alina Sophia, hermanas e hermano; Maria Elena, Marilú y Christian y numerosos familiares e amistades. Alma se reunirá en el cielo con su padre; Benito Garcia. Se fue al cielo con su hija Gema Garcia. "Te extrañamos, Siempre vas a estar en nuestros Corazones".

Gertrude FeinauerHighland Heights - Gertrude (Trudy) Edna Feinauer, of Highland Heights, KY passed away on Sunday, February 10, 2019 at home surrounded by her loving family at the age of 90. She was born in Newport, KY on March 1, 1928, the daughter of Edward Charles and Marie Kathleen (Toal) Cottman. Trudy was a member of St Francis de Sales Catholic Church in Newport, KY until its closing, and later attended St Joseph Church in Cold Spring, KY. Trudy graduated from LaSalette Academy and worked at ULH&P. She raised ten children, volunteered in the cafeteria at St Francis and St Joseph, was a member of the Altar Society and Mother's Club and a volunteer at St Vincent de Paul. Trudy enjoyed playing cards and socializing with friends. Her greatest joy was spending time with her family. Trudy was preceded in death by her husband of 71 years Frank, her parents Edward and Marie, sisters Marg Feinauer and Ree Cottman as well as her grandsons Jeff Kaiser and Dan Feinauer. She is survived by ten children Mike (Debbie), Dick (Violet), Tom (Cathy), Kathy (Gary) McArter, Pat Sears, Terry, Ed (Renee), Linda (Rick) Sester, Ken (Regina) and Elaine (Doug) Deaton; 52 grandchildren; 46 great-grandchildren; and sister Bert Heringer; as well as many other nieces, nephews, relatives and friends that mourn Trudy's loss and cherish the memories they made with her. A Memorial Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday, February 15 at 6:00 pm at St Philip Catholic Church, 1404 Mary Ingles Hwy Melbourne, KY with Rev. Bob Rottgers officiating. Visitation will be at the church for family and friends from 4:30 pm until time of mass. Celebration of Life Reception following mass will be held at the Parish Center. Memorial donations are suggested to St. Vincent de Paul Society, 2655 Crescent Springs Pike Crescent Springs, KY 41017, St. Philip Church Melbourne, KY, American Heart Association 5211 Madison Rd Cincinnati, OH 45227 or Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, 3 International Drive Suite 200, Rye Brook, NY 10573. Special expressions of condolences and memories can be given at www.dmefuneral.com. Dobbling, Muehlenkamp-Erschell Funeral Home is caring for the family.

Dale David Corbin, 78, of Fergus Falls died Friday, March 19, 2021 at LB Broen Home in Fergus Falls. He was born on November 27, 1942, the son of Clifford and Helen (Casavan) Corbin and grew up in Crookston. He attended Crookston Public School. On June 14, 1968, he married Vivian A. Herhusky in Minneapolis. Over the years, he worked as a truck driver, welder, and worked at flea markets. His hobbies and interests included hunting, spending time with family, fishing, watching wrestling and sporting shows.  When his sons were young, he exemplified the meaning of hard work and making an honest dollar, he led by example. He enjoyed and was very passionate about the music of Elvis Presley, Fats Domino, Little Richard, and Patsy Cline. Preceded in death by his father Clifford Leonard Corbin; and wife Vivian Corbin. Lew was a graduate of the University of Florida, and was engaged in the sale of electrical supplies in Jacksonville for 44 years, first in the Meisel family business, Hall Mark Electric Supply, and then his own company, Lew Electrical Supply. Many electrical contractors in Jacksonville obtained their first credit for their young businesses from Lew. Lew was heavily involved in the Jacksonville Jewish community, being a past president of Jewish Family and Community Services, a vice president of the Jacksonville Jewish Center, and his passion, River Garden Hebrew Home, where he served as president of the home and of the Coves, the independent living facility on the campus. No significant event happened in River Garden for almost 50 years without Lew's intimate involvement. After all the years Lew served River Garden, River Garden served Lew beautifully in his last years. Lew was an extremely devoted family man, and is survived by his wife of almost 37 years, Evelyn, 4 children, Steven, Rachel, Beth (Ed) Glad and Bill (Lynn Collins) as well as a stepson, Charlie (Lisa) Hazouri. He had 6 grandchildren, Deborah, Michael, Jennifer, Kirsten, Sydney and Olivia, as well as a step granddaughter, Christina Hazouri. He was a warm, kind, totally generous man who was dearly loved by his family. Lew's funeral will be held on Monday, March 22, 2021 at the New Center Cemetery, 43rd and Liberty Street at 11 am. Rabbi Jonathan Lubliner will officiate. Post funeral visitation will unfortunately be severely restricted by covid considerations. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to either the Jacksonville Jewish Center or River Garden.

Bruce L. Tidwell passed away on November 30, 2021 at the age of 59. Bruce was born to Ernest and Lynda Tidwell in Chicago, Illinois. He was a devoted father who raised his two sons, Bradley and Ryan, and he delighted in his role as “Poppa T” to his grandchildren. He was a graduate of Trinity College in Sioux Falls, South Dakota with a Bachelor of Science in Human Resources. He also was a Certified Human Resources Generalist through the DePaul University Advanced Human Resources Generalist Program and a Certified Senior Professional in Human Resources by the Human Resources Certification Institute. Bruce was employed by Will County, Illinois since January 2002 and served as the Human Resources Director at the time of his death.Bruce loved animals. His first job, while still in high school, was working at a pet shop in Evergreen Park, Illinois; and over the years, he owned several dogs and cats. He is survived by his three constant companions: Delilah, his 11-year-old Maltese/Chihuahua; Talullah, his 9-year-old Chihuahua; and Beulah, his 5-year-old Chihuahua. In addition to his love for animals, Bruce had many other loves. He was a music lover, never missing an opportunity to attend a performance by his favorite artists, especially Dave Matthews Band. He loved to travel -- some of his favorite places were Israel, Rome, Paris, Mexico, the Caribbean, Hawaii and Disney theme parks. He loved to garden. He had the most beautiful flower gardens in his yard every summer, and meticulously tended to them. He loved to cook. He found it to be relaxing and therapeutic. He was constantly trying out new recipes and nailed them every time! He loved his extended family, friends and co-workers. He never missed the many holiday get-togethers, always bringing some new dish he had whipped up for us to try. Finally, he loved a good laugh. He was known for his sharp, quick wit and laughter among his family and friends.Bruce is survived by his two sons, Bradley and Ryan (Bobbi Zabinski), whom he shared with former spouse, Marie Barmes; his father, Ernest; his mother, Lynda; his granddaughter, Raelynn; his grandson, Lincoln; his grandson due in May 2022; his sister, Nancie (Kenneth) Arvin; his niece, Kathryn (Evan) Athanasiou; his nephew, Jonathan (Kaitlin) Arvin; and many aunts, uncles, and cousins.Visitation will be held from 9:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m., followed by a memorial service, on Saturday, December 11, 2021, at Joliet First Assembly, 1741 Essington Road, Joliet, IL.In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Bruce’s church, The Journey Church, 1303 S. Schoolhouse Road, New Lenox, IL 60451 in memory of Bruce.

ObituaryViola Kieffer, age 73, of New Philadelphia, Ohio, and a former rural Sherrodsville resident, died Wednesday morning, April 26, 2023 in the Community Hospice Truman House at New Philadelphia.She was born May 10, 1949 in Bowerston, Ohio and was the daughter of the late Harry Wayne and Emma Grace (Dellinger) Abel. Her husband, Ralph Edward Kieffer, whom she married May 9, 1997, passed away on February 17, 2018. In addition to her parents and husband, she was preceded in death by two brothers, Robert and Michael Abel, and a sister, Yvonne Anno.Although she was primarily a homemaker, she was employed as a cook at the Sunnyslope Nursing Home in Bowerston for about 10 years. Viola loved to spend time engaging in yard maintenance and tending to her flower gardens around her home on the family farm. She was fond of participating in BINGO games with her sister Penny. Her true joy, however, came from the days that she spent in the company of her family. A loving mother, grandmother, and sister, she will be missed by her family and friends.She is survived by three sons, Rick (Sherry) Byrd of Etowah, Tennessee, Tim (Diane) Byrd of Dover, OH, and Tom (Ashley) Byrd Jr. of Gnadenhutten, OH, a daughter, Mrs. Tammy (Chad) Hodkinson of Tuscarawas OH, a daughter-in-law, Amanda Byrd of Strasburg, OH, a brother, George Abel and a sister, Penny Fluharty, both of Cadiz, OH, and 11 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.At Viola's request, no formal funeral services are planned. The Baxter-Gardner Funeral Home in Sherrodsville is handling arrangements. In response to the compassionate care she received by the Truman House Staff, contributions in Viola's memory may be made to Community Hospice, 716 Commercial Avenue S.W., New Philadelphia, Ohio 44663. To leave an online condolence message please visit the funeral home website.Baxter-Gardner(740) 269-9225www.baxtergardner.comTo send flowersto the family or plant a treein memory of Viola Kieffer, please visit our floral store.

His family, his church, the law, and good food shared among friends, formed the center of Wayne Rice’s world. He died on April 26th, 2023, from complications related to bladder cancer.Wayne Rice was born on March 6th, 1951, to Michel and Ruth Rice, two Army service members who met and married while stationed in the Philippines during World War II.He developed a love of English history at the College of Wooster, graduating in 1973. Wayne finished his degree requirements early and started work as a bank teller at the former First National Bank in Akron. Afterwards, he attended law school at the University of Akron, graduating and gaining admittance to the Bar in 1976.He met his wife, Janet, at the Church of Our Saviour, Akron, and the two married in 1978.He began his legal career as a law firm associate but returned to banking as regional counsel for TransOhio Savings Bank and then General Counsel for Falls Savings Bank. After Fifth Third Bank acquired Falls Savings, Wayne and a group of partners founded Cuyahoga Falls Savings Bank. Wayne then went into private practice until securing a full-time position as Bar Counsel for the Akron Bar Association.Wayne’s life taught us the following:In all areas, serve with faithfulness and strive for dignity and justice—at the Akron Bar Association, Wayne’s work focused on upholding the Code of Professional Conduct for attorneys. In addition, he organized and conducted Character and Fitness interviews for applicants to the Ohio Bar. He led the Church of Our Saviour and St. Paul’s Episcopal through interim minister periods, served as Senior Warden at both churches, led stewardship efforts, served as a chalice bearer, and served on the OPEN M Board as President. He also served in leadership roles on the boards of Sumner on Merriman, Sumner on Ridgewood, and the Sumner Endowment.Take your job seriously but make time for your family—The happiest family vacations were trips to England, the Great Smoky Mountains in Tennessee along with Bryce and Zion National Parks in Utah. He never missed a soccer game, band concert, or violin recital. He loved weddings and was grateful to see three beautiful ones this past year.Stay close to the ones you love—Wayne and Jan were married for 45 years, raising a son and daughter, Eddie and Laura, along with four dogs, while tolerating a menagerie of animals: hamsters, hermit crabs, lizards, and snakes. Together, they enjoyed outings at Blossom to hear the Cleveland Orchestra, sharing wine and snacks from West Point Market; Wayne loved to grill and would often host dinners on the patio with friends.Cut with the sharpest knife and serve the beef medium-rare—Thanksgiving, Christmas, and Easter, were Wayne’s favorite holidays. He would plan out the menus months in advance. Please raise a glass to Wayne Rice—his favorite drink at the end of a long day was a gin and tonic with a twist of a lemon, not a lime.Wayne is survived by his wife Janet and two children, Eddie and Laura, and by his brothers, the Reverend Dr. David Rice, John Rice (Bonnie), his sister Janet Miller (Tom, deceased); preceded in death by his sister Elaine Kay. Survived by his nieces Melanie and Chris Miller (Katelyn), Sarah Lahoski (John), and preceded in death by his niece Katherine Marie.The family would like to thank Dr. Jayram Krishnan, the nurses on 5100 at Akron General, and Cleveland Clinic Home Healthcare, and Wound Ostomy nurses. Their care and kindness provided much comfort to Wayne throughout his illness.A memorial service will be held at St. Paul’s Episcopal Church, 1361 W. Market St., Akron, OH 44313, on May 20th at 11:30, with calling hours at 10:30 at the church.In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Akron Bar Foundation Scholarship Fund IMO Wayne M. Rice (www.akronbar.org), OPEN M (www.openm.org), the St. Paul’s Endowment Fund (www.stpaulsakron.org), or Justin T. Rogers Hospice Center (my.clevelandclinic.org).From the Book of Common Prayer, 1928, “For Those We Love. ALMIGHTY God, we entrust all who are dear to us to thy never-failing care and love, for this life and the life to come; knowing that thou art doing for them better things than we can desire or pray for; through Jesus Christ our Lord. Amen.”Services in care of The Billow Funeral Homes & Crematory, Fairlawn Chapel, 85 N. Miller Road Akron, OH 44333.To send flowersto the family, please visit our floral store.

Anne-Louise Strickland, 88, of Stroudsburg PA, passed away peacefully at the Monroe County Hospice House on April 26, 2023 with her family at her side. Born on March 4, 1935 in Atlantic City, NJ she was the daughter of the late Edmund A Strickland, Sr. and Anne-Louise (Baroux) Strickland, founders of the honeymoon resort Strickland’s Mountain Inn in Mount Pocono from 1945 to 1983. She was Vice-President of the resort where she managed the dining room and gift shop.Surviving are her twin daughters Deborah and Melinda Rosen, step brother Howard Hess, daughter-in-law Amy Rosen, grandchildren Adam, Stephanie and Jessica Rosen, and great grandchildren Dylan and Aleni Slizofski. Anne is predeceased by her son Jeffery Rosen, her brother Edmund Strickland, Jr. and husband Wallace Pelton who was her high school sweetheart. They enjoyed spending their time together traveling to the many US national parks and Florida.Anne attended Marywood Seminary, where as a young child she excelled at playing the violin. She went on to Wyoming Seminary High School and received high honors of cum laude. In 1960 she graduated from Rider College in NJ with a BS degree in Business Management.Anne was a member of Mt. Pocono Methodist Church, AAUW, Barrett Elementary School PTA, Girl Scouts Board of Directors and Planned Parenthood; she also volunteered at Ramsey Elementary School. She was an avid bridge player and enjoyed scrabble, crossword puzzles and backgammon.A celebration of life will be held on Tuesday, May 2, 2023 with visitation from 12:00pm - 1:00pm and service at 1pm, at the William H Clark Funeral Home, 1003 Main Street, Stroudsburg. Burial will follow in the Strickland family plot at Laurelwood Cemetery.Anne’s final days at the hospice house was a blessing for the care and compassion she received during her journey home. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her honor to the Hospice House, payable to: LVHN Pocono Foundation, 206 East Brown Street, East Stroudsburg, PA 18360, include Hospice House on Memo line.Anne will be missed but not forgotten by family and friends.

Our beautiful beloved mother, grandmother, great- grandmother, aunt and sister Eufemia V. Reyes of Monahans Texas earned her angel wings surrounded by her loved ones at home on April 26th 2023 under the care of Star Hospice. Eufemia was born on March 20th, 1936. She married Placido M. Reyes on August 12th, 1950, this beautiful couple will be celebrating 73 years of marriage.Eufemia was an active member of the St. John’s Catholic Church, she volunteered with the CCD Youth classes, and helped with preparations of food for church functions. She was a member of the Sacred Heart, and a volunteer with the Special Olympics and other local organizations. Eufemia was an active donor to St. Jude’s, Special Olympics and Wounded Warriors. Eufemia has two son’s George and Martin Reyes who served in the US Navy during Operation Desert Strom, known as the Persian Gulf War, and a grandson Billy Barnett who served in the US Army during Operation Enduring Freedom in Afghanistan. Jamie and Jordan Martinez are proudly serving with the US Air Force, and Ruben Martinez 3rd is serving with the US Navy. It was during these times Eufemia would organize and volunteer in Homecoming events for our military.Eufemia had a love like many grandmothers for all of her grandchildren, great grandchildren and great-great grandchildren. She loved playing bingo, dominoes, which was her favorite, and going to the casinos. She was very competitive when it came to playing games with her grandchildren. Eufemia had a passion for gardening especially roses and painting. She would light up any room with her presence. Eufemia was a loving woman with a big heart, and a sense of humor that was undeniable. She holds a special place with each one of her grandchildren and great grandchildren.Eufemia is proceeded in death by her mother Guadalupe M. Vale and her 13 brothers and sisters. She is survived by her husband Placido M. Reyes and her seven children. Pete and Margie Reyes of Humble TX, Beatrice Reyes and beloved Ruben H Martinez of Monahans TX, Ernestina and Anthony Mason of Odessa TX, Elizabeth and Joe Romo of Monahans TX, George and Sheri Reyes of Temecula CA, Martin and Graciela Reyes of Euless TX, and Leroy and Angela Denise Reyes of Round Rock TX. 23 grandchildren, 27 great grandchildren and 8 great- great grandchildren. Eufemia will be escorted by grandsons Jaime Martinez, Billy Barnett and great grandson Jordan Martinez. Pall Bearers are her grandsons Patrick Reyes, Mario Sotelo, Adam Sotelo, Andrew Romo, Ruben Martinez III, Jeremy Reyes and Isaac Reyes.Rosary is to be recited on Friday April 28th 2023 at St. John’s Catholic Church in Monahans TX at 7pm. Funeral will be held on Saturday April 29th 2023 at St. John’s Catholic Church in Monahans TX at 1pm. In lieu of flowers the family asks you donate to the American Cancer Society.To order memorial trees or send flowers to the family in memory of Eufemia Reyes, please visit our flower store.

Surviving Pat are her daughters Rebecca Lamberson, fiancé Herschel Cunningham, Jeri Leach Mobley and husband Twanye Mobley, Sherry Morton and her husband Ron; son Jay C. Diamond, and step-son Wesley Rogers; grandchildren Courtney Bovey and her husband Mark, Christian Lamberson, Joseph Lamberson, Lance Mobley, Jade Mobley, Hope Sutton, Jessica Mendoza, Jennifer Mendoza, Johnny Mendoza, and Joseph Rogers; great-grandchildren Kiley Sutton, Rain Mendoza, and Sadie Mendoza; five sisters Verda, Larue, Wanda, Zoe, Glenna and brother  Leon Fancher, and many nieces and nephews, and a host of beautiful family and friends throughout Texas and Mississippi who will miss her dearly. Theodotou Helen C. Theodotou, 89, of Upper Arlington, entered into rest Thursday, July 4, 2013. Born August 4, 1923 in Kansas City, she moved to Volos, Greece at a young age, returning at the end of WWII. She received her Bachelor's degree from the University of Missouri on a Julliard Scholarship for music. In 1996 she received her Master's degree in Byzantine History from The Ohio State University and was at the time of her passing a Ph.D. Candidate. As a Byzantine Scholar she spent much of her personal time in her personal library reading and researching. She was the Founder of the Hellenic Heritage Foundation created in memory of her late husband who shared her love for history and culture. Above all, Helen was a devoted mother, grandmother, and wife and she was so very proud of her children's and grandchildren's accomplishments professionally and personally. She and her late husband, Dr. Chris Theodotou, led a full and wonderful life enjoying family, friends, many personal interests and hobbies as well as traveling the world. All of her family will dearly miss her sense of humor, her generosity and indomitable spirit. Helen was a member of The Annunciation Greek Orthodox Cathedral. Preceded in death by her husband Dr. Chris B. Theodotou, and parents Andrew and Pamela Valiatzas. Helen will be missed by her loving children, sons, Basil (Jill Bazeley) Theodotou, Andrew (Ann) Theodotou; and daughter, Pamela Theodotou; grandchildren, Justin Theodotou, Lea (Mark) Sullivan, Christian, Andrew, and Alex Theodotou; and sister, Alexandra Sperides. The funeral service will be held Friday, July 19, 11 a.m. at The Greek Annunciation Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 555 N. High St., Columbus, OH 43215. Rev. Father Demetrios Gardikes, officiating. Visitation will be held one hour prior to the service at the church. Interment Union Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Helen's memory to The Annunciation Greek Orthodox Cathedral Memorial Fund or the Hellenic Heritage Foundation, (in memory of Helen Theodotou) 1500 West Third Avenue, Suite 324, Columbus, Ohio 43212. Arrangements entrusted to SCHOEDINGER NORTHWEST CHAPEL. To share memories or condolences, visit www.schoedinger.com.
Arrangements under the direction of Cage-Mills Funeral Directors, Corpus Christi, TX.

Services for June Robinson will be at 1:00PM on Wednesday, July 10, 2013, at the Rose Hills Memorial Park.June Lovvorn Smith Robinson was born June 17, 1924 in Los Angeles, California to Ernest Lovvorn and Leona Webb Lovvorn. She left us on July 4, 2013.June is survived by her husband of 49 years, Dale Robinson, and her three children, Ronald Gene Smith and wife Candy, and John Allen Smith and wife Marguerite, and Sheila Dell and partner Jody.Her grandchildren are Carie and husband Luis Guzman, Christina and husband Ron Weems, Shannon Smith, Austin Smith, Shawn and wife Kelly, Nanette and husband Andrew, Sandra and husband Rudy Jaramillo, Jeff and wife Chantelle Dell as well as  her great-grandchildren Gabriella and Rio Guzman; Aliyah and RJ Weems; Raye and Wyatt Smith;  Justin, Hannah, Logan and Clarisse Beaumont; Ethan, Allysa, and Riley Dell; and Christopher and Rieley Jaramillo..June is also survived by her sister Inez Morrell and her brother Pep Traynor. Her sister Marie and brother John preceded her in death. June was a VERY POSITIVE person and a very good soul. She had her masters degree in nursing and worked as a registered nurse for many years. She played the guitar for a while and she was a wonderful artist in painting and ceramics. She loved to travel and took photos of everything she saw!We had just celebrated her 89th birthday with a big party that included lots of family and cousins. It was a great party.
Burial arrangements under the direction of Ridgewood Memorial.

Louise Krslovic, 89, of Manasquan, NJ, passed away on Saturday, April 23, 2016 at Laurelton Village Rehabilitation Center in Brick, NJ.  She was born in Manhattan, New York and lived in Jersey City before moving to Manasquan in 1970.  Louise worked for Equitable Life Insurance in New York City.  Louise was a communicant of St. Denis Roman Catholic Church in Manasquan where she was a member of St. Denis Seniors.  She loved flowers, gardening and spending time with her grandchildren.Louise was predeceased by her husband, Ante Krslovic in 1975.  She is survived by her son, Anthony Krslovic, Sr. and his wife Jeanne of Brick, NJ; 2 sisters, Carmela Piscopo of New York and Jennie Maciaszek of Florida; 4 grandchildren, William, Matthew, Kara and Anthony, Jr.; and 3 great-grandchildren, Makayla, Holly and William.Visitation will be held on Friday, April 29, 2016 from 2-4 and 7-9pm at Neary-Quinn Funeral Home, 39 South Street, Manasquan, NJ.  Funeral Mass will be held on Saturday, April 30, 2016 at 9:30am at the St. Denis Our Lady Star of the Sea Beach Chapel, 554 E Main Street in Manasquan.  Burial will follow at St. Catharine Cemetery in Wall.

Esther M. Cadmus Longtime New Providence resident worked at Overlook Esther M. Cadmus, 90, of New Providence, N.J., passed away on Jan. 4, 2017. Visiting hours will be held at Bradley, Brough & Dangler Funeral Home, 299 Morris Ave., Summit, N.J., on Friday, Jan. 13, from 1 to 3 and 6 to 8 p.m., with a service at 7 p.m. during the visitation. A graveside service will be held on Saturday, Jan. 14, at 11 a.m., at Hollywood Memorial Park, Union, N.J. For further information or to send a condolence, please visit bradleyfuneralhomes.com. Born in Summit, the daughter of Walter and Mabel Smith, Esther also lived in Springfield, N.J., before moving to New Providence in 1946. She worked as an accredited record keeper at Overlook Medical Center for 30 years. Esther was a longtime and active member of both the New Providence United Methodist Church and the New Providence Seniors Association. She loved attending New Providence High School football games. Esther was the beloved wife of the late William Cadmus Jr. for 46 years. She was the loving mother of William Cadmus III and his wife, Michele, the late Walter Cadmus and his wife, Merry, and Robert Cadmus and his wife, Sally. She is also survived by her many cherished grandchildren and great-grandchildren and her companion and soulmate, Byron Wurst. She was the last of the 13 Smith siblings. Donations in Esther's memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 400 Morris Ave., Suite 251, Denville, N.J. 07834.

NEWPORT NEWS - Donald Wayne Deaver, 82, passed away on Wednesday, January 4, 2017 after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease. Donald was a native of Roanoke Rapids, NC and had been a Peninsula resident for 62 years. He graduated from the NNSY&DD Co. Apprentice School as a Piping Designer. He worked for the shipyard until 1977 and was later employed in the Engineering Dept. of Allied Signal, Inc. in Hopewell until his retirement. He was a member of Hidenwood Presbyterian Church where he served as a deacon and was a past member of the Warwick Lions Club. Donald was preceded in death by his parents, Lovie Letha Daniels and Sandy Oberson Deaver; and his brothers, Rudolph and Robert. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Shirley Ivey Deaver; daughters, Faith D. Belote (David) and Julie P. Deaver; his son, Gregory W. Deaver (Lisa); nine grandchildren, Clark, Jillian and Blair Belote, Amanda and Adam Stepp, Logan, Kylee, Owen and Bennett Deaver and nephew, Robert E. Deaver, Jr. The family would like to thank the staffs of Commonwealth Senior Living and Medi Hospice for their loving care and support. The family will receive friends on Wednesday, January 11, 2017 from 6:00 to 7:30pm at Weymouth Funeral Home. A Memorial Service will be held at Hidenwood Presbyterian Church on Thursday, January 12, 2017 at 3:00pm by the Rev. William G. Lamont and Mr. Caleb J. McClure. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hidenwood Presbyterian Church Memorial Fund or The Alzheimer's Association, P.O. Box 96011, Washington, DC, 20090-6011. Arrangements by Weymouth Funeral Home.

Ruth Nadine (Mitchell) Brown, 98, of Chicopee, KS, passed away at 1:40 p.m., Thursday, May 31, 2018, at Medicalodges of Girard. She was born September 15, 1919, at rural Arcadia, KS, the daughter of Jesse Thomas and Chleo (Smith) Mitchell. She attended Girard High School and graduated in 1937. She then graduated from Kansas State Teachers College with a Bachelor's degree and then a Master's degree in Education On September 5, 1942, she was united in marriage to Marvin A. Brown at Lamar, MO.  He preceded her in death on July 18, 2001. Ruth was a school teacher for over 42 years. She taught in Hatch, Lane, Weir, Treece, and Girard Middle School. In 1981 she was honored by receiving the "Master's Award" for the Girard school district #248. Membership was held in the Farlington United Methodist Church. She is survived by her sister, Willadean Bever of Girard, KS; nieces, Susan Friggeri and her husband Robert of Girard, KS, Judy Nelson and her husband Randy of Fort Scott, KS, and Kay Page and her husband Joe of Chicopee, KS; nephew, J.T. Mitchell of Pittsburg, KS, and several great nieces and nephews.           She is preceded in death by her parents, a brother, James Smith Mitchell, a niece Janice Mitchell and nephews, Greg Bever and Rod Bever. A service will be held at 10:00 a.m. Monday (June 4) at the Brenner Mortuary with Pastor Dallas Peterson officiating. Burial will follow in the Garden of Memories Cemetery. The family will receive friends thirty minutes prior to the start of the service on Monday at the funeral home. The family suggests memorials to Farlington United Methodist Church and/or Chicopee Foundation Inc. These may be left at or mailed to the Brenner Mortuary, 114 E. 4th St., Pittsburg, KS 66762. Friends may also leave condolences online at www.brennermortuary.com. Arrangements are under the direction of the Brenner Mortuary.

Mary Ellen (Martell) Scully, 98, met her Lord face to face on Monday, 2/11/19.Born in Crookston, MN to Henry & Celina Martell in 1921, "Ellen" married Robert Scully (her neighbor) in 1941 at St. Peters Church in Gentilly, MN. They moved to the Yakima Valley in 1945 with other family members from Minnesota. Mom and Dad resided in an 8' x 16' cabin in Naches and did migrant work at local orchards.  Dad eventually became an ironworker, and he and mom built a home in North Yakima in the early 1950's and raised their family.Mom was a woman of deep faith and prayed consistently for patience while raising their eleven 'crazy' kids (who all took after their father). Her home was always the focus of family, with lots of laughter, playing card games, and watching Mariner games. Everyone always felt welcome to her home and knew where the 'treat' counter was located, in the kitchen.She was a devoted member of Catholic Daughters of America, St. Paul's Church, and YLI.Highlights of her later life after Dad retired from Northwest Ironworkers, was playing cribbage twice weekly with close friends Lane & Phyllis Woodard, traveling with family, and celebrating the holidays with as many family members who could fit into her house (even hanging out the windows).Ellen is survived by nine children: Donna (Jim) Kendrick, Jan Hall, Darryl (Sharon) Scully, Joanne Scully, Mike Scully, Keven (Debbie) Scully, Lauren Scully, Bruce (Jill) Scully and Renee McGuire (friend Pat Lawler); 16 grandchildren: Sean (Rachele), Glenda (Kevin), Biff (Kim), Shannon (Dave), Dale (Karen), Jennifer (Chris), Rebecca (Garret), Darren (Karlee), Sara (Jesse), Logan (Liz), Kristen (Anatolio), Justin (Kelsey), Angela (Chris), Morgan (Tyler), Blake, and Madison (Justin). She is also survived by 15 great grandchildren and three great-great grandchildren, along with many beloved nieces and nephews, and sisters in law, Barb and Orella.Mom was preceded in death by husband Robert, sons Virgil and Gary, three brothers, Francis (Sis) Martell, Benedict (Marge) Martell, and Dan Martell; sons in law Sherwood Hall, and Bruce McGuire, and daughter in law Lynda Scully Viewing and visitation will be Sunday 2/17/19 from 1:00 PM - 5:00 PM at Langevin El Paraiso Funeral Home. Funeral Services will be Monday, 2/18/19 at 10:00 AM at St. Paul's Cathedral. Graveside service will be Wednesday 2/20/19 at 10:00 AM at Calvary Cemetery. To share a memory of Mary please visit www.lepfuneralhome.com

RAYMOND - Craig D. Steensen, born October 16, 1956, died peacefully in his home after a brief battle with cancer, on October 25, 2019.Craig was a recently retired stone and gravel scale master, previously working in various construction jobs and owning and operating a successful landscaping business for 10 years.He enjoyed spending time with his family, playing golf, watching football, working on projects in his yard and traveling to Puerto Rico. He was warmly known for his sense of humor, colorful language, innate ability to make friends with anyone he met and always providing a helping hand.Craig was married to his wife Karen for 33 years. They have three children: Danielle, Craig James and Chelsea. He is also survived by his mother, Patricia Smith; his sister, Debra Zelechoski; cousins, niece and nephew. He is predeceased by his sister, Robin Steensen; and his stepfather, Robert Smith. . SERVICES: His Memorial Gathering will be held in the Phaneuf Funeral Homes and Crematorium, 250 Coolidge Ave., Manchester, on Saturday, Nov. 2, from 1 to 4 p.m. with a Memorial Service at 3 p.m.In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to NHFoodbank.org.To view Craig's online tribute, send condolences to the family, or for more information, visit www.phaneuf.net.

Joycelyn Hatler Sheppard, 84, passed away on March 20, 2021.Visitation will be held on Wednesday, March 31, 2021, at Azle and Lake Worth Funeral Home beginning at 1:00 PM followed by a Funeral Service at 2:00 PM.  Interment will be rendered at Azleland Cemetery & Memorial Park.Joycelyn was born on April 14, 1936 to Buck and Florene Hatler.  She was a mother of five boys who filled her heart with joy.  In 1997, Joycelyn married Tommy Glenn Sheppard.  She enjoyed fishing, camping and watching football.  Joycelyn was a shining light on the dance  floor and spent many nights participating in Shuffle Board tournaments.  She had a soft spot for animals, but above all, Joycelyne cherished the time she spent with her husband and children.She is preceded in passing by her parents and three of her sons, Johnny, Danny, and Tommy Poindexter.Joycelyne will be deeply and lovingly missed by her husband of 23 years, Tommy Glenn Sheppard; sons, Ronnie Walcott and Randy Walcott; and a host of loving extended family and friends.

William Maurice Kennedy, 84, of Farmington, NM and formerly of Sun City West, AZ, joined our Heavenly Father Sunday, August 14, 2022. He was born May 22, 1938, in Vincennes, Indiana to Maurice Kennedy and Helen Keynon Kennedy.Bill married Phillis Ann Daily on Aug. 18, 1956, in Washington, Indiana and together they started what would be generations of family members, beginning with their daughter Debora Lee (Kennedy) Martinez of Farmington, NM and their son William Allen Kennedy of Morrison, CO. Daughter Debora married, John A. Martinez of Farmington and together they gave Bill two granddaughters transforming him lovingly into “Ponca”. His granddaughters, Christine L. Martinez and husband Gregory P. Martin, and JoAnn N. Martinez, all of Farmington gave a total to 5 great grandchildren, James Isaac Bender, Megan A. Bender, Jake C. Anderson, Finn A. Anderson, Cian R. Anderson, and 3 step-great grandchildren, James G. Martin, Nicholas D. Martin and Angelina R. Martin, all of Farmington, NM. Son William Allen continued to add to the generations through Bill’s grandson, and namesake, William Max Kennedy and girlfriend Hailee Field.Bill has lived and moved across the country from the Midwest to the Southwest, eventually making the Southwest his home. He has made numerous friends along the way and was great at keeping those connections throughout his life time. He was smart as a whip, could fix anything, always had a smile, enjoyed a laugh, and loved spending time with his people. He worked for several companies in the region including Peabody Coal Company, Utah International and Central Arizona Project in the area of electrical engineering. In the last several years he developed a love for Harry Potter books and movies and he enjoyed his time with his beloved canine buddy, Rufus.He will be greatly missed, always loved, and his stories and memories carried on through his family.Bill was preceded in death by his parents. He is survived by his son, daughter and son-in-law; grandchildren and their families; his brother, Robert Kennedy and wife Debbie Kennedy, numerous nieces and nephews; and his brother John Kennedy.The viewing for Bill will be at 1:30 p.m. Friday, August 19th at the Brewer, Lee and Larkin Funeral Home, 103. E. Ute St. in Farmington with services to follow at 2:00 p.m. Interment will follow at the Memory Gardens Cemetery in Farmington.Bill's care is entrusted to Brewer, Lee and Larkin Funeral Home, 103 E. Ute St. in Farmington, 505-325-8688. Those who wish to express their condolences may do so at serenityandcompany.com.To send flowersto the family or plant a treein memory of William Maurice Kennedy, please visit our floral store.

Sharon Kay Witt, age 80, passed away peacefully on April 27, 2023. She was born July 10, 1942, in Madison, Wisconsin, to Tom and Dorothy Reynolds (Mehrkens).Growing up, Sharon always joked about being a tomboy, running with a group of boys in her neighborhood. One time, they climbed the Spaanem Avenue water tower. She loved to share that story as well as so many more.In 1960, she graduated from Monona Grove High School.Sharon loved her many jobs that she worked at throughout her life. But the job that most defined her was the 33 years she spent working for the Madison School District as a teacher’s aide. Everyone who attended school at Elvejhem Elementary has a “Miss Sharon” story. After she retired, Sharon continued for years at the school volunteering.She had so much joy, caring for her many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Everyone received a birthday card from her, as well as the phone call, so she could sing “Happy Birthday”. There wasn’t a better example of a grandmother than Sharon.She was loved by many and will be missed dearly.Sharon is survived by her children, William Witt IV (Janel), Brian Jon Witt (Lori), Bradley Thomas Witt, and Kari Ann Witt (Mark Johnson).Grandchildren, Zach Witt, Annelise Witt (Coker), Bryce Witt, Alexis Wood, Chayce Rayner, T.J. Georgia W. SmithCharlotte, NC - Georgia W. Smith (née Georgia Lee Weaver), 90, passed away Tuesday, February 12, 2019 in Pineville, NC. She was born in Knoxville, TN on June 4, 1928 to Clarence Robert Weaver and Una Weaver (née Una Vivian Miller). In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband of 62 years, Clifford Calhoun Smith, Jr.Georgia dedicated her life to her family and to others. She and Cliff raised four sons, moving throughout the Southeast before settling in Prattville, AL, where they lived for over thirty years. She served as a den mother for the Cub Scouts several times and later joined the Prattville Spinners, a community service organization, serving as president for a time.Music and bridge were sources of enjoyment for Georgia. Each time she and Cliff moved, she ensured her piano went with them. She was active in church choirs and was a member of the Prattville Community Chorus. She and friends gathered weekly to enjoy playing bridge.Georgia will be sorely missed by her four sons, Clifford Calhoun Smith III (Anne), Gregory Lee Smith (Beth), Michael Parker Smith (Beth), and Edward Timothy Smith (Marisa); seven grandchildren; and nine great-grandchildren.A private family committal service will be held on February 22 at Ft. Mitchell National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Alzheimer's Association (www.alz.org).

Ruth Marie Clark, 89 of Elkhorn, WI, passed away on Sunday, March 21, 2021 at her home in Elkhorn, WI. Ruth was born on April 22, 1931 in Princeton, Minnesota, the daughter of Herman Carl Hammel & Florence Lillian Lindell Hammel. When Ruth was 6 years old she came with her family to Southeastern Wisconsin. Ruth graduated from Elkhorn High School in 1949. She worked for the State Probation & Parole Office & the National Food Store. Ruth married the love of her life, Rulo, on March 29, 1952 in Elkhorn Wisconsin. Rulo passed away on March 9, 2004, and they farmed in Sugar Creek Township on Taylor Road for all of their 52 years together. This is where they raised their four children. Ruth continued to live on the farm, she loved the farm life. Ruth was a long time member of the Bethel United Methodist Church on the corner of Highway 12 and County Road A. She was a lay leader, lay member to annual conference, Administrative Council and many other teams and committees. Her church relationships where very important to her. Ruth was an active 4-H Leader for over 40 years. She was a Photography Leader for the Sugar Creek 4-H Club for 23 years and in charge of the Junior Photography and judging at the Walworth County Fair. A member of the Sr. Leaders’ Association, Awards Committee and judged photography at the state level. She was an active member of the Walworth County Farm Bureau and was Secretary of the Women’s Committee, on the Dairy Committee and longtime Chair and Co-Chair. Former member of the Millard Aires-Homemakers, Walworth County Young Homesteaders, and Saturday Afternoon Card Club. Ruth worked at the Sugar Creek Polls for many years. Ruth was an avid Packer Fan, when the games where on it is known that she could get pretty vocal about the action happening! Watching her children & grandchildren participate in sports and school activities was a highlight in her life. Ruth has many hobbies that she enjoyed over the years, such as, collecting thimbles, cardinals, toothpick holders, ceramic chickens and music boxes. She enjoyed playing cards, reading, and photography. When Ruth was not busy with any of the many things she was involved in, she found time to go on two hot air balloon rides in the Lake Geneva area!Ruth is survived by her Children; Jim (Debbie) Clark, Elkhorn, (Jon) Kevin Clark, Arpin, Susan Clark, Elkhorn, and Kari Clark, Milwaukee. Grandchildren: Cory Landreman, Racine, Ryan Landreman (Fiancé Jessalyn Knapp), Elkhorn, Rachel (Pat) Schmuhl, Arpin, Jill (Nick) Musgrove, Elkhorn, Ben (Katie) Clark, Elkhorn, and Kelly (Craig) Guthrie, Elkhorn, and Honorary Grandmother to Lindsey Duesterbeck. Great Grandchildren: Clayton, Harper, & Gabby Landreman, Elliot & Maddex Knapp, Hadley & Libby Landreman, Isabella & Cameron Schmuhl, Jory & Raven Musgrove, Nathan & Natalie Clark, & Lexi, Cheyenne, Allen, & Chase Guthrie; brother and sister–in-law, George & Rita Wyatt, and many nieces, nephews, cousins, friends and her church family.Ruth was preceded in death by her parents, husband Rulo, brothers Robert & Harry, sister Phyllis Jebens, brother-in-law Lester Jebens, Sister-in-law, Joyce Hammel, and Daughter-in-law Mary Jo Clark.At this time, the family would like to thank Jessalyn Knapp and Hospice for all your loving care and thoughtfulness, not only to Ruth but to her family also!A funeral service will be held on 11:30AM on Friday, March 26, 2021 at Haase-Lockwood & Associates Funeral Homes and Crematory, 730 N. Wisconsin St. Elkhorn, WI 53121. Visitation will be 3:00PM to 7:00PM on Thursday, March 25, 2021 at the funeral home and 10:30AM on Friday until service time.  Online guest book available at www.haaselockwoodfhs.com.  Arrangements for Clark Family were completed by Haase-Lockwood & Associates Funeral Homes and Crematory.

ELEANOR JEAN WILSON, 98, formerly of Alta, Iowa, Carson City, Nevada, and Fowler, Ohio, passed away Sunday evening, March 21, 2021 at Methodist Manor Retirement Community in Storm Lake, Iowa.The Boothby Funeral Home in Cherokee, Iowa is assisting the family with the arrangements. Her remains were cremated and there will be no visitation. Memorial services will be held at a later date in Ohio. The family requests that memorial donations be made to St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital, one of Eleanor’s favorite charities. Online condolences can be made at www.boothbyfuneral.comEleanor was born on January 2, 1923 in Fowler, Ohio to Jacob Allen & Ida Frances (Grogg) Hefner. She graduated from Fowler High School in 1940 and married Harry D. Wilson in October 1942. Together the couple had five children and were married for 42 years. Eleanor was a meticulous homemaker and hard-working stay-at-home mother. After raising her family, she moved to Nevada, her home for the next 30 years. In her 50s, she was hired by the housekeeping department at Carson Tahoe Regional Medical Center where she worked until her retirement in 1995.She was a past President of the Ladies Auxiliary VFW Bailey-Barto Post 7614 in Johnston, Ohio. Eleanor enjoyed letter writing and corresponding with family members and many friends. Grandchildren delighted in her regular packages filled with trinkets, stickers, books, mittens, and sundry personal care items.Eleanor was preceded in death by her parents; brothers Gail Hefner, Dwight Hefner; sisters Dessa Doud, Margie Whipkey, Frances Stoddard, Ruth Oates, and Helen Lewis Stamm; former husband Harry D. Wilson, daughter Judy Dean, son-in-laws Larry Popowich and Don Hicks.In addition to brother-in-law Carl Wilson of Cortland, Ohio, Eleanor is survived by four children: Carol Deiber (Ron) of Alta, Iowa; David Wilson (Mary Anketell) of Elizabethtown, Pennsylvania; Connie Wilson of Cortland, Ohio; Bob Wilson (Holly) of Papillion, Nebraska; 13 grandchildren, 24 great grandchildren, and seven great-great grandchildren.To send a flower arrangement or to plant trees in memory ofEleanor J. Wilson, please click here to visit our Sympathy Store.

He Married the love of his life, Linda Joyce Karhoff on December 9, 1967 in Rockford Illinois. Gerald (Jerry) was a jack of all trades, and a master of none.
