MONTGOMERY– Clinton A. Levis, age 87, passed away on Friday, December 3, 2021, at Brownway Residence in Enosburg Falls.He was born in Montgomery on September 29, 1934, to the late Carmi W. & Eve (Hoyt) Levis.Clinton grew up in Montgomery Center on his family’s dairy farm and attended the Montgomery School House. He looked forward to going for long drives, while enjoying one of his favorite snacks, trips to the fair, and visiting with his friends. One of Clinton’s favorite past times was listening to music, he loved singing along to his favorite Johnny Cash or Merle Haggard songs or playing his harmonica and plucking his guitar. He had a flair with the ladies and was always there to greet you with a friendly smile.He is survived by dear friends and guardians, Martha and Terry Bergeron of Sheldon; care givers, Heidi Kobera of Sheldon, and Lorraine Bergeron of Sheldon; special friend, Bill Bell of Sheldon; and several other friends who will miss him dearly. Besides his parents, he was predeceased by his siblings, Hallie (Levis) Grant and her husband Ralph, Hilda Levis, Ralph Levis, Helen Levis, Ida Levis, Carmi “Sonny” Levis, Beverly Levis, and Raymond Levis; and a chocolate lab, Bear who he was incredibly fond of.For those who wish contributions in Clinton’s memory may be made to the Franklin County Home Health Agency, 3 Home Health Cir # 1, St Albans City, VT 05478.Services will be held in the spring with interment to follow in the Montgomery Center Cemetery.Goss Life Celebration Homes is the area’s exclusive provider of Life Celebration events. Please visit our website to share condolences, photos and favorite memories at www.gossfs.com

Graveside services for Virginia D. Lewis will be held at 2:00 PM, Sunday, August 21, 2022, at Rosefield Cemetery, Rosefield, LA, with Pastor Denver McBroom officiating. Services are under the direction of Riser Funeral Home, Columbia, LA.Virginia was born in 1935 to Luther and Pearl Lewis and passed away in 2022 at 86 years of age. She is survived by her four children: Kevin, Kathy, Cynthia (husband, Hoyt) and James; her six grandchildren: Jessica, Hayden, Michael, Cody (wife, Whitney), Elizabeth, and Kelli; as well as her four great-grandchildren: Violet, Hazel, Archer, and Knox.She was preceded in death by her parents, Luther and Pearl; her brothers: Walton, Clyde, Clinton, and Luther Ray; and sisters: Alice, Ruby, Sybil, and Darlene.After her children left the nest, Virginia embarked on a career in writing. She moved to Branson, MO and wrote articles for tourist magazines and other publications which included interviews with the stars of the theater shows. She also created and marketed a Branson themed Trivia Game as well as a set of humorous post cards reflecting tourist life in Branson.Ms V, as she was affectionately known in Olla, LA, had a deep abiding relationship with her Lord and Savior Jesus Christ and despite her love of Branson, she felt the Lord asking her to move back to Olla in order to help look after her brother Clinton, who was in declining health. This she did for several years until his passing.Virginia worked for several years at the Centennial Cultural Center in Olla. She loved her job - working with the kids at summer camp, interviewing and writing stories of local legends in the area; she enjoyed chatting it up with out-of-town tourists who visited the Cultural Center and she wrote a humorous column in the local paper. After her job ended, she continued to volunteer at the Center.Afterwards, Virginia began attending Zion Hill Baptist Church which she loved dearly and where she made close friends. When her health took a turn and she realized she could no longer be on her own, she lived her remaining time in a nursing home in Natchez, MS. She has now gone on to be with Jesus.She will continue to be loved and remembered by all who knew her.

Beulah Louise Dorsey Bell, a native of Chicago was born on September 20, 1928 to the union of Clarence and Esther Dorsey. She was home to be with the Lord the morning of September 17, 2010. She was preceded in transition by her brothers Robert "Bobby" Dorsey, Sydney B. Dorsey, Sr., and sister Clara K. Dorsey Holton. Beulah grew up in the Woodlawn Community where she was baptized at Lincoln Memorial Congregational Church where her family remained active for over eighty years. She participated in the church's Sunday School and Vacation Bible School programs. Beulah graduated from McCosh Elementary School and Englewood High School. She extended her quest for learning and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from Chicago Teachers College( now Chicago State University) and a Masters of Education degree from Loyola University. While at Chicago Teachers College, Beulah became a member of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc. As a lifelong member and Golden Soror, Beulah was a dedicated member of Chicago's Theta Omega Chapter. Beulah began her teaching career with Chicago Public Schools at Carter Elementary School. She went on to serve as Assistant Principal of Reavis Elementary School. Education was always the cornerstone of her existence. Students, teachers, parents and administrators alike welcomed and benefited greatly from her nurturing yet firm and fair approach to the educational process. Beulah retired from Chicago Public Schools in 1988 after more than thirty five years of service. At a ski party in January of 1964, Beulah met William Bell. Six months later they were united in holy matrimony on June 20, 1964. Together they raised their daughter Carolyn and son Billy to always strive for excellence. Beulah's Christian values and beliefs were practiced daily in how she lived her life and how she treated people. With her jovial and easy-going demeanor, Beulah enjoyed socializing with her family and friends especially in Union Pier, Michigan on Thanksgiving Day. Beulah's happiest times were spent with her family, especially her grandchildren. During recent years, Beulah obtained much joy and comfort residing in her second home in Pembroke Pines, Florida during the winter months. Her intense love for world travel found her arranging trips for large groups of family members and friends to countries in five continents: Africa, Asia, Europe, North America and South America. Beulah would also arrange cruises to various parts of the Caribbean. Beulah belonged to several social groups, bridge clubs and civic organizations. Beulah will be greatly missed. She leaves to Cherish her memory, her husband William; daughter Carolyn Bell-Richards; son William Bell, Jr; five grandchildren; Jasmine Leslie, Sydney Wadkins, Eboni Richards, Scott Richards and David Richards; a sister-in-law Myrtle Dorsey; a special cousin Mary A. Smothers; and a host of other cousins, nieces, nephews and friends.
Burial arrangements under the direction of Pierce Brothers Valhalla Memorial Park.
Arrangements under the direction of Palm Downtown Mortuary, Las Vegas, NV.

Gilbert "Gil" Gericke, age 89, a resident of Spooner, died on Sunday, July 7, 2013, at the Spooner Health System.Gil was born in Chicago, Illinois, to parents Otto and Minnie Gericke.  After school, he joined the U.S. Marines Corps in 1943.  During the Battle of Pallalu, Gil suffered a knee injury that ultimately led to him being medically discharged as a 1st Sgt on August 8, 1946.  On October 9, 1948, Gil was united in marriage to Ruth Thornley in Chicago, Illinois.  To this union, a daughter Lynn was born in 1949.  In 1952, the family moved to Spooner where Gil worked various jobs and eventually retired from the U.S. Post Office in 1974.  After his retirement, the couple continued to live on Middle McKenzie Lake for many years.  Gil was a member of the Disabled American Veteran, the Masons, and a attended the Spooner United Methodist Church.Gil is survived by his grandchildren: Tina (Troy) Bol of Chetek, WI, Shane Roberts of Rice Lake, WI, several great grandchildren, brother in law William "Bill" Thornley Sr., and many nieces and nephews.Gil is preceded in death by his parents, wife Ruth, daughter Lynn, one brother and 2 sisters. Memorial services for Gil Gericke will be held on Wednesday, July 17, 2013, at 1 pm, at the Dahl Funeral Home with visitation from 12-1 at the Funeral Home on Wednesday. Interment with Military Honors will follow at the Spooner Cemetery.

Raymond MillerYork - Raymond E. Miller, 94, passed away at home in York Sunday June 3, 2018 in the love and comfort of family. He was the husband of Gail R. (Albright) Miller "his sweetie" with whom he enjoyed 30 blessed years of marriage. Ray, as he was known by his many friends, was born in Dallastown, to the late Herman and Hazel (Stine) Miller. He attended Dallastown Area HS. His love of country called him to enlist in the U.S. Army in 1943 and serve as an Anti-Aircraft Gunman in 502nd Artillery Battalion. He received numerous medals including Philippine Liberation Ribbon, several Bronze Stars, and WWII Victory medals. He worked as Parts Manager at York Mack for 52 years. He also worked part-time for many years at Conrad's Delicatessen, owned by his late sister. Ester and her husband. Joe Conrad; along with three of his four children, Don, Lisa, and Grant Miller; and two nephews, Larry and Chris Conrad.In addition to his wife, Gail, he is survived by his daughter, Lisa Miller and husband, Mike Barbery of VA; stepdaughter, Julie Smith and husband, Chad Smith of Dover; and Gay Lynn (Miller) Miller, wife of the late Donald R. Miller, his eldest son; four grandchildren, Dirk Auman, wife Katlyn, Brandon Barbery, Bryan Miller, wife Megan, and Kelly (Miller) Barna and husband, Pete; and three great-grandchildren, Olive and Freya Miller and Arianna Barna. Ray is also survived by his youngest sister, Ruth and husband, Jim Burkett; along with Ruth's five children, Connie Wertman, Dan Deller, Beth Harlacher, Deb Long and Joann Hullman. He was preceded in death by three of his children whom he dearly loved and has now joined in everlasting life, Donald, Suzanne and Grant. Longtime residents of York County, Ray and wife, Gail, lived in Palm Bay, FL for ten years, enjoying the ocean, their swimming pool, warm weather, family and many good friends. Ray was a longtime member of Christ Lutheran Church of Dallastown and a member of Dallastown American Legion Post 605, and West York VFW. A Memorial Service Celebrating Ray's Life will be held at 12 p.m. Saturday June 16th at Paradise (Holtzschwamm) Evangelical Covenant Church, 6777 Lincoln Hwy, Thomasville, where he attended. A reception will immediately follow in the fellowship hall. Heffner Funeral Chapel & Crematory, Inc., 1551 Kenneth Rd, York is in charge of arrangements. Contributions in Ray's memory may be made to Paradise Holtzschwamm ECC, 6777 Lincoln Hwy, Thomasville, Pa 17364 or Easter Seals, 2550 Kingston Rd Suite 219, York Pa 17402. Share Memories of Ray and Send Condolences at HeffnerCare.com.

Freda Lea Isaacks, 74, passed away on Thursday, February 14, 2019 at Mesilla Valley Hospice in Las Cruces, NM.Freda was born April 12, 1944 in Albuquerque, NM to Clois and Freida Teston of Truth or Consequences, NM.  Freda and her Brothers Milton and Cliff Teston Grew up in Truth or Consequences, NM. Spending most of her Summers at Elephant Butte lake water skiing. She had a zest for life, climbing to the top of turtle back mountain as a teenager, knowing that if her father and mother found out her summer was over. She attended Hot Springs High School where she met her husband Mike Reid.  They married shortly after and Moved to California, where her Sons Michael and Chris Reid were born. They moved a few years later to Farmington, NM and Shawn and Shannon Nicole Reid were born. They divorced and Freda eventually settled in Las Cruces, NM to raise her 4 children working at Sears and Roebuck for many years. She later met Joe Isaacks who passed several years later.  Freda worked hard and was the type of mother that did all she could for her children. Even cashing in her retirement to take Shawn and Shannon to Disney Land. She always gave to her children and never asked for anything in return. Freda always spoke of how proud she was of her children. Especially her dachshund's that replaced her grown children while they went off to make their own lives. She is Survived by her brother Cliff Teston and spouse Sally Teston of Denver Colorado and Sons Michael James Reid of Las Cruces, Christopher Lee Reid and Spouse Shawna Reid of Aztec NM, Shawn Reid and spouse Charlotte Reid of Las Cruces NM, Shannon Nicole Hopkins and spouse Craig Hopkins of Bayfield Colorado.Grand children: Jacob Reid and Jenna of Las Cruces, NM, Chantal Villescas of Las Cruces, NM, Cori Reid of Longview, TX, Molly Reid and fiancé William Melius of Pasadena, California. Mitchell Reid and Spouse Kelsey Reid of Aztec, NM. Bradley Martin and Spouse Meriel Martin of Bayfield, Colorado. Bonnie Metoyer and spouse Gabe Metoyer of Farmington, NM. Chelsie Reid of Atlanta, Georgia. McKinzie Reid and fiancé Justice Francisco and Sara Reid of Durango, Colorado.7 Great Grandchildren: Jesse and Ellie Winkel, Samantha and Levi Reid, Madalyn Metoyer, Paisley and Hudson Reid, with 3 more babies on the way, Many Nephews and nieces. She is preceded in death by her parents Freida and Clois Teston, brother Milton Teston, Joe Isaacks, and Mike Reid.Visitation will be held on Tuesday, February 19, 2019 beginning at 10am, followed by a memorial service at 11 am at Getz Funeral Home 1410 E. Bowman Ave. Las Cruces, NM 88001 with Pastor Frank Zamora Officiating.    Graveside services will follow at Vista Memory Gardens Cemetery in Truth or Consequences, NM.Pallbearer's are Sons Chris Reid, Shawn Reid. Grandsons Jacob Reid, Mitchell Reid, Brad Martin. Son in law Craig Hopkins. Honorary Pallbearer Michael James Reid.Arrangements are with Getz Funeral Home 1410 E. Bowman Ave., Las Cruces NM 88001. Please visit www.GetzCares.com to sign the local online guest book.

Patricia Ann Yones, 84, of Tecumseh, Oklahoma passed away Thursday, February 14, 2019 in Dallas, Texas.She was born October 4, 1934 to Kendell and Violet (Bevins) Stevens in Tecumseh, Oklahoma.Patricia was raised in Bethel Acres and attended Bethel Public Schools.  She graduated from Bethel High School where she played Basketball and was on the OKC Women’s League.She met her future husband, Herb L. Yones while she was working as a telephone operator at Southwestern Bell Telephone. They were married on February 26, 1954 at Blackburn Chapel Baptist Church in Bethel Acres and he preceded her in death on September 11, 2013.Patricia was a devoted wife, mother and grandmother.  Her greatest passion in life was being a mom to her three children Mike, Kim and Joel.  After her children were older she went to work outside the home selling Fashion 220 cosmetics, worked as a real estate agent and owned and operated Antiques, Etc. in Tecumseh.She loved going to the casinos and was considered to be the luckiest person on the slot machines.  Patricia enjoyed being with her children and grandchildren; they were the focal point of her life.  She was a wonderful mom and grandmother and will be dearly missed by all those who knew and loved her.She was preceded in death by her husband, Herb Yones; and her parents, Kendell and Violet Stevens.Those left to cherish her memories are her daughter and son-in-law, Kimberly and Jim Rayburn of Dallas, TX; 2 sons and 1 daughter-in-law, Michael S. Yones of Oklahoma City, OK and Joel and Sally Yones of Prague, OK; 6 grandchildren, Christopher and Cameron Yones, Patrick and Shelby Yones, Steven Yones, Carrie Reddin, Taylor and Collin Hoover, and Alexandra and Andy Broussard; 11 great-grandchildren; and many loving friends and extended family.Visitation will be from 9:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m., Wednesday, February 20, 2019 with family gathering to greet friends and family from 5:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. at Cooper Funeral Home.  Services will be 10:00 a.m., Thursday, February 21, 2019 at Cooper Funeral Home Chapel with Reverend Larry Sparks, Blackburn Chapel Baptist Church officiating. Burial will follow at Brown Cemetery under the direction of Cooper Funeral Home of Tecumseh.

El Solo Se Lleva Lo MejorDios, vio que él estava cansado una curación no debia ser, asi que él puso sus brazos alrededor de él, y susurrando dijo "Ven A Mi". Con los ojos llorosos lo miramos sufrir, y lo vimos partir, aunque lo amamos, no lo pudimos detener. Un corazón de oro paró de latir, y sus manos trabajadoras descansan. Dios rompió nuestros corazones para provarnos que, él solo se lleva lo mejor.

ROBERT OLSON, 85 of Ogallala, passed away March 23, 2021, at the Indian Hills Manor in Ogallala.Robert was born March 25, 1935, at Tilden, Nebraska, to Alvar and Ethel (Robertson) Olson. He graduated from Omaha Benson High School with the class of 1953.Robert entered the U.S. Navy on September 9, 1954, and served during the Korean Conflict. Following his discharge in October of 1956, Bob married Patricia J. Karlovec at Omaha. The couple made their home in Omaha for several years where he worked at Western Electric before moving to Yankton, SD where Bob took a job with Dale Electronics. From there Bob took a job with TRW until his retirement. Their union was blessed with three sons, Don, Ron, and David.Bob favored spending time outdoors and loved sports. Bob was always involved in the sporting exploits of his children, either as a coach or as an official for their events. Those moments Bob shared with his children were always close to his heart. In later years, he cherished the time he got to spend with his grandchildren and great-grandchildren.Bob was preceded in death by his parents, and an infant sister, Beverly.Survivors include his wife, Pat of Ogallala, three sons, Don (Tamra) Olson of Claremore, OK, Ron (Sandy) Olson of Ogallala, David Olson of Abilene, TX; eight grandchildren; and twelve great-children.Condolences may be shared at prairiehillsfuneralhome.com.Private interment of cremains will be in the Ogallala Cemetery at a later date.Prairie Hills Funeral Home of Ogallala is assisting the Olson family.

Virginia (Jenny) Shaw Akins died on December 4th, 2021. She was born in Russellville, Kentucky, on August 23, 1928, to the late James Payne Shaw, Jr. and Mary Mason Shaw. She was preceded in death by her husband of forty-six years, James Edward Akins, her brother James Payne Shaw Ill, and three of her five daughters, Lucinda Akins Welsh, Richner Akins Belonger, Caroline Akins O'Connell. She is survived by two daughters, Mary Ann Wolcott (Jon Stafford) and Elizabeth Shaw Akins (Jim Schork), her son-in-law, Paul Belonger, fourteen grandchildren, fourteen great-grandchildren, two great-great grandchildren and her sister Lelia Moyers (Bob). Jenny earned a Bachelor of Arts from Kentucky Wesleyan College and a Master of Education from the University of Louisville. She taught English at Ballard High School and chaired the English Department for five of those years. In 1981 she founded The Lampmaker, a lighting store in St. Matthews, from which she retired in 1998 and which still exists today. Jenny's children and grandchildren were inspired by her commitment to education, her business acumen, her love of classical music, and her fondness for travel. They were not much inspired by her bran muffins but have decided to let that one go.Funeral services will be held on December 9 at 12 p.m. at Pearson’s, 149 Breckenridge Lane. Visitation will be 11- 12 p.m. A private burial will follow. VERNELL STAFFORD WAYEVernell Stafford Waye was born on March 24, 1936 in the Sampit Community of Georgetown, SC. She was the eldest child of eight children to the union of the late Thomas and Bessie Bryant Stafford. She transitioned from this earthly life at the age of 86 on Wednesday, August 17, 2022 at Pruitt Health Systems in Moncks Corner, SC."Nell" and "Ma" as she was affectionately called attended the public schools of Georgetown County. At an early age she was baptized and became a member of St. Paul A.M.E. Church, (Sampit Community) of Georgetown, SC.She moved to New York City, New York, that's where she met the love of her life Charles L "Charlie" Waye. They were married on Christmas Day, December 25, 1957. To this union, three children were born. They were married for 53 years before the passing of "Charlie" on December 21, 2010.She was a firm believer in prayer and her faith has always been strong. She lived by the Scriptures of Proverbs 31:10- 31 and Matthew 6:33. "Ma" always put God first in her life and she always taught her children and grandchildren about putting God first in their lives and having faith.While living in Roxbury, Mass., she was a member of Charles Street A.M.E. Church. She was employed with Teradyne until her health prevented her from working.In 1977, she moved back to the Sampit Community, and she renewed her membership back to her home church St. Paul A.M.E. Church. She served on the Hospitality Committee, and a former Building Fund Captain.She always believed that a family that prays together stays together. In 1985, she helped organize the bi­ annual Bryant and Stafford Family Reunion, along with the offspring of Late Robert and Lula Smith Bryant and the Late London and Kiziah Gasque Stafford. She was a childcare caregiver in the community when parents needed someone to watch their child/children she would watch them while they were at work. Vernell loved to cook and really excelled at it. Her dishes would always leave everyone wanting for more. She taught her daughter, son, 3 of her grands and her brother to cook in the manner she did.Her community involvements were helping organize the Sampit Community Action Group along with her Late husband "Charlie". She was a member of the Sampit Community United Women Social Group.She was preceded in death by: her parents, Thomas and Bessie Bryant Stafford; her husband, Charles "Charlie" L. Waye, Sr.; one daughter Lula M. Strickland; two brothers, Franklin L. Stafford and Joseph 'JH' Stafford; and two sisters, Suziah Stafford Bell and Cleo Stafford Smith.She leaves behind: her children, daughter, Carrol Waye (Jefferson) Tompkins, Georgetown, SC, two sons Charles Jr., Atlanta, GA and Thomas (Alexis), Milton, MA. Her 7 grands, Khalid Strickland (Sachiko), New York, NY, Jasmine (Paul) Bush, Atlanta, GA, Andre Tompkins, Columbia, SC, Syreeta (Anderson Sr.) Lane, Blythewood SC, Antoine (Candice) Tompkins, Murfreesboro, TN, Alexandra Waye, Los Angeles, CA, Nathaniel Waye Atlanta, GA, Painiya Waye, NC. Also 5 great-grands, Anderson "A.J.", Aubrina and Aviana Lane, Blythewood, SC, Noah Strickland, New York, NY and Siani Tompkins, Nashville, TN; brothers Randolph Stafford, Roslindale, MA, Jimmy (Queen) Stafford, and Edison (Pamela) Stafford, all of Georgetown, SC; sisters-in-law Joan Stafford, Braintree, Mass, Florence Downs, Everett, PA; brother-in law George Hull, Salisbury, MD; two special cousins Lila Mae Prout, Georgetown, SC and Leroy McKnight, Roxbury, MA; special friends Kermit and Phyllis Holliday, Stoughton, MA; and a host of nieces, nephews, loving relatives and friends, all of whom will miss her dearly and celebrate her life.

Dolores “Dee” Griner (nee Thomas) was born in Springfield, IL on July 11, 1927 and passed away on August 17, 2022 in Spring Hill, TN at the age of 95. She was the daughter of T. Dale and Gertrude Thomas of Centralia, IL. Dee graduated from Centralia Township High School before graduating from Lindenwood University with a degree in Home Economics.In a time where not many women were graduating from college and joining the workforce, Dee excelled in her studies and became an educator. She spent her career teaching students in Home Economics, Gifted Programs, and Special Education. She was an active member of the Philanthropic Educational Organization (PEO) Sisterhood, receiving recognition in 2016 for 50 years of membership. She served as chapter president on two occasions. Her husband was active in the Shrine and she served as the Potentate’s wife, which was a 10 year commitment. Through her work as a teacher, her volunteer contributions, and numerous cross country moves, Dee was able to positively impact many lives.Dee began sewing at the age of 10 and continued until her final years, making jackets that doubled as art pieces, quilts, and dozens of baby blankets that she gifted to family and friends. She was also an avid reader, a lover of classical and country music, and in her retirement years, a chardonnay enthusiast. If it was 3pm in the afternoon, you’d see Dee with a glass of white in her hand and the Hallmark channel on tv.Dee was fortunate enough to meet the love of her life, Jimmie “Jim” Neil Griner, in high school and spent 65 years by his side. Their love was deeply rooted in friendship and their simple, yet thoughtful acts like a newspaper section and coffee placed out in the morning served as a reminder that no matter how long you’re together, you need to put the effort in. Jim preceded Dee in death in 2016 after a long battle with Alzheimer’s Disease. The pair were inseparable in life and could not be separated by death itself, choosing the words, “partners in life and beyond” for their final resting place together.She is survived by her brother, Don, with whom she maintained a close relationship right up until her final days and her daughters Carolyn Hoyer and Vicki Matijevich, both strong women whom she was deeply proud of. One of her favorite titles during her life was ‘grandma.’ She was actively involved in the lives of her 4 grandchildren as they grew up by providing guidance on homework, sewing lessons, and root beer floats upon request. She is also survived by 5 great grandchildren and 3 granddogs (we don’t know if you count those, but Dee would have). Her legacy is carried on by the family that loves her.To leave a condolence or share a memory of Dee visit the Tribute Wall.To plant a beautiful memorial tree in memory of Dolores, please visit our Tree Store or plant a tree.

She returned to Panama City after she completed high school and later emigrated to the United States in the late sixties.She worked in healthcare for over 30 years caring for many patients during her time there.She was very devoted to her church community and family.Grace is survived by her children, Carl F. Scott jr., Katrina Scott Wilks, John Scott and Samuel Scott; seven grand-children, Amaiya Wilks, Samantha Wilks, Leah Scott, Caleb Scott, Norah Scott, Aaron Scott and Mila Scott; five siblings, Marva Martinez, Lilia Mora, Flora Brands, Esther Pilato, and Ruth Shoenfeld.Funeral Services will be held on Monday August 29, 2022 at 12:00noon at the Bensing Thomas Funeral Home, 401 North 5th Street, Stroudsburg.Burial will follow the service at 2:30pm in the Stroudsburg Cemetery, Stroudsburg.1 Peter 3:8 NIVFinally, all of you, be like-minded, be sympathetic, love one another, be compassionate and humble.“Ah, kindness. What a simple way to tell another struggling soul that there is love to be found in the world.”― Alison MaleeTo plant a beautiful memorial tree in memory of Grace, please visit ourTree Store or plant a tree.

Perry N. Davis, 74, Michigantown, passed away Wednesday, August 17, 2022. He was born March 24, 1948, in Frankfort, to Herbert and Naomi (Robertson) Davis.Perry was a 1966 graduate of Clinton Central High School. He went on to receive his Civil Engineering Degree from Purdue University in 1971. He worked at Doyne Crum Construction, then was owner of Davis Drainage Contracting, and then worked for Indiana Department of Transportation as an engineer until his retirement in 2013.Perry was a lover of horses. He bred, cared for, and raced quarter horses. He was a member of the American Quarter Horse Association, where he won New Breeder of the Year, and Indiana Quarter Horse Association.He is survived by his siblings, Cathy J. Davis, Steven (Katherine Constable) Davis, David Davis, and Carolyn Davis; nephew, Jason (Jill) Davis; niece, Jen Davis; and great-nieces, Jenna and Joy Davis.He was preceded in death by his parents and a brother, Phillip Davis.A Celebration of Life & Open House will be hosted by his Siblings from 8:30a.m.–6:30p.m. Saturday, September 17, 2022 at the Michigantown Lions Club-Alumni Community Center (MLC-ACC) located at 500-504 Ohio Street, Michigantown, IN 46057. Perry’s Siblings hope your schedule will be flexible and you can find a time to join us when able for morning coffee & rolls/donuts or some light lunch or afternoon cookies & milk or a happy hour toast to Perry (5:00-6:30p.m.) with finger foods. Flowers are always welcome, however in lieu of flowers—the Davis Siblings respectfully request that Memorial Donations may be made to any of the following: IU Simon Comprehensive Cancer Center for Pancreatic Cancer Research; The Building Fund Michigantown Lions Club-Alumni Community Center; Purdue University School of Veterinary Medicine Giving to Purdue Fessler Large Animal Surgery Residency Research Fund Endowment; Clinton County Humane Society. Also, the Davis Siblings wish to thank Genda Funeral Home, 608 North Main Street, Frankfort, IN 46041 for assisting the family with arrangements. Please share a memory here on Perry's obituary or https://clintoncountydailynews.com where you may leave a message for the family under obituaries.P.S. The MLC-ACC is formerly Perry’s Grade School and Home of the Ganders. As such, the day will be olden days low-tech “Show & Tell” so please bring paper photographs or photocopies so the items can be pinned to a tribute wall. The MLC-ACC has a ‘Museum Room’ full of historical photographs and memorabilia, plus, we will be in the restored ‘Gymnasium’ dating from 1924. Oh yeah--you might want to bring along a magnifying glass too!!To send flowersto the family or plant a treein memory of Perry N. Davis, please visit our floral store.

Thomas J. Rodgers, 80, of Auburn, died peacefully Wednesday, August 17th, 2022 surrounded by his loving family.Tom was born in Hudson, MA, one of six children of the late James and Gladys (Benjamin) Rodgers.In 1967, Tom started his career as a mechanic at Bercume Shell in Marlborough, MA, where he made many friends. He then went on to open his own service station and garage, both in Worcester and Auburn before closing them and starting a new career as a Maintenance Engineer for Fidelity Investments in Marlborough. He worked there for 15 years before retiring in 2012.He leaves his loving wife of 43 years, Susan E. (O’Connell) Rodgers; his daughters Kimberly E. Rodgers and Amanda M. Rodgers both of Auburn; eight grandchildren, Mackenzie M. Donahue of Auburn, Joseph, Nicole, Amber, J.P., Jesse, David and Jessica; his nephews, Michael and Daniel Rodgers; and his Australian Shepherd, Molly. Besides his parents, he was predeceased by five siblings, Mary, John, James, Robert, and William, as well as his daughter, Donna Rodgers.His family and friends will remember Tom for his work ethic - he was such a hard worker and was always willing to help anyone who needed it. He especially loved working with his hands, working on projects around the house, building and fixing things, and working on cars. Tom loved classic cars, most notably his 1965 Chevy Nova. Tom will be loved and missed by all who knew him.In lieu of flowers, memorial donations can be made to the American Cancer Society (www.cancer.org/donate).Relatives and friends are invited to visit with Tom’s family on Tuesday, August 23, 2022 from 5-7 PM followed by a prayer service at 7 PM at the BRITTON-WALLACE FUNERAL HOME, 91 Central Street, Auburn. Burial will be held privately in Hillside Cemetery, Auburn.

Nicholas P. Mazza of Shrewsbury, NJ, age 82, passed away at home on August 17, 2022 after a long illness.  He was predeceased by his parents, Philip and Kathryn (Figaro) Mazza.  He attended Red Bank and Shrewsbury grammar schools and Red Bank High School graduating in 1958,  New York Institute of Photography, RCA Institutes - Basic Electronics Correspondence Course 1968, and Brookdale Community College - some business courses.He worked at Hospital Portrait Service, Red Bank, NJ, during his high school years to 1975.  He then studied and became a locksmith, later buying his own company named Acme Locksmith Service most recently located in Oceanport.  He joined The Master Locksmiths Association of New Jersey, Inc.  He served on the Exhibit Committee for the Association Convention and the Committee to Rewrite the By-Laws of the Association.He served in the U.S. Army Reserve, Army Security Agency for six years with Top Secret Cryptographic Clearance.He was a member of the Red Bank Volunteer Fire Department serving in various capacities including Captain and after 38 years he became an exempt member.He enjoyed volunteering as a Shrewsbury youth baseball, soccer, and basketball coach for 13 years.He is survived by his wife of almost 60 years, Loretta (Sinclair) Mazza, son Geoffrey P. Mazza, brother John A. (Jacqueline) Mazza, nieces Jessica Mazza and Christine Levesque, brother-in-law Herbert J. Sinclair (Alexandra Hahn), niece Jodi (Sinclair) Gardner, husband Erik and sons Jackson and Mason, and numerous cousins, nieces, and nephews.No services are planned.

Alejo Garcia passed away peacefully at his residence in San Antonio on August 17, 2022. He was born on January 30, 1929, in San Antonio, to Jose and Maria Garcia. Alejo is now reunited with his loving wife of 70 years Asencion Garcia.Alejo married Asencion in1952 and together they had four children. He is survived by his daughters, Rebecca Flores (Johnny) and Rita Campos (Gilbert Fuentes), son, Reyne Garcia, Grandchildren, John Flores (Barbie), Jacob Flores (Shandra), Bianca Reyes (Manny), Benjamin Fuentes (Melody), Justin Garcia, Gracie Garcia, and Rebecca Garcia; and 15 great-grandchildren. Also, by his favorite Sister-in-law Irene Delacruz, numerous, nieces, nephews, and loving friends.Alejo was preceded in death by his son, Ralph Garcia, and his granddaughter, Sonia Flores, and all his brothers and sisters.Mr. Garcia proudly served in the United States Navy. He then joined the United States Post Office as a mail carrier for the downtown area of San Antonio. He worked there for many years until his retirement. Mr. Garcia was a wonderful father and loved to coach for his children in sports. He was a self-taught “Jack of All Trades”. He was always ready to help anyone that needed him. He had many friends and was well-loved. He loved to play golf. He played every chance he got and if you were looking for him, he was either playing golf, fishing at the coast, or watching any sports he could find on TV.The family would like to thank the nurses from Trinity Hospice Care. Patsy Jo Pimlott age 78, of St. Lucas, IA, died Sunday, April 30, 2023, peacefully at her home.A private family graveside service will be held at a later date.Hugeback Johnson Funeral Home and Crematory in New Hampton has been entrusted with arrangements. Online condolences for the Pimlott family may be left at www.hugebackfuneralhome.com.641-394-4334Born on February 9, 1945, in Waverly, Iowa, Patsy was the cherished daughter of Bert and Marlys Maloy. She will be deeply missed by her family and friends who were touched by her gentle spirit, creative mind, and love for life.Patsy's interests were as varied as her talents. A lover of travel, she enjoyed exploring new destinations and immersing herself in different cultures. Her passion for reading allowed her to experience countless adventures within the pages of her favorite books. Patsy also found solace in gardening, where she could nurture and care for the beautiful plants and flowers that brightened her days.Above all else, Patsy cherished the time she spent with her family and friends. Her gentle spirit and loving nature brought comfort and joy to all who knew her. Patsy was the type of person who could make anyone feel at ease, and her warmth and kindness will be remembered by all who were fortunate enough to have known her.Patsy Jo Pimlott will forever be remembered as a loving mother, grandmother, sister, and friend. Her gentle spirit, creative mind, and unwavering love for her family will live on in the hearts of those who were blessed to know her.Patsy was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Dave Pimlott, and her dear son, Thomas Pimlott.She is survived by her loving children, Ken and (Shelley) Pimlott of Nashua, Carol (Ward) Hamann of Eldridge, and sister Linda and (John) Estes, College Station, Texas. Patsy was a proud grandmother to Ethan, & Grace Hamann, and Courtney and Lucas Pimlott. She also has three great grand children, Destiny Pimlott, as well as Angel and Trey Gentry. Her grandchildren will always remember her for her unwavering love and support.

Beverly Kersnick South, 96, passed away Monday, July 8, 2013, of heart failure after a short illness. Graveside service: 10 a.m. Saturday in Greenwood Memorial Park. Visitation: 5:30 to 7:30 p.m. Friday at Greenwood Funeral Home. Memorials: In lieu of flowers, please make donations to American Lung Association, P.O. Box 470773, Fort Worth, Texas 76147; American Heart Association, 2630 West Freeway, Suite 250, Fort Worth, Texas 76102; or Humane Society of North Texas, 1840 E. Lancaster Ave., Fort Worth, Texas 76103. Beverly was born June 23, 1917, in St. Joseph, Mo., to Nina and Ira Kersnick. She graduated from Stripling High School (before it was Arlington Heights High School), class of 1933. As she raised her children, she was president of the PTA and a room mother for both of her children. In addition, Beverly modeled for Meacham's and The Fair department stores. She went to work at the Fort Worth Neiman-Marcus store when it opened in 1965 and was recruited by Stanley Marcus and Tom Barnett, manager of the store. She enjoyed her position there as top salesperson until her retirement in 1980. Beverly was president of the Junior Woman's Club from 1950 to 1951 and executive director to the Junior Woman's Club from 1958 to 1961. Beverly was an active member of the Fort Worth Woman's Club and charter member of Beaux Arts. The Bevey Award, an award named in her honor, is presented annually to the most outstanding member of the Junior Woman's Club. For many years, she personally presented the award. Beverly was also a member of Ridglea Country Club, Ridglea Garden Club, The Petroleum Club and numerous bridge clubs. Beverly was the epitome of a "Lady." Everyone adored her, her humor and quick wit. She was preceded in death by her parents, Nina and Ira Kersnick; sister, Vyra Everett; and the love of her life, Joe M. South Sr. Survivors: Son, Joe M. South Jr.; daughter, Sheryl South Walker; and grandson, Christopher Lowe Walker and wife, Michelle.

Ann Nancy Sharpe of Newtown died on Friday, March 21, 2014 at Holy Redeemer Hospital.  She was 57.Nancy grew up and lived in Levittown before moving to Newtown 3 years ago.She worked at U.S. Steel in the Coke works for several years before beginning her career as a certified nurses assistant at Buckingham Valley Nursing Home where she was employed for 20 years.Nancy will be lovingly remembered as a caring person who was always ready and willing to take care of anyone at any time but her greatest accomplishment was being a loving mother to her pride and joy, Caitlin.Nancy was the daughter of the late Joseph D. and Rosemarie F. (Cannon) Sharpe.She was the devoted and beloved mother of Caitlin M. Drews and was the loving sister of John J. Sharpe (Marla) of Pittsburgh, PA and Dan J. Sharpe (Debra) of Saylorsburg, PA.She will also be missed by her nephews Joseph, Michael and Bryan; her niece Erin and many close friends and extended family members.Family and friends are invited to attend her funeral mass on Thursday, 10 a.m. at St. Joseph the Worker Church, 9172 New Falls Rd., Fallsington where friends may call from 9:30 until the time of the mass.In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Colon Cancer Alliance, 1025 Vermont Ave, NW, Suite 1066, Washington, DC 20005.

Maria Elena Romero (Nena) Lee, age 83 years & 6 months of Nashville, TN passed away on April 27, 2016 unexpectedly.Nena was born October 5, 1932 in Julimes, Chihuahua, Mexico; a small agrarian community, to parents Jose Luis Romero and Maria Severa Quintana. She was the seventh of ten children. She met her future husband, Don Lee, in El Paso, Texas and was married in 1963.Ms. Lee is preceded in death by her parents, her husband, and six of her brothers and sisters.Ms. Lee is survived by her son, David Lee (Jan Cortelyou Lee); grandchildren Seth and Matthew, of Raleigh NC. Additionally she is survived by an older brother, Andres Romero (Juarez, Mexico ); a younger sister, Enriqueta Rivas (Chihuahua, Mexico) and younger brother, Lupe Romero (Wichita Falls, TX), and a small host of nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews.After moving to Nashville, she worked for the Standard Candy Company, the maker of King Leo peppermint sticks and GooGoo clusters. She then entered and graduated from the Hassler Barber College in 1970 and ultimately became part of the Unique Barber and Style Shop. She cut hair in downtown Nashville, first in the Exchange Building and then the First American Center, for over 35 years.Ms. Lee was a devoted and active member of the congregation of the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Nashville for over 50 years. In addition to the Church, Ms. Lee gave tirelessly of herself and her time to various groups over the years, in particular groups assisting with international families that made the move to Middle Tennessee from abroad.A Memorial Mass will be held at the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Nashville on Saturday June 11, 2016 at 10 am. A small reception will follow in the Fleming Center adjacent the church. A second memorial service will take place in Chihuahua Mexico the following week.In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to the Ladies of Charity or the Legion of Mary at the Cathedral of the Incarnation.

Howard Wilson "Sonny" Berry, July 22, 1940 - April 27, 2016.Sonny was the son of the late Lawrence P. Berry Sr. and Alma Talley Berry.  He is also preceded in death by his brother, Wayne Berry. He is survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Betty Lego Berry; his children, Jeffrey S. Berry and wife, Birgit, Kevin Berry and Melissa Berry Merritt and husband, Robert "Sparky"; grandchildren, Joey Merritt and wife, Amy, Felicia Berry and Savannah Merritt, his brothers, Lawrence Berry Jr. and wife, Debbie, Charles Berry and wife, Nancy; sister-in-law, Helen Berry; and his aunt, Reba Talley.He was retired and loved working in his shop and gardening. He loved playing darts and corn hole with family and friends and was always willing to help family with repairs and home improvements. He is much-loved and will be missed.

Obituary for William Jack Hale | Morton Chapel favorite_border Donations Pledges library_books Back to Home Page William Jack Hale September 18, 1941 ~ June 4, 2018 (age 76) William Jack Hale, age 76 of Linn, passed away Monday, June 4, 2018, at his residence. Jack was born September 18, 1941, in Jefferson City, a son the late Frank Hale and Bernice Fern (Wilson) Hale. Jack was a 1959 graduate of Linn High School where he excelled as a basketball player. On October 28, 1994, he was united in marriage to Judy Crowe in Linn. She survives of the home. Jack owned and operated JR's Tavern, Jack's Tavern, and U-Save Grocery Store in Linn. He also sold cars for Knollmeyer Auto Sales, drove a dump truck and worked as a crop adjuster. He was a member of the Linn Masonic Lodge and enjoyed fishing, hunting, cooking, camping at the Osage River with family and friends, watching Cardinal Baseball and Mizzou Basketball, and spending time with his family, especially his grandchildren. In addition to his spouse of 23 years, Jack is survived by: five sons, Scott Hale and his wife Maryann of St. Louis, Shane Hale and his wife Donna of Albuquerque NM, Curt Hale and his wife Lori of Columbia, Craig Hale of Las Vegas, NV, and Craig Russell and his wife Megan of Linn; one daughter, Renzi Russell of Holts Summit; three sisters, Peggy Singer of Jefferson City, Carol Sloan and her fianc? Dollie M. GatewoodZanesville - Dollie M. Gatewood, 92 of Zanesville, died 8:20 PM, Friday, February 15, 2019, at Genesis Morrison House Hospice following a brief illness. She was born Wednesday, November 24, 1926, in Zanesville, the daughter of Edward Gatewood, Sr. and Erma (Young) Gatewood and was a member of Trinity Evangelical Lutheran Church. Dollie was born, raised, and resided in Norval Park until her death. She lived her entire life in the home next door to her birth place. The youngest of seven children, Dollie enjoyed working in her yard, cooking, and playing the piano. She had a great sence of humor and was known for her out spoken opinions. Dollie was a Typesetter with the Times Recorder for many years, but will be best remembered as the lady at the meat counter with the bright red hair. She began her career at Powell's Market, worked at Kroger and retired from Mr. Moneysworth (Pick & Save).Dollie is survived by two nieces: Charlotte (Willard) King of Zanesville; Peggy Stouffer of Cincinnati; one nephew: Jerry (Eliza) Gatewood of Stuart, FL; nine great nieces & nephews; seventeen great-great nieces & nephews; one great-great-great niece and many friends including: Cheryl Smith of Zanesville.In addition to her parents, Dollie was preceded in death by two sisters: Helen Basford and Dorothy (Bob) Becker; three brothers: Bernard Gatewood, Leonard (Lee) Gatewood and Donald Gatewood; one infant brother: Edward L. Gatewood, II; two nephews: Ronald Basford & Douglas Gatewood and one great nephew.Graveside Services for Dollie will be held 10:30 AM, Thursday, February 21, 2019, at Woodlawn Cemetery, 548 Pershing Road, Zanesville, with Pastor Howard Thompson officiating. Memorial contributions may be made to Trinity Evangelical Lutheran Church, 122 South Seventh Street, Zanesville or Genesis Morrison House Hospice, 713 Forest Avenue, Zanesville, Ohio 43701 in Dollie's memory. To sign the online register book or to send a personal condolence note please visit www.hilliscombsnestor.com

Brenda Jean Lindstrom - 1957 - 2021She left us too soon. Not of her own choosing, but as the result of a cruel disease. We are left with a gaping hole in our heart.Brenda Lindstrom, 63, passed away March 24, 2021, after a valiant struggle with lung cancer. She is survived by her husband, John "Q" Lindstrom, her daughter, Vanessa (and husband, Tom) Bridges, her brother, Scott (and wife, Char) Butler, her nieces, Lindsay Jones and Channing Butler; her “earth-mom”, Bobbie Butler, her grandchildren, Chase Bridges and Seth (and partner, Emily Heckenlaible); her great grandchild, Jesse Mendez-Garcia; and a host of family and friends, many of whom were able to be with her in her final moments. Brenda was conscious and aware until the end, surrounded by friends and family expressing and receiving love and embraces.Brenda was born to Jules and Roxie Butler in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Jules served with distinction in World War II, and later in Korea. Roxie hailed from a large Catholic family. She instilled the love of laughter, loyalty and pride of their Irish roots deep into Brenda’s soul. Brenda met her future husband, John “Q” Lindstrom when she was a Technical Sargent at the 934th Tactical Airlift Group in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Q was a C130 Pilot in the Air Force Reserve. They both were involved in support missions in the 1980’s and 1990’s. Brenda and Q were married in 1986, and raised their daughter, Vanessa, in Wayzata, Minnesota. They later moved to South Dakota in 2003, where Brenda served for a time as the Whitewood City Finance Officer.Brenda is remembered for her talents in photography, creative crafting of jewelry and cards, and even a mastery of the ancient game of Mahjong. She loved games of all kinds, especially the ones she found in Deadwood. Throughout the years, she volunteered her time and talents in developing and helping in programs. She assisted the Wayzata Booster Club by directing a talent show called “Off the Wall,” raising thousands of dollars for Wayzata High School Sports. Once in South Dakota, she continued her generosity by reviving Whitewood Bingo for the senior center. In all her endeavors, she was an energetic inspiration to those around her.The family would like to give a special thanks to Northern Hills Hospice and the wonderful angels who have stood by our side.In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations in Brenda’s honor be made to Monument Health Hospice of the Northern Hills.Brenda will be interred in a private service (due to Covid restrictions), Monday, March 29 at Black Hills National Cemetery in Sturgis, SD.Until we meet again, may God hold you in the palm of his hand --Traditional Irish blessingTo plant Memorial Trees in memory of Brenda J. Lindstrom, please click here to visit our Sympathy Store.

Emma Louise Frye Hughes died on Sunday, December 5, 2021, at age 95. She was preceded in death by her parents, William A. and Anna Mae Kelley Frye, her husband Charles A. Hughes to whom she would have been married 75 years, her brother John Clark Frye, and her sister Dortha Frye Barr.Louise was born in Athens on November 7, 1926. She graduated at the top of her class from McMinn County High School and attended business college in Knoxville. She returned to Athens, where she worked at First Farmers Bank and became the first elected female Bank Officer and Bank Vice-President in the Athens area.Louise was a life-long member of North Athens Baptist Church, where she taught Sunday School, was an active member of the church’s music program, and held numerous offices in church leadership. She deeply loved her family and was known as a wonderful cook, who enjoyed preparing favorite meals at holidays, birthdays, and other special occasions until she was well into her nineties.She is survived by a daughter Phyllis and her husband Steve Byrum from Signal Mountain, and a son Alan and his wife Claire from Knoxville. She took great delight in her grandchildren—Philip Byrum and his wife Katie, Elizabeth Hughes Sigman and her husband Mark, Aaron Hughes and his wife Ashley, and Meredith Brown and her husband Sullivan—who all adored their “Mimi,” as did her 7 great-grandchildren, May, Charlie, Olivia, Tate, Braden, Adley, and Bradford.The family would like to express thanks to the staff of Morning Pointe Assisted Living and to Robin Muller, her special caregiver for several years.A private graveside service for the family will be held at Cedar Grove Cemetery in Athens, where she will be laid to rest alongside her husband, her parents, and other family members.In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Lung Association or a charity of your choice. Visit www.laycock-hobbs.com/obituaries/Louise-Hughes to share condolences with the family or any personal tributes to Louise. Laycock-Hobbs Funeral Home is in charge of arrangements.To plant memorial trees or send flowers to the family in memory of Louise Hughes, please visit our flower store.

John Carlos Santos was born on September 10, 1936 in Murtosa, Portugal. He was the oldest of two brothers born to Antonio and Maria. He passed away peacefully on December 5, 2021 after a courageous battle with Parkinson's disease.John emigrated to the United States at age 11 and was a graduate of Fairleigh Dickinson University with a Bachelor of Science degree. Athletically, he became the first All-American soccer player in FDU history. He still holds two NCAA men's soccer records: saves in a game and saves per game in a season. In 1960, he was drafted into the Army where he proudly served his beloved country. After graduation and his service he went to work for Nabisco, then spent the rest of his long career as an executive at AT&T Bell Laboratories until his retirement in 1994.John is survived by his wife of 58 years, Felicidade, his three sons and daughters-in-law: John and Jacqueline, Dave and Roberta, Ken and Cristina, and his beloved 11 grandchildren, Natalie, John III, Graydon, Brooke, Benjamin, Riley, Jack, Antonio, Victoria, Cristian, and Tea. Also surviving is his brother Anthony and sister-in-law Alcina, and his sister-in-law Eliza and brother-in-law Rick DiOrio. He also leaves behind many nieces, nephews, friends and family members. Pop Pop, as he was known, was a great husband, dad, grandfather, son-in-law, uncle, nephew, coach, fan, and friend and will be greatly missed by many.Visitation will take place on Friday, December 10 from 3-7 pm at the Thompson Memorial Home, 310 Broad Street, Red Bank, NJ. A Funeral Mass will take place on Saturday, December 11 at 10 am at the Church of the Nativity, 180 Ridge Road, Fair Haven, NJ. Burial is private. To honor John's legacy, please take the time to go watch your grandchildren, children, nieces, nephews, or neighbor's children play a sport and cheer them on just like Pop Pop would.In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

The man, the myth, the legend was called to Heaven on Thursday, August 18, 2022. Wayne loved salt and pepper and he put both on everything he ate to “give food some taste” along with cheeseburgers that we referred to as hockey pucks because they were burnt to a crisp. Although he would joke about hating old people, small children and dogs; anyone that had the honor of calling him a friend knows that those are the 3 groups that flocked to him without hesitation to bask in his unwavering kindness.This mountain of a man lived a life that would give any Hollywood movie script a run for its money. From breaking both arms at the same time in a Waggener High School football game and proudly serving his country in the Vietnam War, to singing in a band that opened for the Rolling Stones and racing motorcycles and cars (well past his prime), Wayne lived life to the fullest. He also opened his own small business in Middletown, announced all of the Eastern High School football and basketball games for 20 years and was an active member of the Wilderness Rangers.But the greatest love of his life (and no, not his 47 Oldsmobile) was his wife of 52 years. Wayne and Debbie demonstrated what it meant to love unconditionally without fear. All the laughter and joy shared together throughout the years were the rewards for their incredible devotion to their marriage.Surrounded by family, friends and loyal dogs, Wayne is survived by his wife Debbie, his son Eric (Tonya), his daughter Courtney (Jamie), four grandchildren that were the center of his world, JD, Grayson, Eleanora and Maggie and his brother John (Wanda). His celebration of life will take place Saturday, August 27 at Ratterman’s Funeral Home in Middletown, Kentucky. The visitation will be held from noon to 3:00 immediately followed by the service at 3:00. In lue of flowers, the family ask that you make donations in his name to the Shamrock Pet Foundation, Inc.

Irvin, Jr., Barlow Irvin Jr., Barlow, insurance agent and rancher, passed away at age 82 on Friday, October 26, 2012 at McKinney Medical Center. Barlow was in the insurance business where he spent 25 years working for AAA as an agent. He then opened his own insurance agency in the Dallas area. A San Antonio native, Barlow was born on September 28, 1930 to Hazel and Barlow Irvin, Sr. Both parents came from South Texas ranching families with ancestors who resided in Texas when it was a republic. Barlow graduated from Alamo Heights High School in San Antonio in 1948. He went to Schreiner College in Kerrville, Tx where he participated in football and track. After graduation from Schreiner College he served in the US Army in Germany during the Korean War. After serving our country, Barlow went to SMU where he met the love of his life Bobbye Hughes and received a Business Degree in 1955. After graduation, he and Bobbye were married for 57 years where they spent much time enjoying each other while traveling. He was active as an adult at Highland Baptist Church, where he volunteered his time as the track and basketball coach. He also attended Prestonwood Baptist Church and Stonebriar Community Church in Frisco. Barlow will always be remembered for his easy going, gentle and kind personality. He had many passions in life, Dallas Cowboys Football and Texas Aggie Football, but none more than the love he had for his children and grandchildren. He is preceded in death by his wife Bobbye Irvin, his parents Barlow Irvin and Hazel Irvin, and his brother John Irvin. He is survived by his children Barlow Irvin III, Barry Irvin and Sherry Ruckman, grandchildren Chris Ruckman, Lee Ruckman, Allie Irvin, Alana Irvin, and Brittany Henderson, great grandchildren Marin Ruckman, Luke Henderson and Cassidy Henderson; and his niece Kathleen Loughlin, nephew Charles Irvin and sister-in-law Kathleen Walo. Funeral services for Barlow will be held on Friday, November 2, 2012 at 11am in Restland Memorial Chapel. A reception will be held following the service. Visitation will be on Thursday, November 1, 2012 from 6-8 pm at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, memorial may be made to Texas A&M Association of Former Students: Barlow (Bones) and Hazel Irvin Scholarship Fund, 505 George Bush Dr. College Station, TX 77840.
Burial arrangements under the direction of Crest Lawn Memorial Park.

Obituary Romera Elan Henderson was born to Wesley and Marion A.Henderson on November 15, 1965 in the Bronx, New York. She was preceded in death by her mother.Romera was a talented young woman with a blessed spirit and voice, which music and singing was her life at what she studied while in high school. Romera was 15 when she performed at the great Carnegie Hall in N.Y. Romera which she was so proud of her accomplishment. She graduated from Murray Bergtraum High School in New York then moved to Miami, Florida in 1987 where she attended Miami Dade College where she studied African History & Business Communication at Barry University. Romera became a very prominent leader and speaker for the Black Student Union at Miami Dade College. She changed the name of the organization to African American Student Union. She joined the Yoruba Culture in the late 90's; and studied in the house of Ile Ife in Miami where she then became known as Asabi. In November 1997 she elevated her spirit within the Yoruba culture and was initiated to the Orisha Oshun. As her understand of the culture developed as an active priestess she took on the role of a padrina (God mother) to many and later earned the name Omisoore. She enjoyed being with her children & family, traveling, cooking, Bembes, and making her African attire.  She leaves to cherish her memories 5 children Ajike Harrison(Michael), Omodunbi Harden, Ogunlana Harden, Adeniyi Harden, Rukiya Harden, 4 sisters Yolanda Dash, Nikia Kennedy, Joanna Brown, Tunisia McClan, 2 brothers Howard and Shawn Dodson, 2 grandchildren Brandon and Kiyiomi Harden, and a host of nieces, nephews, and cousins.
Arrangements under the direction of Kuehl-Nicolay Funeral Home, Paso Robles, CA.
Arrangements under the direction of Cypress View Mortuary, San Diego, CA.

Date of Death: February 16, 2019Date of Birth: October 10, 1928Jack, age 90, passed away peacefully on February 16, 2019 with his family by his bedside. Born in Lancaster, PA. to Lucile Johnson and JohnJ. Evans, Jr. where he lived until moving to New York City to begin his career in banking at the Hanover Bank.Jack graduated from The Lawrenceville School, where he was captain of the 1946 Eastern Interscholastic Championship Swimming Team. Aninvitation to Noreen Blakeley to attend the School's senior prom eventually led to a marriage that lasted 67 years. Graduating from Wesleyan University, he was President of his fraternity and Business Manager of the University newspaper. Graduate School of Banking (Wisconsin) and studies at N.Y.U. and Harvard Business School followed.Activated with the New York Air National Guard, he served during the Korean War, and upon deactivation received a direct commission, continuing as an officer of the New York Air National Guard.Jack's entire career was with the Hanover Bank and its successor, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., now a part of J.P. Morgan. He retired as a Vice Chairman of the Board of Directors of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co.Jack served as: Trustee, Depository Trust Co.; Trustee, National Genetics Foundation; financial responsibilities at the diocesan and parish levels, Long Island Episcopal Church; Trustee, Huntington Hospital, N.Y.; Trustee, Sons of the Revolution, N.Y.; Trustee/Treasurer, Society for the Preservation of Long IslandAntiquities; Director of the Computer Museum, Boston.In 1990, the Evans moved from Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. to Yarmouth, Maine. In retirement, Jack was involved in a number of not-for-profit institutions including: Trustee/Interim Director, Portland Museum of Art; Trustee/Interim Director, Victoria Mansion; Trustee, Southern Maine Agency on Aging, where he concentrated on planning and executing A Better Day Facility in Scarborough. A founder, he served as President and C.E.O. of Maine Care Life Community Inc. from 1994 to 2001 during the planning and building of Piper Shores. From 2001 to 2006, he held the office of Chairman. He was a Corporator and member of the LegacySociety of Maine Medical.During the summer, the Evans family camp on Squam Lake, N.H. provided the base for the annual get together with the senior Evans, their three children, Anne, John and Elizabeth, five grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Then there were the years of cruising and racing (member New York Yacht Club) as well as many travels abroad. Not to be forgotten was Jack's active collecting and restoration of early American Antiques.A memorial service will be held at a later date at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Yarmouth.Gifts in Jack's memory may be sent to Portland's Victoria Mansion or Southern Maine Agency on Aging.

Linda Louise Sullivan Hood., 73, of Austin, Arkansas died Sunday, July 12, 2020 at her home. Lin, as known to family, was born in Porter, Alabama to Imogene (Black) Sullivan and R. L. Sullivan. Linda met and married the love of her life, Edward Eugene Hood on September 6, 1962. She held a career in cosmetology until becoming a full time mother in May 1979. Linda was a devoted member and leader, helping direct children’s church at the Church of God of Prophecy in Hammond, Indiana. In May of 1988 Linda walked the stage with honors to graduate from Purdue University with a major in education.Linda and family relocated to Austin, Arkansas in the fall of 1990 where she began her teaching career and encouraged each student to set goals and chase dreams. She was loved and valued, not only, by her students but also her peers. Linda retired from the education field in 2007 to care for her mother. Through her retirement she enjoyed planting flowers, shopping, tea with her sisters, road trips with her husband and any moments that allowed for a memory with family. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Edward Eugene Hood, her mother Imogene Sullivan-Taylor, father, R. L. Sullivan, bonus father, L. F. Taylor, one sister, Patsy Sullivan, two nieces, Kalena Billingsley, Maria Tuttle, and many other loved ones.Linda lovingly leaves behind one daughter, Jennifer Lynn Hood-Fields and husband Jeremy, one granddaughter, Taylor Marie Lynn Benton and husband Matt, one grandson Jeremy Cash Fields, two great grandsons, Fletcher Hayes, Beau Edward Benton, three sisters, Mary White, Barbara (Kenneth) Billingsley, Debbe (Leon) Johnson, a sister-in-law, Diane Hood-Holmes, and many nieces, nephews, and extended family. Graveside funeral services are 10:00 am Wednesday, July 15, 2020 at Cotton Plant Cemetery by Garth Funeral Home of Des Arc. Bro. J. D. Eddins officiating. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Jude.

Kathleen Calvo Schulte, 63, of Easton, PA passed away on Thursday, March 25, 2021 at St. Luke’s Hospice House in Bethlehem, PA due to complications from Multiple Sclerosis, embolisms in her lungs, and pneumonia. Kathy struggled with MS for over 40 years and was strong throughout, always pushing forward and doing her best to work through her disease. Born in Allentown, Kathy was the daughter of Ruth (Zimpher) Calvo and the late Rocco Calvo of Bethlehem. She was the wife of David Schulte and would have been married for 30 years on May 25th. Kathy graduated from Moravian College in 1979 with a B.S. in computer science and worked as a software developer/administrator at AT&T/Lucent/IBM for over 20 years. In high school and college, she enjoyed riding her horse TR, playing oboe in the Freedom Band & Fife Core, and participated in Freedom Band’s 50th reunion in 2017. She was also a member of the Nazareth Moravian Church, participating in the Nazareth Moravian Orchestra. In 2005, Kathy and Dave adopted the best gift they ever received, their daughter Bethany, who is now 17. Kathy was so very proud of Bethany. In spite of her MS, Kathy took Bethany to hangouts with friends, summer sessions at the public library, and attended all her school events. Kathy especially loved watching Bethany play in the Easton Area Middle School and High School bands. Bethany was Kathy’s everything and she loved her more than words can say. Kathy will be lovingly remembered by her husband, Dave, daughter, Bethany, mother Ruth Calvo, brother, Rocky Calvo and wife Marianne, sister, Lois Calvo, nieces, Larisa Calvo, Amy Folk and husband Drew, and nephew, John (Rocky) Calvo and wife Maggie, as well as all of her riding friends and friends from school/work. Kathy did not want a viewing, so there will be a private burial held at the Nazareth Moravian Cemetery. A Celebration of Life Service will be held at the Nazareth Moravian Church at a future date when COVID-19 concerns are no longer an issue. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to the National MS Society 1251 N. Cedar Crest Blvd. Allentown, PA 18104, or the St. Luke’s Hospice House c/o Development Office 801 Ostrum St. Bethlehem, PA 18015. Send online condolences to . Our family wants to thank everyone for their thoughts and prayers during this most difficult time and extend to you a blessed Easter celebration.

Diane passed away unexpectedly after a brief illness on Thursday, March 25, 2021. Age 71 years.She was born October 24, 1949 at Saginaw General Hospital to Russell E. Simons and Molly P. (Kirby) Simons. She graduated in 1967 from Chesaning High School and immediately started her career at age 17 at the Saginaw ISD, retiring after 35 years.Diane was known for her quick wit and enormous volume of valuable advice, joking often about “hanging out her shingle.” She enjoyed meditation, her Namaste group, researching her ancestry, crosswords, music, trivia and especially her day trips with family. Diane traveled to England many times with her mom (her homeland) and throughout the U.S.She was never hesitant to help anyone, often driving friends for appointments and errands. One of her favorite quotes was, “Money is just numbers on paper and is only valuable when in the hands of those who need it.”Diane is survived by her siblings, Deb (Gary) Tanner, Garry (Melanie) Simons, Dennis (Michelle) Simons, and Jason Simons; nieces and nephews, Jolene (Tim) Bester, Mark Harding, Melissa (Scott) Seamon, Stacey Simons, and Ashley Simons; her honorary daughter, Gretchen (Matt) Lough and granddaughters Kathryn and Maggie Lough; 7 stepsiblings, (The Pendell Clan), and many friends. She was predeceased by her father Russell, mother Molly, stepfather David, and nephew John Harding IV.Funeral service will take place at 3:00 p.m. on Monday, April 5, 2021, at W. L. Case and Company, 201 N. Miller Road. Pastor Karen Sorden will officiate with cremation to follow. Friends may visit with the family on Monday from 11:00 a.m. until the time of service. In lieu of flowers, be kind to someone. Our precious memories are now our greatest treasures.In accordance with the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services ordinance, indoor capacity is limited to 25 persons, face coverings are required, and social distancing encouraged. We appreciate everyone’s efforts to reduce the spread of covid-19 in our community.

Doris Schaefer died peacefully on March 25, 2021 at the age of 91. Her family and friends in the United States and Switzerland will deeply miss her vivacious, generous spirit.    Doris was born on May 25, 1929 in Heiden, Switzerland. Because her father, Ernst Marti, was a Methodist minister, her family had an itinerant lifestyle, moving every few years to serve congregations in various towns in the German speaking part of the country. Her mother Rosalie was a devoted pastor's wife, helping her husband in his ministerial work, cooking meals at large extended family gatherings, while also finding time to play the harmonium in church. Doris was soon joined in the Marti family by sisters and brothers: Mich, Dan, Ruth, and Theo.   As the eldest child, Doris took wonderful care of her younger siblings – teaching, admonishing, and loving them. Her sister recalls how Doris managed her father's rabbit hutch in the garden, feeding and talking to the rabbits while carefully protecting the vegetables and flowers with netting. During the resource-scarce war years Doris was heartbroken when her charges began to go missing, only to wind up on the dinner table – she refused, of course, to eat the rabbit stew.   Doris always loved music and was an accomplished young recorder player. She performed in her school orchestra, several times as a soloist, and the whole Marti family would proudly attend her concerts.   During Doris' childhood years, young people living in German speaking Switzerland were obliged to spend a year in the French speaking cantons in order to learn the language. Doris went to Lausanne where she worked as an au pair. The experience gave her the opportunity to travel abroad as a teenager – working as an au pair, baby nurse, or house sitter and other jobs in London, New York, Miami, and Chicago. She was always much appreciated and loved by the families she stayed with.   When she returned to Switzerland after her overseas adventures, she worked as an elegant receptionist and secretary for Graphis, a graphic design magazine, at its Zurich headquarters. While working at the prestigious publication she met and befriended many artists and writers.  While in Zurich, Doris also met a young American doctor visiting Switzerland from his station at a US Air Force base in Turkey. Robert Schaefer had in fact made the long trip with a secret purpose in mind: to marry the lovely and eligible Doris. He was acting on a tip he received from an Air Force colleague, Ron – who had recently married Doris' sister Ruth. Bob's attempts to woo Doris were not always on the mark. For example, Bob had acquired a pair of traditional Austrian lederhosen, which while fashionable in some German speaking regions of the Alps were not in vogue at the time in Zurich. Doris, the urbane young woman from an international design magazine, was unmoved by his sartorial display. But Bob was persistent, staying with the Marti family for weeks during his frequent visits to Switzerland, making their home his headquarters for explorations of Europe. Eventually, Doris was charmed by the intrepid Alpine hiker and the two were married in Winterthur in February 1962. Their honeymoon travels included a visit to her sister and Ron in the Middle East.  Doris and Bob moved to Palo Alto for a few years, to complete Bob's medical residency at Stanford, before finally settling in Seattle. Doris enthusiastically immersed herself in Seattle life, finding many ways to engage with the community.  She was active in Plymouth Church where for years she provided the flowers in the sanctuary every Sunday.  She was a dedicated volunteer at Mary's Place, the only women's shelter active in Seattle at that time. Doris loved socializing and would frequently get together with French speaking friends and expatriates to happily converse in the language. Over the years she also fostered, and sometimes adopted, many needy cats from the Seattle Animal Shelter. Doris and Bob were both for many years devoted fans and dedicated supporters of Seattle Opera. Doris loved to contribute as a volunteer driver for visiting musicians and frequently hosted opera luminaries at her house.   Although Doris became a naturalized US citizen and adapted to her new country's culture during her sixty years here, the Swiss girl from Winterthur was always there. She never failed to honor her homeland's National Day on August 1st with a party for Swiss expats on the balcony of her Magnolia home. The setting was decorated festively with lampions and candles, and a giant Swiss flag, visible even to passing ships in Puget Sound, hung from the railing. She kept up old traditions like lighting her Christmas tree with real candles, although one year the tree ignited, leaving a scorched ceiling and an indelible memory for her young niece and nephew from Tacoma. Her Brätzeli – thin, intricately decorated Swiss cookies, made on a special imported waffle iron – were coveted by all who knew her. When Doris' family and friends from Switzerland came to visit, their suitcases would always be stuffed full of the thing they knew she craved - bars of Shoggi, genuine Swiss chocolate. And in another touching connection late in her life, Doris' brother-in-law Erich called her every week from the town of her childhood, holding up the phone so she could hear the familiar peals of the church bells of Zofingen. Her crisp Swiss accent never lost its lilt during her six decades in America.  Doris and Bob were intrepid travelers, making trips to far flung destinations like China and Antarctica when those places were still far off the beaten path.  Most of all, Doris will be remembered by her loved ones for her warmth and charm. She was full of energy (in spite of the Seattle gloom, when she preferred sunshine) and seemed to be in action nonstop. She loved visits from family: although she had no children of her own, she cared for her nephews and nieces, both in the US and Switzerland, with infinite kindness and patience. Indeed, throughout her life Doris was a family linchpin: she loved throwing magnificent Thanksgiving and Christmas parties at her house and hosted a steady stream of visitors from Switzerland and all parts of the world. Doris was elegant but down to earth, funny and honest. She touched many people during her life and her passing leaves a large empty space but also wonderful memories.   In her final years Doris' health suffered with the effects of stroke and dementia. But she was cared for lovingly by Bob. He took over the cooking, played music for Doris and read to her, often poetry. They were separated when Bob succumbed to Covid on March 25, 2020, and it seems fitting that Doris passed away on the same day as her companion of 58 years, one year later.    Doris will be remembered fondly by her brothers, Dan and Theo, her sister Ruth, and by her extended family, including the Becks in Seattle and Denver, the Martis and Scholls in Switzerland and the Schaefers and Abrams in Boston and Raleigh.

FLOYD MARTIN ROSE1933 - 2007Floyd Martin Rose, age 74, of Pensacola, Florida passed away Friday, November 23, 2007. Floyd was born on July 17, 1933 in Winter Haven, Florida. He joined the Army at a young age. During his stint, he gained experience as a M.P., which would prepare him for his career as a life long law enforcement officer. In December of 1956, Floyd joined Escambia County Sheriff's Department as a radio operator. Over the next 45 years, he proudly served the people of Escambia County. His exceptional leadership abilities led him to his final role as Chief Investigator. He would command many units, such as homicide, major crimes, narcotics, swat team, street crimes, as well as marine patrol, mounted patrol and air ops. When Floyd retired in 2001, he left with the rank of captain and the reputation of being a man's man and a cop's cop. Floyd also fulfilled his civic duties through such organizations as the York Rite, Hadji Shrine Temple and the Oriental Band.Preceding him in death was his father Charles Rose; mother, Bernice Took; stepfather, Rubert Took; sisters, Evelyn Barnett and Alma Hartley Charbonneau. Survivors include his wife, Rosemarie Rose; sons, Floyd M. Rose Jr. (Martha) and Wesley R. Rose; stepchildren, Laura M. Allison (Shayne), Michael L. Rivers (Lisa) and Nikki Johnson (Robert); grandchildren, Justin Rose, Ashley Wood, Daniel Wade, Gorden Wade, Shayne Allison Jr. Elizabeth Allison, Shannon Allison, Leah Allison, Erin Johnson and Olivia Johnson; three great grandchildren; and his longtime best friend, Steve Dunn.Funeral services will be held on 10:15 a.m. Thursday, November 29, 2007 at Faith Chapel Funeral Home North-Cantonment with the Reverend Don Neese officiating. Interment will follow at Barrancas National Cemetery. Serving, as pallbearers will be the Escambia County Sheriff's Office Honor Guard. Honorary pallbearers will be Fran's Over The Hill Gang and all law enforcement officers.In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Covenant Hospice or charity of your choice in Floyd's name.The family will receive friends at the funeral home from 9:00 am until 10:00 am with services starting at 10:15 am.Special thanks to Dr. John Bray and staff of Pensacola Lung Group, The VA clinic especially Dr. Ruth Mills and staff, the staff and doctors at the Joint Unit of Sacred Heart as well as the staff of Covenant Hospice and to Dr. Henson and his staff for years of care. FAITH CHAPEL FUNERAL HOME North, 1000 Highway 29 South Cantonment is in charge of arrangements.

Shirley Ann Shelley July 8, 1952 - June 9, 2013 Shirley Ann Shelley of Eugene died Sunday, June 9, 2013, at the age of 60 of complications related to diabetes.  Shirley was born July 8, 1952, in Eugene, Oregon to Vi & Herb Koller. Out of college, she married Mark Hepner, with whom she had a daughter, Sarah. They divorced in 1980, and Shirley later married Bruce Shelley on August 24, 2002 in Eugene, OR.  Shirley graduated from Willamette High School in 1970. She worked as a medical transcriptionist at Sacred Heart Hospital and was a member of Eugene Christian Fellowship Church.  As a teenager, Shirley was diagnosed with juvenile diabetes, and eventually was faced with the challenge of needing a kidney/pancreas transplant. Thanks to a generous organ donor, at the age of 47 Shirley received a double transplant. Later, Shirley became a spokesperson for organ donation.  Shirley is survived by her husband, Bruce; daughter, Sarah Trice (husband Rick); grandson Gunnar Trice; Father, Herb Koller (wife Beth); brother, Mike Koller, as well as many other beloved family members. Her mother, Vi, preceded her in death.  Shirley was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother and friend who loved spending time with her family on vacations in Maui, Hawaii and working side by side with her husband Bruce in their glorious garden. Her thoughtfulness, kindness, quick wit and giving spirit will be greatly missed.  A celebration of Shirley's life will be held at her home in August. Contributions can be made to Donate Life Northwest in Shirley's memory. By Mail - PO Box 532 Portland, OR, 97207 or online at - www.donatelifenw.org
