Jan. 14, 1944 – April 30, 2020Cheryl B. Schrader, a physical education teacher and longtime ticket center manager at Kissing Bridge, died April 30 under hospice care in her home in Glenwood after a battle with lung cancer. She was 76.Born Cheryl Norris in Burlington, Vt., she was a 1962 graduate of Clarence High School, where she was president of the Girls' Leaders Club, which worked with the physical education program, and was a member of the Swimming Club and Water Ballet.She earned a bachelor's degree in education in 1966 from Brockport State College, where she was a member of the synchronized swim club.She was a physical education teacher at Griffith Institute High School in Springville from 1968 to 1972. She coached synchronized swimming, organized water shows and was an adviser to the cheerleading squad."She said many times that the breath control she learned in synchronized swimming extended her life for the last year and a half," her daughter-in-law, Bethann Schrader-Giancarlo said.Looking for a seasonal job after the birth of her son, Mrs. Schrader began working in the ticket center at Kissing Bridge in 1973 and within five years became its manager.As the ski area grew, she also oversaw operations of ski rentals, the ski school and group sales."That ticket center really is the heart of Kissing Bridge," her daughter-in-law said.She retired in 2017.She was an avid softball player and an accomplished golfer and bowler. A dedicated Buffalo Bills fan, she and her husband were season ticket holders in the team's early years.She was deeply involved with her grandson and his step-brothers, accompanying them to their first day at school every year and attending their hockey, lacrosse, soccer, baseball and football games."She was the grandparent on the sidelines," her daughter-in-law said. "She was either yelling at the ref or telling people why the referee was right. She was a great advocate for the boys. If her boys played a sport, she loved it."She and her husband, David L. Schrader, a retired diesel mechanic and driver for Southern Erie Construction Co., were married in 1968. Their son, Scott, died in 2005.In addition to her husband, survivors include a brother, Brett Norris; a grandson and two step-grandsons.A memorial service will be held at a later date.

Richard "Riko" J. Alcock  March 18, 1965 - Feb. 3, 2022  AUBURN - Richard "Riko" J. Alcock, 56, of Auburn passed away Thursday, February 3, 2022, at Auburn Community Hospital. Riko was born in Auburn on March 18, 1965, the son of Virginia Hanna Sternberg and the late Richard "Dick" Vadala. He was employed at Parkers Express before working many years at McQuay. Rik was a member of the SK American Legion Post 1324 and a member of their Sons of the American Legion. Rik is survived by his wife of 31 years, "Moley" Donna (Hribick) Alcock; his mother Virginia; sisters: Amy Capone and Debbie Clark; several aunts, uncles; cousins; nieces, nephews, great-nieces, great-nephews; and his two special girls Julie Lewis and Emily Mead; numerous friends including Pete, John, Donnie and Chris. He also leaves behind his and Moley's cat Beatson; and his special dog, Sophie. Rik was a friend to everyone and a thoughtful giving person. He was known by some as the "Candy Man" leaving candy at the doors of others; a surprise treat to let them know they were thought of. Services will be held Saturday, February 12, 2022 at 2:00 PM at the SK Post, on State St. with Rev Matthew Binkewicz, officiating. Immediately following the services there will be a Celebration of Rik's Life at the SK Post, until 6:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Rik Alcock may be made to the Finger Lakes SPCA of CNY, 41 York St., Auburn NY "Rik you will be Forever in our Hearts". Arrangements with White Chapel Funeral Home, Inc, 197 South St., Auburn. To offer condolences to the family please visit www.whitechapelfh.com.

Charles A. Gilmore, 83, of Harrisburg, died after a long illness on April 16. Mr. Gilmore was born September 23, 1919 in Columbia, SC, to Arthur William and Rose Amelia Scott Gilmore. He was preceded in death by his sister, Jacqueline Cooper and brother, David William Gilmore. Mr. Gilmore earned a B.S. in Public Administration from Temple University in 1949 and a M.G.A. from the Wharton School in 1960. His career of government service began as a training officer for the City of Philadelphia from 1957-1962. He then helped create and implement the Manpower Program, first in Albany and later in Washington, at the U.S. Dept. of Labor. As Manpower Training Specialist and Chief, Mr. Gilmore was responsible for the development and oversight of all Manpower programs in the nation. In late 1967, he returned to Philadelphia and joined the senior administrative staff of the community college, where he helped initiate and advance the commuity college movement in Philadelphia, including suggesting and completing the acquisition of the Old Mint as the permanent site of the Philadelphia Community College. He continued on assignments in Harrisburg with the Dept. of Community Affairs and the Dept. of Education, functioning as liaison and ombudsman for two-year institutions and four state-related universities until his retirement in 1982. He continued to work in education as a private consultant for over a decade. Additionally, he served as a Trustee to HACC from 1987-1994, was Treasurer and Vice-President of the Board of the PA Federation of Community College Trustees. He served on the Board of Trustees and as interim President of Thaddeus Stevens State School of Technology in Lancaster. Mr. Gilmore has been recognized for his contributions to higher education as a recipient of the HACC Founder's Day award and was awarded a Doctorate of Public Service by Thaddeus Stevens. Mr. Gilmore was also named a Paul Harris Fellow by Rotary International.  Lt. Colonel Gilmore served on active duty during World War II and the Korean Conflict and served stateside during Vietnam. While in Basic Training, he founded and conducted a school for illiterate soldiers. He was one of the first graduates from Officers Candidate School at Fort Benning in 1942. Mr. Gilmore was a longtime member of Lakeside Lutheran Church, and he served on its administrative council. He was director for Multi-cultural ministries of the Lower Susquehanna Synod and was on the Board of Directors for Tressler Lutheran Services for two terms. Mr. Gilmore is survived by his wife, Josephine; their children, Martha and J. Andrew; sons, Charles Jr. and Michael; five grandchildren and a great-granddaughter. Mr. Gilmore will have a private military funeral at Indiantown Gap National Cemetery. Memorials may be made to Lakeside Lutheran Church, 245 Division Street, Harrisburg, PA 17110. www.pennlive.com/obits

Anna May Hollenberg Loving mother, avid runner, tireless volunteer  Longtime Redlands resident Anna Hollenberg died on December 20, 2014 at her home in Mount San Antonio Gardens in Claremont after a short illness. She was 85.   She was born in Los Angeles in December 1929 to Carl and Ruth Hoglund and raised in Alhambra. She graduated from the University of Redlands in 1951, where she met and married John Leland Hollenberg. After stints in Berkeley, Hawaii, Fullerton and Claremont, the couple moved to Redlands where Lee was a chemistry professor for 28 years.  Mrs. Hollenberg was a gifted runner and trained with the Loma Linda Lopers for many years. She completed the Los Angeles Marathon 10 times, winning her age group five times and placing in the top three every time. She also competed in shorter races and received over 100 medals. She was active in the American Association of University Women and the University of Redlands chapter of the Alpha Sigma Pi sorority.  She was very generous and supported many causes. She donated blood regularly and volunteered for Meals on Wheels for many years. She will be greatly missed for her love, thoughtfulness, kindness, warmth and sense of humor.  Anna was preceded in death by her sister, Melba Hawkins. She is survived by her husband of 63 years, Lee; by her daughter and son-in-law, Sandra Hollenberg and Bill Daub of Claremont; by her sons, John Hollenberg and Dave Hollenberg of Los Angeles; and by her sons and daughters-in-law, Stan Hollenberg and Molly Kellogg of Portland, Oregon and Jim and Linda Hollenberg of Redlands. She also leaves her sisters-in-law and brother-in-law, Marion Hollenberg of Hillsboro, Oregon, Donna and Darrel Taylor of Claremont and Anne Derfer of Redlands; her nieces and nephews, Carla and Jim Robertson of Twisp, Washington, Susan Hollenberg of Austin, Texas, Mike and Kim Hollenberg of Amarillo, Texas, Kristin and Reggie Reed of Woodland Hills, Scott and Laurel Taylor of Encinitas, Karen Derfer of Redlands, Greg Derfer of Geneva, Illinois and Brian and Jesi Derfer of San Diego; her grandchildren, Eric Daub of Memphis, Tennessee, Brian and Ginger Price Daub of Livermore, Michael Daub and Taryn Rathbone-Daub of Redmond, Washington, Mary Beth Daub of Irvine and Tommy and Clark Hollenberg of Portland, Oregon, as well as and twelve great nieces and nephews.  A memorial service will be held Saturday, January 24 at 1:30 p.m. at the United Church of Christ Congregational, 233 Harrison Ave. in Claremont. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Robert and Beverly Lewis Cancer Center at Pomona Valley Hospital Medical Center.

Henry August Widdecke Jr., a devoted husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather, died peacefully Thursday evening, Aug. 26, 2010, during his 94th year after a long and rewarding life. Service: Military honors will be held at 9 a.m. Wednesday, Sept. 8, in Dallas-Fort Worth National Cemetery, with religious services officiated by the Rev. Dr. William Longsworth of First United Methodist Church of Fort Worth. Those wishing to attend should arrive at the cemetery no later than 8:45 a.m. Memorials: In lieu of flowers, consideration of expressions of sympathy may be given to Broadway Plaza at Cityview, benefiting the Assisted Living area, 5301 Bryant Irvin Road, Fort Worth, Texas 76132; First United Methodist Church of Fort Worth, 800 W. Fifth St., Fort Worth, Texas 76102; or a charity of one's choice. Born in Bryan on Jan. 10, 1916, Henry was the son of Henry A. and Josephine F. Baker Widdecke. He married Rogerina W. Clay on Aug. 20, 1940. They lived happily for more than 60 years before Mrs. Widdecke's death in 2001. Henry served in World War II as a lieutenant commander in the U.S. Naval Reserve. Following the war, he worked at the Federal Reserve Bank and then moved to Kansas as an officer of First National Bank of Kansas City. In 1953, he moved to Fort Worth joining the then-Fort Worth National Bank as an officer, retiring from Texas American Bancshares in 1981 after a very successful career. Mr. Widdecke served as chairman on the Merit System Council and as a board officer for several corporations and schools. He had been an active member of First United Methodist Church of Fort Worth, serving on its board and as chairman of the Commission of Finance. He was preceded in death by his parents, wife and brother, Maj. Gen. Charles F. Widdecke. Survivors: In addition to his daughters, Suzanne Widdecke Miller and her husband, Gary, of Fort Worth and Pat Widdecke Hermans and her husband, Tony, of Poolesville, Md., Henry is survived by his granddaughters, Nancy Toombs of Pine Hall, N.C., and Karen Hinkson and her husband, Marco, of Poolesville, Md.; and great-grandsons, Blake and Trent Hinkson.

English, Ann Marie DrachlerAnn Marie Drachler English, 86, died May 5, 2013 at Elizabeth Church Manor in Binghamton, NY after a long illness. The widow of Peter C. English, she was born the fourth daughter of the late William and Edith Bourgarde Drachler on April 24, 1927, in Greene, NY, where she was a lifelong resident. Before starting her family, she was employed briefly at the Lyon-Raymond Corporation and then served as church secretary at Zion Episcopal Church for many years. Ann was an avid knitter, creating sweaters, baby shawls and afghans but her greatest accomplishment was knitting over 200 special Christmas stockings for family and friends through the years, causing many to hope she had drawn their name for Christmas. She also had a great love for her garden, nurturing plants and flowers that had been grown from plants her mother had in her garden. She and her late husband treasured their dream home on a lake, where they lived for the past 35 years. She is survived by her son, Peter (Julie) English, Jr., Stow, OH; and daughters, Susan English Kaarlsen, of San Antonio, TX and Martha (Joseph) Pyles, of Lexington, KY. She is also survived by eight grandchildren: Karen Kaarlsen Cinelli, Kevin Kaarlsen, Shawn Kaarlsen, Elizabeth Barden Takacs, Cynthia Barden Gorman, Kathleen Barden Maloney, Jonathan English and Ketha English Earp; and 13 great-grandchildren: Noah and Chloe Cinelli, Jessica and Kevin Kaarlsen, Mollie, Mallorie and Gehryt Kaarlsen, Aidan and Madison Takacs, Genevieve, Elijah and Gabriel Gorman and CarrieElla Maloney. She was predeceased by a daughter, Carrie Lynne; a son, Timothy William; and son-in-law, Clarke Kaarlsen. In addition, she is survived by her brother, William C. (Carol) Drachler, and her brother-in-law, Paul (Sue) English all of Greene; a number of loving nieces and nephews and several cherished friends and neighbors. She was predeceased by three sisters, Elizabeth Learned, Grace Schlageter and Katherine Mueller. Cremation will occur followed by burial in Sylvan Lawn Cemetery. A memorial service will be held at a later date at the family's convenience. An announcement will be made of the time and place. The family would like to thank the Staff at Elizabeth Church Manor for the kind and loving care Ann received while a resident at their facility. It made being so far away easier for all of us. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 401 Hayes Ave., Endicott, NY 13760. Arrangements are under direction of Root Funeral Home 23 N. Chenango Street Greene, New York 13778 and condolences may be sent to the family at www.rootfh.com

Barbara C. (Thomson) Brady, a 59 year Bedford resident, died on June 14, 2011, at her home, after a courageous battle with cancer. She was born in Lynn, MA to Jessie and Alex Thomson on August 19, 1927. She was a talented artist, graduating from Vesper George School of Art, Boston in 1947. Early in her career she was a fashion illustrator for Chandlers and Filenes, as well as a gift wrap designer for various companies. She was employed by the Endicott Company and helped create the murals that hung in the Copley Plaza hotel for years. In her later years, she was employed and retired from MA-COM in Burlington, Mass. She was an active member of the Bedford Arts and Crafts Society, winning many awards over the years for her beautiful paintings. Using her artistic and seamstress skills, she was commissioned by the Mall of New Hampshire and the Pheasant Lane Mall to refurbish their holiday sets, bringing back to life elves, bears and clowns for the public to enjoy. In addition, as a longtime member of the Emerson Hospital Auxiliary Puppet Group, she designed the stuffed bear that they now distribute to the children in the pediatric unit. Barbara was a loving mother, nana, sister and friend. She found great pleasure in her last days loving her great grandchild, Alexa. She was married for 48 years to William G. Brady who passed away in 1997. She leaves her daughters Sandra Archer and husband, Fran of Marshfield, MA, Melinda Robinson and her husband, Gordon of Manchester, NH, a brother, Alex Thomson of Butler, PA, four grandchildren, one great grandchild, and many devoted relatives and friends. Her funeral was held recently from the funeral home on Monday, June 20, followed by a Funeral Mass in St. Michael Church, 90 Concord Rd., Bedford. Interment in Shawsheen Cemetery in Bedford.

Sr. Ruth Babineau, DHS 1923 - 2011 PUTNAM - Sister Ruth Babineau, DHS, 88, a member of the Daughters of the Holy Spirit died on Saturday, November 26, 2011 at the Holy Spirit Health Care Center where she has been in residence since 1999. Sister Ruth was born on December 14, 1923 in Palmer, MA, the daughter of the late Arthur and Alexina (Plouffe) Babineau. She entered religious life in 1940 and made her religious profession on August 20, 1945 at the Holy Spirit Provincial House in Putnam, CT. She was then known as Sr. Jeanne Arthur. Early in her religious life Sr. Ruth taught in elementary schools in Putnam, CT; Leominster, MA; Pittsfield, MA; and in Bridgeport, CT. She also served as dietician at Holy Spirit Provincial House in Putnam and at St. Clare Home, Newport, RI. In 1978, Sr. Ruth served as receptionist at the Provincial House until her retirement in 1982. Survivors include three brothers: Rev. Alexis Babineau, A.A. of Worcester, MA; Raymond Babineau of Belchertown, MA; and Joseph Babineau of Boynton Beach, FL; one sister, Marguerite Lussier of Charlton, NY and several nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grand-nephews. Calling hours at the Holy Spirit Provincial House chapel will be on Tuesday, November 29, 2011 from 6:00 to 8:00 PM with a Prayer Service at 7: 15 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday, November 30, 2011 in the Provincial House Chapel at 11:00 AM. Burial will follow at St. Mary's Cemetery, Putnam, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Daughters of the Holy Spirit Retirement Fund, 72 Church St. Putnam, CT. 06260. The Gilman Funeral Home has been entrusted with her arrangements. For memorial guestbook visit www.GilmanAndValade.com

HAMPTON - Edith F. Hellman, 91, died Saturday, April 3, 2010.Born in Onancock, she moved to the Peninsula at a young age and had been a resident of Phoebus since the 30's. A member of Emmanuel Episcopal Church since 1938, she was a member of the Jane Bryan Circle, and had held many positions, including serving as Choir Director. She worked as a clerk for Cooper's Department Store, retiring in 1985 after more than 30 years of service.Affectionately known as "Granny", she was the life of every party. She enjoyed being around people and loved to dance. Her favorite pastimes were gardening, sewing, crocheting, drawing and painting. Always in attendance at the Hampton Cup Regatta, there was always a seat reserved for her.Preceded in death by her husband, Carl A.A. Hellman Jr.; and her son, Carl A.A. Charles Vernon Selman1942-2017 Charles Vernon Selman, 75, died Monday, November 06, 2017 at Community Regional Medical Center.He leaves his wife of 53 years, Nancy (Machado) Selman; his daughter, Christine Ramsey; his grandsons Garret Jacobs and Colin Jacobs and his brother Wade Selman (Margaret). He was preceded in death by his daughter, Francine Selman and his parents, Cliff and Ila Selman.Charles was born in Monday, Texas on May 20, 1942, the son of Cliff and Ila (Wright) Selman. The family moved to San Luis Obispo, CA in 1945 and then to Jackson, CA in 1951. Charles went to Jackson High School where he played football, basketball, participated in drama and was in DeMolay. He graduated in 1960 and then entered the Military for 3 years. During that time he was stationed in Heidelberg, Germany. Charles and Nancy were married at Morris Chapel in Stockton, CA on August 08, 1964 and lived in Stockton throughout their marriage. He worked for Bank of America for three years and then the California Youth Authority, as a Correctional Officer for 28 years. He retired in 1997 and throughout retirement he and Nancy enjoyed traveling, square dancing, writing music, singing and playing the guitar.He was a member of the Masons, the Linden Lions Club, the Draggin Wagons Traveling Club, Head Turners Car Club and G.O.D. (Good Old Days - Youth Authority Retirement Group).A Celebration of Life will be held at the Lions Club, 5041 N. Market St., Linden, CA 95236 on Monday, November 20th at 11 am.Donations can be made to your favorite charity or to Terry's House in Fresno, CA It is a home away from home for the family of critically ill patients. Built in 2011 and funded solely on donations. Terry's house is a place where families can eat, sleep and recharge while their loved one are in the hospital).www.communitymedical.org/make-a-donation/where-to-donate/ terry-s-house/donate-to-terry-s-house

PHILO, LINDA LOU (JOHNSON) Linda Lou (Johnson) Philo, Thompsonville, 66, died May 8, 2014 at Spectrum Hospital. Born on Feb 23, 1948 in Muskegon, MI the daughter of Melford and Marjorie Johnson. Linda Lou loved Jesus. Her love for the Lord shined through her life and warmed all those she touched, especially her family. She was a devoted wife to Jerry for 42 years and a tender mother to Lorri, Stacey, Shannon, Wayne, Dee and Jerry Lee. Family was Linda's joy in life; anything that involved her kids, grandkids and great grandkids was her favorite thing to do. Linda smiled through many years of difficult pain, disease and family sorrows. She carried true Christian love, joy and peace throughout her life. Linda fought the good fight; she finished the race and she kept the faith entering into the presence of God. Her smile broadened when she was reunited with her parents and two beloved grandsons Justin Smith and Jacob Fekete. She is survived by her husband Jerry; children Lorri (Pat) Schneider;Stacey (Mike) Fekete, Shannon (Rob) Laffleur, Wayne (Lisa) Philo, Diane (Aaron) Babcock and Jerry Lee Philo; grandchildren, Jessica (Blake) Edinger, Jordan Fekete, Jared Fekete, Michelle Laffleur, Kalynne Philo, Jason Philo, Devlin Philo, Kristy (Brent) Taylor, Valerie (Paul) Muniz, Kurt (Jacky) Busard, Keri Schneider, Erica (Josh) Keech and Tyler Schneider; sister Karen (Barry) Kieft; numerous nieces, nephews and great grandchildren. Visitation will be on Tuesday May 13 from 6 to 8 PM at the Jowett Family Funeral Homes. Memorial service will be held at 11:00 AM Wednesday, May 14 at Eden Bible Church with Pastor Dan Ingersoll officiating. Burial will be in Thompsonville Cemetery. ERB, JOHN JOSEPH, JR. John Joseph Erb Jr., 68, formerly of Guilford, passed away peacefully on July 6, 2015 at Connecticut Hospice in Branford. His brothers Barry and Kevin were with him at the time of his death. Born on September 15, 1946 in Queens, New York, John, along with his 3 brothers, were moved by their parents John Sr. and Margaret Erb to Guilford in 1954. He went through the Guilford school system, where he was a very good student and athlete. John once scored 42 points in a junior high basketball game. He graduated from Guilford High School in 1965, where he played varsity basketball, baseball and soccer, being captain of the soccer team his senior year. Somehow, in his senior year, he found the time to join the Band and became an all-state drummer. John went on to attend New York University, where he graduated in 1969 with a degree in marketing. John had a love for music, especially jazz and the sea, once owning and living on a sailboat. His love for jazz came from his Dad and his uncle Fred Erb. Like his uncle, John would play the drums professionally for many years. John remembered some great childhood friends, Kenny DeMond, Dan Dolan, John Gibson, Bob Harding and Andy Crampton, just to mention a few. John was predeceased by his parents, his wife Terri, and his loving brother Dennis. He leaves his brothers Barry and Kevin, a nephew Ryan, and nieces Kerry, Taryn, Emily, Elizabeth and Erin. Also left are two special people in his life, Mark Petruzzello and Evelyn Coogan. John’s wish was that his remains be donated for research to the Anatomical Gift Program at Quinnipiac University. His wish was granted. Thank you Jim Casso for making that happen. A special thanks to the nurses and staff at Connecticut Hospice in Branford for their tender and loving care for John in his final days. In a handwritten note given to his brother Barry a week before his death, John wrote “The remaining days of my life are in the hands of some special people in a very special place” So true. God Bless everyone who works at Connecticut Hospice in Branford, a magnificent facility.

MAJ Richard R.N. Grubb, USAR, Ret., age 77, of Lower Paxton Twp., passed away on Tuesday September 15, 2015 at Penn State Milton S. Hershey Medical Center.  Born February 25, 1938, in Baltimore, MD, he was a son of the late Ernest and Louise (Lewis) Grubb. He enlisted in the US Army in 1965 and accepted an appointment in the Regular Army in 1966. Richard served two tours of duty in Vietnam, was stationed in Germany as well as stateside, and attained the rank of Captain; he retired from the US Army Reserve having earned the rank of Major. He accepted a position with the U.S. Government Supply Service Center in Perry Point, MD following his active military service. Prior to his retirement in 2003, he was responsible for directing shipments of medical supplies throughout the world.  Richard served on the Board of Trustees, and was a Gold Legacy Member, of the Shellsville VFW Post 9639. He was also a Life Member of the Vietnam Veterans of America (VVA) Capital Chapter #542 and the American Legion Jeff Davis Post #18 in Centreville, MD. A kind and thoughtful man, he possessed the unique ability to talk to anyone at any time. While he was known to be helpful to a fault, and inclined to step in to assist with any need, Richard always placed his primary focus on his family. He enjoyed gardening and cooking; and, never heard a joke - good or bad - he didn't appreciate and share. Throughout the past two years, even with increasing health concerns, he never lost his sense of humor. The next time you see a formation of geese flying overhead, think of him and smile.  In addition to his wife of 30 years, Patricia A. (Oberlin) Grubb, he is survived by four daughters, Carole Eisenstein of Mechanicsburg, Denise Ackley of Harrisburg, Jill (Jim) Walls of Virginia Beach, VA and Jodi (Bill) Schnoor of Middletown. He is also survived by seven grandchildren, Carl Gesell, Justin Carl, Luke Schnoor, Matthew Reed, Nathaniel Reed, Richard Reed III and Vanessa Carl; four great grandchildren, Jenna, Kamrin, Malia and Zachary; a niece, Elizabeth DePalma and nephew, Jonathan Fallowfield, as well as two great nephews and a great niece. He was preceded in death by his parents and two sisters.  A Service to Honor the Life of Richard R.N. Grubb will be held at 11:00 A.M. on Tuesday September 22, 2015 at the Jesse H. Geigle Funeral Home, Inc., 2100 Linglestown Road, Harrisburg, with Rev. Dr. Charles Hiller, officiating. Inurnment in the Columbarium at Fort Indiantown Gap National Cemetery, Annville, will follow with Military Honors. Relatives and Friends are invited to his viewing, from 6:00 to 8:00 P.M., on Monday September 21, 2015, at the Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that you remember Richard with a memorial contribution to Hospice of Central PA, 1320 Linglestown Rd., Harrisburg, PA 17110 or through their website at: www.hospiceofcentralpa.org Relatives and friends are invited to share memories and condolences with the family at www.JesseGeigleFuneralHome.com or on Facebook.  Arrangements have been entrusted to the Jesse H. Geigle Funeral Home, Inc., Harrisburg.

Raúl A. Baragiola passed away Sunday, June 21, 2015, in Charlottesville, Va.He had led a radiant and full life, led by his three passions, his family and friends, work, and love of learning.Raúl was born on March 31, 1945, in Santa Fe, Argentina to the loving family of Jorge and Apolonia Baragiola. His sister, Matilde and brother, Luis remained very close to him throughout his life, they saw each other frequently despite living in three different continents. While pursuing his studies, he met Beatriz, whom he married and intimately shared the remaining 46 years of his life with. Together, they dedicated their lives to their three children: Verena, Valeria, and Pablo. Raúl loved nothing more than spending time with them, their spouses, and his grandchildren - all of whom he regularly saw. They will most miss his glowing smile and sense of humor.His deep curiosity led him to a career in physics, which allowed him to direct his brilliant mind to the mysteries of the universe. Raúl was the Alice and Guy Wilson Chair and Professor of Engineering Physics and Material Science and he directed the Laboratory for Astrophysics and Surface Physics at the University of Virginia since 1990. Previously, he worked at the Centro Atómico in Bariloche, Argentina, where he also earned his PHD. Aside from the science, Raúl was a caring teacher, mentor, and active faculty member.That same curiosity also led him to a lifelong thirst for knowledge. Along with his wife, he frequently traveled the world trying to better understand it. He loved learning about philosophy, literature, history, music and countless other fields, which he would keenly share with all around him.A Celebration of Life will be held on Saturday, June 27, 2015, at 3 p.m. at Teague Funeral Home in Charlottesville, Va. The family will receive guests starting at 2 p.m.In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Foundation Fighting Blindness to benefit the research of retinitis pigmentosa.Condolences may be offered to the family at teaguefuneralhome.com

Virginia Elena Milner-Piggott- DeLeon went home to be with the Lord April 3, 2023. Born November 5, 1944, in Panama City, Panama to mom Violetta, father Ruperto, and sister Jean, all deceased.She was the mother of three children, Marshall deceased, and surviving daughter Magdalena, and son Michael. She was a proud grandmother of three grandchildren, Angelica, Michael, and Sierra. She also had family members all throughout the US and Panama.She had a great love for music of all genres, singing, and dancing, and was proud to have been a known singer in Panama in her youth. She received her masters degree from University of Panama, and throughout her life was a teacher, court interpreter, and University professor. She was also an LPN and caregiver who loved working with the elderly.Virginia Elena was a devote Catholic. She was greatly loved by her family, and will be missed always, and never forgotten.She is laid to rest at Seabrook cemetery in Seabrook, Texas.In lieu of flowers, donations in her name can be made to Alzheimer’s dementia research.

Richard J. Carolan, 64, of Rahway entered into eternal rest on Monday, Aug. 17, 2009, in his home, surrounded by his loving family.  Relatives and friends are kindly invited to attend the funeral service at the Evangel Church, 1251 Terrill Rd., Scotch Plains, on Saturday, Aug. 22, at 9:30 a.m. Interment will follow in Hazel Wood Cemetery, Clark. Visiting hours will be on Friday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. at the Walter J. Johnson Funeral Home, 803 Raritan Rd., Clark. To offer condolences or for more information, please go to www.walterjohnsonfh.com.  Mr. Carolan was born in Staten Island, N.Y., and resided in Roselle before moving to Rahway five years ago.  Mr. Carolan was a realtor for over 30 years, most recently with Weichert Realtors of Westfield. He was the former owner and broker of Carolan Real Estate and Appraisal Services of Westfield.  Mr. Carolan was a member of the New Jersey Realtors Association, the Greater Union County Association of Realtors, and the New Jersey Certified Residential Appraisers.  Mr. Carolan was a Royal Ranger scouting commander at Evangel Church for over 10 years. He loved to go camping with his children.  Mr. Carolan was the beloved husband for 25 years of Mrs. Cathleen (Colby) Carolan, and the devoted father of Bryan, Allison, Daniel, Matthew, and Christian. He was the cherished son of Mrs. Alice (Evans) Carolan, and the late Mr. Vincent Carolan, and the dear brother of Alice Kosten, Vincent Carolan, Kathleen Sheppard, Patricia Colangelo, and Michael, Joseph, and William Carolan.

Marian A. McCoy, 92, of Ecker Hollow Road, Town of Middleburgh, died Tuesday, April 7th, at Robinson Terrace Nursing Home in Stamford where she had resided since May, 2007. Marian was born July 20, 1916 in the Town of Seward, NY, a daughter of Stanley and Edith (Abrams) Osterhout. She had lived on Ecker Hollow Road since 1945 before entering the nursing home. A 1934 graduate of the former Cobleskill High School, Mrs. McCoy later worked at Fennimore Fabrics in Cobleskill as a machine operator. She also operated a rooming house for downstate children for many years. She was a former member of the Lawyersville Reformed Church and the former St. Andrews Reformed Church in East Cobleskill, along with the ladies guild. For many years, she was also active in the Sunday night bowling league at Schoharie Lanes. Marian was married to Earle C. McCoy on September 7, 1935 until his death on July 31, 1994. Survivors include one son, Kurt H. (Sandra) McCoy of Middleburgh; one sister, Shirley Shafer of Middleburgh; and two grandchildren, Amy Dejesus and Mark McCoy; along with several nieces, nephews, and grand-nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her siblings, Dewitt Osterhout, Gladys Vrooman, Dorothy Reynolds, Gertrude Koenig and Margaret Keller. A graveside service will be held at a later date to be announced at the Slate Hill Cemetery, Sharon. There will be no calling hours. Memorial contributions may be made in memory of Mrs. McCoy to Catskill Area Hospice, 327 W. Main St. Suite #3, Cobleskill, NY 12043. The Langan Funeral Home of Schoharie and Central Bridge and the Robert A. Guffin Funeral Home in Cobleskill are assisting the family with arrangements. Further information is available at www.langanfuneralhome.com.

NELSON, Irving T. - Of Davison, died December 15, 2010, age 79. Irving was born March 17, 1931, to Donald and Margaret Nelson, in Iron Mountain Michigan. He loved Michigan's Upper Peninsula and returned frequently throughout his life. Irving excelled academically, winning the state-wide competition for the Detroit Free Press Forensic Scholarship as a high school student. He was graduated with honors from Michigan State University (1951) and from Harvard Law School (1954). He served his country in the United States Army after law school. He then returned to Michigan to establish his law practice. On June 28, 1958, Irving married Sarah Jane Gwyn, of Flint. Together, they raised four children: Margaret, Jane, Thomas, and Patrick. He was a loving and generous husband and father. Irving possessed a formidable intellect. He read voraciously and was a knowledgeable and perceptive conversationalist in a wide variety of subjects. His interests included history, science, current affairs, sports, hunting and the stock market. He understood and appreciated good music, art, books, wine and food, especially chocolate. In addition to his scholarly pursuits, he was an avid hunter and fisherman; he shared his love for the outdoors with his children whenever possible. Irving was a skilled lawyer and an avid student of the law. He practiced law for over 50 years, primarily in Genesee County. His areas of practice included business law and securities regulation, personal injury, and general civil litigation. His clients benefitted not only from his legal knowledge and skills, but from his sense of humor and deep understanding of human nature. He represented his clients vigorously, but he would readily forgo a short term tactical advantage in the long term best interest of his client. He treated everyone involved in the legal process with courtesy and respect. Irving was a generous and loyal colleague, mentor and friend to many lawyers, judges, and others in the legal community. Irving was an ardent believer in the cause of social justice, belonging to many service organizations including the League of Women Voters, the Welfare Board of Flint and the Valley Area Agency on Aging. During his service on the Welfare Board, he was responsible for expanding the breadth of services to underserved populations, and in increasing the funding to those services from stage agencies. Among others, he was a generous supporter of the Southern Poverty Law Center, Habitat for Humanity and the Food Bank of Eastern Michigan. His survived by his wife, Sarah Jane Nelson, of Davison, his four children, Margaret L. Nelson of Chicago, Jane Marie Nelson of Lansing, Dr. Thomas Edward Nelson and wife Dr. Michele Acker of Columbus, OH and their two sons, Avery Thomas and Oliver Channing, and Patrick Allen Nelson and his wife Mellissa Hasler, MSW, of Flint. He is also survived by siblings Alice Brown of Wauwatosa, WI, Dr. Merlin A. Nelson of Iron Mountain, Donald Nelson of Bloomfield Hills, Carol Krautner, of Hartland Wisconsin, Mavis Powell, of Midland, MI, Norma Scolatti, of Des Moines, IA, The Honorable Allen J. Nelson, of Harbor Springs, and Patricia Nolf of Lake Orion, MI and many loving in-laws, nephews and nieces. He was preceded in death by his parents and by his sister, Katherine Gulash. The family will receive visitors between 4:00 and 7:00 p.m. on Sunday, December 19, at Hansen Funeral Home in Davison. The memorial service will be Monday, December 20, at Noon, at the funeral home. Those who wish to honor Irving's memory may make a memorial contribution to WKAR radio, of Michigan State University, in East Lansing, MI, or the Donald and Margaret Nelson Scholarship Fund, in Iron Mountain, MI, in memory and honor of his parents.

John Henry "Jack" GravesDr. John Henry Graves, 91, a resident of Tallahassee, Florida, passed away, at his home, on May 24,, 2015. John was born on May 11, 1924 in Pottstown, Pennsylvania to Russell and Melicent Graves and was known as Jack to family and friends. He and his wife, Marjorie, retired to Tallahassee in 1986 after residing in Southold, New York.John was a research veterinarian for the Department of Agriculture at The Plum Island Animal Disease Laboratory. His skills allowed him to travel the world in assisting other countries with developing anti-viral vaccines for their livestock.Survivors include three sons, John R. Graves (Peggy) of St. Paul, MN; Robert M. Graves (Sandy) of Tallahassee and Christopher S. Graves (Terry) of Tallahassee, his brothers Russell and Richard Graves, and his sister Joanna Kenyon. John had eleven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. John is preceded in death by his wife, Marjorie, his parents, his son Stephen M. Graves and his sister Susan Lathrop. A private family service will be held at a later date. Todd Wahlquist of Bevis Funeral Home, is assisting the family with their arrangements. 850-385-2193, www.bevisfh.com.

MEADOWS WINIFRED S. "WINNIE" MEADOWS, 91, of Parkersburg, WV, died Wednesday, Feb. 8, 2006 in the St. Josephs Hospital. She was born in Parkersburg, a daughter of the late John H. and Josephine Rector Simpson. She was a member of Trinity Episcopal Church where she served on the Alter Guild and was in charge of the church's food closet. She was a volunteer at St. Josephs Hospital for 25 years. Through the ancestry of Isaac Allerton, born 1586, and an ancestry in the Cooke family, Mrs. Meadows was a member of The Colonial Dames of America. She was a 1932 graduate of Parkersburg High School and attended Marshall University. Winifred participated in the Women's Air Service Pilot Training during WWII. She may be remembered as soloist at First Baptist and Trinity Episcopal Church and was a vocalist in the Old Coliseum Band for several years. She is survived by one daughter, Linda Steffancin (husband Kurt Overmyer) of Cleveland Heights, OH; one granddaughter, Jennifer Julia Steffancin of Brooklyn, NY; two grandsons, John Edwin Poole, currently a student at Hocking College, Nelsonville, OH, and William Arthur Poole, father of great-granddaughter, Madison Hope Szakacs; one cousin, Malvin Burt of Pomeroy, OH; and two nephews, John Cornell Simpson and Mark Hill Simpson and their families. She was preceded in death by her husband, Capt. Clay Everett Meadows, Jr., and one brother, John Hill Simpson. A memorial service will be conducted 11 a.m. Saturday, Feb. 11th, at the Trinity Episcopal Church, Par-kersburg, with The Reverend Larry D. Jackson and The Reverend Jack D. Nielsen officiating. Friends may call at the church ONE HOUR PRIOR TO SERVICES. Memorials may be sent to Trinity Episcopal Discretionary Fund, 430 Juliana St., Parkersburg, WV, 26101. THE VAUGHAN FUNERAL HOME, PARKERS-BURG, is entrusted with the arrangements. A guestbook is available for online condolences at: www.vaughanfh.com

Jeffrey "Willie" Wilson  Feb. 28, 1963 - Oct. 12, 2023  MONTICELLO - Jeffrey "Willie" Wilson, age 60, of Monticello, died at home surrounded by the love of his family on Thursday, October 12, 2023, after a battle with cancer. Willie was born on February 28, 1963 in Dodgeville, the son of Robert and Marge (Nankee) Wilson. He graduated from Hazel Green High School in 1981 and attended Southwest Technical College in Fennimore and later in life, Madison Area Technical College. Willie worked for Advance Transformer in Platteville, Harley Davidson in Menomonee Falls, John Deere Horicon Works, and most recently Sub-Zero Wolf in Fitchburg. He was an avid outdoorsman and sportsman. Willie loved hunting, fishing, bowling, his Harley and taking UTV rides. He will be deeply missed by his wife of 26 years, Cheryl Wilson; his daughter, Layla Hummel (Kevin Ward), all of Monticello; five grandchildren: Alaya, Brock, Jaydan, Harpar, and Hank. He is further survived by his brother, Joe (Jules) of Iron Ridge, WI; his sister, Janet Wilson (Tom) of Marion, IA; three step-sisters: Linda, Cheryl, Marilee; two step-brothers: Merlyn, Matt; many cherished nieces and nephews; and many close friends, old and new, who Willie considered family. He was preceded in death by his parents; step-father, Jim Baker; and a brother, Jay. With deep appreciation and gratitude, we thank our Hospice team, Kelly, Wendy, Joyce, Hillary and Clarice. We will hold you in our hearts always with love and respect. A celebration of Willie's life will be held on Thursday, October 26, 2023, at 1:00 p.m., at Washington Reformation UCC, with Rev. Kelly Volk officiating. Visitation will precede the service beginning at 11:00 a.m. In lieu of flowers, a memorial fund will be established in his name. The Newcomer Funeral Home, Monroe, is assisting the family. Condolences may be shared at www.newcomerfuneralhome.net.

ZELLA PRETZER  Zella passed away on Friday, February 25, 2005, due to complications from a stroke she suffered in 2001. Although the last three years were difficult, her remarkable strength, positive attitude and love of family remained constant. During that time she found comfort and new friends at the California Armenian Home, where she was also able to spend time with Arthur, her loving husband of 57 years, prior to his passing in September 2003. Zella was born on April 27, 1917, to Joseph and Mary De Luca, the youngest of three brothers and three sisters. She was raised in West Fresno's Old Italian Town and graduated from Edison Technical High School. She loved athletics and following her graduation she became a star player for a locally sponsored semi-professional baseball team prior to WW I. She loved spending time with her brothers and sister, be it work or play. Being the youngest still at home she lovingly assumed the responsibility with her sister Rose, of taking care of her mother following a stroke she had until her passing in 1952. It was during this time that she met Arthur and they started their life together. They were married on September 7, 1946, and had two children, Judy and Michael. Zella was proud and steadfast, quiet and selfless and what she couldn't fix with love, hard work, sacrifice, or sheer will she would turn to her Catholic faith, and her love and belief in God. The daily praying of her Rosary can only be assumed by her family as having a positive affect on each of their lives. The daily example of her boundless love, unselfish and forgiving kindness, and true caring will not be forgotten by her family and friends. Zella was a devoted daughter, sister, wife and mother. Among the many domestic talents she had, cooking, baking and gardening made her a superb homemaker. The daily recipients of her loving affection and support was her departed husband Arthur; daughter, Judy Smith and her husband Tim; son, Michael Pretzer and his wife Kimberley; and until her passing, her sister, Rose De Luca with whom she shared a lifelong friendship. She never hesitated to extend herself to all her brothers and sisters, their spouses, numerous nieces and nephews and their families. She took delight in the presence of children and they loved her in return. There was no equal as a Grandmother in the eyes of her granddaughter, Jennifer Foster and her husband John; granddaughter; Erin Smith; grandsons, Jeffrey Pretzer and Ryan Smith. With the addition of her two great-grandchildren, Lindsey and Christian Foster, Zella relished in having new little ones to spoil, teach and nurture in her traditional loving ways. Visitation will be held at Whitehurst, Suillivan, Burns and Blair, on Tuesday March 1, 2005 from 2:00 to 7:00 p.m. Recitation of the Rosary and a Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Sacred Heart Catholic Church in Fresno on Wednesday, March 2, 2005, at 10:00 a.m. Interment will follow at Fresno Memorial Gardens. Please send remembrances to the California Armenian Home for the Aged, 6720 E. Kings Canyon Rd., Fresno, CA. 93727. WHITEHURSTSullivan, Burns & Blair Chapel1525 E. Saginaw 227-4048

TOMAIN, Robert (Bob) Francis Born October 5th, 1941 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and was the oldest of three children. Graduated from Yale University and received an MBA from Georgia State University. Married Marlene Galket also of Pittsburgh in 1963. After serving four years as a captain in the Air Force, he began a life time career in the mortgage lending industry culminating in becoming CEO and Chairman of Home Federal Savings & Loan in Atlanta and HomeBanc, which became the largest home lender in the Metro area. Under his leadership, innovative concepts were introduced to the industry. Ultimately, Home Federal became the first Savings & Loan in Georgia traded on NASDAQ. After the successful sale of the company he held several board of director positions with local financial institutions. In 1996, he ran with the Olympic torch for the games held in Atlanta. He is survived by his wife of 52 years; his three daughters, Leslie Tomain, Robin Shelley, Shelley Taylor and six grandchildren (all within the Atlanta metropolitan area); and his sister, Nanci Tomain of Pittsburgh, PA. He is preceded in death by his parents, Frank and Doris (Broz) Tomain and his brother, John Tomain. Mr. Tomain passed away at Emory's St. Joseph's Hospital in Atlanta on August 1st, 2015. He will be remembered for his generosity, outspoken honesty, caring for those he deeply loved and singing his version of Blue Moon. The family is honoring his request for a private memorial service. Donations may be made in his name for cancer research at donate.cancer.org

Elvira Phelomenia Zimmerman was born October 8, 1913, the daughter of John and Martha Appel Wilwerding. She died Monday, December 17, 2007 at her home in Denison, Iowa at the age of ninety-four years, two months and nine days.Elvira was born on a farm east of Earling, Iowa where she lived with her parents. She attended St. Joseph Grade School and the Earling High School. On February 18, 1936, Elvira was united in marriage to Edward J. Zimmerman at the St. Joseph Catholic Church in Earling. The couple made their home on the Zimmerman farm south of Buck Grove. At home on the farm, Elvira enjoyed the hard work of gardening both flowers and vegetables. They were members of St. Joseph Church in Buck Grove. Elvira was very active in the church, especially with the Altar Society.In 1974, they retired from farming and moved to Denison. She was a member of St. Rose of Lima Catholic Church, their Altar Society, the Catholic Daughters of America and the Legion of Mary. Elvira began her career as a caretaker and housekeeper for the priests of St. Rose in Denison and continued in that position until her retirement in 1999. During her tenure at St. Rose of Lima she enjoyed caring for the altar linens at the church. She enjoyed entertaining her family, especially her grandchildren. In her leisure time she enjoyed bus trips, playing cards and Bingo.She was preceded in death by her parents; her husband, Edward in 1979; six sisters, Jean Kobold and her husband, Bill; Viola Foreman and her husband, Joe; Sister Misana; Tillie Bauman and her husband, Oscar; Lena Zimmerman and her husband, Rudy; and Sister Adelvina, and three brothers, Carl Wilwerding and his wife, Irene; Henry Wilwerding and his wife, Lavira; and Pete Wilwerding and his wife, Clara. Survivors include five sons, James Zimmerman and his wife, Ferdonna of Manilla; Julius Zimmerman and his wife, Sharon of Allentown, New Jersey; Gerald Zimmerman and his wife, Sue of Panora; Delbert Zimmerman and his wife, Detta of Charleston, South Carolina; Larry Zimmerman and his wife, Anna of Sioux City; three daughters, JoAnn Martens and her husband, James of Manning; Thelma Kenkel and her husband, LaVern of Denison; and Anita Hansen and her husband, Leonard of Exira; twenty-two grandchildren and twenty-two great-grandchildren; many other relatives and friends.Mass of Christian Burial was held at 10:30 A.M., Thursday, December 20, 2007 at the St. Rose of Lima Catholic Church in Denison, Iowa. Celebrants of the mass were Fr. Paul Kelly and Fr. Edward Murray with interment at the St. Rose of Lima Catholic Cemetery. Jean Cornelius provided the service music for soloist, Craig Kenkel and the St. Rose of Lima Choir. Eucharistic ministers were: Marilyn Pollack and Joan Gray; Lectors: Christina Kellogg and Larie Martens; Gift Bearers: Rachael Zimmerman and Megan Kirkpatrick; Servers: Hannah Brus and Mackenzie Freese. A Legion of Mary Rosary was held at 4 P.M. Wednesday, with a Vigil Service at 6 P.M. Those serving as honorary pallbearers were: Laura Zimmerman, Christina Kellogg, Mary Zimmerman, Sherri Hansen, Jenny Logan, Lisa Kirkpatrick, Brenda Croghan, Nancy Reynolds, Sheila Plunkett and Vickie Hanson. Pallbearers were: Matthew Zimmerman, Steven Zimmerman, Doug Zimmerman, Randall Martens, Richard Martens, Mark Kenkel, Aaron Zimmerman, Keith Zimmerman, Jack Zimmerman, Ryan Martens, Craig Kenkel and Mike Kenkel. The family invited everyone in attendance at the service to join them in fellowship and lunch at the Parish Center, served by the Altar Society. The Huebner Funeral Home in Denison was in charge of arrangements.

LEXINGTON%%Cecil Joseph Wessinger, 67, passed away on January 7, 2007, at the Palmetto Richland Heart Center surrounded by his family and friends as he held and rubbed his grandbaby’s foot. Born on October 6, 1939, in Columbia, he was the son of the late Henry Cecil Wessinger, Sr. and Mable Yates Wessinger.  He enjoyed hunting, fishing, and telling tall tales, stories, and jokes to family, friends, and acquaintances.  Mr. Wessinger was a lifelong resident of the Columbia-Chapin-Lexington area and a member of Mt. Horeb Lutheran Church.  He was veteran of the United States Army, a member of the SC National Guard, and attended the University of South Carolina.  Mr. Wessinger retired from the City of Columbia Fire Department following 27 years of public service.  Since 1980, he was a shriner with the Jamil Shrine Center where he participated in parades and activities in the Choo Choos Unit.   Mr. Wessinger was a member of the Dutch Fork #402 Masonic Lodge, of the York Rite, of Local 793 Union with his fellow firefighters, and of the SC Firefighters Association.  He was a loving husband, father, brother and grandfather who will be dearly missed.            Surviving are his wife, Anne S. Wessinger of Lexington; daughters, Cecilia Jo Anne Wessinger Hill and her husband, Tommy J. Hill, Jr., of Chapin, Regina Kelly Jo Wessinger of Columbia; brother, Henry Cecil Wessinger, Jr. and his wife, Janie Wessinger of Swansea; one grandchild, Katelyn Anne Tillman Hill; numerous other family members, friends, and family pets.             Funeral services for Mr. Wessinger will be held at 2 p.m. on Wednesday, January 10th, at Mt. Horeb Lutheran Church, Chapin, with burial and Masonic rites following at graveside in the church cemetery.  Officiating will be Rev. Ralph G. Hill.  The family will receive friends from 6-8:30 p.m. on Tuesday, January 9th at Thompson Funeral Home of West Columbia.  Pallbearers will be Chris Wessinger, Robby Wessinger, Bobby Wessinger, Jim O’Cain, David Wiles, Chris Hitt, Chuck Wessinger, and Mike Wessinger.  Honorary pallbearers are Holly Wessinger and Stephanie Reed; his fellow retired firefighters from the City of Columbia and the members of Local 793; and the shriners of the Jamil Choo Choos Unit.             Memorials may be made to Mt. Horeb Lutheran Church Building Fund, P.O. Box 8, 101 East Boundary Street, Chapin, SC 29036 or to the Shriner’s Hospital for Children, 950 W. Faris Road, Greenville, SC 29605.

Vernon Center-Anne K. Hunt, age 95, passed away late December 22, 2020 after a brief illness. She was born on August 30, 1925 in Kirkland, New York a daughter of the late Lincoln and Edith (Clark) Kitchen and grew up on Skyline Drive and graduated from the Vernon High School. Anne married Vincent “Vinnie” D. Hunt on April 6, 1946 at the Lairdsville United Methodist Church and shared that vow of over sixty years until Vinnie’s death on December 23, 2006. She and Vin ran the dairy farm on Hunt Road and Rottamore Roads for many years. Anne was a very active member of the Vernon Center Parkside United Methodist Church where she gave freely of her time. In her early career Anne worked as a hairdresser and after raising her children she worked at the V.V.S. cafeteria. Surviving are her family of four children, Rita Deal, Brian, Bradford (Marcia) and Jeffrey (Barbara) and son-in-law Frank Simmons. She leaves eleven beloved grandchildren thirteen great-grandchildren. Also surviving are her siblings, Mary, Elizabeth, Catherine, Frank and Francis and many nieces and nephews. Anne was predeceased by her husband, “Vinnie”, daughter, Rebecca Simmons and brothers; Eugene and Samuel. Because of COVID restrictions funeral services and burial in Vernon Center Cemetery will be private and at the families convenience. A celebration of Anne’s life will be held at a date, time and place to be announced in the spring or summer of 2021. In memory of Anne please consider donations to the Vernon Center Park Building Fund or the Vernon Center United Methodist Church, both to 5815 Youngs Road, Vernon Center, NY, 13477. Online condolences may be sent to maleckifuneralhome.commaleckifuneralhome.com http://www.lastingmemories.com/anne-k-hunt

Charles Franklin "Chuck" Wendel, 67, of Annapolis, and previously of Houlton, Maine, died November 4 at his residence of heart failure.  He was born January 4, 1942 in Medina, N.Y.  He received a BA in 1969 from Canisius College; MA in 1972 from Niagara University; MS in 1973 from Duquesne University; and PhD from University of Pittsburgh.  Mr. Wendel was the Director of Counseling, Allegheny Intermediate Unit in Pittsburgh; Director of Counseling at Avon Grove High School in Avon Grove, PA, Greenville / Union 60 in Greenville, Maine and Southern Aroostook Community Schools in Island Falls, Maine.  He was a Board Member on the Maine Audobon Society; he published a book of poetry; conducted bird habitat research assessments; and was past president of the Pennsylvania State Counseling Association.  Mr. Wendel was licensed to counsel in Maine, Maryland and Pennsylvania; was a university lecturer in Maine, New York and Pennsylvania.  Hobbies included birding - he participated in Christmas Bird Counts for 25+ years. He also started a quilt guild in Greenville, ME  He is survived by his wife, Sarah Anne Wendel, whom he married May 19, 1988; first wife, Patricia Wendel, they were married Oct. 8, 1978 and divorced in 1987; one son, Thearin R. Wendel of Kensington; two sisters, Patricia Pincus of Pittsford, N.Y. and Jacqueline Cisteros of Anguilla, British Virgin Islands;  Grandson, Alex Wendel of Kensington; his parents, Theresa J. Wendel of Penfield, N.Y. and the late George W. Wendel; daughter-in-law, Sandra Novotny; and brother-in-law, Ralph Cisteros. Sandra Sakonyi, 69, of Constantia, passed away at her home on Monday, surrounded by family. She dedicated her life to serving her community as not only a Girl Scout leader of ten years, but as president for both the K of C and VFW Auxiliary. Sandra enjoyed cooking dinners for the various receptions at Post 7325 in Constantia, but saw her true passion in leadership, moving from Post President, to Oswego County President, on to 5th District President of the VFW Auxiliary. In her personal time she enjoyed knitting, crocheting, and cross-stitching, and was an avid reader. Private Family Mass of Christian Burial for John M. "Mike" Couch, 77, of Center, will be Thursday, December 17th at St. William Catholic Church in Perry, with Father John Henderson officiating and concelebrant Mike's nephew Deacon Bob Leake.Burial will be in St. Paul Cemetery in rural Center.Public Visitation will be Wednesday night from 5 to 7 p.m. at Bienhoff Funeral Home in Center.The family requests that anyone planning to attend the visitation or be present at the cemetery to please wear a mask and follow social distancing guidelines.Mike was born on November 27, 1943 in Hannibal the son of George Elmo and Phyllis Herron Couch.He married Judy Jane Leake at St. Paul Catholic Church near Center on April 28, 1962, and she survives.Other survivors include one son Shawn (Stephanie) Couch of Center and one very special granddaughter Morgan Couch of Hannibal, along with several nieces and nephews.He was preceded in death by his parents and one brother and sister-in-law Gary and Susie Couch and one infant sister.Mike worked for the Missouri Department of Transportation as a crane operator for 38 years and was owner operator of CC Crane Service. After his retirement he worked as a truck driver for Hazzard Elevator, Circle W Trucking, and Stuart Trucking.Mike was a lifetime area resident and 1961 graduate of Mark Twain High School. As a boy and young adult he loved to hunt and fish. He was a collector of International tractors and loved working on them. Mike was a charter member of the Missouri International Collectors and a national member of Red Power Round Up. Mike's prize possession was a 1954 Super M-TA diesel show tractor that he loved to talk about and show. He was a member of the Center Lions Club, served on the Center city council for several years, served as director of Cannon Water Supply District #1 for 18 years, and on the Clarence Cannon Water Board.Mike was a member of St. William Catholic Church and loved spending much time for many years helping with St. Paul Catholic Church and St. Paul Cemetery.Pallbearers will be Chuck Leake, Scott Couch, Brian Torrence, Jerry Elliott, Brian Woodhurst, and Bruce Wisdom.Honorary Pallbearers will be Eddie Palmer, Lindell Jackson, Jerry Ketsenburg, and Glen Manley.Memorial Contributions may be made to St. Paul Cemetery or St. Paul Catholic Church % Bienhoff Funeral Home P.O. GREENSBORO Pascal Ashe Tutwiler III died June 25, 2012 in Greensboro, Alabama. He was born in Greensboro to Pascal Ashe Tutwiler II and Virginia Pope Tutwiler on July 21, 1913. He attended Greensboro public schools before attending Alabama Polytechnic Institute, now Auburn University, where he received his B.S. in Agriculture Science in 1936. While at API, he was in Gamma Sigma Delta (agriculture honor society) and Phi Kappa Phi (academic excellence honor society).After graduation Pascal was an assistant county agent for a couple of years in Monroe County before returning to Greensboro to begin his career as a dairy farmer. He interrupted that career in 1942 to join the U.S. Army as a First Lieutenant and was stateside as a field artillery instructor until his honorable discharge in 1945 as Lieutenant Colonel Reserve.Back home in Greensboro, he with his new family, re-launched his dairy farm. At its peak his farm had over 100 registered Jersey cows. He and his family were recognized as an Alabama Exemplary Farm Family by Progressive Farmer Magazine. He enjoyed working with young 4-H Club members in helping them show dairy cows at county fairs. He also judged many such shows. After he retired from more than 40 years of dairy farming, he assisted Charlie Nelson in his surveying business.He supported numerous community and business organizations and was president/director of many of them: Greensboro Schools Board of Education, Greensboro Farmers' Coop (founding director), Hale County Dairy Association, Farm Bureau, Historical Society, Hale County Board of Education, and Alabama Jersey Cattle Association. In addition he was a member of the National Rifle Association, American Legion, and Auburn Alumni Association.He was most dedicated to the Greensboro First Presbyterian Church, having joined when he was 10 years old. He taught the men's Sunday school class for over 50 years and was an active Elder for over 50 years. He became Elder Emeritus in 2003. For a time his gravelly bass graced the choir. He once gave the sermon in the absence of the minister. His topic was beauty, and he somehow managed to get a coon dog into his lesson, much to the delight of the congregation.Pascal was a God-loving man who read the Bible every morning and prayed before going to milk cows. He had an appreciation of the outdoors that was reflected in his love of vegetable gardening, hunting, and working the land. He enjoyed sharing with others, and many people were recipients of good Jersey cream, vegetable bounties, shelled pecans, or jars of homemade jams or jellies from his own hands.Pascal was preceded in death by his parents; sisters and brothers-in-law, Virginia Lankford (Lewis) and Elizabeth Coyle (Jack); brother-in-law, James McCool; son-in-law, David Prince; and stepdaughter, Kathryn Bonds Summerville. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Taylor Bonds Tutwiler; sister, Rosalie McCool; brother, Strudwick Y. Tutwiler (Margie); son, Thomas A. Tutwiler (Marguerita); daughters, Marilyn Tutwiler and Pamela Tutwiler Richards (Matt); stepsons, James Bonds (Marikay), Mike Bonds (Joleane), Bruce Bonds, and Paul Bonds; many grandchildren, nieces, and nephews; and his very close friend, Charlie Nelson.Services were held 2 p.m. Saturday, June 30, 2012, at Greensboro First Presbyterian Church with Rev. Josh Carmichael officiating. Burial followed in Greensboro Cemetery with Kirk Funeral Homes Greensboro Chapel directing.Pallbearers were Ralph Cothran, Keith Glover, Lamar Hall Jr., Mickey Harrow, Jimmy Payne, and Donnie Wedgworth.In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Greensboro First Presbyterian Church, 905 Demopolis St., Greensboro, AL 36744.

Emily Filipek Grabicki SchenectadyEmily Filipek Grabicki, 98, of Schenectady, passed away peacefully on Wednesday, October 31, 2012 at The Kingsway Community Nursing Center with family by her side. She was a retired New York State employee and a lifelong parishioner of St. Adalbert Roman Catholic Church where she was a member of the Rosary Society. Emily loved roses and cultivated them in her small, home garden and was an active member of the Schenectady Rose Society. Emily was preceded in death by her husband, Boniface; sisters, Sadie Filipek, Isabelle Maciejewski and Dorothy Corrigan; and brother, Edmund Filipek. Emily was born in Amsterdam, NY to the late Jozeph Filipek and Josepha Piurek Filipek. She grew up on Bartlett Street, attended Amsterdam public schools and graduated from the Wilbur Lynch High School (class of 1933) where she received history honors. In recognition of her award, she spoke at the commencement on the world impact of Russia. This was a remarkable achievement because she had to leave high school for a year to obtain a job taking care of children to help support the Filipek family. Upon graduation, Emily went to work at the Mohawk Carpet mills where she advanced to the position of setter. She married Boniface A. Grabicki in September 1939 and moved to Schenectady where she raised her family and resided for the rest of her life. Emily grew up knowing responsibilities. At age 10, she began to cook for her family, using a kerosene stove. This sparked her lifelong passion for cooking and baking which evolved into gourmet dinner and dessert creations that were greatly appreciated by her family and friends. She also had the responsibility of caring for her younger sister, Dorothy, while her parents worked in the mills. During the Korean War, Emily worked the second shift at GE; however, after being laid off, she took secretarial courses and obtained an entry level position with the New York State Public Service Commission in Albany, NY. She advanced to become the commission's chief receptionist, the position she held up to her retirement in 1979. She then began her new life with enhanced passion, exploration, and enjoyment which focused on the following endeavors: Gourmet cooking: Emily approached each dish with creativity and passion for excellence. Without question, Emily made the best pies on this side of the Rockies. Travel: With her husband, Boniface, she went to Hawaii; with her sister, Isabelle they went to San Francisco, the Rocky Mountains, British Columbia, Canada, and including her sister, Dorothy, they all went to Cape Cod during the summer. Emily also traveled to her grandchildren's high school and college graduations and weddings and spent time at the Outer Banks and the Adirondacks with her sons and their families. Family celebrations: Emily attended and rejoiced in every family event that occurred in life's path for her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Finally, dancing: Emily took up square dancing and loved ballroom dancing. At her grandchildren's weddings she was known as the Dancing Queen. Emily's life can be best described as Love of Family, Love of Husband and Love of God. Emily is survived by her sons: James M. & Valerie L. Grabicki of West Chester PA, and William R. and Joan C Grabicki of Niskayuna, NY, as well as nine grandchildren and 14 greatgrandchildren. Funeral services will be held Saturday morning, November 10, 2012, at 8:30 a.m. from the Leszczynski Funeral Home, 716 Crane St., followed by a Mass of Christian Burial 9 a.m. at the Church of St. Adalbert, 550 Lansing St., Schenectady. Interment will be in St. Adalbert's Cemetery. Calling hours will be held Friday evening from 6 to 8 p.m. to which relatives and friends are invited to attend. Memorial contributions may be made to the City Mission of Schenectady, 425 Hamilton St., Schenectady, NY 12305.

Kathryn Jean LaMont WeltyMONROE -- Mrs. Welty, 40, formerly of Freeport, IL, died Sunday, February 15, 2004 at the Mercy Medical Center in Cedar Rapids, IA.Born November 25, 1963 in Freeport, she was the daughter of Lynn and Joann (Hill) LaMont. She was very active in her church, before her long illness, singing in the choir, teaching Sunday school, and participating in bible studies. She helped others even though she was very ill. A wonderful mom and wife, she enjoyed family events and outings and things in nature, and doing crafts and sewing.Kathy was an accomplished pianist and vocalist. She was also interested in drama, and participated in several plays during her school years. She helped in the family business and was an excellent sales person. She was warm and witty and will be deeply missed by her many, many friends and loving family.Surviving is her husband, Jeff of Monroe, NC; her mother, Joann (Larry) Kerchner of Freeport; maternal grandparents, Elmer (Elsie) Hill of Freeport; two sons, Ryan A. Welty and Brandon C. Welty both of Monroe, NC; three stepbrothers, Jeff (Robin) Kerchner of German Valley, Todd (Teresa) Kerchner of Davis, and Mike Kerchner of Freeport. Main Street, Freeport, IL.A memorial has been established for Christ Covenant Church of Matthews, NC.Please View & Sign the Family Guest Book at www.walkermortuary.com.

Rose W. (Glatzel) Gornik, 81ElyJan. 25, 1930 - March 12, 2011Rose W. (Glatzel) Gornik, 81 of Ely, passed away peacefully on Saturday, March 12, 2011, at her home with her family by her side.She was born January 25, 1930, in St. Joseph, Minnesota, to Frank and Anna (Horsch) Glatzel. She was a graduate of St. Benedict's High School in 1948 in St. Joseph, Minnesota. She attended St. Benedict's College and attained a degree in teaching from St. Cloud Teachers College (St. Cloud State University). She married Anthony Gornik in June of 1960.Her early teaching years included Grants Pass, Oregon, and Minnesota cities of Avon, Litchfield and Forest Center (Isabella). She finally settled in Ely and taught first grade from 1954 to 1962 and then taught Title I students from 1980 to 1995. In retirement she continued to teach religious education at St. Anthony's Catholic Church.She was the president of the KSKJ Lodge #112 in Ely. She was also a member of the AFU Lodge #200, Slovenian Women's Union, Catholic Aid Association, American Legion Auxiliary and St. Anthony's Parish.She loved to sew, garden, pick blueberries and watch Twins baseball. She made the best potica (strudel) on the Range, as anyone who enjoyed it would agree. Above all, she cherished the time she spent with her grandchildren.She is survived by her three sons, Anthony Jr. of Ely; Joseph of Parker, Colo.; Thomas (Maureen) of Little Canada, Minn.; a daughter, Ann (Anthony) Young of St. Paul, Minn., and grandchildren Benjamin, John, and Aaron Young and Maria and Lily Gornik. She is also survived by her brother Leo (Theresa) Glatzel of St. Joseph, Minn.; sister Mary Stang of Belgrade, Minn.; and sisters-in-law Dorothy Glatzel of Santa Rosa, Calif., and Millie Gornik of Ely, along with numerous nieces and nephews.She was preceded in death by her parents Frank and Anna Glatzel, husband Anthony, brother John Glatzel, sister Marge (Leroy) Raupp, brothers-in-law Stanley Gornik and Louis Stang and sister-in-law Marian (David) Desannoy.Funeral mass will be held at 11 a.m. on Thursday, March 17, 2011, at St. Anthony's Catholic Church in Ely. Visitation will be from 9:30 a.m. until the funeral begins.Burial at Ely Cemetery. Family arrangements have been entrusted to Kerntz Funeral Home of Ely.In lieu of flowers, the family wishes memorial donations be given to the St. Anthony Parish (231E. Camp St., Ely MN 55731) fund-raising campaign for a life-sized statue of St. Anthony de Padua to be placed in the church gathering place.

Karen Linn Miller, 66, of San Angelo, Texas, after a lengthy battle with diabetes and complications, was received into Heaven on May 26, 2016. "Rejoice in the Lord always. I will say it again: Rejoice!" Philippians 4:4. Karen was born in Seymour, Texas, on September 19, 1949, to Estes and Modena Hewitt Miller. She was the youngest of four children, growing up on a farm in Baylor County. Working and playing on the farm occupied most of Karen's summers, along with spending time with many cousins who visited. Keeping up with her older siblings and cousins was a challenge and her witty comebacks to situations are still quoted by family members. She also spent a great deal of time with her grandparents, who were a significant influence in her life. Karen attended schools in Seymour and graduated from Seymour High School in 1968. While in school, she enjoyed playing drums in the marching and concert bands and participating in school functions. She enjoyed her classmates and attended each class reunion for years. After graduation from high school, she then attended South Plain College in Levelland, Texas, graduating with an associate's degree. Karen's career included working for data processing companies in Dallas, Wichita Falls, and San Angelo. She was a long time employee of GTE in San Angelo. Professing her belief in Jesus, Karen was baptized was a young child. She was a member of First Baptist Church, Seymour. Karen's interests included reading, shopping, computer games, and sports on TV. She was a fan of the Texas Rangers and the Dallas Cowboys, in particular. She also enjoyed her nieces, nephews, and great nieces and nephews, keeping up with their lives and activities. Every Christmas, she sent a special ornament to each family. In spite of her poor health, Karen always displayed a congenial and optimistic attitude. Karen is survived by her sister, Janet Hudgins and husband, Dean, of San Angelo; brother, Larry Miller and wife, Annette, of Seymour; and sister, Minda Parks and husband, Don, of Midland. She is also survived by her nieces, Alisen Hudgins Sanders and husband, Brandon, of San Angelo, Chelsi Miller Orsak and husband, Chris, of Seymour, and Charla Parks Bibby of McKinney; and nephews, Ryan Miller and wife, Mandy, of Seymour, and Brint Parks and wife, Disa, of Arlington. Also surviving are great-nieces, Ethne and Ella Miller, Blake Bibby, Aasra Parks; great-nephews, Bryson, Jackson, Mason and Hudson Sanders, Jake Orsak, Burke Bibby, and River Parks; and by her aunt, Orene Covington of Wichita Falls. Karen was predeceased by her parents and a great-niece, Calliope Parks. Graveside services will be held at the Masonic Cemetery in Seymour on July 23, 2016. Memorials may be made to the American Kidney Fund, 11921 Rockville Pike, Suite 300, Rockville, Maryland 20752. This organization supports direct financial assistance to kidney patients for medical care such as dialysis, or to a favorite charity. Many thanks go to the doctors and nurses on staff at Community Hospital and Shannon Hospital in San Angelo and Zale Lipshy Hospital in Dallas for Karen's care. And thank you to Regency House in San Angelo for providing a caring home atmosphere for Karen.

John Roland KelleyGREAT FALLS —John Roland Kelley, formerly of Butte, met his Lord and savior, Jesus on July 1, 2014. John died at his residence in Great Falls, surrounded by his sisters and close family. John's family extends a warm invitation to friends to join the family for the funeral liturgy at noon on July 10, 2014 at St. Ann's Cathedral in Great Falls, with Father Oliver Doyle presiding. Immediately following Mass the family invites friends to a Celebration of Life, co-sponsored by the Kelley family and John's Walleye friends, at Tuffy's Sunset Inn, in Sun Prairie. A memorial service and Mass will be held in Butte at a later date. John was born July 31, 1944 in Ogden, Utah to Dr. J.E. Kelley, a Butte Optometrist, and Margaret Gaddie of Sugar City, Utah. John married Phyllis Spencer in 1965; they were wed for 19 years.John attended Catholic schools in Butte, starting with St. Ann's grade school, graduating from Butte Central in 1962 and from Montana State University in 1973 in Agricultural Science. John spent the first six years of his post college career as a Clinical Technician with the Lionhead Guest Ranch near Big Timber, where he became one of the few veterinary clinicians in the U.S., conducting embryo transplants to extend cattle genetics.John's early hobbies included hunting, fishing, snowmobiling as well as riding in rodeos. He loved bucking broncos, steer wrestling, and roping. After several years with Cooper Pharmaceuticals, John moved to Billings, then to Great Falls in 1992 to manage Western Ranch Supply, specializing in the use of pharmaceuticals to improve farming and ranching. Since his retirement in 2009, John dedicated his energies to the Walleyes mission; building fish habitats in Tiber and other reservoirs, teaching kids to fish as a way to stay off drugs, and maintain a healthy lifestyle. He was a strong advocate for the free fishing pole/free tackle box programs, helping distribute thousands of fishing poles to deserving kids throughout the state. During his tenure as President, John also strongly supported the fight against Invasive Species, an initiative also sponsored by Walleyes. He was a spokesman for this initiative, as seen on local TV public service announcements. These past few months while fighting cancer, John was inundated with visitors, calls and emails wishing him well. His incredibly unique sense of humor; his ability to form life long friendships; his dedication to doing the right thing for the right reasons as he was inspired to do as an altar boy, set John apart.Whether it is in the world of farming or ranching, hunting or fishing, recreation or conservation, friends or neighbors, he will surely be missed. John enjoyed very much the friendships he made during three terms as President of Walleyes Unlimited, Great Falls Chapter. He was currently serving as the President of the State of Montana Walleye Association. He lived according to principles such as: "Do the right things for the right reasons. Keep fish and fishing alive. Make friends with everyone you meet."John is survived by his sisters, Colleen (Kelley) Murray and husband, Don of Eugene OR, and their children Julie Fulton, Sean, and Kevin and 7 grandchildren; Patricia (Kelley) Nicholls and husband Phil of Surprise, AZ, children Heather Nudo and Allison, and 2 grandchildren; Karren (Kelley) Hughs-Pasco of Henderson, Nevada, children Brian, and Chris Hughs, and 2 grandchildren; Michelle (Kelley) Franich and husband Jack of Black Diamond, WA, their children Jody, Jeff, and Megan, and 5 grandchildren and one great-grandchild; Denise (Kelley) Seilstad and husband Scott of Denton, their children Kelly Markovich, and Kendra; half-sister Kimberly (Kelley) and husband Loren LeFebre of Great Falls, her children, Zachary, Rebecca and Chay; and John's former spouse, Phyllis (Spencer) now of Big Timber.He is preceded in death by his parents; and son John Vance.In lieu of flowers, please make any donations to Walleye Unlimited Great Falls Chapter, P.O. Box 937, Great Falls, MT 59403.As one of his friends said so well, "If friends were dollars, John would be a millionaire."Condolences for the family may be posted online at www.schniderfuneralhome.com.
