ST. CHARLES - Robert E. Weick, 90, passed away peacefully of natural causes with his family by his side, on December 27, 2020, at River Glen of St. Charles. Bob was born in 1930, in Chicago, IL. He graduated from Tilden Technical High School in Chicago in 1947, and attended Cornell College in Iowa. His legacy lives on in his five children, Robert (Marianne), Gail (Stephen) Miller, Darrell (Lynn), David (Joanne) and Beth (Arthur) Huskey, fourteen grandchildren, and four great grandchildren. Bob is also survived by many other members of his extended family. Bob was preceded in death by his loving wife of 66 years, Charlotte (nee Boland), mother, Elizabeth Eggebrecht, and brothers, William and Clarence (Bud) Weick. Charlotte was the love of his life, and their marriage was an example to all who knew them. He began working in the Chicago stockyards at Swift & Company, a meat- processing company, in 1948. He worked his way up from loading trucks as a teenager to managing one of the largest plants in the company. His career began in Illinois and took him and his family to Ohio, New Jersey, Nebraska, and Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Bob was tapped by the company to turn underperforming plants into profitable ones. In 1992, he retired from his position as Plant Manager for Armour Swift-Eckrich. The Methodist Church was always a big part of Bob's life, where he often volunteered his time and effort. At a young age, he attended Morgan Street Methodist Church in Chicago, IL, where he met his future wife, Charlotte. With each move, Bob and Charlotte quickly established membership for the family at the local Methodist Church. On their final move back to Illinois, they became active members of the United Methodist Church of Geneva, in Geneva, IL. Participation in athletics was an ongoing part of his life, including competitive wrestling in high school and college. He worked as a summer ranch hand on the McFarland White Ranch in Montana in 1948. Bob had a special passion for golf having played many famous courses in the United States, Ireland, and Scotland. Over the course of twenty years, he enjoyed annual golfing trips with his three sons. Woodworking was his hobby, and he built many fine pieces of furniture, which are now in the homes of his children and grandchildren. Cars were a lifelong passion for Bob. As a young man, he was the go-to mechanic for the extended family. With a crank here and a tinker there, he could get an "old jalopy" engine running. He was faithful to the Chrysler brand throughout the years, and the purchase of his 1949 Chrysler Windsor brought him great enjoyment. That car was similar to the first car Bob and Charlotte owned in their early years together. The 1949 Chrysler was famous for participating in the Hawthorn Woods, IL, 4th of July parade and for taking family and friends on trips to the ice cream parlor. Throughout his travels, Bob made many treasured friendships that lasted a lifetime. With a ready smile and an outstretched hand, Bob touched all of those around him with his warmth and generosity of spirit. "You Always Cared About People" The family would like to thank the staffs of River Glen of St. Charles and Solace Hospice & Palliative Care, Inc. for the love and care that was given to Bob. A private service will be held for the family at Chapel Hill Gardens South Funeral Home & Cemetery in Oak Lawn, IL, and a celebration of life will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family would be honored if donations would be made in Bob's name to the Salvation Army, an organization that Bob held dear.

Margret MuckenthalerOak Ridge, TNMargret Fitzsimons Muckenthaler, age 92, a resident of the Alexander Guest House, in Oak Ridge, passed away Sunday, August 14, 2016. Born in Kansas City, Missouri, she was a graduate of St. Teresa's Academy and magna cum laude from College of St. Teresa, now Avila College. She then worked at TWA as an accountant. She was married to the late, Francis "Buzz" Muckenthaler, for over 65 years and moved to Oak Ridge, TN, in 1950, where she has lived since. After raising her children, she became a dedicated substitute teacher for over 20 years, also enjoying helping out with the library personnel. Margret volunteered her time doing reading for the blind. She also was an avid bridge and duplicate player. She and her late husband spent many months a year traveling to New Jersey, to Florida, and to Tennessee, to support their grandchildren in all their sports activities.She was also preceded in death by her daughter, Deborah; and her son, Randall. Anne Barksdale Cargill Anne Barksdale Cargill, 65, died on November 12, 2013, at her home in Charlottesville, Virginia after a two-year battle with brain cancer. Anne was born October 5, 1948, in Richmond, Virginia to the late James Nelson Cargill and Frances McDaniel Cargill. Anne is survived by her husband, the Rev. James Baker; three sons, Sam Baker and his wife, Jennifer Jones, of Los Angeles, California, and Nathan and Reuben Baker, both of Charlottesville; one brother, James Nelson Cargill Jr. and his wife, Gloria, of Newport News; two sisters, Nancy Cargill Vachon and her husband, Brian, of Montpelier, Vermont, and Dr. Sally Page Cargill, also of Montpelier; two sisters-in-law, Judie Alfrey and her husband, Carl, of Ocala, Florida and Janet Anderson and her husband, Terry, of Ft. Wayne, Indiana; and nine nieces and nephews. Anne grew up in Richmond and enjoyed spending time at her parents' summer place in Deltaville. She attended Collegiate School and spent many summers at Camp Alleghany in West Virginia as both a camper and a counselor. Anne was a graduate of Salem College, in Winston-Salem, N.C. and earned a master's degree in theology and ethics from Vanderbilt University. She married her husband Jim in 1973, and after spending two years at the American Church in Paris, they settled in Charlottesville, where Jim has served as pastor for the Westminster Presbyterian Church congregation for over 30 years. While raising their three sons, Anne worked as a travel agent for Enterprise Travel and in recent years for the Head Start program in Charlottesville. One of Anne's greatest joys was the time she spent at the "river house" on the Potomac, home of family friend Dr. John Owen. At the river, Anne loved sitting on the beach, reading, working on the house, entertaining her college friends, and eating seafood with her family. She also returned to Camp Alleghany on many occasions for reunions and to work towards providing camp scholarships. Anne loved singing camp songs and reminiscing with her friends, many of whom remained close companions in her final years. During her days at camp, Anne honed her shooting skills and became the National Junior Rifle Champion. Anne was passionate about travel, and she and Jim spent many happy times in South Carolina, England, Scotland, and France. Anne was a devoted member of Westminster Presbyterian Church. She served as a youth leader, organized a church tennis league, and loved visiting older members of the congregation, who eagerly anticipated her chocolate candy each Christmas. Anne could make conversation with anyone. Her sharp wit and self-deprecating manner helped others feel at ease. Her joyful outlook on life amused her husband, her many friends, and her three sons and daughter-in-law, who were the greatest joys of her life. Anne was a storyteller, and her family and friends joked that others could travel the world yet still couldn't compete with Anne's story about an ordinary trip to the grocery store. Anne's life "story" came to an end too quickly, but her grace and light will forever be interwoven with everyone she touched. The family wishes to thank Anne's many caregivers, especially Dr. John Owen, Dr. Karen Maughan, Joyce Green, and Connie Anderson, who unselfishly and graciously served Anne until the end of her days. There will be a memorial service to honor Anne's life on Saturday, November 23, 2013, at 2 p.m. at Westminster Presbyterian Church, 400 Rugby Rd., Charlottesville, Virginia with a reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Camp Alleghany Scholarship Fund (checks payable to the Greater Greenbrier Valley Community Foundation, P. O. Box 1682, Lewisburg, WV, 24901); the Chesapeake Bay Foundation (Save the Bay, Capitol Place, 1108 E. Main St., Suite 1600, Richmond, VA 23219); or the Westminster Endowment Fund (Westminster Presbyterian Church, 400 Rugby Rd., Charlottesville, VA 22903). Friends may sign the register book at www.hillandwood.com

Norma Iola Novak, Bismarck, passed away peacefully at Missouri Slope Lutheran Care Center, Bismarck, on Sept. 15, 2009, at the age of 86. A private family memorial service was held on Sept. 17.Norma (Wilhelm) Novak was born May 13, 1923, in Minot, to Lloyd and Mabel (Ross) Wilhelm. There she attended elementary school and Minot High School, graduating in 1941. She married Joe Novak on Nov. 21, 1942, in Stamford, Texas, while Joe was stationed there with the U.S. Army Air Force during World War II.They spent their early married years living in Minot before moving to Bismarck. There, they raised two daughters, Delaree and Patrice. After the girls were in school, Norma worked at the Gold Bond Stamp Store as the store manager. She also worked at Barker's as a saleslady helping young brides choose their wedding gowns, and later she worked at JC Penney, Marna's and Herberger's helping area women choose just the right outfit for their special occasions.Norma was a loving wife, mother and grandmother who enjoyed her grandchildren and more recently her great-grandchildren. In her retirement years, she spent time with her friend, Bev Kaufman, walking in the mall, and she was also an avid reader.Norma is survived by her husband of 67 years, Joe; her daughters, Delaree Novak, Bismarck, and Patrice (Dan) Dietz, Fargo; six grandchildren, Mundi Schmidt (Jeff), Steele, Patrick Dietz, Dickinson, Mary Dietz, St. Cloud, Minn., Chris (Kelli) Gabel, Mandan, Nicole Dietz, Combermere, Ontario, Canada, and Ryan (Jennifer) Dietz, Fargo; and 12 great-grandchildren, Alex, Taylor, Rebecca and Andrew Schmidt, Ella Gabel, Levi, Ethan and Seth Dietz and Christian, Elizabeth, Annabelle and Olivia Hennager. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her.She was preceded in death by her parents, Lloyd and Mabel Wilhelm; and her sister, Carol Jean Bohn. (Perry Funeral Home, Mandan)

Virginia James, 93  PORTLAND -- Virginia James, 93, of Portland, died Thursday, Nov. 13, 2008, at a Portland hospital after a brief illness.  Born in Yarmouth, Jan. 23, 1915, she was the daughter of Murray and Bernice (Mills) Gokey. Virginia was educated in Yarmouth schools and was a graduate of North Yarmouth Academy in 1932. She then attended St. Barnabas School of Nursing in Portland and graduated in 1937. In 1938 she married Frederick O. James.  Virginia was an R.N. at Mercy Hospital for 10 years. In 1959, she started work at Pineland Hospital and Training Center and eventually became nursing director. She retired in 1975.  After retiring, she and her husband wintered in Zephyrhills, Fla. Virginia also enjoyed traveling, bridge, reading, knitting, and crafts. She was a member of the Woman's Literary Union and Mercy Hospital Auxiliary.  She was predeceased by her husband in 1985; a son, John Augustus in 1979; and her sister Beverly in 2008. Survivors include three sons, Frederick O. Jr. and his wife Carol of Cumberland, Thomas and Timothy, both of Estero, Fla.; daughter-in-law Janice Hilton; eight grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.  A 10 a.m. graveside service will be held Monday, Nov. 17, in New Calvary Cemetery. Arrangements by the Conroy-Tully Crawford Funeral Home, 172 State St., Portland. Online condolences may be expressed at www.ctcrawford.com.  Virginia James

Elizabeth May Massouris, age 89, of Council Bluffs, passed away Sunday, December 12, 2011, at 5:45 a.m., in Omaha, Neb. She was born November 27, 1922, in Council Bluffs, to Floyd and Clara Colton Batten and a graduate of Thomas Jefferson High School, in 1940. During World War II, Elizabeth spent two and a half years welding in a ship yard in Portland, Ore., and one and a half years at Scientific Radio in Council Bluffs, making Radio Crystals for the military. Elizabeth is preceded in death by her parents, Floyd and Clara Batten; husband, Phillip J. "Sonny" Massouris, in 1992; and her brother, Leo Batten. Survivors include daughter, Katherine Taylor and husband, Mike, of Council Bluffs; three grandsons, Phillip, Brent and Shawn Taylor; six great grandsons, two great granddaughters, three great great grandsons, one great great granddaughter; sister, Evelyn Greenwood; nieces and nephews. Miriam Taylor Henderson May 9, 1919 - October 21, 2009 Mimi, as she was affectionately known, grew up in Moab, Utah, the daughter of L. L. and Pearl Taylor. Their house was always filled with music and as young women, she and her sisters would often play and sing at local dances. She graduated from the University of Utah and subsequently was an advertising manager for the Deseret News in Salt Lake City and then for the newspaper in Santa Fe , New Mexico. It was there that she met and married her husband, Zane Henderson. They had one daughter, Kristy, while living there. The family moved to Denver and at age fifty, Mimi decided to go back and get her Master's Degree in Business Education. After she completed that, she, Zane, and Kristy bought a hay farm in Durango, Colorado and became farmers. Shortly after this move, she was contacted by Fort Lewis College and asked to teach, which she did for almost twenty years. Her door was always open to her students. In every home she lived she always had a wonderful vegetable garden and beautiful roses. Shortly after Zane died in 1991, she moved to Boise, Idaho to be closer to her daughter and two grandsons, Ben and Matt Mors. She loved them dearly. They brought so much joy to her life and she brought a real sense of family and caring to theirsand she baked the best apple pies in the world. Her other interests included quilting, duplicate bridge, and a love of cats. Mimi always had time to listen, great compassion for others, a dry wit, and a wonderful sparkle in her blue eyes. She will be deeply missed. She was preceded in death by her husband, Zane and her three sisters, Cecil, Lorena, and Sally. Survivors include her daughter, Kristy and her husband, Scott Bowlden, grandsons, Ben Mors and his wife, Raylene, Matt Mors and his wife Whitney, her brother, Sam Taylor and his wife Adrien, and numerous nieces and nephews. Special thanks go to all of the wonderful staff at Plantation Place Assisted Living for their years of incredible care and loving. Instead of sending flowers, please plant a rose, grow a garden, or send a donation to the Humane Society or your local animal shelter in her name. Private services will be held at a later date. We love you, Mimi.

HARRELL, JOE EDD 80, of Cranston, RI passed away on April 30th, 2012. He was the beloved husband for nearly 59 years of Elizabeth (Correra) Harrell. Joe was born in Carthage, Mississippi to Dan and Christine (Scott) Harrell on August 27, 1931. He served in the Navy during the Korean War. He had worked for General Electric Co. at the former Providence Base Plant for 30 years, before becoming the head of maintenance for the RI Department of Corrections in Cranston, retiring in 2005. In addition to his loving wife, he is survived by three daughters, Cynthia (Harrell) Bailey and her husband Gene, Joanne (Harrell) Miller, and Brenda (Harrell) Melucci and her husband Ralph. He is also survived by his sister, Carolyn (Harrell) Cook and her husband Ted of Bossier City, LA, and his brother, Chris Harrell and his wife Margaret of Lewisville, MS. He had nine grandchildren, Justin and Scott Bailey, Christopher, Margo, Alex and Audrey Miller and Joshua, Domenique and Christiana Melucci, Joe enjoyed salt water fishing, country western music, and gardening. He was a talented wood worker and mechanic. He was devoted to his family and his faith in Christ which gave strength to those around him. He will be sadly missed by all. His funeral will be held on Saturday at 8:45 am from the NARDOLILLO FUNERAL HOME & Crematory 1278 Park Ave., Cranston followed by a Funeral Service at 10 am in First Baptist Church, 550 Cowesett Ave., Warwick. Faye Nelson Quick Rosser Faye Nelson Quick Rosser passed away Tuesday, July 22, 2014, in Madison, Virginia. We remember you in this hour, our dear Mother, when your tender love watched over us like a guardian angel. The image of you will live within our hearts always. Born in Staunton, Virginia, on October 11, 1917, Faye graduated from Beverly Manor High School in 1935 and Madison College in 1939. In 1941, she married Lindsay "Bill" Rosser and they spent their married life of 47 years in Alexandria, Virginia. Bill predeceased her in death by 26 years. She leaves behind three children, Billye and spouse, Wally West, and Stephen and Travis Rosser. She will be missed by her seven grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren. Faye is also survived by her sister, Mary Frances Deaver of Staunton as well as her extended family and friends. Faye started her career in teaching at a two-room school at Slate Mills, Virginia, in 1939. After marrying and moving to Alexandria, she taught at George Washington High School from 1947 until 1948, and was principal of Etlan School. She then went to work for the Federal Government and retired from there in 1977. The family received friends at Everly-Wheatley Funeral Home, 1500 W. Braddock Road, Alexandria, VA 22302 on Friday, July 25 from 6 until 8 p.m. In celebration of her life, a graveside service was held at Mount Comfort Cemetery, Alexandria, on Saturday, July 26, 2014, at 11 a.m. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice of Rapidan, P.O. Box 1715, Culpeper, VA 22701; Hospice of the Piedmont, 675 Peter Jefferson Parkway, Suite 300, Charlottesville, VA 22911; or Madison County Rescue Squad, P.O. Box 868, Madison, VA 22727. A guest register may be found at www.everlywheatley.com

Carla Sue OsgoodMarch 18 1930 - June 20, 2020Carla Sue Osgood, age 90, passed away in Riverside, California, on June 20, 2020 due to weakening health and COVID-19. She was born March 18, 1930 in Los Angeles to Dorothy and FA Cummins. She earned her bachelor's degree and teaching credentials at University of California, Berkeley. She met fellow student and her future husband, Joseph Osgood on campus. They married the winter of 1951 and enjoyed a long life together, until he died in 2008. Carla was a dedicated teacher. She first taught children of immigrant farm workers in agricultural communities in southern California. When the family moved to Tehama County in 1969, she initially substituted as a teacher and then settled into teaching 7th and 8th grade at Gerber Elementary School. She taught at Gerber from 1973 until she retired in 1990. She was well liked by students, teachers and staff. Carla loved Lake Almanor and Lassen Volcanic National Park. She loved to swim in the lake and walk in the cool climes of the Sierras. Both Joe and Carla were active at Sacred Heart Catholic Church, where they sang in the choir and undertook volunteer work. Dachshunds accompanied her for most of her adult life. Minnie was the first, John and Frieda arrived when the children were very young, Toto was a fierce protector, Helmut and Ziggy provided entertainment, and Oscar saw her through widowhood and moving. In 2015 Carla moved to Riverside to be closer to her eldest daughter, Eileen Paine. She is survived by three daughters, Eileen, Karen Blount and Diane Osgood, and a grandson, Joseph Blount. There will be a family-only graveside ceremony in Red Bluff. In lieu of flowers, the family asks to please consider contributions in her memory to Sacred Heart Catholic Church or the Abbey of our Lady of New Clairvaux.

Robert A. D'Auria HAMILTON TOWNSHIP - Robert A. D'Auria, 50, passed away Monday at his home. Born in Garfield, he was a longtime resident of Hamilton Township. He was a graduate of Hightstown High School and Trenton State College. He was previously employed by state and local governments before becoming president/CEO of Boston Billboards, Everett, MA. Mr. D'Auria was a member of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Massachusetts and the Everett Chamber of Commerce. He spent many years coaching his sons in area sport organizations, including Nottingham Little League, Hamilton YMCA, Catholic Youth Organization and Hamilton Little Lads. He was an enthusiastic participant of the "Sunday morning flag football league" and the "guys' monthly poker night." He is survived by his wife of 23 years, Denise DiBongrazio D'Auria and his two sons, Glenn and Paul. Also surviving are his mother-in-law, Mary DiBongrazio; brother-in-law and sister-in-law, William and Donna DiBongrazio; three nieces, Lacy, Ashley and Amy DiBongrazio; his uncle and aunt, Louis and Dawn D'Auria; cherished extended family and many devoted friends. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 10 a.m. Saturday at St. Gregory the Great Church, Hamilton Square. Calling hours will be 6-9 p.m. Friday at M. William Murphy Funeral Home, 1863 Hamilton Ave. in Hamilton Township.

HARTSUFF, NANCY Annie Virginia "Nancy" Hartsuff (King) died on Monday, July 2, 2012. She was 81. Daughter of Ted and Peggy King, she graduated from Jackson High School in 1949 and then attended Jackson Junior College. She married Raymon Hartsuff in 1951 and had two children before working at Mercy Hospital and Foote Hospital. She retired from Foote in 1991. A devout Episcopalian, she was an active member of St. Paul's Episcopal Church from early childhood. In her retirement she volunteered there, as well as Hospice and the American Cancer Society. Her family was her pride and joy. Of her five siblings she was preceded in death by her brothers Theodore (Jr.) and William King. She is survived by her brothers David and Fred King and her sister Julia Taylor. She was seldom apart from Ray, her beloved husband of 61 years, who survives her along with her daughter and son-in-law Katherine and Mathew Thornton (of Buchanan, MI) and her son Thomas Hartsuff (of Jackson). She was especially fond of her five grandchildren - Jadon Hartsuff, Emily Griffith, and Molly, Elizabeth, and Sean Thornton - and their families and accomplishments. Visitation will be held at Desnoyer Funeral Home on Thursday, July 5, from 10:00am - 1:00pm, followed by a 1:00pm reception at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, a funeral Mass at 2:00pm at St. Paul's, officiated by long-time family friend The Rt. Rev. Peter H. Beckwith, and graveside burial at Hillcrest Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to St. Paul's Episcopal Church or the American Lung Association. To send condolences to the family go to www.desnoyerfuneralhome.com or www.mlive.com. Desnoyer Funeral Home Family owned for 122 years

SAINT PETERSBURG, FL - Paul A.Henkel 58 of Saint Petersburg, FL, formerly Racine, Wisconsin, passed away on May 23, 2017, at the Moffitt Cancer Center in Tampa, FL. Paul was preceded in death by his father, Charles L. Henkel and mother, Faye E. Henkel (nee Biehn), and his grandparents. Paul was an avid Chicago Cubs fan and never thought he'd see them win the World Series, but he did, for that we are all so thankful. He loved fishing and he loved Florida for its beautiful beaches and easy, slow-paced lifestyle. He loved working in the yard, planting flowers and plants everywhere. He also loved motorcycles and rode whenever he could. Mostly he loved his family. He was a wonderful husband, father, brother and grandfather to all. Paul is survived by his wife of 24 yrs. Julie, his son Paul Jr., his stepchildren Chad and Kate Jackson, Nathan and Sommer Jackson, Mara and Dan Gilmore, Megan Zoller and Nick Neapolitan. He is also survived by his two brothers Marc (Linda Henkel) and Charles Henkel and other family members and many grandchildren whom he loved so deeply. In accordance with Paul's wishes we will be holding a celebration of his life at the Lutheran Church of the Resurrection on August 19 at 11:00 for visitation and a service at 12:00. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, Moffitt Cancer Center, Tampa , FL or a charity of your choice.

Beloved mother of Joseph Jr. (Myra), Rita Ryan (David), Mark (Winnie), and Norine Melillo (Tom); loving grandmother of Sarah, Karen, Meg and Michael; great-grandmother of Lillian and Miriam; and aunt of many nieces and nephews. Barbara was born and raised in Hackettstown. She graduated from Hackettstown High School in 1933, where she was captain of the girls' basketball team. Barbara received a nursing degree in 1938 from St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Elizabeth, NJ, where she was an obstetrical and general duty nurse until she joined the US Army Air Force in 1942, rising to the rank of lst Lieutenant. Upon returning to Hackettstown to raise her family, Barbara volunteered as the school nurse at St. Mary's Parochial School as well as with the annual Red Cross Blood Drive. She was employed at Newton Hospital and then at Picatinny Arsenal as an Occupational Health Nurse. Barbara was a member of both the American Legion and the Legion Auxiliary. Both she and her late husband, Joseph, were honored to be the Grand Marshals for the Hackettstown Memorial Day parade in 2007. Barbara was an avid sports fan. She especially followed the Yankees and the Giants, and was a perennial winner of the March Madness bracket pool. She enjoyed creating beautiful needlepoint which were stretched, framed, and proudly displayed. Barbara also enjoyed traveling; especially the M&M bus trips to the Atlantic City casinos. Visitation will be held at the Cochran Funeral Home, 905 High Street, Hackettstown, NJ 07840 on Friday, June 17, 2016 from 4-7 pm. A funeral mass will be held at St, Mary's Church of the Assumption, 305 High Street, Hackettstown, NJ 07840 on Saturday, June 18, 2015 at 12:30 pm. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to: The American Legion Post #164, P.O. Box 332, Hackettstown, NJ 07840 in memory of Barbara.

Gerald Alfred Kipper1936 - 2023Gerald Alfred Kipper entered the next chapter in his journey with God peacefully and surrounded by family in the rainy morning hours of March 9, 2023, in Santa Maria, CA. His passing was marked by the same qualities with which he lived his life: Faith, Trust, and Love in Christ. In his own words: Looking back on my life I can say it all started from, a gift, to me from God. He placed me in a family that was deeply Catholic. His Spirit guided me all through my life, even when I turned my back on Him, or did things that widened the gap between us. He never stopped loving me. Gerald was born to Leonard Peter Kipper and Margaret Sophie Egidy on July 10, 1936 in Oak Park, IL, a suburb of Chicago. He was the first of 7 children, being the older brother of Leonard, Joan, Lorna, Karen, Mary, and Sandy. From Oak Park his family moved to Richmond, KS and then to Kansas City. There he attended and graduated from Redemptorist High School.After graduation, Gerald went on to serve in the United States Army from 1955-1957. He was honorably discharged with the rank of Specialist Third Class, Artillery, Regular Army.He then attended and graduated from Central Technical Institute in Kansas City, and from there moved to Santa Maria to begin a 42-year career at nearby Vandenberg Air Force Base. At various points he worked on the base for General Dynamics, Lycoming Engines, and ITT / Federal Electric Company. During this time he also supplemented his credentials by attending and graduating from Allan Hancock College with an AS in Electronics, an AS in Data Processing, and an AA in Public Accounting. He retired from Vandenberg Air Force Base as a Systems Supervisor at Building 7380, where he oversaw launch timing and countdown.He lived in Orcutt and the Santa Maria area for the entirety of his adult life. He shared 36 years of marriage with his first wife Sharon Enyart Kipper, who preceded him in death. Gerald and Sharon together welcomed 5 children into the world with the birth of Kevin, Katrina, Jerry, Joyanne, and David. Their family grew with the addition of daughters-in-law Susan, Yvonne, and Amber, persons Gerald very much considered his own daughters.As a natural expression of his Faith and Love in God, Gerald was exceptionally involved with the community at St. Louis de Montfort Catholic Church from the beginning-even being present as a founding parishioner when the church was established in 1963. Gerald served as a Religious Education Teacher and Eucharistic Minister. He was also a Fourth Degree Knight with the Knights of Columbus, Council 2475, where he had previously served as a Grand Knight and a Faith Navigator. He also volunteered as a Eucharistic Minister at Marian Medical Center.Through his engagement with the church community, Gerald met his second wife Mary Jane Kipper and further expanded his family through the addition of Mary Jane's daughters Cindy and Kristie, and son-in-law Jeff.Gerald is survived by his six siblings, his wife Mary Jane, his 3 sons and 2 daughters, 2 stepdaughters, 3 daughters-in-law, 1 son-in-law, 11 grandchildren, and 8 great-grandchildren.Visitation will begin 2:00 p.m. on Sunday, March 19, 2023; followed by the Recitation of the Holy Rosary at 4:00 p.m. in the Chapel of Magner-Maloney Funeral Home. Mass of Christian Burial will be 10:00 a.m. on Monday, March 20, 2023 at St. Louis deMontfort Church with interment following in the original section of the Santa Maria Cemetery.In lieu of flowers, please donate to the CCD program at St. Louis de Montfort Catholic Church.Arrangements are in the care of Magner-Maloney Funeral Home and Crematory. Sympathy notes and words of support may be expressed at www.magnermaloney.com.

Longtime Durango resident John F. Gutierrez died Thursday, Nov. 8, 2012, at the Valley Inn in Mancos. He was 78.Mr. Gutierrez was born to Juan and Margaret Miera Gutierrez on Jan. 11, 1934, in Lumberton, N.M., which is just across the state line from Chromo, Colo. In 1954, he married Elizabeth Kelly in Waterflow, N.M.He was a truck driver all of his life, and he worked for Kimbel, Durango Mercantile Co., Holsom Bread, Yellow Freight and NW Transport for more than 40 years. His family said Mr. Gutierrez received a number of awards for safe driving. He was a member of Sacred Heart Catholic Church and the Teamsters union. He was an avid golfer, bowler, pool player, fisherman and hunter.Mr. Gutierrez was preceded in death by his daughter Joni Nelson. Virginia Garcia June 21, 1921 - September 2, 2017 RACINE – Virginia Garcia, 96, went home to be with her Lord and Savior on September 2, 2017. Virginia was born in Guayama, Puerto Rico to Rufino Felix and Mercedes Torres on June 21, 1921. She was married to Francisco Velasquez Garcia until his death on February 28, 1973. Virginia attended St. Edward’s, St. Rose’s, and St. Patrick’s churches. She had a passion for gardening. Her family would say Virginia had a magical green thumb because she could grow anything. Virginia also enjoyed cooking for family. She loved her family, especially all her grandchildren, and will be missed dearly. Virginia is survived by her children: Sonia Marema, Hector Garcia, Tomas Garcia, Harry Garcia, Francisco Garcia (aka Junior), Virginia Spencer, and Angela Garcia; 15 grandchildren, 38 great-grandchildren, and several more that she considered her grandchildren, as well as many other relatives and friends. Virginia was preceded in death by her husband, Francisco Garcia, two sisters, and four brothers. A celebration of Virginia’s life will be held at Wilson Funeral Home (1212 Lathrop Ave) on Friday, September 8, 2017 at 7:00 p.m. with Father Allen Bratkowski of St. Edward’s officiating. Relatives and friends may meet with the family from 5:00 p.m. until the time of service at 7:00 p.m. at the funeral home. Virginia will be laid to rest with her husband, Francisco, at Cementerio de Guayama Municipal in Guayama, Puerto Rico. Online condolences may be made at www.wilsonfuneralhomeinc.com. Virginia’s family wishes to extend a special thank you to Katherine, Jennifer, Shirley, Brian, and Brianna from Aurora at Home Hospice, Deacon Greg from Aurora Hospice, and Sandra Moreno for their compassionate care of Virgina.

COGGINS-ROHLING, Mary Mary Coggins-Rohling passed away on Wednesday, December 8, 2010, at the age of 71, after a gallant fight against kidney cancer. Mary is survived by her husband, Jim Rohling, sister Susan Foreman, daughter Joan Hart, daughter-in-law Kathleen Coggins, grandchildren Kerrin Hart and Stephen Coggins and her aunt JoAnn Sedmak. She was preceded in death by her mother, Mary Jo Sedmak, and her son, Jeffery Coggins, aunts Paulyne and Agnes Sedmak and uncle John Sedmak. Mary came to Sacramento from Walsenburg, Colorado, with her family in 1946 and attended Our Lady of Fatima Elementary School, St. Joseph Academy for Girls, and American River College. Throughout the years, she kept in touch with many of her school friends. She always enjoyed reminiscing about the ''good old days''.Mary retired after working 25 years at McClellan AFB, and achieved great success in her career. She rose from a clerk-typist position to a Logistics Management Specialist in the Communication-Electronics Division.Mary loved her husband, her family, and friends, followed closely by her love of golf. An avid golfer, Mary belonged to the Lawrence Links Golf Club, Cherry Island, Haggin Oaks, McClellan Golf Association, and Top Flight Golf Association. She achieved the position of first woman president of McClellan Golf Association. Mary and Jim had many wonderful memories of playing golf with her Uncle Johnny and Aunt June Sedmak at various courses throughout California and Nevada. She combined her love of the sport with another favorite pastime, camping, at Graeagle, California was one of her favorite spots. She called it ''Gods Country''.Jim and Mary also loved traveling, including trips to Mexico and the Orient; they reminisced about these trips over martinis for years. Mary always kept a journal about her trips, and her family loved to read about her escapades on these travels. Mary also enjoyed, and was very accomplished at, arts and crafts, especially ceramics.A celebration of life will be held Wednesday, December 15th at 1:00 pm at The Pavilion at Haggin Oaks Golf Complex located at 3645 Fulton Avenue in Sacramento. She is deeply adored and will be greatly missed by her family, many friends, and golfing buddies. P.S. Mary says, ''No tears''.In lieu of flowers, Mary would like donations sent to St. Claire's Church at 1950 Junction Blvd., Roseville, CA 95747.

Oct. 25, 1915 - Dec. 26, 2007A private family gathering will be held at a later date for Murrel LeRoy Walton, 92, of Coos Bay. Cremation rites will be at Ocean View Memory Gardens in Coos Bay.Murrel was born Oct. 25, 1915, in Crofton, Neb., to Clarence S. Walton and Gra V. Lentz. He died Dec. 26, 2007, in Coos Bay.He married Daveda Fay Fitch in 1937, in Yankton, S.D. They had five daughters. He was a World War II veteran, having served in the U.S. Army. He was involved in seven Philippine beach landings.In 1968, he moved to Coquille, where he worked as a mechanic until his retirement. He moved to Coos Bay in 1992.Murrel came from a very musical family background. He could play almost any instrument. He played music with the Old Time Fiddlers for many years and the Gold Coast Music Makers.Murrel will be missed by all of his family and all who knew him.He is survived by his daughters, Lois Neilsen of Coos Bay, Ivis Albert of McKay, Idaho, Emma Jean Albert of Shelley, Idaho and Mildred Calvert of North Bend; granddaughter, Carole Jean Hayworth of Coos Bay; 17 grandchildren; 32 great-grandchildren; six great-great-grandchildren; and one great-great-great-grandchild. He was preceded in death by his wife, Daveda; daughter, Edith E. Golding; grandson, Leslie L. Walton; and his parents.The family suggest memorial contributons to the organization of choice.Arrangements are under the direction of Coos Bay Chapel, 267-3131.Sign the guestbook at http://www.theworldlink.com.

Margaret L. Rodriguez, our beloved mother and grandmother, passed away peacefully on Nov. 21, 2008, with her loving family at her side.She was born on July 9, 1927, and was a lifelong resident of Santa Paula.Prior to retirement, Margaret worked at Santa Paula Memorial Hospital as a housekeeping supervisor for many years. She also worked at Oxnard Frozen Foods.Margaret enjoyed cake decorating and made beautiful cakes for weddings and birthdays for her family. She also loved to embroider and crochet and made the prettiest sets of dish towels she gave as gifts. Her hobbies were growing roses and orchids. Most of all, she enjoyed spending time with the family. Her greatest joys were attending her grandchildren's sports activities.Margaret was a very good cook, and we will miss our "Taco Tuesdays," tamales at Christmas, and the best homemade flour tortillas, all made and served with love.The family would like to thank Assisted Home Hospice for their help and support in caring for our mother.Margaret is survived by her husband, John; daughters, Anita (Tony) Perez, Vivian (Ted) Thames, Rosanna Coker, Alice (Al) Duran; son, John (Lee) Rodriguez; and numerous grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and great-great-grandchildren.A Mother's LoveA mother's love is somethingThat no one can explain -It is made of deep devotionAnd of sacrifice and pain.It is endless and unselfish and Enduring, come what may.For nothing can destroy itOr take that love away.It is patient and forgiving when all Others are forsaking, and it never Fails or falters even thoughThe hear is breaking.Author - Helen Steiner RiceA memorial Mass will be celebrating at 10 a.m. Monday, Dec. 1, at St. Sebastian Catholic Church, 235 North Ninth St., Santa Paula, followed by burial at Santa Clara Catholic Cemetery, 2370 North H St., Oxnard.In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Assisted Home Hospice, 2140 Eastman Ave., Suite 203, Ventura, CA 93003; American Lung Association, 61 Broadway, Sixth Floor, New York, N.Y. 10006; or St. Sebastian Catholic Church, Santa Paula.Funeral arrangements are under the direction of the family-owned and -operated Garcia Mortuary, 629 South A St., Oxnard, CA 93030. Robert Rey Garcia Jr., Funeral Director. For further information please call 805-486-9148.

Frank Charles Dalton Sr., 82, a retired salesman, passed away Thursday, Feb. 27, 2003, from complications of congestive heart failure. Memorials: American Heart Association.Mr. Dalton was a former resident of Arlington for 34 years and had recently moved to Breckenridge with his wife, Louise S. Dalton, who passed away July 12, 2002. They celebrated their 58th anniversary July 4, 2002. Mr. Dalton met his wife at the Douglas Defense plant in Tulsa, Okla., and they were married July 4, 1944. During World War II, Mr. Dalton was a B-25 bomber pilot in the U.S. Army Air Corps. After retirement, he was an avid golfer with the Arlington Senior Men's Golf Association. Mr. Dalton was born in Afton, Okla., on July 1, 1920.He was preceded in death by his wife, Louise S. Dalton; two brothers and two sisters; and his parents, Andrew Jackson Dalton and Edith LaVivian Baker Dalton.His family will remember him as extremely talented and innovative. We will miss him very deeply.Survivors: Daughter, Ann Welton and husband, Ray, of San Antonio; sons, Frank C. Dalton Jr. of Arlington and Scott Dalton and wife, Crystal, of Breckenridge; four grandchildren; and six great-grandchildren.

For directions or to send condolences to the family, please visit www.galantefh.com. John was born on June 27, 1939, in Newark, N.J., to Frances Pedalino and Thomas McCue. He graduated from Newark East Side High School in 1957. John married the love of his life, Linda A. McCue, in 1971, and moved from Newark to Chatham Township, N.J., shortly thereafter. John, better known as "Sid" to his friends and colleagues, worked as a longshoreman in Port Newark, N.J., for 54 years, and held the position of sergeant-at-arms for I.L.A. Local 1235. John spent two years serving in the Army, and made numerous contributions to educational and charitable foundations, including Hillsdale College, the Wounded Warrior Project, and St. John's Church in Newark, N.J. John loved his dog, Riley, and all the greyhounds he rescued over the years, and also loved driving his Cadillac down to his yearly beach vacations in Avalon, N.J. He was an avid sports fan when the N.Y. Yankees and N.Y. Giants won. John is survived by his son, John T. McCue, and daughter-in-law, Maria Bennani of Chatham, N.J.; brothers, Thomas McCue of Union, N.J., and Salvatore McCue of Nutley, N.J., and his sister, Mary Ann Tamburino of Lyndhurst, N.J. John was preceded in death by his mother, Frances Pedalino; father, Thomas McCue, and wife, Linda A. McCue.

Family-Placed ObituaryCOLE, Hazel Kettring Age 85, 565 E. Market St. Celina, passed away at 4:07 a.m. October 31, 2005 at St. Rita's Hospital, Lima of cancer. She was born April 9, 1920 in Montezuma to C. Boyd and Minnie Arnold Kettring. On May 17, 1941 she married Robert Cole, who preceded her in death on June 30, 1993. Hazel Kettring was a 1938 graduate of Celina High School. She was a member of Ars Nova, The Order Of Eastern Star, a lifelong member of the Montezuma Church Of Christ and the former president of the J.O.Y. Circle at the church. Hazel and Bob co-owned Cole's IGA Market from 1946 to 1987, Cole's Drive In Restaurant from 1950 to 1971, and Cole's Motel from 1950 to the present. Children include two sons, Robert (Jeanie) of Troy, Tom of Montezuma, and two daughters, Susan (Don) Heyne of Centerville and Stacy (Joe) Sanders of Celina, Pallbearers will be Hazel's nine grandchildren; Tom Cole and Julie Cole Fleck, Brent Cole, Tammy Cole Garwick and Rebecca Cole, Melissa and Erin Heyne, Kelly and Cole Sanders. Hazel also has four great-grand children. Funeral services will be at 10 a.m. on Thursday, Nov. 3, 2005 at the Montezuma Church of Christ. The Reverends James Wagner and Kevin Neumann will be officiating. Burial will be in Swamp College Cemetery. Friends may call at Lehman, Hogenkamp and Dzendzel Funeral Home on Wednesday from 4 p.m. to 8 p.m. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

Sherry Rapozo of Rio Linda, CA passed away peacefully after a brief illness on October 13, 2018 at the age of 70. She was born and raised in the San Francisco bay area and moved to the Sacramento area in the mid 80's, where she called home for the remainder of her life. She is survived by her loving daughter Lanette Hall, sister Eileen Monge, brother Gary Massey, niece Lisa Della Chiesa and her son Justin Della Chiesa, and nephew Gene Mariano. She is predeceased by her husband, Robert Rapozo, mother Elsie Massey, father Clarence Massey, brother Greg Massey, and sister Karen Mariano. Sherry was a beautiful, vibrant and loving person who made friends easily and cherished the many friends she met while living and working in the bay area and Sacramento area, and also through her husband's pigeon racing hobby. She was a huge animal lover, Giants fan, loved helping others and took pride in making her home a welcome place for family and friends. Online condolences can be made at PriceFuneralChapel.com A celebration of life will be held for family and friends.

October 11, 1939 - June 8, 2016Mr. Thomas Arthur "Tommy" Hostetler age 76 of San Antonio Texas, went to be with the Lord on June 8, 2016 in North Central Baptist Hospital. He was a devoted husband to his wife, Alejandra Hostetler. Thomas was an extraordinary individual and was unswerving in devotion to his family and friends, and to his country.Thomas was the son of the late Verne Hostetler and Louise Barrett born on October 11, 1939 in Chapin, Illinois. He went to high school in Corpus Christi Texas and graduated in 1958. Thomas served in the Air Force as an Aircraft Maintenance Technician. He proudly served his country during the Vietnam War. Thom was transferred to Albrook Air Force Base in the Panama Canal Zone, where he met the love of his life Alejandra Hostetler and married her a month later. He attended the Canal Zone College and after retiring from the Air Force, he went on to earn a Bachelor of Applied Art and Sciences from Southwest Texas State University. Thomas worked as a Police Officer for Trinity University, Child Care Worker for the Bexar County Juvenile Probation Department, and Manager of Sales for Martin Uniforms. He also became a Supervision Community Officer for the 38th Judicial District, Department of Community Supervision and Corrections. Thomas was a committed member of Cornerstone Church where he served fervently. Thomas enjoyed motorcycles, golf, fishing, playing the guitar, harmonica, and reading the bible. But most of all he enjoyed spending time with the family.Thomas was preceded in death by his parents Verne Hostetler and Louise Barrett, his brothers Vern William Hostetler, Theodore Blythe Hostetler and Gary Lewis Hostetler.Thomas is survived by his loving wife of 40 years Alejandra Hostetler, his daughter Patricia Berzinsky and granddaughter Cassandra Lynn Flemming. He is also survived by his sister Sarah Louise Hostetler and his brother Michael Eugene Hostetler. His beautiful life will forever be cherished by a host of nieces, nephews, cousins and friends.In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Lung Association at 55 W. Wacker Drive, Suite 1150 Chicago, Illinois 60601. The family also wishes to extend their gratitude to Cornerstone Church for their support.Visitation and Services will be held at Funeral Caring USA, 6500 N Interstate 35, San Antonio, Texas on June 17, 2016 at 12:30 P.M. A reception will follow. Funeral Caring USA will be handling the funeral arrangements.

Braintree Nancy E. (Shedd) Valle, 85 years of age of Braintree, where she was a life long resident passed away at her home on Thursday, May 1, 2008. She was born in Boston and was a graduate of Braintree High School and a Comptometer School. In her earlier years she was a comptometer operator for the Armstrong Cork Company in Braintree. Prior to her retirement she was a sales lady at the Jordan Marsh Store at the South Shore Plaza. She was a life long member of the First Church of Braintree and belonged to the Fortnighters Club of the church. Nancy was a Past President of the Braintree Women's Club and Braintree Gardener's Guild. She was also a Past President Teachers Association in years past. Viola (Vye) Hazel Wieland, Fargo, ND, formerly of Jamestown, ND, passed away peacefully on Friday, August 14, 2015 at Essentia Health. Vye was born in Rushford, Minnesota, November 24, 1927 to Hilda (Bakken) and Carl Olstad. She graduated from Jamestown, ND High School in 1945. Gladys M. McAmbley Gladys M. McAmbley, 95, of Morro Bay, CA, died on Tues., July 12, 2011 at her home. She was born to Lewis and Lillian Frenz in 1916, in Olean, New York. Her parents had been married for 9 years at the time she was born, and her name was chosen to commemorate the joy they felt at the birth of their first child. Gladys and her younger brother, Bob, grew up on a poultry farm and attended a rural one-room school, which she always remembered fondly. The two children lost their mother when Gladys was only 5, and their father 6 years later, and they were sent to live separately with relatives. Gladys lived mainly with her grandmother, Margaret Guy, in Bradford, PA.  Gladys graduated from Bradford High School in Bradford, PA in 1933. In the 30's she discovered a love for tennis, and eventually won the Bradford women's doubles city championship. She married the late Joseph McAmbley in 1940. After raising two children in Bradford and, later, in Warren, PA, the two were divorced in 1981. Gladys moved to California in 1985 to be near her daughter and family in Orcutt, Los Osos, and finally in Morro Bay, CA. Before her marriage, she worked as a bookkeeper for an oil supply business and for Pennsylvania Electric Co., where she met her future husband. When the children were both in school she worked for the Bradford Community Chest. After her move to Warren, PA in 1963 she worked in the business office of Warren General Hospital until her retirement in 1981.  Gladys was an active member of the First Presbyterian Churches of Bradford and Warren, PA, and belonged to the Orcutt Presbyterian Church after her move to California. She played bridge all her life, and loved to knit, read, cook and do crossword puzzles. As a parent and grandparent she was generous with her time and affection; she played an active part in the childhood of all 4 of her grandchildren. Gladys lived up to her name in many ways: she enjoyed small things, found meaning in the ordinary, dwelt on the positive, and enjoyed humor.  Gladys is survived by 2 children: Chris McAmbley (Bette) of Warren, PA; and Jean O'Carroll (Philip) of Morro Bay, CA. She is also survived by four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. She was preceded in death by her brother, Robert L. Frenz of Bradford, PA.  Donations in Gladys' memory may be made to Hospice Partners of the Central Coast, or to a charity of choice. A memorial service will take place on Sat., Aug. 27 at 10:00 a.m. at the First Presbyterian Church of Warren, PA. Burial will be at Saint Bonaventure Cemetery in Allegany, NY.

Doug ChaffeeGreenvilleDouglas Chaffee, 75, of Greenville, SC, died April 26, 2011 at the Greer Medical Hospital.A native of upstate New York, son of the late Ralph and Marjorie Chaffee, he served his country for several years both in the United States Army and then in the Army National Guard. Doug also attended college at Bob Jones University where he studied Art and History. After college, he began his career at IBM and worked there for nearly 20 years. Upon retiring from IBM, he started his own company where he provided illustrative and graphic-design services to a number of fields including, by not limited to; Christian periodicals, military publications, science-fiction publications, and technical journals. His work can be found not only in Sunday School literature, Vacation Bible School literature, and Christian-School textbooks, but also in the Smithsonian Institute, in National Geographic magazine, Naval Proceedings magazine, and in the White House.All through his life and career, his heart was always toward serving his Lord and Savior. Much of his time, talent, and effort was invested in illustrating the stories and lessons found in the Scriptures. His main desire was that some of the work he produced and the interactions he had would point those affected toward Christ.Surviving are his wife, Melba Chaffee of the home; and a son and daughter-in-law, Scott and Rebekah Chaffee of Greenville, SC. He also had two grandsons, Holden and Stewart Chaffee of Greenville, SC. A memorial service, to be conducted by Rev Dan Brooks, is to be held at Heritage Bible Church in Greer, SC on May 4, 2011 at 11:00 AM.Palmetto Mortuary of South Carolina is serving the Chaffee family.

CLARENCE L. DELKERClarence L. Delker, 86, passed away peacefully in his sleep at home in Palermo, Thursday, August 19, 2010. A Memorial Service will be held at Evangelical Free Church of Oroville on Thursday, August 26, 2010 at 11 a.m. He was born June 6, 1924, in Eureka, South Dakota, to Jacob and Matilda (Lutz) Delker. The Delker family moved to Worland, Wyoming, in 1938. Clarence graduated from Washakie County High School in 1942 and then served in the Army during World War II. Later, Clarence moved to Oroville to work on the construction of the Oroville Dam and was a member of the Laborers Local 185 for over 50 years. He and his wife have attended the Evangelical Free Church in Oroville during most of their married life. Clarence helped with the construction of the church sanctuary and other building projects as the church grew in size. He valued the friends he made through work and church and was known for his gregarious personality. His passing is our loss and heaven's gain.Clarence is survived by his beloved wife, Ruth, of 46 years; daughter Beverly (Rick) Gentry; three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren; brother Leeland Delker of Worland, Wyoming; three sisters Denelda Brill of Worland, Mirian (Ted) Lohrer of Cody, and Libbie (Chuck) Wilkie of Worland, Wyoming; as well as numerous nieces, nephews and other relatives. Clarence is preceded in death by his parents, brother Marvin Delker and sisters Vera Meyer and Frances Clark.Viewing is Wednesday, August 25, 2010, 4-8 p.m. at Scheer Memorial Chapel. Clarence will be laid to rest at Oroville Cemetery on August 26 following the memorial service and reception at the Evangelical Free Church. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to Oroville Christian School.

A. Patricia (Pina) Smith, of Plymouth, passed away Saturday, Jan. 30, 2010, at Boston Medical Center, from complications arising from a heart attack. Patricia "Pat" was born and raised in Carver, July 30, 1939, and graduated from Plymouth High School in 1957. She was a loving daughter of the late Theodore and Amelia (Perry) Pina and one of nine children. Her career in nursing began at Taunton State Hospital. She worked tirelessly in healthcare as a dedicated and compassionate caregiver. She was a certified nursing assistant for over 45 years, most recently at Radius Healthcare in Plymouth for the past 20-plus years, where her impact was profound. Although raising seven children prohibited her from following her dream to become a registered nurse, her medical knowledge was comparable and respected by her peers. She loved to walk Plymouth's scenic waterfront, spend time with her seven children, 14 grandchildren, sisters, extended family and friends. She was extremely proud of her Cape Verdean heritage, spoke Creole and loved to attend annual Cape Verdean festivals. She enjoyed attending her grandchildren's school, recreational and organized events and was affectionately referred to as "Nana". Her legacy is her children whom she never stopped being a mother to and loving. Her strong will and determination instilled within her children the drive, focus and confidence to achieve their goals, tempered by her caring, compassion and love. She was the epitome of a strongly independent, loving mother and grandmother whose wonderful smile, humor and undying support will be greatly missed by her family. She is survived by her husband of 30 years, Thomas J. Smith. She was the loving mother of Robert M. Hunt, William D. Hunt III and his wife Kim, Lori A. (Hunt) Spencer, Alan J. Hunt, Tracey L. Hunt, Keith A. Hunt and Meclina M. Hunt and her partner Jeremy Murphy. She is also survived by her grandchildren, Stephanie, Melina, Aron, Qiana, Alex, Alecia, Jessica, Austin, Christopher, Josh, Sydnie, Ariyanna, Olivia, Rileigh and the late Jasmin Nicole. She is also survived by her sisters, Pauline, Mary-Ann, Irene; and many nieces and nephews. Funeral services will take place Feb. 4, 2010, with a Mass at St. Peter's Church at 10 a.m. followed by a burial service at Otis Air Force Base in Bourne at 12:30 p.m. Arrangements were handled by Bartlett-Garrity Funeral Home, 338 Court St., Plymouth. To send an online condolence or for directions, go to www.bartlettgarrity.com.

He is predeceased by his parents and his brothers, Raymond and Jerry. He will be missed by his special nieces and nephews, great nieces and great nephews, and countless friends. David was an avid sports fan, especially of the NY Yankees, and enjoyed many rounds of golf with family and friends. He was inducted into the Corning-Painted Post Sports Hall of Fame. He was very active in the Campbell United Methodist Church and held several roles, including Chairman of the Administrative Board. Robert Corwin Horn September 12, 1935 - October 6, 2012, 77, of Golden, Colorado, and formerly of Nome, Texas, departed this world to be in the hands of the Lord, Saturday, October 6, 2012, following a long neurological condition. He was born September 12, 1935, to Ruby May and Arlie Odus Horn of China, Texas. Robert graduated from China High School as Valedictorian, and continued his post-secondary education at Texas A&M and Lamar University. He started his farming career working with his father in 1955. Over the years he became known as a leader in the industry and was recognized as Farmer of the Year by the 1983 Texas Rice Festival. Robert ventured into several crops, such as soybeans and grain sorghum, and helped to start many business ventures related to the local agricultural industry. He retired in 2003, at which time he relocated to Golden, Colorado, to be near family. His passion to serve others led him to spend many years on the National Soybean Association Board, Hardin-Jeffer- son School Board, Jefferson Country Drainage District 6 Board, and The Lakewood Mile Hi Church Foundation Board. Robert was well known for his ability to see through complex issues and call on his uncanny common sense to develop a simple and logical solution to even the most complex problem. Robert is survived by his wife of four years, Lillian Konopasek Horn of Golden, Colorado; brother, Stuart Horn and wife, Susan of China, Texas; sister, Kathryn Warren and husband, James of Nome, Texas; sons, Corwin Horn and his wife, Jane of Fannett, Texas; Brad Horn and his wife, Mary of Des Moines, IA; daughter, Marcia Noyes and husband, Mike of Golden, Colorado; daughter, Suzanne Horn of Austin, Texas; stepdaughter, Lisa Uhrig and her husband, Blaine of Brush, Colorado; stepson, Craig Konopasek of Loveland, Colorado; 12 grandchildren; 2 step-grandchil- dren; and 2 great grandchildren. Robert is preceded in death by his loving parents and wife of 52 years, Barbara Sigler Horn. A gathering of family and friends, to celebrate Robert's incredible life, will be held at Christian Fellowship Worship Center, 3950 Pointe' Parkway, Beaumont, Texas 77706, October 20th, 2012, at 11:00 a.m. The family has invited all guests to join them in the fellowship hall, following the service, for a time of sharing and remembering the man we loved. In lieu of flowers, we ask that donations be made to the Christian Fellowship Worship Center, Elder Fund. The fund is used exclusively to assist the elderly with spiritual, mental, and physical needs, who are living their remaining days in assisted care.

LOWELL - Henry Babcock, Jr., 79, a veteran of the Korean War and Lowell resident for more than five decades, died Thursday evening, Oct. 30, at a Lowell nursing home following a long illness. He was the husband of June Lorraine (Wakefield) Babcock, to whom he was married for 52 years. He was born in Newburgh, N.Y., July 24, 1924, a son of the late Henry and Anna (Christenson) Babcock. He resided in Lowell for more than 50 years.Mr. Babcock served in Army during the Korean War. He was a member of the VFW Post 662 and of the local Korean War Veterans organization. Prior to his retirement, he worked as a union laborer in construction for many years. Besides his wife, he is survived by four daughters and three sons-in-law, Nancy and Ernest Sirois of Derry, N.H., Diane and George Sirois of Lowell, Carla and Robert Renk of Derry, N.H., and Kelly Babcock of Lowell; a son and daughter-in-law, Henry and Theresa (Montminy) Babcock of Lowell; seven grandchildren; eight great-grandchildren; also many nieces and nephews.  Mr. Babcock's three brothers and two sisters are deceased.

Richland, Wash.July 30, 1913-Nov. 9, 2008Dorothy Vivian Nelson passed away peacefully on Sunday, Nov 9, 2008, in Richland at the age of 95. The youngest of three daughters born to Milton Lee and Alwilde Hanson Donaway, Dorothy grew up in Bellingham, Washington.Bellingham was an interesting place  Dorothy could watch the last of the tall ships in full sail from a hilltop overlooking Bellingham Harbor and the beautiful San Juan Islands.There were long walks in the woods and chasing the draft horses for riding bareback in the sawmill yard. In the summer, she jumped off the pilings and swam in the bay at the foot of the hill. On rainy winter days, the girls would clear the furniture out of an upstairs bedroom and go rollerskating. And when the Navy made Bellingham its 'port of call,' the neighborhood girls would dress up in their prettiest outfits to dance with the sailors at The Nebraska Club. All under the watchful eyes of the girls' mothers! Dorothy graduated from Fairhaven High School and then earned a degree in education from Bellingham Normal School, which today is Western Washington University. Teaching jobs were hard to get in the Depression, but Dorothy taught in Tekoa, Carnation and Pasco, Washington. Dorothy enjoyed a formidable reputation as a teacher. Parents would fight to get their children into her classes because they knew that their children would learn more. In Pasco, Dorothy met Roy W. Nelson, whom she married in February 1942. Dorothy and Roy loved to dance. During World War II, Dorothy traveled with Roy on his many deployments throughout the United States, but her favorite was Norman, Oklahoma, where she worked in the personnel department at the same Navy base where Roy was an aviation machinist's mate instructor.Three children were born to Dorothy and Roy: David, Marywilde and Britta Nelson-Maki. Education was a top priority in the Nelson household, especially in the performing arts. Dorothy loved music but was unable to realize her long-cherished goal to play the violin. So she made sure each child got a thorough music education. She never missed her children's performances. She also made sure her children were involved in scouting and exposed to concerts and ballet. Dorothy did what mothers everywhere do. She was the glue that held it all together  the motivating force that made it happen. Dorothy retired from the Pasco School District in 1976 and enjoyed a long retirement. She was an artist and loved to paint watercolors and oils. She assisted at polling places on election day, was active in Order of Eastern Star, and was a member of Women's Bible Study Fellowship and a member of Delta Kappa Gamma, a sorority for exceptional women in education. Dorothy and Roy were able to travel to Hawaii and to Sweden to visit relatives during retirement.Dorothy was preceded in death by her parents and two sisters, Bernice Hatfield and Alice-Jean Jorg, and her beloved husband, Roy. She is survived by her three children; three step-grandchildren, Lacey Ahlf, Eric Maki, and Dana Rognier; and numerous nieces and nephews.A private memorial service is pending. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Lower Valley Hospice of Sunnyside, WA, or the charity of your choice, in Dorothy's name.

ELMER, EDGAR S. 89 - of Margate passed away peacefully in his home on Saturday October 8, 2011 surrounded by his family. He was born on October 22, 1921 in Millville, and has been a resident of Margate for 61 years. A 1939 graduate of Atlantic City High School and member of Bones Fraternity, Ed continued his education at Notre Dame, Dartmouth, and Harvard for his naval officer's training. He served as a lieutenant in the Navy during WWII. He worked as a district manager for Philip Morris for many years. Upon retirement, he enjoyed working in the pro-shop at the BL England Golf Course. Edgar was a former member of the Atlantic City Rotary Club, Power Squadron, Margate Historical Society, and The Save Lucy Committee. He was also an active and involved member of the Margate Community Church. He was passionate about his golf game, and had regular games well into his eighties. He also took great pride in his gardens, which he tended to religiously. Edgar loved his family deeply, and in recent years had adored his great grandchildren, Maggie and George, and his beloved great-granddogs, Leonard, Otis, Samson, Rosie, Stella, and Roobee, for whom he always had a pocket full of treats. Edgar is survived by his loving wife, Phyllis, of 66 years; children Scott and Eileen Elmer of Chesapeake, VA and Judy and Rich Patterson of Margate, NJ; grandchildren Lindsey and Matt Cope of Charlotte, NC, Stephanie and Jody Eidt of Paris, Ontario, Kristi and Eric Grimley of EHT, NJ, and Emily and Jason Antonucci of Norfolk, VA; two great grandchildren; sisters-in-law Elaine and Gus Gustofson, Marjorie Brown, and Patricia and Don Jackson, and many nieces, nephews, friends and caring neighbors. Relatives and friends are invited to attend Edgar's Life Celebration and Memorial Service on Thursday October 13, 2011 at 11am at the Margate Community Church, 8900 Ventnor Ave Margate NJ 08402. Friends may call from 10 to 11am at the church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Margate Community Church at the above address. To share your fondest memory of Edgar please go to www.lifecelebration.com. Family services by Jeffries and Keates Funeral Home Northfield.

Roger M. Dolloff, 65    WESTBROOK - Roger M. Dolloff , 65, of 51 Reed Street died Saturday, April 22, 2006 at his home after a courageous battle with cancer.      He was born in Portland on Aug. 18, 1940, a son of Alfred K. Dolloff and Thelma K. Grendall Dolloff. He attended Westbrook schools.      After High School, he was employed at Eastern Beauty & Barber Supply Company. He later worked for M.F. Bragdon Paint Company. Due to his visual impairment caused by a progressive eye disease he pursued a career in the State Of Maine Blind Vending Stand program where he managed the snack bar in the Fredrick G. Paine Portland Federal Building at 151 Forest Avenue for 20 years. After that he worked 11 years at the PO Box Lunch vending stand in the Portland Post Office at 125 Forest Avenue. He retired in August of 2000.     Roger had a quick wit and loved talking with people. He made many friends while employed in the Federal Building and Post Office. He loved sports, music, reading books on tape, traveling, trains, and old time radio shows. He was a member of the Maine Fraternal Association of the Blind where he served eight years on the board. He was also a member of the Presumpscot Grange No.15 in Portland.      He was predeceased by both parents.      He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Jeane Dolloff; a son, David A. Dolloff of Westbrook; stepmother, Marjorie Dolloff of Scarborough; a sister, Nancy Hart of Troy, N.H.; nieces, Melinda Hillock of Paxton, Mass., Melody Hillock of New York, NY, Jessica Hart of Troy, N.H.; a nephew , Jason Hart of Troy, N.H.; and grandnephew, Seneca Hillock-Longstein of Paxton, Mass.; aunt and uncle, Irene and Marvin Barker of Standish; a sister-in-law, Dorothy Hillock of Old Orchard; and life long friends, David and Nancy Curit of Portland; and several cousins.     Per his wishes, he will be cremated and a graveside service will be held at 10 a.m., on Saturday, April 29, at Brooklawn Memorial Park, 2002 Congress Street, Portland.         In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to:    Iris Network     189 Park Avenue     Portland, Maine 04101    or    Animal Refuge League     449 Stroudwater Street    Westbrook, Maine 04092    or    American Cancer Society    1 Main Street Suite 300    Topsham, Maine 04086        The family would like to thank doctors Michael Shuman, Anna Niegowska, Lisa Beale, and the various staff members at both the Mercy and Maine Medical Centers for their excellent care. A thanks also goes out to Marie Aikins, Karen Mayo and other staff members of VNA Home Health Care for their care and support.    Jones, Rich & Hutchins     Funeral Home & Cremation Service    775-3763

Beverly PalmerSt GeorgeBeverly Palmer, age 88, passed away on September 20, 2017. She was born on September 27, 1928 to John and Metta Weston in Milford, UT. Beverly was married to Paul Palmer and had two children, Paul Palmer Jr and Sharon Gifford. Beverly was raised in Milford, where she went to school and spent her childhood growing up with her loving family. Some of her favorite memories involve growing up with her nephews and trips to Puffer Lake. After school, Beverly attended college to become a secretary. She lived in Sacramento for a time, before settling down in Las Vegas to raise her family. After retirement, she moved back to St. George to be closer to family and return to Utah. Beverly was a faithful member of the Mormon Church and served in several roles. Her favorite job was as ward librarian and she loved working with everyone. Beverly also enjoyed doing her family's genealogy and studying the past. She had a great appreciation for her family and always did anything she could to help them. Beverly's grandchildren were her world and she cherished every moment she had with them. . Beverly is survived by her daughter, Sharon; and grandchildren Joshua, Rachael, and Ashley Gifford. The family would like to thank Zion's Way hospice, the nurses, Relief Society/Church members, and many others who helped Beverly; especially in the past few years. Beverly was a very outgoing person who appreciated all the love and support shown on her behalf. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, September 28 at 11:00 AM at the Milford LDS Church. Following the service, an interment will be held at the Milford Cemetery. Family and friends are invited to share condolences online at www.SerenityStG.com. Arrangements and memorial tree planting by Serenity Funeral Home, 986-2085.

Christiansen, Hyrum Eugene    Passed away January 10 at Huntington Memorial Hospital in Pasadena. Gene was born in Salt Lake City, Utah on July 26, 1929. He was 83 years old at the time of death. He resided in Pasadena area most of his young life. He attended elementary school in Highland Park and then Elliot Jr. High School, Pasadena City College, graduating from lower division in 1947, then John Muir College where he received his Associate of Arts degree in 1950. While at Muir he was Golden Gloves champion for 3 years. Gene also became interested in Photography. He was assigned to photograph the contenders for the 'Turkey Tussle' queen when he met his future wife, Barbara Scott who became queen that year.  Gene joined the Naval Air Reserve and was called for his pre-flight training in Pensacola, Florida. He went to Carrier Qualifications Unit and was accepted for duty with the United States Marine Corps in Corpus Christi, Texas for combat pilot training. Barbara and Gene were married February 4, 1953 just before  he was sent overseas to Korea. After returning from Korea he studied Accounting at Woodbury College and graduated CUM LAUDE in May, 1957. He became a Certified Public Accountant and has had an practice in the San Gabriel Valley for 55 years. He loved Dixieland Jazz, Golf, Bowling, Football and Dominos. He was an active member of the Pasadena Optimist Club, and La Canada Tournament of Roses and was an active participant in many other charitable organizations. Gene is survived by his son Scott Eugene Christiansen of La Canada, and daughter Susan Gay Lawson, grandchildren Kaitlyn, Jake and Rielly all of Kalispell, Montana. Gene also leaves his sister Karen Hesse of La Canada as well as many other family and friends and a Scottish terrier 'Bonnie'. Gene is predeceased by his wife of 54 years, Barbara in September, 2007.  A memorial will be held at the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter day Saints, in La Canada, on Friday, February 1, 2013 at 10:00 AM. The National Cemetery in Riverside will be Gene's final resting place. Graveside services will be on Friday, January 25, 2013 at 10:45 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family appreciates donations to the Optimist Youth Homes, 6957 N. Figueroa St., Los Angeles, CA 90041-1076 or to your favorite charity

Williams, Bro. Queen Esther 8/15/1933 - 2/23/2018 Muskegon, MI Bro. Queen Esther Williams, age 84, departed this life at home on Friday, February 23, 2018. He was born on August 15, 1933 to Cleveland and Mary Williams in Utica, Mississippi. The Williams family moved from Utica to Muskegon, Michigan, when Queen was a young boy. He attended Muskegon Heights Public Schools where he participated in basketball and track. After graduating from Muskegon Heights Public Schools in 1952, Queen enlisted in the U.S. Army and bravely served our country in Korea until his honorable discharge two years later. Queen was affectionately known to some as Quincy E. What many might not know, is that prior to his birth, Cleveland and Mary believed they were having a baby girl and chose to name her Queen Esther. After delivering a healthy baby boy, his parents could not depart from the original name they had chosen and declared that would still be his name. After Queen was older, he took it upon himself to offer an alternative, thus taking on the name Quincy E. However, we can all agree that no matter what he was called, he was indeed the same man we all came to love and adore. Queen was married to Barbara Rhone and to this union two children were born - - Phyllis Starr and Andre Williams, Sr. As a very dedicated man, he also lovingly helped raise the Burt children, Anthony, Greg, Mark, and Linda McKee. He accepted Christ at a young age and attended Beulah Missionary Baptist Church under the leadership of the late Rev. Richard J. English. He served on Beulah's Usher Board until he became ill. Queen was a devoted Detroit Lions and Detroit Tigers fan! He also enjoyed watching countless episodes of "Steve Harvey's" Family Feud with his sisters, Clara and Hedesene. Lastly, he was a member of Muskegon's elite Brothers Eleven social club. Bro. Williams was a true entrepreneur. He bought and flipped homes to rent and/or sell while still maintaining full-time jobs at Continental and Kaydon Corp. He often worked multiple jobs to help support his immediate and extended families. After 40 years of dedicated service, Queen retired from Continental. Queen is survived by his loving children, Phyllis Starr of Muskegon, MI and Andre Williams, Sr. of Los Angeles, CA; three grandchildren, Brandi Sones of Grand Rapids, MI, Carl Sones III of Kalamazoo, MI, and Andre Williams II of Los Angeles, CA; three sisters, Tennie Lee Riley of Grand Rapids, MI, Clara Williams and Hedesene Fields of Muskegon, MI. He is also remembered by the Burt family, as well as a host of cousins, nieces, nephews, and friends. He was preceded in death by his parents, Cleveland and Mary Williams; his brother, St. Clair Williams, and sister, Mary McClendon. A celebration of life will be held on Saturday, March 3, 2018 at 11am at Beulah Missionary Baptist Church, James Williams, Sr., Pastor. Visitation will be held on March 2, 2018 from 2pm to 6pm at the church.

Bryan C. Yingst, 74, passed away on Wednesday, May 8, 2019 at Lancaster General Hospital surrounded by his loving family. He was born in Harrisburg, PA, the son of the late S. Harold and Kathleen (Via) Yingst. He was happily married to Julie A. (Johnson) Yingst for almost 54 years. He proudly served in the U.S. Army from 1966-1968. Prior to retirement, Bryan worked as a builder for Millstream Construction. He was a member of Lancaster Seventh-day Adventist Church where he served as head elder and a board member for many years. He also served on the board of the SDA PA Conference, Blue Mountain Academy, and the former Central Penn Christian School. He enjoyed golfing, car shows, racing, and was an avid fan of the Phillies and Eagles. His greatest joy was spending time with his family. Bryan always had a mischievous grin and a twinkle in his eye and was known for his sense of humor. He lived a life of service to the Lord and deeply impacted the lives of all who knew him. He was loved by all and will be greatly missed. We look forward to the day when Christ returns and we will be reunited with him. Surviving besides his wife Julie are his children, Bryan Kelly Yingst (Dawn), Stacy R. Whitacre (Wayne), Wendy C. Eavenson (Scott), and Brady C. Yingst (Jill); his brother, Robert A. Yingst (Bambi), his sister, Pamela K. Griffin (Darrell), thirteen grandchildren and six great-grandchildren who lovingly called him Papa, as well as numerous nieces and nephews. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his brother, Harold Yingst. Family and friends are invited to attend the Services on Wednesday, May 15, 2019 at 6:00 pm at Lancaster Seventh-day Adventist Church, 151 City Mill Rd., Lancaster, PA 17602. Friends may greet the family from 4:00 pm until the time of service. Burial with military honors will be on Thursday, May 16, 2019 at 9:00 am sharp, at Indiantown Gap National Cemetery. If desired, contributions in Bryan's name can be made to the Lancaster SDA Church at the above address. Please visit Bryan's Memorial Page at www.TheGroffs.com. www.pennlive.com/obits
