BROWNJoe H. Sr.  Joe H. Brown, Sr. passed away January 2, 2016. He was preceded in death by his wife, Edith (Gibson); his parents; sister, Elizabeth Pugh, and many beloved relatives and friends. Joe was born April 27, 1924, in Barton, Ohio to Henry and Josephine (McDaniel) Brown. He later moved to Logan WV where he briefly worked in the coal mines, played semi-pro baseball then in 1943 he enlisted in the 330th Army Air Forces. He was awarded a Bronze Star, WWII Victory Medal, Asiatic Pacific Campaign Medal and was Honorably Discharged. He returned home to begin a music career playing the drums and later began his own band playing local gigs. He was a member of the Professional Musicians of Northwest Ohio, Local 15-286- AFL-CIO. He retired from Interstate (Overnight) Trucking and had a second career as a Captain for Pinkerton and Jowa Security Services.  He met and married Edith Gibson; he became a stepfather to Gregory Brewton (Zeke) Gilda, The Woodlands, TX. Their union created 5 children; Cheryl (Cheri) McClellan, Joe Jr., (Butch) Terry Williams, Elizabeth (Tina), Leslie (Mickey) and Kathy. He was the proud grandfather of Gregory Brewton Jr., Courtney McClellan, Charles Williams, Jenna McClellan, Leslie Brown, Jr. Evan Brown, Jimmie Martin, III, Clarissa Martin, Sydney Brewton, Alyssa Brown and 11 great-grandchildren. The family would like to give a special Thank You to Senior Independence Hospice. Family and Friends will be received for the wake at House of Day Funeral Home Sunday, January 10, 2016, at 2 p.m. with the Funeral at 3 p.m. A Military Burial will be Monday, January, 11, 2016, at 11 a.m. at Ottawa Hills Memorial Park.

Dr. Mary E. Loos, passed away on June 7, 2018. She was born in Ottumwa, IA. She will be laid to rest next to her parents in Iowa.Mary was the first female physician in Sun City West, AZ in private practice in 1987. She was in private practice for 15 years. She was the first physician to admit a patient to the new Del Webb Hospital in 1987 after it was built. Mary was one of a few physicians that made house calls on her patients. If they could not come to the office, she went to them. She always carried her black bag in her car in case of emergencies.Her love and passion was for medicine as it always was first and foremost. Mary worked long and hard to help take care of others. She then became a hospitalist for 16 years and traveled to other states to work.Her only other passion was reading or crossword puzzles. Mary is preceded by her parents, Doris and Robert Loos. She is survived by sisters, Christine Jacobs, her four children of Olathe, KS. Susan Dobson and two children of Lebanon, TN.Mary gave countless hours of dedication. Countless lives touched. Countless families reassured and consoled. Unknown fact, Mary always carried her angel stone in her pocket.Private services were arranged. Condolences may be shared at www.menkefuneralhome.com

William Allen "Bill" Johnson, Sr. Williston - Funeral services for William Allen "Bill" Johnson, Sr., 90, of Williston, SC will be held at three o'clock p.m., Wednesday, January 5, 2022 at Mt. Beulah Baptist Church with the Reverends John Reeder, William Allen Johnson, III and Dr. David Richardson officiating; burial will follow in the church cemetery. The family will receive friends from one-thirty p.m. until the time of the service at the church on Wednesday. Memorial contributions may be sent to Hillcrest Baptist Church, 4384 Williston Rd., Windsor, SC 29856 or Mt. Beulah Baptist Church, 856 Mt. Beulah Rd., Windsor, SC 29856. Mr. Bill passed away on Sunday, January 2, 2022. Born in Windsor, SC, he was a son of the late Thomas Allen Johnson and Leona Wise Johnson. He was a graduate of Windsor High School and retired from E. I. DuPont as an E & I Mechanic after working 33 years. Prior to working for DuPont, he was a SC Highway Patrolman. Mr. Bill loved building houses; he built his own home and one for each of his sons, Michael and Allen, as well as several other houses. He loved to farm, raise catfish, raise registered beagle dogs, and build honey bee hives. He was a long-time servant for the Lord, he served as deacon and music director in several churches and worked in other capacities before making his church-home at Hillcrest Baptist Church. Mr. Bill also enjoyed singing and was a member of the gospel quartet Adoration. Survivors include his loving wife of 62 years Linda Kitchings Johnson; a daughter Susan (Edward) Selden of Aiken; two sons William Allen (Marie) Johnson, Jr. and Michael (Gail) Johnson all of Williston; grandchildren Chelsea Johnson, Slayton (Lilly) Johnson, Raymond Selden, Elizabethe (Bruce) Drebenstedt, William (Melody) Johnson, III, Amber (Ian) Stuart, Ashley Bedenbaugh, Bryson (Ruby) Johnson and Joseph Johnson; three great grandchildren Wyatt Dempsey, Brendan More and Willow Johnson; a brother James Carthel "J.C." Kaney, Jr and his wife Brenda; a sister-in-law Betty Bell Johnson and a number of nieces, nephews and cousins. He was preceded in death by his sisters and brothers Grace J. Kaney, Lonell J. Hiers, Ona Wise J. Quattlebaum, Louise J. Key, Darrell T. Johnson, Donald Lee "Don" Johnson and Daniel J. Johnson. Folk Funeral Home Inc. and Crematory is assisting the family with arrangements. Visit our on-line registry at www.folkfuneralhome.com.

Vele, Leona  WAUPUN - Leona L. Vele, age 82, passed away surrounded by family and loved ones on Saturday, Feb. 20, 2021, at the Christian Home in Waupun. Leona was born on April 26, 1938, in Milwaukee, the daughter of Clifford and Evelyn (Ernisse) Owens. She was united in marriage to Allen Vele on June 14, 1958, in Chicago, Ill., where she lived for most of her life prior to moving to Beaver Dam in 1975. They then retired to the Stockbridge-Munsee Reservation in Bowler, Wis. She devoted her life to being a mother and wife, raising all six of her daughters. She was sassy and funny, and made friends no matter where she went. She loved her margaritas, doing jigsaw puzzles and crafting, and always had her iPad on hand. Living down the road from the casino, she enjoyed her time spent there with her friends. Traveling with her family and going to the theater were also greatly treasured. Leona is survived by her five daughters and "adopted daughter," Victoria (Joseph) Bruns of Beaver Dam, Laura Malak, Tammy Vele and Lisa (Bill) Vele, all of Bowler, Lois (Chad) Cordes of Ashland and Tina Weinheimer of Beaver Dam; grandchildren, Casey, Kelsey (Aaron), Tavondre, Angela, Samantha, Felicia, Dustin, Stacy, Joseph (Adrienne), Alicia, Joshua (Diane), Jennifer, Danielle, Jacob, Hunter, Cheyenne, Samantha, Nathan (Samantha), Bobbie Jo; great-grandchildren, Hayley, Jase, Liam, Brayden, Kade, Michael, Jamison, Nick, Taylor Lynn, Wyatt, Austin, Auburn, Hannah, Zane, Dakota, Jeffrey, Piper, Carlin, Camryn, Jocelyn, Sadie, Loggan, Alec; and other relatives and friends. She was preceded in death by her parents; husband in 2018; daughter, Deborah Corn in 2017; son-in-law, Robert Corn in 2018; sisters, Lois Dornbach, Lorraine Haertel and Luella Royle; great-grandson, Gage Davidson and other relatives and friends. A memorial gathering for Leona will be held on Friday, Feb. 26 at Cornerstone Funeral & Cremation Services, 135 Keller Blvd., Beaver Dam from 3 p.m. until the time of the memorial service at 4 p.m. Inurnment will take place at Red Springs Cemetery at a later date. Cornerstone Funeral & Cremation Services in Beaver Dam is honored to be serving the family. You may send private online condolences or sign the family's guest book at www.cstonefs.com.

Elaine Parker  September 25, 1947 - November 15, 2021  Wichita, Kansas - Elaine Gail Parker, 74, of Wichita, KS, passed away peacefully in her home on November 15th, 2021.  The world doesn't get many folks like Elaine (known to family as "Lainy" or simply "Grandma.") Her love was unlimited, unwavering, and unconditional. A remarkable craftswoman, she could make (or mend) just about anything from clothing to cakes to carpentry. She didn't need a pattern or instructions — she could simply take an idea and make it real. To us it was magic. To her it came naturally.  Elaine served multiple terms as the Mayor of the town of Longton, KS where she left a lasting legacy — securing funding to overhaul the town's aging water system, successfully campaigning for a bond measure to fund a new addition to the high school, and organizing an annual town festival just for the joy of it.  Her favorite author, Terry Pratchett, once wrote: "No one is finally dead until the ripples they cause in the world die away — until the clock he wound up winds down, until the wine she made has finished its ferment, until the crop they planted is harvested. The span of someone's life, they say, is only the core of their actual existence." By this measure she'll be with us for generations to come.  Elaine didn't want a funeral. She didn't want the sadness and tears. She wanted to hear laughter and see smiles. She wanted bright colors and joy. In her honor, let's seek that joy. Let's make the world kinder for her. Do those random acts of kindness that you read and hear about. She would feel so happy, so grateful, so peaceful to know the world got kinder and more joyful on her behalf!  GNU Elaine Parker

Lindley Pond Ayers1961-2022Lindley Pond Ayers never met a stranger. Whether it was through her church, her work or her community, relationships were Lindley's passion. She loved people absolutely and they loved her back. To all who knew her, and with great sadness, we announce Lindley's passing on the 18th of January, 2022.Lindley was born in Houston, Texas to Jane and Robert (Bob) Pond on October 26th, 1961. She came into life as bright and fierce as she left, touching, befriending and caring for people along the way. She attended University of Texas Dental Hygiene School and practiced 19 years as a successful hygienist in both Houston and Austin. Always interested in gardening and landscaping, Lindley began doing side jobs and favors for friends and acquaintances, until critical mass forced her to leave her dental instruments behind and start Lindley Pond Landscaping. Like Dental Hygiene, Lindley's love for people and talent for landscaping proved a successful combination as Lindley Pond Landscaping grew into a successful commercial and residential design and installation firm.During Lindley's career transition, her love of nature and animals led her to Johnson City where she planted her roots, set up shop and built her dream with horses, dogs, cats and chickens. Her landscaping business not only led her to lifelong relationships with customers, but also to Decker Ayers, the love of her life. Lindley and Decker were active in the Henly Baptist Church. As Lindley continued to mature in her faith-walk, she reached out to Don Forrester, her pastor and requested baptism as an expression of her Christian faith. Lindley started her day working the New York Times crossword puzzles in ink and feeding her horses treats from the steps of her house. She lived an active life managing her business, taking care of her animals, cooking and being a cheerleader, friend and confidant to the many family and friends in her life. She was an amazing daughter, sister, aunt and friend. Her positivity radiated everyday and to everyone lucky enough to cross her path.Lindley is preceded in death by her beloved husband, Decker Ayers, her mother Jane Pond and her grandparents. She is survived by her father, Bob Pond (Fran), brothers, Dr. Jay Pond of Fort Worth and Matt Pond (Megan) of Houston, numerous nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles, cousins and countless great friends.A local remembrance will be held at the Henly Baptist Church, 200 Henly Loop, Dripping Springs, Texas, at 2:00pm March 5th, 2022. A celebration of Lindley's life will be held later in the Spring – the date to be announced. For those wishing to make a donation in Lindley's memory, please consider: Henly Baptist Church, The American Cancer Society, or any local animal rescue organization.

GRAHAM - Georgiana Hubbell Mathews, 98, died at her home at the Twin Lakes Center on Wednesday, March 28, 2007.   The body will be cremated and a Service of Witness for Resurrection will be held at 3 p.m. Saturday, March 31, at the Twin Lakes Center Gathering Room. Officiating will be the Rev. Don Kearns.   She was a member of Shiloh Presbyterian Church, where her daughter, Suzanne Shoffner is pastor.   "Georgia" was a retired teacher from Ohio, who loved watching people learning to read. She taught for 37 years.   At age 24, she married Raymond L. Skinner and had two daughters, Rama Lee and Shadra Suzanne. Raymond died when she was 32 and Georgia returned to the classroom.   In 1958, she married William Carlton Mathews of Chillicothe, Ohio. His daughter, Barbra Jean was 11.   After retirement, they enjoyed travel, grandchildren, and gardening.   After "Mattie" died in 1983, she transitioned to North Carolina and made new friends.   She is survived by her daughters, Rama and Edgar Schollmaier of Fort Worth, Texas, Suzanne and Martin Shoffner of Mebane, Barbara and Charlie Hoyle of Columbia, Missouri; as well as six grandchildren; and 10 great-grandchildren.   In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Activity Building Fund at Shiloh Presbyterian Church, 2638 Grand Oak Boulevard, Burlington, N.C. 27215. www.shilohpresbyterian.com   Arrangements are by McClure Funeral Service in Mebane.   Condolences may be sent online at www.mcclurefuneralservice.com

Loved and loving father, grandfather and uncle, George "Ken" Garrett died peacefully on Thursday, Aug. 20, at the age of 86 after a long battle with Parkinson's disease.  Ken was born and raised in Wichita Falls, Texas, and went on to study mathematics and electrical engineering at Midwestern State University and the University of Texas at Austin. An exceptionally strong swimmer and oilfield roughneck, he joined the Navy and served proudly during the Korean conflict.  Through mutual friends, he met the love of his life, Norma Louise Johnson, and they married shortly thereafter. After many different jobs and moves around the country, he made a career with IBM and settled in Pine Island.  Ken was deeply committed to his family and friends, and never tired of being known as Mrs. Garrett's husband. He was blessed with a keen sense of humor and intense curiosity. A tireless student of the game of golf, he was a self-proclaimed member of "Arnie's Army." He enjoyed a long association with the Walleye Investment Club and counted its members as dear friends.  He and Norma retired to Red Wing, where she pursued numerous artistic projects, and he pursued errant golf balls. His greatest joy was cradling his new grandchildren and seeing them grow to young adulthood. He was a strong and compassionate caregiver, and nursed his wife and comforted his family through her long illness and passing. When health declines forced a move to assisted living, he truly missed the camaraderie of Alvina Street.  He is survived by his children, Jim and Ellie, and Jim's wife, Jane; his grandchildren, Conner and Allison; his loving companion, Dolores; and his nieces and nephews, Glen, Laurie, Genevieve, Ben, Connie and Ginger.  In lieu of flowers, memorials are preferred to Mayo Foundation—Movement Disorders Research, or Homes for Our Troops.  Visitation will be Thursday, Aug. 27, from 4:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m., followed by a memorial service from 7:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. at Ranfranz & Vine Funeral Homes, 5421 Royal Place NW, Rochester, Minn. 55901.

PIROLOZZI, Campigliella "Kay" 95, died Feb. 22, 2016 at her son's home in Tampa surrounded by her family. Most people called her 'Mommy,' as she delighted in sharing with many her Italian traditions filled with love and food. She was a simple woman of humble background and lived her life contented as a housewife and mother. Kay's earlier years were spent in New Jersey. It was on a blind date that she met Joe, who would be her husband for the next 63 years, until his death in 2011. They settled in Vero Beach where they raised their two children until Joe's retirement.  The next 22 years they were inseparable as they shared their golden years together; while living in Newberry, their home was often the 'gathering place' for family and friends. Through her actions, Kay demonstrated to those around her the meaning of dedication, commitment and self-sacrifice. Her home was the heart of her family, and her kitchen was the soul.  In their advancing years, they moved to Texas to be with their daughter JoAnn, until her death in 2013. Shortly thereafter, she moved to Tampa to live with her son and family. She is survived by her son, Joe (Marion); grandchildren, Mallory and Brian; a sister, Mary Cuthbert, and a brother, Frank Morano. A Funeral Mass will be held 11 am, Friday, March 4 at Incarnation Catholic Church (corner of Hillsborough Ave. and Webb Road). Kay will then be reunited with her husband at the National Cemetery in Dallas, TX. Please sign our online guestbook at: www.blountcurrywest.com

Bunders John E., of Robbinsdale, died on March 23, 2003, at the age of 84. John was born in LaCrosse, Wisconsin on June 23, 1918. He graduated from Anoka High School in 1936. John served in the Army Air Corps, during the Second World War. He was a member of Westphal American Legion Post 251. He was an active ice and roller skater and worked at the old Minneapolis Ice Arena. He was a member of the BearCat speed skating club in the late 1940's. During most of his adult working life, John was carpenter and belonged to Local # 7, as well as being active in the labor movement from 1940 until 1966. John retired in 1984 and remained active as a volunteer with his deceased wife of 28 yrs., Edna, in nursing homes throughout the metro area. He was past president of Dovre Lodge #3, Sons of Norway. John is survived by son, John and wife Susan; grandchildren, Cynthia and Chris of Maple Grove; brother, Donald of NE Mpls; sisters, Mildred of Col. Hgts, Lila of Richfld, and Vivian of Mpls. Memorial service at Gearty-Delmore, 39th and West Broadway, Robbinsdale, Thursday, April 3rd, at 11 AM. Visitation 1 hour prior to service. Private interment at Fort Snelling National Cemetery. Gearty-Delmore 763-537-4511

HOLLAND, WILLIAM "BILL" E. - age 75 of Seymour, TN went to his eternal home Saturday, November 9, 2013. Bill served a military career in the U.S. Army from January 5, 1952 to September 19, 1957 in both Korea and Germany. He was member of the Mountain View Baptist Church of Sevierville, TN. Bill was also an ordained deacon of Dallas Baptist Church of Daisy, TN on June 6, 1971. He was a member of Daisy Masonic Lodge #706 in Soddy Daisy, TN was initiated- October 8, 1971 passed- November 6, 1971 and raised a master mason - December 4, 1971, Eastern Star #137, Knoxville Scottish Rites, Alhambra Shriners of Chattanooga, TN, Legion of Honor Kerbela Shriners of Knoxville, TN, Shriners Burns Hospital Cincinnati Roadrunners Club, Past Master at Mountain Star Lodge # 197 in Sevierville, TN, President District 20 Masonic Officers, Sheet Metal Union Local #5, and Special Deputy of Sevier County Sheriff's Department in Sevierville, TN. Bill built his life around his wife, children, grandchildren, and especially his great-grandchildren. He made sure that any child, in or out of the community, whether he knew them or not, wasn't left out, either by coaching or transporting them to events that they might not of otherwise been able to attend, or just by handing out shoes at the Scottish Rites. Children were a big part of his life and his list of contributions to them and the community goes on and on. His life brought so much joy and laughter to many, many people. You couldn't help but smile when you were in his presence. Anyone that knew him or had him in their life was very blessed. He made the world a better place just because he was in it. We will carry his honor and spirit with us in our hearts and his memory will not fade from us. We couldn't have asked for a better husband, dad, pawp, papaw, brother, or friend. He will be greatly missed but we will see him again. He was preceded in death by his son, Lloyd Oliver Holland; parents, Lloyd E. and Opal J. Holland; brother, Delbert F. Holland; father and mother-in-law, William O. and Mabel A. (Price) Matthews; brothers-in-law, John E. "Smiley" Matthews and James "Buddy" Cates; sister-in-law, Wanda F. "Toot"(Matthews) Reagan. He leaves behind his loving wife and best friend of 55 years, Genell Holland; daughter and son-in-law, Janis Gibson and husband Dewey; two sons, John and James Holland; 12 grandchildren; 22 great-grandchildren; sisters, Betty Jo and husband, Lynn Helton, Loveta "Witty" Cates; many nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to: Kerbela's Shriners Temple, 315 Mimosa Ave, Knoxville, TN 37920 or Scottish Rites Shoe Fund, 612 16th Street, Knoxville, TN 37916. Funeral service 7 PM Tuesday in the West Chapel of Atchley Funeral Home officiated by Rev. Bill Helton and Rev. Jack Hitch. Interment 11:30 Wednesday, in the East TN Veteran's Cemetery on John Sevier Hwy with American Legion Post 104 providing military honors. Pallbearers include Aaron Dunlap, Joey Cox, Edward Holland, Brandan Perry, Brent Clapper, Caleb Holland, Steven Myers, and Jeremy Walters. The family will receive friends 5:00-7:00 PM Tuesday at Atchley Funeral Home Sevierville, TN (www.atchleyfuneralhome.com)

Andy Klabo, 30, Minot, ND, passed away Sunday, October 27, 2019, at Trinity Hospital in Minot.Andrew Eugene Klabo was born May 8, 1989. At age 11, he became the son of Timothy and Pamela (Krenz) Klabo. He was raised on a farm by Antler, ND.  He graduated from Mohall High School in 2008. Andrew’s favorite part of school wasn’t the academics, it was friendship and football.Andy met Megan Washek in 2013. They were married July 21, 2017 at Our Lady of Grace Catholic Church in Minot. They made their home in Minot, where they raised their four daughters.    Fall was Andrew’s favorite time of the year. He tried to log as many hours as he could hunting deer, waterfowl, pheasants, and his favorite sharp-tail grouse. Andy truly enjoyed hunting, spending time shooting with Megan and his girls. He also enjoyed playing games with his girls, and spending time with his family. Some of the stories Andrew would love to tell the most were somehow related to the great shots that were made and the big ones that got away. When in the field, he was in a steady competition with his brother Scott. Andrew was idolized by his brother, sister, and his four girls. Andy was his mom and dad’s favorite oldest son.Andy was currently working in the oil field for Loenbro.He was a member of Our Lady of Grace Catholic Church and the Knights of Columbus.His loving family includes:  wife, Megan Klabo, Minot; daughters, Jazlynn (10), Makenna (8), Sophie (7), and Alisha (5); parents, Tim and Pam Klabo, Antler, ND; brother, Scotty Klabo, Antler, ND; sister, Crystal Klabo (Kobie Snavely), Cando, ND; parents-in-law, Fred and Michelle Washek, Parshall, ND; foster mother, Kathryn Foster Debertin, Bottineau, ND; a niece, Oakley Rose; nephews, Taylan, Matthew, and Liam; and numerous cousins.Andy was preceded in death by his maternal grandparents, Paul and Rosie Krenz; paternal grandparents, Gordon and Mary Jane Klabo; maternal grandmother-in-law, Karen Theusch; Uncle, Mark Krenz; foster father, Dick Foster; and his poodle, Jewels.Mass of Christian Burial: Tuesday, November 5, 2019, at 11:00 a.m. at Our Lady of Grace Catholic Church, Minot.Interment:  Rosehill Memorial Park, Minot, ND.Visitation:  Monday from 5 to 7 p.m. at Thompson-Larson Funeral Home, Minot.Vigil Prayer Service: Monday at 7 p.m. at Thompson-Larson Funeral Home, Minot.Memorials: In lieu of flowers and plants, memorials are preferred.

Peggy Joyce (Pirnack) Walk  Peggy Joyce (Pirnack) Walk, age 92, passed away November 19, 2023, surrounded by her loving family in Albuquerque, New Mexico.  Peggy was preceded in death by her husband, Bill Walk; parents, Carl J. Pirnack and Irene Pirnack; brother, HJ (Bub) Pirnack; sister, Rosena Evans; twin sister, Patty Eagan; and son-in-law, Bill Moore. Peggy was born in West Plains, Missouri, during the Great Depression, where her family owned Pirnack Grocery & Feed.  Peggy's family relocated to Tucumcari, New Mexico, where she met the love of her life, Bill Walk. Peggy and Bill were high school sweethearts, married soon after her graduation and were happily married for 58 years. Peggy and Bill settled in Albuquerque, New Mexico where Peggy was a resident for 48 years.  Peggy enjoyed her time with her family the most, especially her grandchilren's sporting events, where no matter the sport, she could be heard calling out, "ring em up!" Other interests included: sewing, gardening, crewel embroidery, reading and traveling.  Everyone who knew Peggy, loved Peggy and she knew no stranger. Peggy will be remembered for her beauty inside and out; her kindness, her smile and her laugh will all be missed and treasured!  Peggy is survived by her children, Diana Moore of Albuquerque, Joyce Zugelter and husband Tom of Saint Augustine, Florida, Spike Walk and wife Laura of Albuquerque; grandchildren, Bryan Moore and his wife Terri, Stephanie Moore, Michael Moore and his wife Crystal, Kyle Zugelter, Austen Zugelter and his wife Danielle, Shane Walk and his wife Daniela and Lianne Walk; great grandchildren, Mack and Julia Moore, Will and Tessa Moore.  A graveside service is scheduled for Tuesday December 12, 2023, at 10:30 am at Sunset Memorial Park Cemetery, 924 Menaul Blvd. NE, Albuquerque, New Mexico 87107

Chapman, RichardRichard Otis Chapman passed away peacefully on November 17th, 2020 in Key West, Florida. Richard was born in New Haven, Connecticut on March 19, 1943 to the late Otis and Elinor Chapman. He grew up in Branford with his older siblings, Janice and Alan. One of Dick's most legendary feats was the day he decided to row across Long Island Sound from his home in Branford, Connecticut. He arrived that night on a beach in Long Island, New York and was taken in by a group of people he met at a bonfire. The next day he rowed back to Branford, and his mother thought he was missing because all she could see was an empty boat drifting with the oars up in the air. It turns out he was so exhausted, he had stretched out for a rest.He enlisted in the Army in 1964. He later sailed from Connecticut to Key West where he settled with his longtime partner Henri LaChapelle. Richard was employed as a civilian plumber for the Navy before he retired. He loved Ham Radios, warm weather and the ocean. Richard was a proud member of the Masons.Richard is survived by several nieces, nephews, grandnieces and nephews and one great-grandnephew. He was predeceased by his partner Henri, his parents, his brother Alan, sister Janice Kirby, and nephew Stuart Chapman.A private service will be held at a later date. Donations can be made in lieu of flowers to The Masons, Key West Lodge #64, P.O. Box 1248, Key West, Florida, 33045. Please include "in memory of Richard Chapman" on your donation check. To sign the online guestbook please visit hawleylincolnmemorial.com.

Ronald Wolff, age 79 of Chicago , passed away Saturday, May, 23. He was the beloved husband of Virginia and loving father of Luanne, and Larry (deceased). Mr. Wolff was a graduate of Principia College and then served as an officer in the Marine Corps during the Korean War. He and his longtime friend Donn Chappellet founded Interstate United Corp which became a large food service and vending company. He sold the Company in the 60's and the family moved to the Two Bar Ranch in Wyoming, where he raised cattle, sheep and wheat in an idyllic setting. After returning to Chicago in the 80's, he was business partners for many years with Gerald Finkle in an investment company dealing primarily in real estate and manufactured housing. Services will be private.

Eleanor Jean Schroeder August 16, 1927 – July 6, 2018 STURTEVANT – Eleanor Jean (nee: Celeste) Schroeder, age 90, passed away peacefully at Ridgewood Care Center on Friday afternoon, July 6, 2018. A lifelong resident, Eleanor was born in Sturtevant on August 16, 1927 to the late Ballisario “William” and Frances (nee: Figliolia) Celeste. She was a graduate of Saint Catherine’s High School in 1947. Eleanor was employed by SC Johnson until she retired in 1992 after over 30 years of service. In her earlier years, she also served as a waitress at Hiawatha in Sturtevant. She was a longtime member of St. Sebastian Catholic Church. Proud of her Italian heritage, Eleanor was also a member of Vittoria Colonna. Amazingly active most all of her life, Eleanor enjoyed traveling, golfing, bowling, bingo, casinos, playing cards, and socializing. Above all, she loved spending time with all of her family. Surviving are her beloved son and daughter-in-law, Robert and Jean Schroeder of Mount Pleasant; adored grandchildren, Nicole Jean Schroeder, Jason Robert (Jessica Abulencia) Schroeder and Megan Rose (Jake) Worden; sister, Beverly Arndt; many special nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends – too numerous to mention by name. In addition to her parents, Eleanor was preceded in death by her sisters and brothers, Rosalie (William) Jensen, Mary (Joe Sorenson) (Boze Livengood), Marco (Josephine) Celeste, Ernest (Eileen) Celeste, James (Theresa) Celeste and Josephine (Abe) Kirkorian; and brother-in-law, Richard Arndt. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Wednesday, July 11, 2018 at 6:00 pm in Saint Sebastian Catholic Church, 3126 – 95th Street in Sturtevant, with Rev. Javier Guativa officiating. A memorial dinner will follow. Visitation will be in St. Sebastian Church on Wednesday from 4:00 – 6:00 pm (there will be a brief pause in the visitation for the Vittoria Colonna tribute at 5:30 pm). Interment will take place at 10:00 am on Thursday morning in Calvary Cemetery, 2510 Kinzie Avenue. In memory of Eleanor, memorials to Saint Sebastian Catholic Church have been suggested. A heartfelt note of thanks to the staff of Killarney Kourt and Ridgewood Care Center for their compassionate care and support given in Eleanor’s time of need. May God bless all of you DRAEGER-LANGENDORF FUNERAL HOME & CREMATORY 4600 COUNTY LINE ROAD 262-552-9000 www.draeger-langendorf.com

September 22, 2002 at the Douglas Memorial Hospital; beloved sister of Bill and his wife Jewel of Seneca, South Carolina. Eleanor was born on December 25, 1923 in Royal Oak, Michigan to LeRoy and Alice Jacobs. She was a WWII veteran and served as a medical Corpsman in the US navy which stimulated her interest in the medical profession. In 1949, Eleanor graduated with a B.A. in Psychology from the University of Buffalo; in 1952 with an M.A. in Clinical Psychology; and in 1955 became Dr. Jacobs achieving her Ph.D in Clinical Psychology. From 1951 to 1954 Eleanor began her career as V.A. Trainee at the V.A. Medical Center in Buffalo; was employed as Staff Psychologist in 1954 until 1978; and achieved status as Chief of Psychology in 1978, maintaining title as Acting Chief until 1979. During the span of Eleanor's career with V.A. Medical Center, she was jointly appointed as Research Associate Professor, and Clinical Associate Professor of Psychology at University of Buffalo, teaching from 1949 until her retirement in 1983. As well, Eleanor served as Executive Committee Member for the SUNYAB Multidisciplinary Center for Study of Aging; and acted as Consultant on Call for the Medical Inspectors Office, V.A. Division, Washington, D.C. from 1983 to recent. She has 19 Awards and Honors for Outstanding Performance, Special Recognition, Excellence in Research, one fo the Foremost Woman in the 20th Century, Woman of the Year, Outstanding Career Woman just to name a modest few. Certainly not to place second was her active membership on 17 individual Professional and Community Organizations. Notwithstanding, Eleanor also held Offices and served on the Board of Directors for many of these Organizations. Furthermore, she enhanced her research development and wealth of knowledge with 11 publications in many spectrums of Behavioral Sciences. To deem Eleanor an asset to her profession would not remotely justify the immense credit she deserved for her decades of selflessness and incredibly motivated enduring and endearing dedication. Friends may call at the WILLIAMS FUNERAL HOME, 722 Ridge Road North, Ridgeway from 2-4 and 7-9 Tuesday. Funeral services in the chapel Wednesday morning at 11 o'clock. Interment Ridgeway Memorial Cemetery.

Ronald Glen Smothers Aug. 7, 1938 - Dec. 13, 2013 Born in Delano, CA, died in his sleep at home in Gold Beach, OR.  Ron's family moved to Merced, CA in 1944.  He attended Farmdale, Weaver and Merced High School, graduating in 1956.  Ron bought his first Flying A Service Station on Highway 99 and Child's Ave., then served in the U.S. Army from Dec. 1956 to Dec. 1958.    He married the former Jackie Ford April 12, 1959 and they had one child, Kelly.  Over the next 30 years, Ron owned the Flying A at 16th and L Streets and Smothers Deluxe Shell at 55 W. 16th St. He raced sports cars for years.  He became an avid hunter, belonging to the Modesto Properties Gun Club where he built a cabin and spent many a happy hour in a duck blind. He also enjoyed their pontoon boat on Lake McClure.   In 1992, Ron and Jackie moved to Gold Beach, OR and built their dream home overlooking the Pacific ocean.  Ron loved having company and enjoyed visits from his many friends.  Salmon fishing, crabbing and clamming became his new hobbies.  Ron worked for the Nesika-Ophir Water District for 12 years before retiring a 2nd time.   Ron suffered a stroke three years ago and recovered well.  He and Jackie volunteered for the local Hospice organization, helping to raise money through rummage markets.  He was the "bag man", passing out shopping bags and chatting with everyone.  He was also known as a "chick magnet" because of his still-blonde hair and sense of humor.   Ron is survived by his wife, Jackie of 54 years, daughter Kelly Thomason and her husband Wayne of Hot Springs, AR, granddaughters Emily (Stephen) Slone of St. Louis, MO and Shanelle (Nate) Sundin of Stayton, OR and two great-grandchildren, Gracie and Nathan, also of Stayton, OR.  He leaves behind his sister, Dianne (Don) Collins of Grovetown, GA and many nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his parents, Garnold and Opal Smothers, stepmother Velma and brothers Bob and Dennis.   A Celebration of Life was held December 20th at Ron and Jackie's home - it was a party Ron would have loved.   A later Celebration will be held in Merced in the Spring with an announcement to follow. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Coastal Home Health & Hospice PO Box 493 Gold Beach Or 97444 or your favorite charity.  www.cvobituaries.com

Samuel "Sam" Edward Toman, 90, of the East Mountain section of Scranton, died Thursday night at home after a long illness. He is survived by his wife, Maureen Toman. Born in Scranton, the son of the late Samuel and Anastasia Toman, he was a graduate of West Scranton High School. He was a WWII United States Army Air Corps veteran, serving with the 53rd Weather Recon. Upon returning from the war, Sam studied at Penn State, received his drafting degree from ITT, founded the Toman Construction Co. and was a general contractor in residence, commercial and industrial construction. Sam was a member of Scranton Elks Lodge 123, the Pine Hills T&A Golf League and volunteered with the American Red Cross for many years during many natural disasters, locally, nationally and internationally. Sam was the fifth registered life member of VFW Post 25, Rockwell Avenue, and a life member of the American Legion. He was also an avid golfer, hunter, fisherman, deep-sea fisherman and took trips to Canada many times with his younger son, the late Sam E. II.He is also survived by a son, Thomas E. Toman (Rachel), daughter-in-law, Sharon Toman, two daughters, Linda Derenick (Steve), Sharon McNamara, all of Scranton; eight grandchildren; four great-grandchildren; a sister, Margaret Buholski, Scranton; nieces, nephews and cousins. He was also predeceased by a son, Samuel E. Toman II; his first wife of 60 years, Eleanor; two brothers, John Pertiko and Frank Pertiko; two sisters, Mary Wasylyk and Ann Matan. A private graveside service will be held at the convenience of the family. There are no calling hours. Memorial donations may be made to St. Joseph's Center, 2010 Adams Ave., Scranton, PA 18509; St. Francis of Assisi Kitchen, 500 Penn Ave., Scranton, PA 18503; or the Salvation Army, 500 S. Washington Ave., Scranton, PA 18505. Arrangements are under the direction and care of the Edward J. Chomko Funeral Home & Cremation Services, West Scranton.

AUBREY DANE SAWYER, Jr., MD, 76 LAKELAND - A. Dane Sawyer, Jr. MD, died on Wednesday, August 21, 2013 at Hawthorne Inn of Lakeland Assisted Living Facility, after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease. Dr. Sawyer was born on November 10, 1936, in Jacksonville, FL and was the son of Margaret and Aubrey Sawyer. He attended Robert E. Lee High School and then obtained a B.S. Degree from the University of Florida in 1958, where he was a member of the Kappa Alpha Order. During the summers he served as a counselor and swimming coach at Y.M.C.A. Camp Greenville in Cedar Mountain, NC He loved doing this! . He married Jo Lee Blondheim on December 29, 1961, and obtained his MD degree from the University of Florida College of Medicine in June, 1962. He subsequently did his Internship in Pediatrics at Shands Teaching Hospital, Gainesville, FL 1963 and completed his Residency in Pediatrics at the University of Mississippi Hospital at Jackson, MS in June, 1965. He served in the U.S. Army at the U.S. Army Hospital, Fort Stewart, GA as Chief of Pediatric Service from 1965-1967. Their son, Dane III was born at Shands in 1963 and daughter, Amy Lynne, was born at Ft. Stewart in 1965. Dane moved his family to Lakeland in 1967 joining Boulware, Johnson and Boulware Pediatric Group. The group, including Dr. Ronal Haskins, joined the Watson Clinic in September, 1985. Dane was a Fellow of the American Academy of Pediatrics and a member of the Academy's Section on Adolescent Health. He served on the Executive Committee of the Florida Pediatric Society from 1986 - 1992. He was a Past President and Board Member of The Learning Resource Center, Board member of the Central Florida Speech & Hearing Center, consultant to Children's Medical Services and a member of the Polk County, Florida and American Medical Associations.  Dane was baptized and confirmed at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in Jacksonville, FL, and became a member of St. David's Episcopal Church in Lakeland from 1967 - 1991. He moved his membership to All Saints' Episcopal Church, Lakeland, in 1991, and faithfully served as a member of the Vestry and on the Boards of the Thrift Store and the Child Development Center. Dane loved the Florida beaches and vacationed there with his family. He enjoyed fishing and boating, spending much time at Ozello, his favorite spot! In addition, he also loved the Carolina Mountains - especially in the fall when the leaves were turning. Of course, he loved the football season and "His" Florida Gators! He was avid reader - historical novels were his forte'. Dane truly loved his church, his family, his patients and his friends. He and his family wanted to convey a special "thanks" to Kim Broom and the Hawthorne Inn staff as well as to the members of All Saints' Episcopal Church Order of St. Luke and to Good Shepherd Hospice of Auburndale. Dane was preceded in death by his parents and his daughter, Amy Lynne Hennessey. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, JoLee; son Dane, III Pamela of Rose Hill, VA.; sister, Suzi Loyd Jim of Atlanta, GA.; brother, Thomas Sawyer Duncan of Jacksonville and aunt, Shirley Winterburn of Jacksonville. He has five grandchildren, Neland Sawyer Amanda , Abbey Sawyer and Maggie, Alexandra and Jack Hennessey. He has one great granddaughter, Amy Sawyer. With gratitude, the family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to  Alzheimer's Association, 225 N. Michigan Ave., Chicago, IL., 60601 Floor 17 , Good Shepherd Hospice, 105 Arneson Ave., Auburndale, FL, 33823, All Saints' Episcopal Church Building Fund, 209 South Iowa Ave., Lakeland, FL 33801, or the charity of your choice. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, August 24 at 1pm at All Saints Episcopal Church. Condolences may be sent to the family www.heathfuneralchapel.com

William Bill Fredrick Bucholtz, of Tunk Valley, passed away at North Valley Extended Care in Tonasket on November 6, 2008. Bill was born in Riverside, WA on June 6, 1917, to Florence Flossie E. Smith and Fredrick Fred W. Bucholtz. As a child, he lived in Williams Lake, Canada, Sumas, WA and returned to Tunk Valley. He attended the Upper Tunk Valley School. As a young man of age 24, he entered into the U.S. Army during WWII and spent three years overseas as a Light Truck Driver. He earned Marksmanship, two Bronze Battle Stars for participation in the Central Pacific Campaigns and received several Medals of Honor. In March of 1945, he married Maxine Bobbie L. Marshall. Together, they had four children. After the passing of Bobbie, he remarried and divorced Shirley A. Millen. Bill had been an avid hunter since he was a young boy. He enjoyed skiing and making horse drawn bobsleds. Over the years, he worked as a logger for Herb Cotter, Clyde Freel, Charlie Atchison, George Whitaker, Vern Ewer, Cecil Tugaw and others. His passion was ranching. Bill is survived by his daughters, son and their spouses: Billie Jo Stalder (Chuck), Bonnie L. Bishop (Ron), Suzann L. Miller (Darrell) and Lloyd W. Bucholtz (Barbra). Fifteen grandchildren; and seven great-grandchildren also survive him. He was preceded in death by his wife, Bobbie; father, Fred; mother, Flossie; step-father, Horace Clough; sister, Ruth Townsend; half-brothers, Dick and Bob Clough; and grandson, Sherman Streng. Graveside Services will be held at Tunk Valley Cemetery on Saturday, November 15, 2008, at 1:00 p.m. followed by a Potluck dinner at 2:00 p.m. for family and friends at the Tunk Valley Grange. In lieu of flowers, memorials are suggested to a charity of ones choice. Arrangements entrusted to Precht-Harrison-Nearents Chapel.

EMERICH, Virginia A. "Ginny," 86, of Sun City Center, passed awaypeacefully with family at her side at the Hospice Inn in Melville, N.Y., July 8, 2006. She joined for eternity her husband, Charles "Bud" Emerich. who passed away in April. She is survived by her children, Scott Emerich, Brian Emerich, and Chris Penniman; and by her grandchildren, Scott, Nathan, Maxine, Alex and Eric. She leaves behind many close and supportive friends. Born in Elmira, N.Y., March 16, 1920, she was the daughter of Ruth and Edgar Haskell. She was a registered nurse. Ginny was a much loved wife, mother and grandmother. She and Bud lived in a number of communities, retiring to Sun City Center. An avid tennis player, Ginny also enjoyed playing golf with her family members and friends. Ginny was an accomplished artist and had a great sense of style that was evident in everything she did. Her terrific sense of humor brightened the lives of those around her. She will be dearly missed by her family and friends. Memorial donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 225 N. Michigan Ave., Floor 17, Chicago, IL 60601.

Kenneth R. Diestel, 76, Englewood, died Oct. 10, 2004. He was born Sept. 12, 1928, in St. Louis, Mo. He enlisted in the Navy in 1946 and served in the Korean and Vietnam wars. During his years of service, he also taught at both the Navy's submarine and nuclear power schools. After retiring from the Navy in 1967, he was employed as a technical writer at General Dynamics/Electric Boat Shipbuilding in Groton, Conn., retiring for a second time in 1987. He split his time between Connecticut and Florida, where he served in numerous capacities on the condominium association board of directors, most recently as association president. He was a member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, the American Legion, the U.S. Submarine Veterans, Fleet Reserve, and the Elks. Survivors include a daughter, Katherine Richmond of Pottstown, Pa.; daughters Judith Emory and Donna Lowery, both of Norwich, Conn.; a son, Robert of Gales Ferry, Conn.; a brother, Victor Robert of St. Louis, Mo.; and two grandchildren. A memorial Mass will be later. Burial with military honors will be Thursday in Avery Stoddard Cemetery in Gales Ferry, Conn. Church & Allen Funeral Homes of Gales Ferry, Conn., is in charge. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, 22107 Elmira Blvd., Port Charlotte, FL 33952.

LIRA Benavides, TexasLuz Lopez Lira went home peacefully to be with the Lord on July 10, 2011. She was a life-long resident of Benavides, Texas and a parishioner of Santa Rosa de Lima Catholic Church in Benavides, Texas. Luz Lopez Lira devoted her life to education and taught 47 years in the Benavides Independent School District. She was a dedicated teacher and the student success was a priority. She loved her profession and she gave it her all. She did everything wholeheartedly. During her tenure she taught Spanish, English, math and journalism. She was a member of P.T.A. and T.S.T.A. serving as president in the local school chapters. She was also a member of Delta Kappa Gamma, Beta Pi Chapter, Catholic Daughters of the Americas serving as regent of Father Juan Zavala Court 2012 local court. She sponsored F.T.A., C.Y.O. Organization, U.I.L., journalism, spelling, Spanish Club, the Eagles Nest and many other high school activities. She will be remembered and missed by her students and residents of Benavides.She is preceded in death by her parents, Dr. Francisco Lopez Lira and Taide Varela Lopez Lira, her sisters Carlota Lopez Lira and Taide Lopez Lira, her brothers, Salvador Lopez Lira and Tomas Lopez Lira. Luz is survived by her sister Virginia Lopez Lira Maldonado of Mexico City and numerous nieces and nephews. Rosary will be recited at 9:00 a.m. on Saturday, July 23, 2011 at Santa Rosa De Lima Catholic Church in Benavides, Texas and a Funeral Mass will follow at 10:00 a.m. that morning. The family of Luz Lopez Lira expresses their gratitude to Adriana Carrillo Terry and all of Luz's caregivers: Devyani Dave, Brenda Robertson, David Wallace, Laureanna Laragiaone, Isaac Rodriguez, Stanley Terry, Jimmie Terry, Stephanie Terry, Gema Ramirez, Adalberto Ramirez, Alicia Barron, Pat Curry, Isabella Baez, Carrillo, Anna Garcia, Inglantina Yzaguirre Casas, and Angelique Gonzalez and everyone else that helped with her care. Thanks to all her friends and students who visited her and cared about her. They also want to thank the NSCL, all the nurses physical therapists & staff, and Garza Funeral Home.Anyone wishing to leave condolences for the family may do so at www.garzafuneralhome.com Arrangements entrusted to:

F. Allen  Weisenfluh, 79 DELRAY BEACH, Fla. - F. Allen Weisenfluh, formerly of Cohasset, Mass., passed away on Friday, Dec. 20, 2013, at the age of 79, after a long struggle with complications from Parkinson's disease. He was born to his parents Frederick and Olive Weisenfluh in Ridgway, Pa., on Aug. 17, 1934. He served as a combat paratrooper in the 101st Airborne Division in the Korean War. He was a 1959 graduate of the Pennsylvania State University where he met his first wife Barbara. His career was fixed income portfolio management, most of which was spent as Senior Vice President at the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company in Boston.  He was predeceased by his parents; and by his wife Barbara. He is survived by his devoted second wife, Susan Neer Weisenfluh of Delray Beach and Scituate, Mass.; his daughter Pamela Lessard and son-in-law Kevin Lessard of Woodstock, Vt., his son Kurt and daughter-in-law Maura of Orinda, Calif., his son Bart and daughter-in-law Heather of Falmouth; and his eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 10 a.m. on Jan. 18, 2014, at The Second Congregational Church, Cohasset, Mass. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: The Scituate Animal Shelter 780 Chief Justice Cushing Highway Scituate, Massachusetts 02066 F. Allen Weisenfluh
Mass 10:30 a.m. at St. Patrick Catholic Church, Brighton.

Michael James TURNER Michael James Turner, beloved son of Jerry Lee Turner of Ballard, was a fierce and tender soul who left us on March 4 at the too-young age of 20. Born in Fort Lauderdale on July 1, 1989, he moved to Crown Hill with his dad in 1993. Michael was a spirited kid, a hard worker and a loyal friend who loved cars and music of all kinds. A night owl, he spent hours on Craigslist buying and selling cars and parts, and never met a car he didn't think he could fix. Mike had a dazzling smile, and a sweetness beneath his swagger. He attended the auto body program at SSCC, and graduated from Ballard High School in 2008 with plans to become a mechanic. He is dearly missed already. Survived by his father, two brothers, Thomas and Brian Kessel of Florida, dear friend, Stephanie Namciu of Seattle, grandparents Betty and Jim Turner, and uncle Jimmy Turner, all of Mentor, Ohio. A memorial celebrating his life will be held Saturday, April 10, 1:00 - 4:00 p.m. at Timberlake Church 1460 NW 73rd St., Seattle. Crema tion service at 4:00 p.m. Sunday, April 11 at Solie Funeral Home, 3301 Colby Ave., Everett.

LEONARD  Wanda Joy Walker Leonard, 65, of Gus Hill Road, Clemmons, died Tuesday at Forsyth Medical Center. A memorial service will be held at 5:00 p.m., Thursday in the Davidson Funeral Home Hickory Tree Chapel, with Kandi Thackett conducting the service. Mrs. Leonard was born September 23, 1942 in Cabarrus County to Alfred Ernest Walker and Beatrice Steeves Walker. She was a retired plant supervisor for Quality Embroidery, where she worked for 23 years. She had previously worked for Duracell. Mrs. Leonard was preceded in death by Keith Leonard who passed away in 1994 to whom she was previously married to, three brothers, Fredrick E. Walker, Floyd L. Walker, and John S. Walker, and a sister Caroline Walker Cash. Surviving are her two daughters, Stephanie Leonard Walser and husband Chris of Clemmons, and Danita Porter of Rural Hall; two grandchildren Chris Rogers, of Tampa, FL and Joe Biles of Kernersville, a sister, Effie M. Walker Mullis and husband Earl of Concord, and special family Susan, Marvin, and Wesley Little, several nephews, and a special friend Glenn Romesburg. She is also survived by Stoodles, Sassy, and Daisy her canines, and her many cats who brought joy to her life. The family will receive friends following the memorial service from 6:00 until 8:00 pm Thursday at the Davidson Funeral Home Hickory Tree Chapel. Memorials may be made to The Humane Society of Davidson County, PO Box 1791. Lexington, NC 27293; or to The American Red Cross, Northwest North Carolina Chapter, 690 Coliseum Drive, Winston-Salem, NC 27106. Davidson Funeral Home, Hickory Tree Chapel is serving the family. Online condolences may be made at www.davidsonfuneralhome.net.

Lyle Ray Nealon, 74, passed away at his home with his beloved family by his side Friday, Oct. 30, 2020. Lyle was known for his love of bluegrass; he picked the banjo with a skill that stemmed from years of careful devotion to his craft and, of course, a touch of natural talent. He enjoyed the outdoors - cutting hay and tending to his cattle with a humble admiration that only comes from one with a true reverence for the land and the creatures in it. Lyle also deeply loved his family, Chevrolet trucks and tractors. His family and friends will dearly miss him. He was greatly loved by his family who will continue to love him for the rest of their lives. He was preceded in death by his father, Houston Nealon. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Iretta Nealon; mother, Novalee Nealon; sons, Doug Nealon (Angela) and Bradley Nealon (Ramona); daughter, Cheryl Oran (Jason); grandsons, Joseph Nealon (Montana), Jacob Oran and Joshua Oran (Lacey); granddaughters, Mary Ann Sexton (Jake) and Laura Melton (Levi); and great-granddaughter, Hadley Oran, all of Rockwood. Other survivors include many cousins, loved ones and friends.The family met at 4 p.m. ET Sunday, Nov. 1, at Mt. Vernal Baptist Church Cemetery, Rockwood, for a graveside service with Bro. Jamie Nelson and Bro Wayne Nelson officiating. The family can draw comfort from Hebrews 4:16: "Let us therefore come boldly unto the throne of grace, that we may obtain mercy, and find grace to help in time of need." Evans Mortuary, Rockwood, is in charge of arrangements.

Marilyn GiffordMesa - Marilyn Gifford, age 87, died peacefully on July 14, 2019 at Dobson House, a Hospice of the Valley facility, in Chandler, Arizona, after a brief struggle with cancer. She was born in Friend, Nebraska to Art and Geraldine Meinke. Marilyn is survived by her son Gary (Becky) Barmore, her sisters Lois (Mel) Steggs and Jean Godaert, as well as her grandchildren, great grandchildren, nieces, and nephews.Marilyn enjoyed sewing and embroidery, getting together with family and friends, traveling, watching sports on television, and participating with various church groups.Marilyn chose whole body donation through Science Care Anatomical's HOPE program to further medical training and research.A memorial service will be held at Arizona Community Church, 9325 South Rural Road, Tempe, Arizona on Saturday, September 21 at 1:30PM. In lieu of flowers the family requests memorial donations in Marilyn's name be made to Hospice of the Valley, 1510 East Flower Street, Phoenix, Arizona, 85014.

GREENSBORO — Mr. Benjamin Ira Johnson, Sr., 82, passed away in the early morning hours of July 14, 2010 at Moses Cone Memorial Hospital.   A memorial service will be held 11:30 a.m. Saturday, July 17, 2010 at Rehobeth United Methodist Church with Reverend Ben Shepherd and Dr. Charles Adams officiating.   Mr. Johnson was born August 23, 1927 in Prince George Co., Maryland to the late Ira Neander and Addie Phifer Johnson.   Ben was a member of Rehobeth United Methodist Church, and a US Navy veteran (WWII). He was a builder in the construction industry for more than 35 years, overseeing various commercial and industrial projects across the southeast. In addition to his work, he greatly enjoyed collaborating on personal building projects for family and friends, and his help was sought after by many. His talent for woodworking and metalworking is evident in the numerous items he lovingly crafted for his children and grandchildren over the years.   Mr. Johnson is survived by his wife of 58 years, Polly McGee Johnson; daughters Cindy Stubbs (Dan) of Asheville; Robin Miller (Randy) of Newton; Linda Johnson of Cornelius; son, Benjamin, Jr. "Benjy" (Stephanie) of Greensboro; sister, Dolly Strickland (Lindell) of Summerfield; grandchildren, Kathryn Stubbs Fickett (Bradley) of Charleston, SC; Davis Benjamin Stubbs (Jillian) of Rabun Gap, GA; Addie Miller Bean (Chris) of High Point; Lucy Miller of Newton; Ashlyn Zales and David Zales, Jr. of Greensboro; Benjamin Johnson, III "Ben" and Abraham Johnson of Greensboro; and great granddaughter, Roxy Bean of High Point.   The family will receive friends beginning at 10 a.m. Saturday in the church sanctuary.   In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Rehobeth UMC Family Life Center Fund, 4475 Rehobeth Church Rd., Greensboro, NC 27406, or to Hospice and Palliative Care of Greensboro, 2500 Summit Ave., Greensboro, NC 27405.   George Brothers Funeral Service is assisting the family with arrangements.   Offer condolences at www.news-record.com/nr/obits/

Smith, Doris Dexter, Michigan Age 90, died Tuesday, September 13, 2011 at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital. She was born August 10, 1921 in Ann Arbor, the daughter of Hugo and Clara (Knapp) Volz. On January 20, 1980 she was preceded in death by her loving husband of 39 years, Neil Smith. They were married on March 1, 1941 in Ann Arbor. Survivors include four sons, Robert (Carol) Smith of Chelsea, Gerald (Barbara) Smith of Dexter, Thomas Smith of Dexter, and Steven Smith of Dexter; one daughter, Suzanne (Larry) Jones of Chelsea; a sister, Rosemary (Herbert) Clifford of North Carolina; six grandchildren, Jeffrey (Debbie), Kristine, Michael, Debra (Chris), Mark (Elizabeth), and Julie (Adam); ten great-grandchildren, Shon, Alex, Elliott, Michael, Elizabeth, Anna, Kaleigh, Kyra, Madeline, and Maxwell; and several nieces and nephews. She was preceded in death by a very special identical twin sister, Dorothy Peterson and a brother, George Volz. Doris graduated from Ann Arbor High School in 1940. She was a long time member of St. Andrew's United Church of Christ in Dexter, where she was very active in the choir, assisted in all church activities, and was always there when the church needed her. She loved animals, and really enjoyed the time spent with her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Doris was a loving person who took care of several family members. Funeral services will be held Saturday, September 17, 11:00 at St. Andrew's United Church of Christ, Dexter with the Reverend Larry Slambrook officiating. Burial will follow at St. Andrew's Cemetery, Dexter. The family will receive friends at Cole Funeral Chapel, Chelsea Friday, September 16 from 1 to 4 and 6 to 9 p.m. and at the Church Saturday from 10 to 11 a.m. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Andrew's United Church of Christ.

SKUBA, Charles R. Charles R. Skuba, 85, of West Hartford, husband of Marion (Macsarka) Skuba, died Thursday, (August 2, 2007) at West Hartford Health and Rehabilitation Center. Born in Florence, VT, the son of the late Charles and Sophie (Cylo) Skuba, he served in France with the U.S. Army during WWII. He graduated from the University of Vermont and earned a Masters Degree from the University of Hartford. Mr. Skuba began his career as a stockbroker with Walston, and eventually Advest, where he retired in 2002. He had recently been recognized for the 50 years he spent working in the stock market. He was active with his Bible Study Group for many years. Aside from his wife, he is survived by his three children, Karen Skuba of West Hartford, Charles "Chuck" Skuba and his wife, Kathy, of West Hartford, and Bonnie Timmerman and her husband, Erik, of Morrisville, VT; five grandchildren Elizabeth, Nathaniel, and Seth Skuba, and Alsacia and Freyja Timmerman; his brother-in-law, Frank Livak; and nephew, Mark Livak. He was predeceased by his sister Mildred Livak. Calling hours will be Sunday, 1 – 3 p.m. followed by a Funeral Service at 3 p.m. at the Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, 136 South Main Street, West Hartford. Burial will be in Proctor, Vermont. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 279 New Britain Road, Kensington, CT 06037.

HAMPTON - On Aug. 25, 2007, Fred Samuel Bennett of Hampton, Va., age 95, was beckoned into immortality by Almighty God who guided his last breath of life to a land of freedom, peace, quietness and rest. For the last year, Fred was in the loving care of the Walter Reed Convalescent and Rehabilitation Center in Gloucester, Va.Fred was born to the late Elie and Violet E. Bennett on May 15, 1912, in Wadesboro, N.C. Fred met and married the late Harriet Staton in North Carolina in 1933 and later remarried Victoria Rivers in 1948. Fred has one son, Fred Thomas Bennett. Fred retired from the Civil Service in 1963.Fred Bennett was a member of Miracle Temple Baptist Church in Newport News, Va., where the Rev. Dr. F. M. Blackwell is the Pastor. He loved spending time at the Senior Citizens Center on Kecoughtan Road in Hampton, where he was fondly given the nickname, ' Rooster'.He leaves to cherish many nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Fred was loved by all and will surely be missed.A viewing will be held 10:30 a.m. to noon on Thursday, Aug. 30, 2007, at Miracle Temple Baptist Church, 617 32nd Street, Newport News, VA. A funeral service will be held at noon Thursday, Au. 30, 2007, at Miracle Temple Baptist Church. The Bennett family is receiving services of comfort at Nicholson-Cummings Funeral Home, 4304 Victoria Blvd., Hampton. (757) 728-0122.

William E. PIERSON, M.D. Age 77, passed away on September 3, 2011 at the Anderson House in Shoreline, Washington. His wife of 54 years, Louisa Brown Pierson, and his children were at his side. Dr. Pierson was born on May 5, 1934 in Spokane, WA to Lucille and Wren Pierson. He grew up in Cheney, WA, graduated from Cheney High School in 1952, and went on to the University of Washington where he was a member of Phi Delta Theta fraternity. He graduated in 1956. He earned his medical degree from Northwestern University in 1960. Dr. Pierson served in the U.S. Navy from 1960 to 1963 as a medical officer aboard ship (USS Kearsarge CVS-33) and at Bremerton Naval Hospital. Dr. Pierson interned at Harborview Medical Center, and did his allergy residency and fellowship at Seattle Children's Hospital. Dr. Pierson was one of the original partners in N.W. Asthma and Allergy and Springbrook Associates where he practiced pediatric allergy. He eventually rose to become the Chairman of the Washington State Medical Association and later President of the American Academy of Allergy and Immunology. He was a clinical professor during his entire career at the University of Washington School of Medicine and Co-Director of the Department of Allergy at Children's Hospital. In 1984, he proudly served on the U.S. Olympic Committee. Dr. Pierson was devoted throughout his life to his wife, his family, his parish, Assumption/St. Bridget's, his neighborhood, Laurelhurst, and his alma mater, the University of Washington. He is survived by his wife, Louisa; his five children, Bill Pierson, Jr., Marnee Iseman, Christie Bush, Frank Pierson, Tom Pierson; and seven grandchildren. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated Wednesday, September 14th, at 4:00 p.m. at St. Bridget Catholic Church. 4900 NE 50th St., Seattle, 98105. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to The Pierson Lectureship or Allergy Fellowship at Seattle Children's Hospital, 4800 Sandpoint Way N.E., Seattle, WA 98105. Please sign Dr. Pierson's on-line Guest Book at the obit website Hoffner Fisher & Harvey

James "Jim" Howard Baker, Jr. September 13, 1947 - July 26, 2020Resident of AptosJim passed away last month in the arms of his beloved wife, Hope, in their mountain home in Aptos. He left us all too soon, sorrowfully succumbing to lung cancer.Originally from San Francisco, he built his dream home in the Aptos forest creating a paradise where he was the most gracious of hosts, sharing his love for nature, animals, fine wine and cooking with family and friends. Jim was a strong advocate of improving health and fitness at every age, and was a co-owner of CrossFit Santa Cruz Central. He was an innovator in the field for seniors and was sought out for his expertise by CrossFit trainers around the world. Before that, Jim was an educator for 26 years, as a devoted principal for both special needs and alternative school students. His kind heart, generosity and loving spirit touched many in both his personal and professional lives.Jim had a passion for travel, having visited countless countries to explore the life and culture of others. His sense of humor was appreciated by all, and his bright eyes and infectious smile seemed to be the only stamps needed on his passport to be welcomed in.Jim is survived by his wife; Hope Rhode Baker, brothers; Rick Baker and Danny Baker, former wife; Debby Baker, son and daughter-in-law; Sean and Kristen Rogers and grandchildren; Shane and Reese. He was preceded in death by his parents; James Howard Baker, Sr. and Anna Uglesich Baker.In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Kainos Home and Training Center, 3631 Jefferson Avenue, Redwood City, CA 94062. If you would like to offer your condolences to Jim's family, share your memories (or photos) or light a candle in his honor, please visit www.scmemorial.com. Jim's Celebration of Life details will also be announced on the above website at a later date. View the online memorial for James "Jim" Howard Baker, Jr.

Ervin F. Kastning Born August 14, 1919 to Herman and Louise Kastning in Itasca, Illinois, passed away March 28, 2008. He is survived by the love of his life, his wife Lorraine and daughters, Beverly Trunick, Dar (Mike) Beck and Barbara Christenson. He has six grandchildren, Ron (Dina) Trunick, Wendy Trunick, Erin (Jim) Spray, Tanner Morgan, Ryan (Erica) Christenson and Tyler Morgan and three great-grandchildren. He and Lorraine were married in Itasca, Illinois on May 20, 1944. They lived in Illinois until 1996, when they moved to Arizona, after wintering in Green Valley for six years. They eventually wintered in Green Valley and summered in Pinetop. Erv attended Business College in Illinois. In 1946 he joined State Farm and was a dedicated and extremely successful agent for 41 years. After retiring, he and Lor enjoyed golf and traveling together. They will always be Erv and Lor - Lor and Erv. He was devoted to his family and adored by his daughters. Erv will always be remembered as kind, loving, thoughtful, the eternal optimist, without an enemy in the world. A celebration of life will be held Friday, April 11, 2008 at 3:00 p.m. at Valley Presbyterian Church in the Spiritual Life Center, 2800 S. Camino del Sol, Green Valley, Arizona. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to your favorite charity in Erv's name. You are "simply the best" Dad, we love you and will miss you dearly.

WOODWARD Mary Jo Mary Jo Woodward, age 73, of Holland and formerly of Laguna Hills, California, died Monday June 11, 2007, at Spectrum Health System, Butterworth Campus in Grand Rapids. She was born September 29, 1933, in Toledo, Ohio, to Charles and Loretta (Fawcett) Smith. She was a graduate of Ottawa High School in Ottawa, Ohio and graduated from the Toledo School of Nursing in 1954. She received her bachelor of science degree in nursing from California State University at Long Beach in 1976. Mary Jo was employed by the American Red Cross, retiring in 1991. She married Edwin Woodward in 1960, and later divorced. Mary Jo was a member of the Crystal Cathedral in Garden Grove, California for 34 years, where she also served as a tour guide. She is survived by a daughter, Linda (Vince) Bush of Zeeland; a son, Randy (Dora) Woodward of Tacoma, Washington; 3 grandchildren; a brother, Melvin "Bud " (Paulette) Smith of Pandora, Ohio. Memorial services will be held Thursday, 11:00 a.m. at Freedom Village. Memorials may be given to the Myelodysplastic Syndrome Foundation. Arrange-ments are by the Dykstra Life Story Funeral Home, Holland. Visit  www.lifestornet.com  for further information.

HEENAN WILLIAM L. , William (Bill) L. Heenan, 88, died Tuesday, April 3 in Fayetteville, Arkansas. He was born February 11, 1919 in Columbus, Ohio to Flora and William J. Heenan, who both died when Bill was a young child. He was raised by his maternal aunt and uncle Louise & Forest Irwin in Columbus. After graduating from Ohio State University and serving in the U.S. Army in the Pacific, he moved to Dallas, Texas and practiced architecture there until 1998, when he moved to Fayetteville, Arkansas to be near family. He was preceded in death by his wife of 44 years, Elizabeth Shea Heenan and two sisters, Jane Heenan and Ruth Meany. Bill attended college at Ohio State University in Columbus, where he earned an architecture degree. He entered the U. S. Army as a second lieutenant in 1942 and was stationed at the Engineering School at Fort Belvoir, Virginia and at Camp Beauregard, Louisiana before his unit was dispatched overseas, first to Karachi, India, then Calcutta and finally Burma, where he helped build the Burma Road. After his discharge in 1945, he joined an architecture firm in Columbus, Ohio. In 1947 he was recruited by a Dallas architecture firm and married Betty Shea of Little Rock, AR. They subsequently became business partners, specializing in residential and hospitality interior design and architecture in Dallas and other cities. Bill was a great lover of art, a devoted husband, father and grandfather as well as an accomplished baker. He loved to share his home baked breads and cookies with friends and family. Survivors include a daughter, Elizabeth Shea Weidner and her husband Gary, of Fayetteville, three grandchildren, Matthew Weidner of Fayetteville, Christine Crain of Kansas City, Carolyn Dux & her husband Damon of Atlanta, Georgia, a step-grandson Aaron Weidner & his wife Beverly of Kansas City, and a niece, Diane Vandervoort of Columbus, Ohio. Memorial services will be held at Butterfield Trail Village in Fayetteville, Saturday, April 7 at 2:00 p.m. with The Rev. Lowell Grisham of St. Pauls Episcopal Church officiating. Moores Funeral Chapel, Fayetteville, is handling arrangements. Graveside services will take place at Hillcrest Memorial Park in Dallas on Monday, April 9 at 11:00 a.m. Arrangements are being handled by Sparkman/Hillcrest Funeral Home of Dallas. In lieu of flowers, donations may be to St. Pauls Episcopal Church, 224 N. East St., Fayetteville, AR 72701. To sign the online guest book, visit www.mooresfuneralchapel.com Moore's Chapel Fayettevilles, AR 479-442-7314 OB6 Obituaries, Notices

FT. WALTON BEACH, Fla. Sarah Graham Cork, age 87, of Ft. Walton Beach, Fla., formerly of Tuscaloosa, died July 26, 2007, at Ft. Walton Beach Medical Center. Services will be 2:30 p.m. Sunday, July 29, 2007, at Trinity United Methodist Church with Rev. Dan Kilgore and Rev. Alan Head officiating. Burial will follow in Tuscaloosa Memorial Park with Memory Chapel Funeral Home, a Dignity Memorial Provider, directing. Visitation will be tonight from 5 to 7 p.m. at the funeral home. The body will lie in state one hour prior to services at the church.Her husband, Walter C. Cork, three brothers and four sisters preceded her in death.Survivors include her daughters, Sallie Reeder Colwick (Larry) of Huntsville, Ala. and Candy Williamson (David) of Niceville, Fla.; sister, Lois Hulsey of Tuscaloosa, Ala.; sister-in-law, Willene B. Graham of Mobile, Ala.; brother-in-law, Wilburn Hamner of Romulus, Ala.; grandchildren, Jeremy Reeder (Stephanie), John Reeder, Luke Williamson (Melanie), Paul Williamson (Heather) and Katie Williamson; and great grandchildren, Mark and Julian Reeder, Ian and Abby Williamson.Sarah was born on December 7, 1919, in Romulus, Tuscaloosa County, to John C. Graham and Preasha East Graham. She graduated from Tuscaloosa County High School in 1937. She worked as a salesperson at Sears, Belk Hudson and J.C. Penney, and as a librarian at Jemison School. She was the activity director at Heritage Nursing Home and was president of the Alabama Association of Activity Co-ordinators.She was a charter member of Trinity United Methodist Church of Tuscaloosa. She was awarded lifetime membership in United Methodist Women.She and her husband owned and operated Corks Christmas Tree Farm in Tuscaloosa County. In 1991 she published a children's book about their experiences, "The Bottlestoppers Christmas Tree Farm".Pallbearers will be her grandsons and Lyman Hulsey and David Hall.Honorary pallbearers are the Fellowship Sunday School Class and Explorers in Faith UMW, and the Tuscaloosa County High Class of 1937.

David Joseph Lawson David was born in Champaigne, Illinois on November 21, 1940 to Glenn and Louise Lawson, passed on Friday July 4, 2008 at 4:30 am while fighting a fire in his home in Montgomery Creek, California. "Joe", as he was affectionately known, attended school at Western Illinois University, grade school and High School in Macomb, Illinois, graduating in the class of 1958.  Joe entered the U.S. Marine Corps shortly thereafter and worked his way up to the rank of Sergeant. He took great pleasure in scuba diving and as swim instructor and swim facility operator for USMC Force Recon.  Honorably discharged in 1961, Joe attended and graduated from Cabrillo College in Aptos, California in 1964. Joe received his Bachelor of Science degree in Physical Therapy from Long Beach State University in 1968. He launched and managed a successful Physical Therapy practice in Los Gatos, California for twenty years. At a seminar in 1987, Joe met Zayda Pascual, who became his business partner, companion, best friend and sweetheart.  The two opened new branches and expanded their therapy business further into the San Francisco Bay Area, opening several successful therapy clinics throughout the greater Bay Area.   Joe and Zayda purchased a ranch and retired to Round Mountain, California in 1992 where he loved living on his picturesque ranch reforesting- planting trees replacing those ravished by the devastating forest fire. Joe loved fishing and 'garage sailing' in his spare time. He was an avid white water rafter and a participant in the National Geographic expedition which traversed the length of the Tigris River in India by raft. His contagious smile and boisterous laughter will be dearly missed and always treasured. He is survived by his long time companion and best friend, Zayda Pascual of Round Mountain, California and his three children, Joseph Scott Lawson, Lynn Lawson, and Laura Lawson of Aptos, California.  He is also survived by his three grandchildren, Brittany Langreder, Jasmyne Lawson, and Alyxandra Lawson of Aptos, California and by his three loving siblings, Marilynn Mc Coin, of Branson, Missouri, Carole Herrmann, of Creve Coeur, Illinois, and Ronald Lawson of Saratoga, California. A military memorial service, conducted by the Veteran's Association in Montgomery Creek, California is scheduled for Saturday, July 12, 2008 at 2:00 pm followed by a small reception at the Round Mountain Community Center. A second memorial service will be conducted in Macomb, Illinois on July 26, 2008 at the Assembly of God Church at 1:00 pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions are requested to be made to an organ donor association or can be sent in care of: Zayda Pascual, PO Box 152, Montgomery Creek, CA 96065.

LITTLE EGG HARBOR -- Kamil J. "Shorty" Malinowski, 71, died Thursday at the Southern Ocean County Hospital, Manahawkin.A resident of Little Egg Harbor, "Shorty" grew up in Trenton, attended Trenton High School and began a sheet metal career, which spanned 51 years. He joined the U.S. Marine Corps and served from 1956 through 1960. He was a sheet metal journeyman, then served as the president of the Sheet Metal Workers' Local 27 Retirement Club for the past 11 years."Shorty" was passionate about fishing, boating, crabbing, claming and scouting. He demonstrated leadership and craftsmanship in everything he pursued.Surviving are his wife, Maryann; three sons and their wives, Norman and Kendall, Michael and Juliette, William and Donna; four stepsons and their wives, Joseph Jr. and Carol, Craig and Deborah, Timothy and Sue, Jonathan and Joanne Hepworth; nine granddaughters, Brittany and Brianna Malinowski, Rikki Kay, Leslie, Tina, Jacklyn, Victoria, Elizabeth, and Grace Hepworth; and also three siblings, Helen Walker, Joseph Malinowski, and John Malinowski.There will be no funeral services per his wishes.In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your favorite charity.

Allen, Alice Rose Louise (nee Poske) Ypsilanti, MI Age 88, died on Wednesday, April 5, 2006. She was born in Batesville, IN on February 22, 1918, the daughter of Ethel Sophia (nee Huber) and Fred Henry Poske. Mrs. Allen worked as a draftswoman for Batesville Casket Co. and for General Electric until she had her two daughters. She and her husband lived in New Haven, IN, Toledo, OH, and Indianapo lis, IN. After her husband re tired, they moved to Carmel, IN where they lived for over 20 years before moving to Ann Ar bor and Ypsilanti to be near their daughter. Mrs. Allen was a member of PEO and a long time member of Broadripple Garden Club and Pleasant View Luther an Church in Indianapolis, IN. She and her husband loved to play bridge and were members of various bridge clubs over the years. Her daughter, Janet Durbin and son-in-law Wesley Durbin, grandson Stephen Doan, sisters-in-law and broth er-in-law Doris Poske, Virginia Allen Dawes, Jo Allen, and Leslie Allen, survive Mrs. Allen. Mrs. Allen is also survived by nieces and nephews Carol Poske Roberts, Daniel and William Poske, Christopher Dawes, and Sherry Allen Hardin. She was preceded in death by her loving husband of 64 years Robert Stanley Allen, her daughter Barbara Elizabeth Allen, and her brother Huber Henry Poske. Funeral services will be held at 11:30 on Satur day, April 8th, at Muehlig Funeral Chapel (403 S. Fourth Ave., Ann Arbor), with visitation from 10:30 until the time of the service. Burial to follow at Beth lehem Cemetery. Those who wish may direct memorial con tributions to St. Louis Center, 16195 Old US 12, Chelsea, MI 48118.

Marilyn Jane JorgensenOct. 18, 1925 -Dec. 30, 2017Marilyn Jane Jorgensen passed away on December 30, 2017 at John Knox Village in Lee's Summit, MO, at the age of 92. She was born to parents Edward J. and Eleanor (Nellar) Normington in Milwaukee, WI, on October 18, 1925. Marilyn attended Iowa State University where she met Jerold (Jerry) Jorgensen. They were married in 1945 and moved to Forest City, IA, where he had his veterinary practice for 25 years, and here they raised their family. Ida Anderson, 89, Bismarck, died Jan. 22, 2001, in a Bismarck hospital. Services will be held at 10:30 a.m. Friday at Our Savior's Lutheran Church, Bottineau, with burial in Oak Creek Cemetery, Bottineau.Visitation will be from 10 a.m.-9 p.m. today at Nero Funeral Home, Bottineau, and will continue at the church one hour before services.Ida A. Anderson, a daughter of Julius and Augusta (Heuer) Gonitzke, was born on the family farm near Kramer, on March 22, 1911. She was raised and educated at Kramer. On Feb. 15, 1928, she was married to Edmund G. Klebe at Bottineau, and in 1945 the couple moved to Grand Forks. Mr. Klebe later passed away.She taught ceramics, and was affiliated with the Ceramics Association in Grand Forks. In 1972, she moved to Bismarck. She was later married to Jack Anderson, and he passed away a number of years ago. Except for a few years living in Bottineau, she has made her home in Bismarck since.While living in Grand Forks, she was a member of Immanuel Lutheran Church, and the women's organizations within the church. In Bismarck she was a member of Zion Lutheran Church. She was also a member of Senior Citizen's groups in Bismarck, including the Swing Band, and other musical groups.She is survived by one daughter, Carole Klebe, Bismarck; one daughter-in-law, Myrtle Klebe, Des Plains, Ill.; three grandsons; six great-grandchildren; one sister, Augusta Bauch, Puyallup, Wash.; and one brother, Elmer Gonitzke, Inkster.In addition to her husbands, she was preceded in death by one son, Virgil; her parents; five sisters; and six brothers.Memorials are preferred to Shepherd Hills Retreat at Bottineau, or Zion Lutheran Church in Bismarck.
