JOHN PHILIP WEST APRIL 18, 1923-JAN 30 2009 After a long battle with pneumonia, John West died on January 30th, 2009 in Modesto, CA. He is survived by his sister, Charlotte Haass, her husband, John Haass of Casper, WY and their 10 children. John was preceded in death by his mother, Louise West and sister, Susan Hughes. John West was born in Quincy, Illinois in 1923. He was a veteran of World War II where he served in the U.S. Army in Europe. After the war he remained in Europe and learned the art of pipe organ building and repair. John was also a talented organist. He received his Master of Music degree from the St. Louis Institute of Music in 1952. Prior to residing in Modesto he lived many years in San Francisco and Pleasant Hill, CA, where he built and installed pipe organs in and around the bay area. He was church organist at Church of the Advent in San Francisco for 25 years. After moving to Modesto, in 2004, he enjoyed travel, daily visits to the library and retirement.www.modbee.com/obituaries

Judy Coleman passed away from the side effects of Parkinson's Disease on Wednesday, March 18, 2020. She was 77 years old. A memorial service will be held graveside at Resthaven Memorial Park Tuesday afternoon at 1:00 pm, April 20, 2021. An only child, she was born Judy Uhrig February 7, 1943 in Santa Maria, California. The family moved to Midland in 1948. At an early age she was bitten by the ballet bug and marveled at troupes such as the Ballet Russe that traveled through Midland in the fifties. She graduated Midland High School and at Texas Christian University took a double major in ballet and theatre. Judy successfully auditioned for the Radio City Music Hall Ballet Corp in New York City and as the shortest member of the group she danced several seasons at the end of the line. She made lifelong friends from the experience. In 1991 Judy had moved back to Midland and opened her own studio, Coleman Academy, a school of ballet for girls (and a few boys) of all ages. The following year she founded Midland Festival Ballet as a non-profit performance outlet for her students. The production grew to a full-length version of "The Nutcracker" with live music from the Midland-Odessa Symphony and Chorale. At its 25th year Celebration the MFB Board established the Judy Coleman Scholarship Fund, which provides pointe shoes and lessons for promising children needing assistance. Over the years several students have moved on to professional careers. Judy was preceded in death by her parents, Fred and Nell Uhrig. She is survived by her husband Bill Warren of Midland and his children Shannon Cochran of Kingwood and Kelly Blankenship of Plano. Memorials may be made to the Judy Coleman Scholarship Fund, Midland Festival Ballet, P.O. Box 52034, Midland, Texas 79710.

TROXEL, JR.,   SAMUEL H.  91, of Waterman Village, Mount Dora, died on May 3, 2008. He was born in Quakertown, PA to the late Samuel H. Troxel and Daisy Druckenmiller Troxel on September 22, 1916. He received his B.S. degree in Electrical Engineering from Lehigh University and after graduation was employed by Philadelphia Electric Company until 1941 when he was commissioned an Ensign in the U.S. Naval Reserve and assigned to the Bureau of Ships in New Jersey inspecting various size vessels destined for service in WW II. He was later assigned to the Navy spare parts agency in New York City until the end of the war with a commission of Lt. Commander. After that he went to work for Strong-Cobb Company, a pharmaceutical company in Cleveland, Ohio as Plant Engineer. Later on he worked for Ohio Bell Telephone Company from which he retired in 1978. While working in Cleveland he was active in the Professional Engineers Society, was a Councilman then Mayor of Bentleyville, Ohio and a member of Kiwanis. Upon retirement Sam and his wife of 66 years moved to Arizona where they lived for 20 years. Sam played trumpet in the Sun City Concert Band for 15 years. For many years he delighted children and adults with his drawing of a man's face with numbers from one to ten. Sam and his wife moved to Florida in 1999 to be near their daughter. He is survived by his wife Dorothy Stem  Troxel; brother David I. Troxel (Jean); daughter Betty Jane Perrow (Roy); son Jon E.  Troxel (Nancy); and two granddaughters Elizabeth Shuman (William) and Kathryn Troxel. Sam was a member of the Shaker Heights Unitarian Church. Memorial services will be private. Burial will be at the Florida National Cemetery in Bushnell, FL.

Santiago "Jimmy" Parra After a lengthy illness, Santiago "Jimmy" Parra, 54, of Guadalupe passed away on May 11, 2011, surrounded by loved ones. Jimmy, also known as Chago to his family, was born on July 25, 1956 in Los Angeles, California. When he was 11 years old, his parents moved the family to Guadalupe where Jimmy was a student at local schools then attended Ernest Righetti High School and received his GED later in life. For 28 years Jimmy worked as a fork lift operator at Guadalupe Cooling. Through the years he developed many wonderful friendships thanks to his charisma, charm and inability to pass up a get-together with people he cared about. His smile was contagious and he was very generous with it! Jimmy collected models and Homies figurines but in the months prior to his death his attention shifted to what mattered most to him: his family. He would spend hours piecing together collages from pictures that he had collected of family portraits and gatherings. His family was a vital portion of who he was but his 2 children were what truly brightened his world. The love and pride that he felt for them whenever he mentioned their names was tangible. It was obvious that he considered Matthew and Alina the greatest achievements of his life. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Jimmy is survived by his children: Matthew James Parra and Alina Nicole Parra both of Oahu, Hawaii; Sisters, Maria Antonia Sanchez (Miguel) of Bakersfield, Maria Elena Munoz (Francisco) of Santa Maria and Maryann Canas of Guadalupe; brothers: Roberto Parra Jr. of Guadalupe, Rogelio Parra (Frances) of Santa Maria and Anthony Parra of Guadalupe as well as numerous nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his parents: Roberto and Jennie Parra, his sister Rosemary Rodriguez and nephews: Miguel Sanchez Jr. and Jose Juan Sanchez. A rosary will be held on Friday, May 20, 2011 at 7:00 p.m. in Guadalupe at Our Lady of Guadalupe Catholic Church. A memorial mass will be said in his honor on Saturday, May 21, 2011 at 10:30 a.m. also at Our Lady of Guadalupe Catholic Church followed by a reception at Calvary Chapel at 4719 West Main Street, Suite A in Guadalupe. Arrangements are under the direction of Dudley-Hoffman Mortuary, Crematory and Memory Gardens.  Dudley-Hoffman Mortuary & Crematory (805) 922-8463 www.dudleyhoffmanmortuary.com

died peacefully on Saturday, June 3, 2017, at the age of 85. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Dr. Hermann "Bud" Menges, Jr., and son Fritz L. Menges. She is survived by her children, Katherine, William, Peter (Elizabeth Finegan), David (Kimberly O'Gorman), and John; and her grandchildren, Andrew, Emily, Kyle, Jake, Erin, Carly, Bobby, Sean, Daniel, and Cara. She was a graduate of Wellesley College, and the Harvard Graduate School of Education. She was a talented 7th grade English teacher for a number of years before turning her attention to raising her young children. Family was everything to Sally. Above all, she was a devoted wife, mother, mother-in-law, and grandmother. She took special pleasure in watching her children and grandchildren participate in their assorted sports and activities, and she showed genuine interest in their ongoing exploits. Sally loved to travel, and family trips, especially to the mountains of West Virginia or Lake George, New York, were of particular delight to her. Trips alone with Bud or together with their friends were frequent and meaningful to her. Sally was very active within the community. Born and bred in Cleveland, she loved the cultural vitality that the city has to offer, and she expressed that love by giving generously with her time to a number of charitable organizations. Arts education was a particular passion of hers because it blended together Sally's profound love for music with her devotion to education. She was also very active within the local Alcoholics Anonymous community for over 30 years, serving as a role-model, sponsor, and mentor to countless people. Sally was deeply spiritual. Plymouth Church of Shaker Heights was a uniquely special place to her, where she and Bud were married, where her children were baptized, and where she worshipped throughout the better part of her life. Selfless, eternally hopeful, and positive, Sally was a joy to be with. Her warm, calm, and smiling presence will be sorely missed by those who knew and loved her. Charles Leonard Wallace, 77, of Charlotte, died Tuesday, December 31, 2002 at Presbyterian Hospital following a courageous battle with cancer.His funeral service will be held 11 a.m. Friday, January 3, at the Wilson Chapel of Hankins & Whittington Funeral Service, 5301 Albemarle Road. The Rev. Mike Farley will officiate. Interment will follow in Evergreen Cemetery. Scott Bland, Chris Helms, Eddie Thompson, Randy Griffies, Justin Bland and Joseph Thompson will serve as active pallbearers, and Zachariah Helms will serve as honorary pallbearer.Born October 16, 1925 in Charlotte, Mr. Wallace was the son of the late Zeb and Nell Aycock Wallace. He was a graduate of Old Tech High School and was a U.S. Army, World War II Veteran, having served in Germany and Austria.Mr. Wallace retired in 1991 from The Charlotte Observer/The Charlotte News Composing Room after 42 years of service. He was a member of East Gate Masonic Lodge, The Oasis Temple and Scottish Rite Bodies.Mr. Wallace enjoyed life to the fullest, deriving the most joy through his wife, daughters, sons-in-law and especially his grandchildren. He loved spending time and vacationing with his family, and enjoyed dining with them at the Landmark Diner.Survivors include his loving wife of 44 years, Trudy Wallace; and three daughters, Becky Bland, her husband, Scott and their children, Justin and Rachel, all of Davidson, Jana Helms, her husband, Chris and their children, Ashleigh, Zachariah and Hannah, all of Matthews, and Lisa Thompson, her husband, Eddie and their children, Joseph and Emily, all of Concord; and a sister, Joyce Pallagut of Greensboro.Memorials may be made to Hospice at Charlotte, 1420 East Seventh Street, Charlotte, NC 28204.The family expresses their appreciation to Hospice at Charlotte, and caregivers Minnie and Dot for their loving care and compassion.Arrangements are by the Wilson Chapel of Hankins & Whittington Funeral Service, 5301 Albemarle Road, online at hankinsandwhittington.com.

Walker, Mary Lou SELKIRK May Lou Walker, 58, entered heaven on Saturday, July 27, 2011. After several months battling congestive heart failure she left this world quickly while vacationing with family at a favorite state park in Virginia. Mary Lou was a graduate of Ravena-Coeymans-Selkirk High School in 1971 and Nyack College in 1975. She and her husband were members of the Wycliffe Bible Translators and had lived, worked and raised their four children in Papua New Guinea for most of the 30 years of their married life. She was involved in providing support services (hospitality, post office, preschool and personnel) for the missionaries who worked at that remote station. Mary Lou is survived by her husband Steve and their children Ben (Maggie), Daniel, Nick and Julie; her parents, Chet and Joan Bolen; her siblings, Bruce (Katrina), Nancy, Jill (Rance), Bobby (Joanne), Jim (Pam), Melissa (Kevin), Wally, Cathy (Bill), Richard (Lisa), Chip (Lorraine) and Jennifer (Rob). Also surviving are many nieces, nephews and cousins. She was preceded in death by her sister Ginny. Mary Lou had a gift of hospitality and was able to put others at ease with her sense of humor and easy going nature. She loved her large family and many friends, but especially her Lord and those less fortunate than herself. She wanted to see others come to know her Savior, particularly those in Papua New Guinea with no access to the Bible in their own language. Funeral services will be on Saturday at 10 a.m. at Pineview Community Church, Washington Ave. Ext., Albany. Calling hours will be Friday from 5 to 8 p.m. at New Comer Cannon Funeral Home, 343 New Karner Rd., Colonie (Rt. 155-south of Central Avenue). Interment will be in Elmwood Cemetery, Selkirk. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Wycliffe at www.wycliffe.org in memory of Mary Lou Walker. To leave a special message with the family online, visit www.newcomeralbany.com.

Dysart Donald "Don" Neff of the Brightview Community in Annapolis died peacefully on August 7, 2021. He was 89. Born in Los Angeles to Harold and Gwenda Neff in 1932, Don grew up in southern California where he developed an early love for automobiles and mechanics, an avocation that turned into a lifetime career. After a stint in the U.S. Navy during the Korean War era, Don entered the automotive and industrial supply industry, where he worked for decades as an engineer. His work took him and his family from California to New Jersey and Oklahoma before eventually settling in Annapolis fifteen years ago. Those who knew Don remember him as always laughing, telling captivating stories, sharing memories, and offering useful advice. He fixed everything in sight, from toasters to bicycles to cars: his grandkids called him "Pop Pop Who Fixes." He is survived by his wife of more than 55 years, the former Karen Lee Zetsche; two brothers, Glenn of Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, and Paul of Newport Beach, California; two sons, Darrell of Bayville, New Jersey, and Kevin of Greenville, California, a daughter Jennifer Neff Macris of Annapolis, Maryland; eight grandchildren, and five great grandchildren. A service will be held at St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Annapolis on Tuesday, October 12th at 3pm. His committal will be at the Los Angeles National Cemetery at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the Servant's Heart Foundation in Newport Beach, California.

Andrew K. Tanzola Mantua, N.J. Our Angel, Andrew K. Tanzola, age 20, of Mantua passed away suddenly on Saturday, August 12, 2017. Andrew graduated from Clearview Regional High School in 2015 and from GCIT in 2016 with a certification in Automotive Mechanics. Survived by his mother, Catherine Tanzola and her fiance, Dave Chicosky, brother, Nicholas Tanzola and his wife, Angela, sister, Tracy Tanzola, grandmother, Ann Musumeci, along with numerous aunts, uncles, and cousins. Predeceased by his father Kenneth, maternal grandfather Angelo Musumeci, and paternal grandparents, Dave and Dolores Tanzola. If you look in Webster's Dictionary for the definition of smile, it says "a pleased, kind or amused facial expression usually showing friendliness." The first thing most people who knew Andrew remember or comment about is how he was always smiling. His smile lit up a room so bright you'd wish you had your sunglasses on. Look no further than Facebook or Twitter for comments from his friends and loved ones about what a kind, easy going, friendly soul he was who always liked to joke around and laugh. Friendliness was second nature for him. He was an avid fan of basketball (76ers), baseball (Phillies), and football (Steelers). He played basketball and football for the Clearview Youth Program and baseball for Mantua Township Little League, where he met and befriended countless good kids. The world will forever be partly cloudy without this ray of sunshine in it! He truly will be missed. Family and Friends are invited to visit from 9:00 am to 10:45 am on Friday, August 18, 2017 at Infant Jesus Parish at St. Margaret's Church, 845 Third Street, Woodbury Heights, NJ 08097. Funeral Mass will be held at 11:00 am. Burial to follow at St. Josephs' Cemetery in Swedesboro. Donations can be made to Ashley, 800 Tydings Lane, Havre de Grace, MD 21078. Memories and condolences can be shared at www.smithfhmantua.com

Fischman, Joseph H. Joe passed away on October 5th, one day shy of his 88th birthday. Joe had two children, Michael and Jeffrey. Joe was a devoted stepfather to Caroline's 3 daughters: Carrie, Valle, and Kelley Janes and beloved fatherin-law to Caryn Fischman and Sandra Fischman. Joe had 14 grandchildren and 1 greatgrandson. Walter Prapolsky SOUTH CAIRO -Walter Prapolsky in his eightieth year of life, succumbed to lung cancer early Monday morning, May 9th, 2011. He passed peacefully at home in South Cairo with his family by his side. Walter loved nature and all things related to water. He was a Master Gardener, an avid reader, and had a wonderful sense of humor. As a young man he was a lifeguard on Rockaway Beach before entering the Coast Guard during the Korean War. After several occupations dealing with water pumps, pools and water treatment systems, Walter retired from Exxon as an oil tanker pumpman. His most recent years were spent feeding chipmunks and hummingbirds, fishing with his grandsons, being an active community member, and gardening with the students at Cairo Elementary School. Walter was born in Manhattan in 1931. He is survived by Joyce (Sievers), his wife of 56 years, their five daughters, Denise Mink (Michael), Cathy Prapolsky (Herb Lambertson), Janet Prapolsky Sauer (Russell), Pat Ublacker (Paul Lubera), and Mary Murphy (Thomas). He also leaves behind eight grandchildren, Annie McQuillan, Kelly Murphy, Timothy Murphy (Kathleen), Randy Ublacker, Maegan Ublacker, Christian Prapolsky-Sauer, Jesse Prapolsky Sauer and Aron Prapolsky-Sauer, and two great-grandchildren, Ian and Bridget Murphy. Walter will be cremated and a Funeral Mass will be held for him on Saturday, May 21st, 2011 at 12:00 noon at Sacred Heart Church in Cairo. All are invited to share in fellowship at the Glenbrook Resort in Round Top immediately following the Mass. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Lung Association or the Disabled American Veterans. Funeral arrangements by Richards Funeral Home, Cairo. Electronic condolences may be made at www.richardsfu neralhomeinc.net.

BRIAN MEYER  Brian Meyer, of Reno,  NV, passed away  unexpectedly on April 17, 2009 at the young age of 29. He was born in  Concord, CA on June 20, 1979. During his life, Brian experienced becoming a certified EMT, attending graphic arts school, working at Snowbird Ski Resort and at Berry- Hinckley's in Reno. Many fun times were shared with his twin brother, Brad; older brother, Scott; parents, Janet and Jerry; loving partner, Jennifer; their beautiful two year old daughter, Cloe and Jennifer's wonderful six year old son, Jakub, many other family members and friends. May 25, 1938 - April 6, 2009 Everett LeRoy Taylor has gone home to be with his Lord and Savior. He died at home surrounded by his family, on Monday, April 6, after his battle with cancer. He was 70 years old. Everett was born to Everett Leslie and Anna Bernice Taylor on May 25, 1938, in Aberdeen, Wash. The family moved to Sweet Home when Everett was in the sixth grade. He graduated from Sweet Home High School. Upon graduation, Everett joined the United States Navy. After leaving the Navy, he worked in Washington on a commercial tugboat. He later moved back to Sweet Home and went to work for the Lebanon Telephone Company. He married Rosanne Marie Dlouhy on June 15, 1963. After their honeymoon, the couple settled in Lebanon. In 1966, the couple moved to Las Vegas, where Everett worked for the telephone company. While in Las Vegas, Everett enjoyed flying, and earned his private pilot's license. In 1976, the family returned to Oregon, where Everett worked for Pioneer Telephone Co-op. The family settled in Philomath, where they continue to reside. Everett loved being a father and a grandfather. He enjoyed attending the academic and sporting events his children and grandchildren were involved with. Everett was devoted to service to his community as well as to the Lord. He volunteered for 23 years on the Philomath Warriors' football "chain gang." In 1999, he traveled as part of a church missions team to El Salvador, and again in 2000 to Costa Rica to help with construction projects. His hobbies included taking his family camping and fishing. He was a talented woodworker and often built beautiful pieces for his family. After his three grandchildren were born his focus shifted to building gifts for them and taking his grandsons fishing when they came to visit. His wife of 45 years, Rosanne; son David of Philomath; daughters Sharon Taylor of Salem and Amy Strand of Hawaii; and three grandchildren, also of Hawaii, survive him. Everett was preceded in death by his parents. With his wife, Everett loved attending Suburban Christian Church, where his memorial service will be held. The service will be at 1 p.m. Friday, April 10, at 2760 S.W. 53rd St. in Corvallis. Memorial donations can be made to the Everett Taylor Memorial fund at any Wells Fargo Bank. The family wishes to thank his Hospice nurses Jenny and Reenie as well as his therapist, Russ, for their wonderful care and support. Services are under the direction of Twin Oaks Funeral Home.

Genes Boyd Mrs. Genes Frances Reel Boyd, 92, passed away Monday, May 12, 2008, in Pitt County Memorial Hospital. The funeral service will be conducted Thursday at 3:30 p.m. in the Wilkerson Funeral Chapel. Burial will follow in Greenwood Cemetery. Mrs. Boyd, the youngest child of the late Leonard and Fannie Reel, was born April 20, 1916. A native of Pitt County, she lived her early life in the Gardnerville community and was a graduate of Farm Life School in Vanceboro. She married Woodrow Boyd on January 2, 1937, and they moved to Greenville in the early 1950's. Mrs. Boyd was a homemaker and always enjoyed spending time with her family and friends.  Mrs. Boyd was a charter member of the local Disabled American Veteran's Auxiliary in which she held many positions including commander. She was a life member of the DAV Auxiliary and the Charles Gray Morgan VFW Auxiliary. She was also a longtime member of the American Legion Auxiliary. Mrs. Boyd had been a member of First Christian Church for over 50 years. In addition to her parents, Mrs. Boyd was preceded in death by her husband of 58 years who died November 14, 1995; brothers, Clen, Jim, John, Laurie, and George Reel; and sisters, Lucy Lancaster, Estelle M. Reel, Kate Moore, Reba Buck and Karrie Ann Haddock. She is survived by her daughter, Barbara Boyd Hart and special son in-law, Raymond J. Hart III, of Greenville; four sisters-in-law; and many dear nieces and nephews, whom she loved very much. The family will receive friends from 2 to 3:30 p.m. Thursday at Wilkerson Funeral Home prior to the service. Flowers are welcome or memorials may be made to First Christian Church Building Fund, P.O. Box 2366, Greenville, NC 27836-0366.

Robert H. Tinnen passed away on Saturday, May 2, 2020, at the age of 77. He was born September 1, 1942 in Cushing, Oklahoma to Irma and 'Doc'. Bob graduated from Oklahoma State University with a Masters in Electrical Engineering and a wife named Michael Ann. A few short years later, Bob and Mike moved to Colorado and Bob went to work for Hewlett Packard where he would remain until he semi-retired 22 years later. Bob was born to be an engineer, but his real joy came from helping people, particularly kids. In the hospital for the birth of his son, Bob picked up a pack of 'twisty' balloons. He would spend the next 4 1/2 decades tying and giving away balloons across four continents and in more than a dozen countries. Balloons were always free, with the insistent directed to donate to Colorado Christian Home (later part of the Tennyson Center) or the local church. There were many stories of Bob simply helping people. Late one night - after a full day of setting up sound equipment for a concert in Estes Park - Bob was driving back to the motel for some much needed rest when he stopped to help an old school bus on the side of the road. 'Do you know anything about electricity?' A few hours later, Bob joined his family at the motel, the electrical system revived and the bus on its way. At First Christian Church in Loveland, he gave immensely of his time and talent. He was an Elder, a camp director, a Children's Sermon giver, and always 'The Balloon Man'. For Colorado Christian Home, he was a fierce champion for children who needed one. He raised money, helping others to understand the need, the duty, and the lives that could be touched. Bob is survived by his wife Michael Ann, sons Rob and Nathan, brother Bill, and three grandchildren. A belated service will be held later this year, date to be determined. Go to www.viegutfuneralhome.com for online condolences.

Roger J. Corigliano  Roger John Corigliano, 55, of Marysville, passed away on February 19, 2009 at home with his wife, children and grandchildren at his side after a short fight with brain cancer.  He was born on November 21, 1953 in Bayonne, NJ and was the son of the late Roger and Mary (Frushon) Corigliano. Roger was formerly employed at Appleton Papers for 21 years and also as an ER Tech at Holy Spirit Hospital and most recently for Lincare. He enjoyed being outdoors, riding his motorcycle, spending time at home, but most of all he enjoyed spending time with his family. He earnestly enjoyed helping people and was always eager to lend a hand. He was a sincere man and touched the lives of every person whose life he was involved with. Roger continued to give even in his passing as he donated himself to the Humanity Gifts Registry. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Robins, Eldon LeRoy  Eldon LeRoy Robins, MD, Aug 21, 1922 - Nov 9, 2010. Born to Edwin and Grace Robins in Gaston Oregon, Eldon grew up in and around the Willamette Valley outside of Portland, Oregon. With the Depression, he joined the CCC'S (Civilian Conservation Core) for a time, moving on for a short stint with Lockheed Aircraft in California. When war was declared, he joined the US Navy in 1941. July 16, 1944 while he was with the US Pacific Fleet Unit, he received both a commendation for his 53 missions in combat over Rabvul, in the South Pacific, and a Purple Heart. He was honorably discharged as Aviation Machinist's Mate 2nd Class Nov 22, 1945. He married Myrtle A. Rogers while stationed in Corpus Christi, Texas in 1945. After his discharge, they made their home in the Pacific Northwest. He graduated from Walla Walla College with a BA major in biblical language June 10, 1951. But dissatisfied, he decided to pursue medicine. In 1960 he graduated from medical school at the Universidad Autonomo, Guadalajara, Mexico. He completed a general internship at Washington Adventist Hospital in Tacoma Park, Maryland (1960), and a 2 yr. rotating general practice residency at St. Luke's Hospital in Spokane Washington. He went into general practice there. In July, 1966, Eldon and Myrtle moved the family to Arizona where he set up a practice in Glendale until 1990. He closed his practice at the age of 68 and worked with the Dept. of Health Services in Long-Term Care facilities until April of 2003. His professional accomplishments could not have come about without the steadying, nurturing support of his wife Myrtle, who worked tirelessly to help him in each of his endeavors. She preceded him in death May 26, 2009. Survivors include 6 children: Dr. Lanny Robins, Claudia Harrington, Bodie Robins, Roque Robins, Nancy Lutter, and Dr. Edwin Robins; 16 grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren. Viewing and reception will be held on Tues., November 30, 2010 from 11:30 AM - 1:00 PM at Camino del Sol Funeral Chapel, 13738 Camino del Sol, Sun City West. Graveside Service will follow at 2:00 PM at the National Memorial Cemetery of Arizona, 23029 N. Cave Creek Rd., Phoenix, AZ.

Dumas, Steven Brawn  47, of Phoenix, died early Monday, May 19, 2009. Steve was born in St. Petersburg, Florida on September 9, 1961 but lived most of his life in Phoenix. Steve is a graduate of NAU in Flagstaff with a degree in mechanical engineering and has spent his career with several major companies including General Dynamics, Allied Signal, Mobility, Honeywell and most recently as an engineering consultant. Steve was an avid outdoorsman and loved hiking and fishing trips to the Black River, Christopher Creek and the back woods and lakes of Arizona. His greatest pride and joy was being with his children and supporting them in all of their activities. After his battle with leukemia he had an even greater zest for life and cherished every day he had with his children and family. Steve is survived by his three children Christopher, Matthew and Allison. Also surviving are his mother, Helen Isenman Dumas of Phoenix, father and stepmother, Sam and Charles Dumas of Prescott, three brothers, Eric (Kristin) of Seattle, WA, Paul (Judi) of Flagstaff and Peter (Penny) of Gilbert, AZ. Steve also leaves behind his beautiful friend, Sharon Haynes, who has meant so much to him. Steve's family wants to pay great tribute to the doctors and nurses of the City of Hope, Bone Marrow Transplant Unit at Good Samaritan Hospital for their outstanding support and care. A Memorial Service will be Friday, May 22, 2009 at 9:30 am, at Whitney & Murphy Funeral Home, 4800 E. Indian School Road. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 3877 N. 7th Street, Phoenix, AZ 85014.

ROBERT MERCER MENEFEE  Uncle Bob, passed away suddenly on Thursday, December 10, 2015 in the evening. The cause of death was cardiac arrest, in the ambulance, on the way to the hospital. Uncle Bob was 77 years old and lived most of his adult life in Fairfax City, Virginia. He was born in Richmond, Virginia on July 15, 1938 to Anne and Robert Menefee. He grew up in Sperryville, Virginia, before graduating from East Carolina University and then serving in the US Army Reserve. A true baseball guy, he first taught and coached at Mount Vernon High School before moving to Robinson High School in 1971, where he taught and coached until he retired. The Robinson baseball field was named in his honor and remains that way today. A scholarship, in his name, was created several years ago to assist student/athletes at Robinson High School as they move on to college. This scholarship is still going strong today. Uncle Bob''s closest family were his brother Ed Menefee; sister-in-law, Shirley Menefee and their son, Robert L. Menefee. After Robert L. Menefee married Juana Mari Garcia in June of 2011, Uncle Bob developed a caring relationship with Mari''s two girls, Sofia 15 and Nicole 13. In his words, the last true love of his life was Robert and Mari''s daughter, Alina Lynn Menefee, four years old. She loved Uncle Bob and he never left without reminding her that "Uncle Bob loves you". Uncle Bob was a kind soul and peaceful man who always made those around him feel at ease. Uncle Bob''s quick wit and desire to laugh led many people to say "he''s one of the funniest people I''ve ever met"A Celebration of Uncle Bob''s Life will take place Thursday, December 17, 2015, at 10 a.m., at Belle Haven Country Club, in Alexandria, Virginia. No flowers or donations are necessary. Uncle Bob, as most know, liked to keep it simple and not burden anyone. We miss Uncle Bob, but are eternally grateful for the many lives that he touched and how he impacted those lives in a positive way. Online condolences and fond memories of Bob may be offered to the family atwww.moneyandking.com

Betty Jean “Graston” LutzShe was born Betty Jean Graston on May 23, 1932. To all those who knew her she was Jean, Betty was her first name that she hated, never knew why. To others beside Mike and myself she was “Mom”. She took to our friends as if we were all one family.She finished High School at Arsenal Tech downtown Indy. She worked at the time was a “Five and Dime” store I thing it was Woolworths. She working in a Photograph Studio, and other clerical positions, one being at All State Insurance near Shadeland and Washington St. She later was hired by the Indianapolis Public Health Department. Retired from there in the late 70s or early 80s.Jean was a lady with a Big Heart. She had a love for animals both domestic and wild. She taught her boys the love and care for all kinds of creatures. The ones that were from the outdoors were loved and cared for before they were released back to the wild. I was told a story about myself when I found a mouse, that I named: Mickey Mouse, I thought he was sleeping and I ask if we could keep him? She convinced me that when Mickey woke up he would want to go home to his family. So, we put Mickey back outside and he must have awoken and went home, as he was nowhere in sight the next day. She once shared with me about a good friend who was travelling thru Alaska with his Dad. They stopped into the Forestry Campgrounds that Mom and Dad were a host at. Mom found out it was my good friends’ birthday, and with supper that night she had made him a birthday cake. Those were some of the life lessons I loved my mom for, Love, Caring and Kindness. Those were some of the Life Lessons that made my brother Mike and I the men, we are today. There is one lesson that did CLASH with our Dads’ Life Lessons. I will refer to it as “When I get around to it”. From time to time there were things that had a clock on them to be done. So, I would ask mom about the progress of that protectoral thing, her reply was, I’ll get around to it. Myself being the “poop” and “jokester”, I got a wooden coin at the State Fair that had the words printed on it “Around 2 It”. So, the next time I received that answer. I pulled that wooden coin from my pocket, and handed it to her. That’s about all of that story I wish to share.When we would say good bye from a visit or phone call she would almost always say: “I love you and Keep my nose clean”. On a call to her from overseas at the end of the conversation she gave me her normal advice, “I love you and Keep your nose clean”. This time I replied “Yes mom, I’m picking it now”. She then calls me a” Shitass” and we both laughed and ended the call. I will always remember those special moments in life.As life often does, it comes to those final days of our life journey. I went to see her on the 25th of April, she was sleeping a lot and you just felt that time to go, home was near. I whispered to her it was OK and Dad was waiting on her. A couple of days later Mike was visiting the night before she passed, he also told her Dad was a little concern that she was taking to long. He told her it was OK and he had THIS, and things would be alright. The next morning on April 29, 2023 she was home with Shorty, just a little over 5 months from his passing. Those who knew my Mom and Dad, I know will miss them, and I already do

Block, Jerome V.Jerome V. "Joe" Block, 85, of Sheboygan Falls, died on Friday evening, May 27, 2011, at Pine Haven Christian Home in Sheboygan Falls. Joe was born on Dec. 12, 1925, in the Town of Sheboygan, the fifth of nine children, born to Martin and Katherine (Schmitt) Block. His Plymouth family would be forever altered by the tragic death of his father in 1941. The economic hardship spurred by his father's death redefined education and family life for him. On March 29, 1952, he married the love of his life, Marilyn Clemens, in Plymouth. Together they built their marriage and made their home in rural Sheboygan Falls. Joe worked for Hydro Excavating, but he most fondly remembered the camaraderie of the folks in the Maintenance Department at Bemis Mfg., where he was employed for 19 years until his retirement in 1997.Joe enjoyed stock car racing and football. A man of few words, his twinkly blue eyes and boyish grin spoke volumes. Slight in stature, but long on grit and determination, Joe had the uncommon gift of being wholly content being at home in his yard. On any given sunny day he could be found sitting in his chair in front of the garage watching cars go by.Joe is survived by his wife, Marilyn; one daughter, Kristi Schuchardt (Dale), Sheboygan; two sons, Steven (Darlene) Block, Sheboygan Falls; and David Block (Leesa), Plymouth; six grandchildren, Zachary and Rebecca Schuchardt, Abby Dotz (Ryan), Elizabeth (Ron) Rekowski, Emily Block and Joseph Block; one great-grandson, Marcus Rekowski; two sisters, Leona Gilboy, Plymouth; and Mary Ann Verhage, Sheboygan; one brother, Raymond (Mary) Block, Cleveland; and two brothers-in-law, Edward (Mary) Brinkman, Lakewood; and Jerry Brinkman, Plymouth.Joe was preceded in death by his parents; two sisters, an infant, Hildegarde Block and Helen (Willard) Brendel; three brothers, Leonard "Red" (Lorraine), Herbert (Patricia), Robert "Curly" (Sandra) Block; two brothers-in-law, Norbert Gilboy and Lawrence "Hap" Verhage; and a sister-in-law, Carol Brinkman.A private family memorial service will be held at the Chapel of Eternal Light.For online condolences and additional information, please visit www.wenigfuneralhome.com. The staff of the Wenig Funeral Home of Sheboygan Falls (920-467-3431), is assisting the Block family.In lieu of flowers, a memorial fund has been established in Joe's name for the Sheboygan Broughton Marsh Project.

Donald Lee Jacobson June 23, 1928 ~ December 28, 2008  Monterey – Donald Lee Jacobson, a long-time Monterey Peninsula resident, went to be with his Lord and Savior on December 28. He was born in St. Paul, NB and moved to Pacific Grove as a young boy.    Following graduation from Pacific Grove High School, Class of 1947, Donald served with the U.S. Army in Korea. He then began his 33-year Civil Service career at the Naval Postgraduate School. Donald then had a second career working at the Harrison Memorial Library in Carmel for 15 years. An active member of the First Baptist Church of Monterey, he also attended the First Baptist Church of Salinas.    Don was a loving, caring man with a great sense of humor. He loved singing, especially old hymns. A history buff, he also enjoyed old movies. Don loved telling stories of his childhood in Nebraska and his time in the service. He loved eating out, especially at the Victorian Corner in Pacific Grove. Don said that he had a good life, loved his Lord, family and his country. He was also proud of his Swedish heritage and had traveled extensively. Don knew he was well-loved by his family who surrounded him until the end.    Donald is survived by his daughters, Laurie (Chuck) Dillard of Monterey and Deborah Becerra of Seaside; his sisters, Laverne Stoddard of Lodi, Dorothy (Jack) Gunter of Pebble Beach and Arvilla Sikes of Poulsbo, WA; his grandchildren, Anthony, Megan, Jeannette, Christina, Cody, Jason, Joey and Sara; two great-grandchildren and many loving nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his wife, Helen, in 2003; his infant son, Donald Larimore Jacobson; his brother, Quentin Jacobson and his sister, Arlyne Coons.    Visitation will be held at The Paul Mortuary Chapel today, Tuesday, December 30, 2008 from 4:00 - 8:00 PM. Funeral Services will take place tomorrow, Wednesday, December 31, 2008 at 1:30 p.m. at the First Baptist Church of Monterey followed by burial at Mission Memorial Park. Memorial contributions are suggested to VNA Hospice, P.O. Box 2480, Monterey, CA 93942.    Please visit www.thepaulmortuary.com to sign Donald's guest book and leave condolences for his family.

Phillip Joseph Koonuk Gribble Sr., 72, passed away on July 3, 2015, at home in Anchorage, Alaska. Funeral service will be held at 3 p.m. on Thursday, July 9, 2015, at Legacy Funeral Homes Heritage Chapel, 440 East Klatt Road in Anchorage. Phillip was born on Dec. 10, 1942, in Ottawa, Ill. He served in the United States Marine Corps, receiving an honorable discharge. He moved to Alaska in 1980, making Anchorage his home. He worked as a truck driver for AFS Construction Services and then at Red Dog Mine, where he retired from. He enjoyed going out camping and fishing with his wife and two sons, taking his boys out golfing and many other activities with his wife and sons. His family stated, "Phil will be greatly missed by all family. He was such a humble man and treated everyone with love and compassion. He was truly a man of God, always loved to take his family to church." He was preceded in death by his parents, Nolan and Yvonne; parents-in-law, James and Hannah Hawley; and his brother in-law, James Hawley Jr. He is survived by his wife of 25 years, Alice Hawley Gribble; two sons, "PJ" Phillip Jr. and Nolan James; stepchildren, Hilda Hawley, Samantha Hawley and Jamy Bob Perry Hawley;three brothers, Kenneth, Denney and Nowell; and many other relatives. Memorial donations can be sent to 4110 Debarr Road Space E8, Anchorage, AK 99508. Arrangements entrusted to Legacy Funeral Homes Witzleben Chapel. To share words of comfort with the family please visit www.legacyalaska.com.

AHEARN, Thomas and Kevin Thomas (Tom) Richard Ahearn, long time resident of Marietta, Stone Mountain and Atlanta, Georgia and most recently of Sierra Vista, Arizona, passed away peacefully at home on March 17, 2020. Tom, the youngest son of Thomas Theodore and Rose Inez (Rowan) Ahearn, was born in Altoona, Pennsylvania on December 12, 1930. He graduated from Altoona Catholic High School in 1949 and Penn State University in 1954. Tom also earned his Master of Education from the University of Texas in San Antonio, TX in 1962 and a PhD in Education from the University of Georgia in Athens, GA in 1968. He served in the Air Force at Sheppard Air Force Base in Wichita Falls, Texas and Shaw Air Force Base in Sumter, South Carolina. Dr. Ahearn spent his career in education and guidance counseling at Kennesaw Community College and then as the Director of Counseling from Georgia State University (DeKalb) Perimeter College where he retired in 1988. Kevin Ahearn, a long time resident of Sammamish, WA, who recently moved to Sierra Vista, AZ, passed away on April 1, 2020 after fighting cancer and kidney failure. Kevin, the oldest son of Thomas and Alicia Ahearn, was born on June 13, 1957 in Sumter, South Carolina. Kevin graduated from Georgia State University in 1980 with a Bachelor of Business Administration in Marketing. Kevin pursued a career in computers. Tom and Kevin are survived by daughters/sisters, Eileen (R. Wade Barfield) of Gleeson, AZ, Kathleen (David Barlow) of Coventry, VT, Marguerite (Jerry Bevers) of Elgin, AZ, son/brother, Patrick Ahearn of Woodstock, GA, and two granddaughters/nieces, Chastain Barber and Alison Barlow. Tom and Kevin were predeceased by wife/mother (Maria) Alicia Pelaez Isaza in 2010. Interment will be on Tuesday, 18 August 2020 at 11 AM, at Arlington Memorial Park in Sandy Springs, GA. The celebrant will be Deacon Antonius Anugerah from Our Lady of the Assumption Catholic Church.

Edmund Lee KavanaughIntercourse, PA - 52, Passed away Friday, October 26, 2018. He was preceded in death by his parents, Ed & Rita Kavanaugh, of Louisville, Ky. and his beloved son Ollie. He is survived by his sister Whitney Nall (Roy), nephews Lee (Moe) & Austin, and great niece Madison.He was a lifelong mechanic and motor head. He began working in his father's auto service station on Bardstown Road when he was 8 years old between school and football practice. He loved working on cars and high performance engines. Lee loved to go fishing anytime of the year and was most at peace on the lake or under the hood of a car. He loved listening to Willie Nelson, enjoyed a good smoke and a taste of fine bourbon after a long day of work or a good meal. Lee was a true Renaissance man and unique hand model for many years. He was a world traveler, did performance art in his free time and was the life of any party on a karaoke machine. The friends he leaves behind will miss him dearly and have so many memories and stories of him to tell that he will live on forever in our hearts. If you were his friend there is nothing he wouldn't do for you. A celebration of his life will be held for his friends and family where he will be honored in a style befitting of the man. If you don't know where it's at, don't ask, he wouldn't want you there!

Elizabeth Willey Samuels BOULDER, CO - Elizabeth Willey Samuels, 88, of Colorado, died Dec. 9 in Boulder, CO. Mrs. Samuels was born in Trenton and had resided in Princeton before moving to Colorado two years ago. She was a graduate of Miss Fine's School in Princeton and Trenton State Teachers College, and received a master's degree from Temple University, Philadelphia. She was a teacher at Miss Fine's School, a sales representative for the American Book Company, and a learning disability specialist with the Hopewell Valley School System, retiring in 1988. Predeceased by her husband, James W. Samuels, and daughter, Wesley Ross, she is survived by a daughter, Brenda Zellner and her husband Jack of Boulder, CO; three granddaughters, Melissa Jones, Kirsten Thomas, and Allison Zellner; three grandsons, Jack Ross, Colin Merritt and Jamie Merritt; three great-grandchildren, Kelly, Christopher and Annie; and her cousins, Andrew R. Willey and Margaret Ritter. A memorial service will be held May 5, 2007 at the Nassau Presbyterian Church, Princeton, at a time to be announced in the spring. Interment will be private. Memorial contributions may be made in Mrs. Samuels' memory to the Make a Wish Foundation of America, Gift Processing Center, PO Box 29119, Phoenix, AZ 85038. Arrangements are under the direction of the Saul Memorial Home, 1740 Greenwood Ave., Trenton.

NEWPORT NEWS - At sunrise on Saturday, March 10, 2012, Mary Louise Edmonds answered the Lord's call and entered into eternal rest at Riverside Regional Medical Center in Newport News, Va.Mary was born on Feb. 3, 1944, in Welch, W.Va., the second of 11 children born to Eddie Taylor, of Birmingham, Ala., and Mary Lou Taylor nee Estes, of Bassett, Va. Mary was raised in Bassett, where as a child she attended Mary Hunter Elementary School, and was a member of Water Way of the Cross Church. Upon coming of age, Mary went to work at Stanley Furniture Factory where she was an upstanding, hard-working employee while raising her children, and regularly attending church with her kids. In 1977, Mary and her family moved to Newport News, Va., where she joined Living Waters Way of the Cross Church, and was a member for 35 years. Also while in Newport News, Mary went to work at Langley Air Force Base where she worked in food service before retiring in 1986. Mary always was a hard worker, and faithful servant of the Lord. She rarely missed church and loved her pastor and congregation dearly. During her many years at Living Waters, Mary was a member of the S.E.J. Choir, the Flower Club, and the Women of Zion organization. She also enjoyed sewing prayer caps and other garments for her brethren. To know Mary was to love her. Rarely did Mary not carry a smile on her face. She was always a hard-working, selfless woman who would always go out of her way to help her family and others in any way that she could. Mary got great joy and satisfaction out of life by serving the Lord and, raising her children and grandchildren. Mary was preceded in eternal rest by her parents, Eddie and Mary Lou Taylor. She leaves behind to carry on her legacy four children, Mildred Annette Harmon, Gary Taylor, Sharon Louise Taylor, and Allison Bernadette Garner, all of Newport News, Va.; 11 siblings, Eddie Cornelia Hairston, of Newport News, Va., Rosa Lee Webb, Evelyn Martin (Larry), Lewis Taylor (Debra), Eddie Lee Taylor, Linwood Taylor, and Wilbur Taylor, all of Martinsville, Va., Ann Joan Moore, Gwendolyn Everett, and Ralph Taylor (Peggy), all of Bassett, Va., and Eddie Taylor Jr., of Birmingham, Ala.; 15 grandchildren, Terri, Kenneth, August, Kendon, Antario, Quinton, Karen, Asheena, Quintel, Chelsey, Quayla, Quaret, Quaylin, and Quayvon, all of Newport News, Va., and Loren Jr., of Georgetown, Del. Mary also leaves to cherish her legacy 16 great-grandchildren, and a host of nieces, nephews, extended family and friends.Services for Mrs. Edmonds will be held at noon Thursday, March 15, 2012, at Living Waters Way of the Cross Church, 617 8th Street Newport News, by Bishop James Jackson. Interment to follow in Greenlawn Memorial Park. Mrs. Edmonds may be viewed today from noon to 5 p.m. C. C. Carter Funeral Home, 3314 Roanoke Ave., and at the church two hours prior to the service.Services of dignity and respect are provided by the staff of C. C. Carter Funeral Home, 3314 Roanoke Ave., Newport News, Va., cccarterfuneralhome.com. View and post condolences on our online guestbook at dailypress.com/guestbooks.

Betty J. Handy MEDWAY Betty Jane (Hanley) Handy, 63, of Medway died, unexpectedly Sunday, Dec. 14, 2008, at Milford Regional Medical Center. She was the wife of Michael D. Handy for 44 years. Born in Lancaster, N.H., on May 7, 1945, she was a daughter of the late Lawrence and Frieda (Davis) Timson. Betty was a resident of Medway for the past 12.5 years, and formerly resided in Dillon, Colo., Van Nuys, Calif., and in Marshfield from 1968-1978. She grew up in East Concord, Vt., and graduated from Concord High School. Before becoming disabled, Betty was a marketing administrator at Rohm & Haas in Marlborough for several years. She previously worked for many years as director of operations for Keystone Symposia, formerly UCLA Symposia. Betty was a member of the Rosalie Rebekah Lodge in Dillon, Colo. She was a tremendous country singer and performed on her own and with bands in local lounges. A very giving person, Betty opened her home on many occasions for post-doctorates unable to make it home for the holidays. She was an avid shopper and loved spending time with her grandchildren. Besides her husband, she is survived by two sons, Mark Handy and his wife, Cathy, of St. Johnsbury, Vt., and Richard Handy and his wife, Ann, of Medway; two brothers, Harry Hanley of Wells River, Vt., and Edward Timson of Lunenburg, Vt.; two sisters, Marie Paradis of Greenville, N.C., and Neva Macie of Lunenburg, Vt.; and her grandson, Christopher Handy of Medway. She was grandmother of the late Alex Handy, who died in 2006. Betty is also survived by her mother-in-law, Marion Handy of Austin, Texas; two brothers-in-law, Netcy Handy of Detroit, Mich., and Jeff Handy of Gainesville, Fla.; two sisters-in-law, Linda Sparks of Manchester, N.H., and Andi Handy of Austin, Texas; and several nieces and nephews. She was a sister of the late Bobby Hanley and daughter-in-law of the late Sam Handy. Relatives and friends are invited to attend her funeral on Thursday, Dec. 18, from the Ginley-Crowley Funeral Home (www.ginleyfuneralhomes.com), 3 Barber St., Medway at 11 a.m., followed by a funeral Mass at St. Joseph Church, 151 Village St., Medway at noon. Calling hours will be held on Wednesday, from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Betty's memory to Project Alex, 11 Lee Lane, Medway, MA 02053 (www.projectalex.net).

Lillian Mary Hunter 86, of Longview, passed away due to complications from Alzheimer's on December 1, 2003 at Hospice. She was born May 22, 1917 in Gackle, North Dakota. She was raised in the hardworking Finnish immigrant farm family of Andrew and Greta Karjalainen.  She moved to Portland in the late 1930's to work in food service. She met Chet Hunter and they were married October 26, 1940. They had a son Clifford, then moved to Newport, Ore. in 1946 where another son, Burton, was born. "Lil" worked continuously with food service (for many years with her own restaurant) in Newport for nearly fifteen years before moving to Longview in 1961. Chet was a longshoreman and Lil was active with the ILWU Auxiliary and loved to bowl.  Her life was dedicated to taking care of other's needs. Cooking and baking her famous Finn pastries was her pleasure.  They moved to Yuma, Ariz. for winter stays beginning in 1983 while spending their summers on the much-loved Oregon coastal beaches back in Newport. Longview became their current residence again in 2001.  She is now survived by her husband of 63 years, Chet; two sons, Cliff, daughter-in-law Cheri and son Burt; with numerous nieces and nephews through out the U.S. Not to mention innumerable friends wherever she went.  Lillian will be long remembered for her compassion and loving care for everyone she met. For that reason, the family is asking that anyone who would like to make a memorial contribution, make it to Community Home Health & Hospice PO Box 2067 Longview, WA 98632-8189, where she was so well cared for.  A memorial gathering will be held at 2:00 p.m. on Tuesday, December 9, 2003 at First Christian Church Chapel on 20th and Kessler Blvd.  Cremation has taken place under the direction of Cascade Northwest Funeral Chapel at Green Hills Memorial Gardens & Crematory.

MORGAN, Judith Rab Age 96, passed away peacefully at The Osborn in Rye, New York on Thursday March 1, 2018. She is survived by her daughter Victoria Morgan Amon and son-in-law Simeon Amon of Larchmont NY, granddaughter Laura Amon-Thurber, grandson-in-law Daniel Thurber, niece Nancy (George) Stolz, nephews Larry (Sharon) Rab, Paul (Ruth) Rab and George (Wendy) Rab, six grand-nieces/nephews and eight great grand-nieces/nephews. Born in Hungary, she came to the US in 1924 with her late older brother Thomas and parents Alex and Sarah Rab, and lived most of her life in Dayton, Ohio. She was a bookkeeper, artist, baker and homemaker and was devoted to her family. Though profoundly disabled physically during the last four decades of her life, she still was able to find joy in small things and was graceful, cheerful and hopeful to the end. She was a remarkable woman who will be deeply missed. A private family service will be held in Dayton.

BRADLEY, Rodney J. 73, passed away gently Tuesday, April 19, 2016 and ended his valiant and heroic struggle of nearly eight years with esophageal cancer. Rod grew up in Chesterland, OH a graduate of West Geauga High School. He graduated with a Ph.D from The Ohio State University and was a life-long Buckeye fan and alumnae supporter. Rod, with his wife Linda and son Dan, moved to Florida in 1979 to enjoy the sunny, warmer climate and water sports. Rod was a talented and passionate classical musician and a long-term member of The Suncoast Symphony Orchestra. The family wishes to express our deepest regards to those symphony members who willingly give their cherished hours to bring music to the community. We also wish to especially thank the Moffit team of doctors who participated in affording Rod a truly great quality of life for such a long time. A loving look-back for family and friends will be held at Heritage United Methodist Church at Landmark and 580 Saturday, April 30, at 3:30 pm. Donations to The Suncoast Symphony would be much appreciated.Dobies FH-Tarpon Avenue

Dr. Blaine G. Schmidt, Ph.D.Age 91, of Newark, DE passed away peacefully at his residence, surrounded by his family, on Tuesday November 13, 2007.Dr. Schmidt was a United States Army Veteran of WWII. He served in the European Theatre, where he received the Bronze Star. He continued his service in the Army Reserves, attaining the rank of Colonel in the 390th Civil Affairs Unit. Dr. Schmidt received his doctorate in Economics from St. Louis University in Missouri. He was a professor and served as the Chair of the Department of Business Administration at the University of Delaware for 27 years and retired in 1986. He was an avid painter and was an instructor for the Academy of Life Long Learning at the Wilcastle Center. Dr. Schmidt is survived by; his wife of 69 years, Mrs. Adele E. Schmidt; his children, Prudence Worthington and her husband, Robert of Exton, PA., and Richard G. Schmidt and his wife, Rebecca of Jackson, TN; 4 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren. Charles A. McKeeCharles A. (Mac) McKee died October 18, 2016 at the age of 91.He was born on July 10th, 1925 in Gregory, South Dakota, the youngest of seven children of Herbert and Martha Jane McKee. He attended elementary and high school in Gregory, and then attended South Dakota School of Mines and Technology in Rapid City, SD, for one year. He spent two years in the Army Air Force and then received his bachelors degree in Business and Industrial Engineering at the University of South Dakota (USD) in Vermillion. While at USD he met Shirley Snorteland and they married in 1952. The newlyweds lived in Beloit, Wisconsin, where he worked for Fairbanks-Morse and then moved to Minneapolis, Minnesota, where he worked for Worthington Corp. Most of Mac's career was with Control Data Corporation in Minneapolis, Houston, TX, and Bloomington, MN, followed by Magnetic Peripherals Incorporated (MPI) in Rapid City, SD. After he retired in 1987, Mac and Shirley moved to the Rio Robles retirement community in Kerrville, TX, where they lived for 26 years. While there, they were avid travelers in their motorhome and volunteers for Habitat for Humanity and the Family Motor Coach Association. In 2014 they moved to Good Samaritan-Denton Village in Denton, TX.Mac is survived by his wife Shirley and their three children: Ron and his wife Laurie of The Colony, TX, Gordon and his wife Dana of Robins, IA, and Jane and her husband Ernest of Vicksburg, MS; three grandchildren: Kyle and Christian McKee and Tyler Smith; and three nieces and six nephews.Memorials may be made to the American Heart Association https://donatenow.heart.org/.

William Parson, 85 William Joseph "Bill" Parson, Sr. age 85, passed away at his home in Kalispell, Montana on Tuesday, August 29, 2023. Bill was born November 23, 1937, in Binghamton, New York to Albert E. and Lillian L. (Roy) Parson. After high school Bill attended the New York State Ranger School - State University College of Forestry Syracuse University. Soon thereafter he jumped on a westbound train matriculating at the University of Idaho, graduating with a degree in Forestry. Bill then joined the United States Maring Corps in 1961, becoming a Naval Aviator piloting his beloved A-4 Skyhawk and serving nearly 6 years in active duty which included a 9-month tour in Vietnam where Bill spent several harried nights in the jungle after his surveillance plane crashed during a mission into the side of a mountain due to severe weather during monsoon season. Bill was honorably discharged from the United States Marine Corps in 1966, achieving many flight qualifications including flight instructor at Cherry Point, NC, and Weapons Handler & Nuclear Weapons Currier. His military awards include Air Medal with Gold Star, Vietnamese Service Medal, National Defense Service Medal, and Vietnam Campaign Medal. Following military service Bill headed West yet again putting his degree to direct use working for 30 years in the forestry business in Montana beginning with Burlington Northern Railroad and ending his distinguished civilian career as Director of Resources for the Rocky Mountain Region with what evolved into BN Timberlands and then Plum Creek Timber Company (now present-day Weyerhaeuser). Upon Bill's retirement in 1995 he was awarded "The Grandfather of Environmental Forestry" distinction for leading efforts in resource innovation, repurposing production waste byproducts, and meeting the increasing demands in responsible forestry. Bill's love of flying and airplanes followed him into civilian life; completing the complicated blueprint build of a tail drag airplane from scratch in 1980 while living in Bozeman; and building a designed for kit construction high wing, strut braced Avid Flyer completed in 1993. He fearlessly piloted these experimental homebuilt aircraft well into his later years in both the Gallatin and Flathead Valleys. He proudly and passionately served as Director of the USAF Thunderbird Airshow held here at Glacier Park International Airport in the early 90's and relished the opportunity to expose an endeavor he found so exhilarating to the younger generation in the Flathead Valley and to all his fellow Montanans. There was seemingly nothing Bill couldn't do when he put his mind to it. If he was in your corner, you unquestionably had an advocate you could count on. He enjoyed challenging himself regularly, as well as anyone sturdy enough to join him --- be it on hikes atop Glacier's highest peaks, within the Bob Marshall Wilderness, and Montana forests --- to Alaska moose and caribou hunts, to flying into remote areas, racing sailboats on Flathead lake out of North Flathead Yacht Club where he served a term as Commodore in 1997; or planning travel to the likes of Germany, New Zealand, Honduras, the Ambergris Caye, Belize, trekking Copper Canyon Mexico on bike and foot, or sailing adventures throughout the Caribbean and Virgin Isles. Planning such adventures, spending time with his family and making memories while doing so was what it was all about to Bill. An avid sportsman and outdoorsman; his hobbies too numerous to list included shooting trap, sailing, downhill skiing, and spending time on Hungry Horse Reservoir; but spending a lifetime successfully chasing the elusive wapiti and packing out elk himself well into his late 70's was undoubtedly his favorite Montana memory making activity. Bill is preceded in death by his parents, his older Brother Albert C. "Al" Parson, his Niece, Darci Parson and numerous aunts, uncles, and cousins. Bill is survived by his three children, Jennifer Marie Parson (Braley), William Joseph Parson, Jr., Christopher Albert Parson, his wife Stephanie, and their daughter Hailey, all of Kalispell, MT; as well as his Brother Brian D. Parson, wife Marsha and their family out of Missoula and Troy.

Mary Adele Blackwell, 77, of Cuero passed away Monday, Nov. 15. She was born Oct. 29, 1944, in Cuero to Howard and Mary Kleinecke. She married Claude "Buddy" Blackwell, Jr. on Oct. 20, 1962, and they had two children, Kimberly Lynn Blackwell Powers and Finley North Blackwell.Mary Adele graduated from Cuero High School. She attended Texas A&I University in Kingsville and earned her degree in Home Economics. She was very active in the community. She served on the Cuero Library Board; she was a hospital volunteer and a member of Shutterbugs. She was a devoted Elder, choir member, organist and Presbyterian Women officer. Mary Adele enjoyed photography, gardening, horseback riding and she taught piano lessons for many years. She was Buddy's right-hand cowgirl and professional gate opener. She loved working for the family business, Cuero Livestock.  Mary Adele's favorite holiday was Christmas. She loved celebrating Christmas and took pride in celebrating it all year long. She never missed an opportunity to spend time with her family and friends.She is survived by her son, Finley (Anissa) Blackwell; sisters, Bonnie (Rick) Wheeler, Becky (Les) Richter and Gaye (Paul) Avery; brothers, Jack (Sharon) Kleinecke and David (Stephanie) Kleinecke; grandchildren, Paige (Jess) Powers Nyegaard, Kyle Powers, Cassidy (Wes) Blackwell Wyrick and Dixie Blackwell; great-grandchildren, Weston Nyegaard and Adelynn Nyegaard.She was preceded in death by her loving husband of fifty-two years, Buddy Blackwell and daughter, Kimberly Lynn Blackwell Powers.Visitation will be held Tuesday, Nov. 16, from 5-7 p.m. at Freund Funeral Home. Funeral Services will be held Wednesday, Nov. 17, at 2 p.m. at First Presbyterian Church with Pastor Stanley Larson officiating.Pallbearers include Mary Adele's nephews; Richard Wheeler, David Scott Kleinecke, Mason Kleinecke, Dean Kleinecke, Christopher Richter, Aaron Richter, Gage Richter, Dakota Blackwell, Tucker Blackwell, Mike Pagel, Gary Pagel and David Pagel.Memorial Contributions may be made to First Presbyterian Church or the Friar Ag Center.You may sign the guestbook or send condolences at www.freundfuneralhome.com.Freund Funeral Home, 361-275-2343.

STILLWELL-Pauline (Fern) Stillwell, was born in Mulberry Grove Illinois on May 21, 1908 to Paul and Josephine (Vaughn) Studebaker. Pauline's uncles Harry and Clement had invented the first Studebaker car in 1902. Paul ine shared joyful memories of her childhood in Mulberry Grove helping her father milk the cows on their family farm, of driving her cart and pony named "Cutie" to the schoolhouse each day, and attending the family Mennonite church built by her grandmother Vaughn, remembering that as a child she couldn't wait to reach the age when she would wear her hair up with a pretty lace bonnet. Pauline went to college receiving her teaching certificate and taught children in a one room schoolhouse before relocating to California where she continued her teaching career for many years while also working alongside her husband at Stillwell Upholstery Shop. Even after her retirement, Pauline devoted her time to children who needed help with reading, hand printing hundreds of phonics cards and books for each and every one of her young students. Pauline met and married her husband George Ross Stillwell on October 5, 1933, who passed away in 1976. Their son George Bruce, the joy of Pauline's life was born in 1940, and in 1952 th e family moved to a 1921 historical home on Wedgewood Place in San Gabriel, originally one of the churches built by Aimee Simple McPherson, where Pauline lived until moving to California Christian Home in October 2003. The Stillwell family became active members of San Gabriel Union Church and in 2002, Pauline was honored for 50 years of faithful service, where she served in the Missionary Guild and taught Sunday School every week for 50 years. Pauline was a faithful servant to her Lord Jesus in volunteering for Child Evangelism Fellowship, Faith Expressed, Helping Hands, People to People, Fernview Retirement Home or anywhere that help was needed, and at a banquet on April 3, 2003, Pauline received honorary recognition from YMCA of Greater Whittier for her volunteer work in the city of San Gabriel. Pauline is survived by her son, George Bruce Stillwell who resides in Pasadena, California, and will be fondly remembered for her devotion to children and her witty humor by all who have known her. Her Graveside Ser vice is scheduled for 1:00 P.M. Monday, October 17th at Forest Lawn, 1712 S. Glendale Ave., Glendale, Ca. GLENDALE FOREST LAWN

Judy Diane Oswald  November 10, 1954 - October 20, 2020  Lexington, South Carolina - Judy Diane Oswald, 65, of Lexington, South Carolina, died peacefully at home on October 20th 2020. Born November 10, 1954 to the late Willie Horace Sharpe Sr and the late Carrie Elizabeth Gordon, she grew up in the Connie Maxwell Children's Home in Greenwood, South Carolina. Mrs. Oswald met the love of her life, the late Kenneth Oswald Sr while working at the Cornell Arms (Long's) Pharmacy. They were married in 1976, and they enjoyed their journey together for 35 years. She completed her high school diploma later in life, as she devoted the majority of her life to raising her children and assisting her late husband in the family wholesale automobile business. Mrs. Oswald was a member of First Baptist Church of Lexington, where she enjoyed the Encouragers Life Group and the many friends she made there. She was a kind spirit and loved helping others, which she did in her most recent position at Mission Lexington. She enjoyed caring for others and humbly met the needs of her friends and family, even if it meant she sacrificed things for herself. Her contagious laugh, sweet smile, and witty spirit will be engraved in our hearts forever.  Mrs. Oswald was predeceased by her parents, her loving husband, Kenneth Oswald Sr., and three sisters. Surviving are her daughter Lisa (Timothy) Altman of Lexington, her son Kenneth (Monica Sparkman) Oswald Jr. of Columbia, a grandson Gary Sparkman-Couillard of Columbia, a sister Bonnie Keeter of West Columbia, a sister Pearlie Turner of Lexington, and many loving nieces and nephews. She was also especially fond of her fur-grandbabies: Jackson, Oliver, Bella, and D.  Her family would like to thank the members of the Encouragers group and Mission Lexington for their devoted support during her illness. In lieu of flowers, memorials can be made to Mission Lexington, 216 Harmon St, Lexington, SC 29072, or the Connie Maxwell Children's Home, 810 Maxwell Ave, Greenwood, SC 29646. The family would like to thank the wonderful staff of Heart of Hospice, Kindred at Home, Right at Home and Solutions for Living at Home for their loving care of Mrs. Oswald during her last months. The medical expertise of Dr. Jonathan Engh, Dr Asheesh Lal, and Dr Daniel Hess has been priceless during the recent months.  Visitation with the family will be held at Thompson Funeral Home Lexington, 4720 Augusta Road, Lexington, from 6-8 pm on Thursday, October 22, 2020,with a celebration of her life at Thompson's Funeral Home Lexington Chapel at 1:00 pm on Friday, October 23, 2020, officiated by Pastor Ralph Sneck and Bishop Mark Crumpton, directed by Thompson's Funeral Home. The family asks that all guests to both events wear face masks.

Charles Conrad Abnet (Charlie) died January 27, 2010 after 7 months working hard  to survive cancer for the second time.  He died with his family nearby and in the tender care of Providence Centralia Hospital in Centralia, WA.  Charlie was born July 20th, 1937 in La Crescent, Minnesota, the fourth son in a family of five boys and one girl.   Charlie grew up on his father's farm and always enjoyed telling stories of his childhood. As a young man, he left the farm and Minnesota and joined the Navy.   He became an air traffic controller and worked for the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) for 40 years.   During his time working as a controller in Boise, Idaho, he met the love of his life,  M. Penny Lisk.  He married Penny on September 26, 1966 and they eventually settled in Renton, WA to raise their two children. Throughout his life, Charlie developed a love of gardening and recently became a Master Gardner through the Washington State University Master Gardener program.  He had a passion for collecting new and antique tools, working with wood,  and planning small, medium, and large projects around the house (often large).  Charlie was a member of the Midwest Tool Collectors Association.  After his retirement from the FAA, Charlie and Penny moved to Curtis, WA in 1999 to build a new home in the Boistfort valley and plan new projects on their 16 acres of land.  They made good friendships in the valley and were members of the Baw Faw Grange and St. Joseph Church in Chehalis.   Penny and Charlie had a wonderful 43 year adventure together.  Charlie is survived by his wife, Penny, his daughter, Lara, his son, Cameron, and four granddaughters, Cydney (7), Lila (4), Annabelle (3), and Penelope (1.5).  He is also survived by three brothers Greg, Rich, David and his sister, Rosanne.  Charlie was preceded in death by his parents, Charles and Angeline, and his older brother Clint.  Charlie is further survived by several unfinished projects, a beautiful garden,  and a workshop full of tools.We love you Charlie, Dad, Grampa-Loo, Papa, Grampa, Daddo, Chuck.Memorial services will be held at Baw Faw Grange, 995 Boistfort Road in Curtis, WA on Saturday, April 17, 2010 at 11AM.His family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations are sent to the Providence Health Care Foundation, 914 South Scheuber Road, Centralia, WA 98531.  (360)807-7940.  Donations can be made online at http://providence.org/swsa/facilities/centralia_hospital/donation.htmPlease sign the guest book at the obit website

Arline Levitt, 83, died June 14, 2022. She is survived by her husband of 61 years Harvey, and her children Terri Kramer and her partner Neil Malkin and Bob Levitt and his wife Robin. She also leaves her grandchildren Melanie (Kramer) and her husband Colin Willis, Rebecca Kramer, Ryan Levitt and Morgan Levitt. Born in Hartford, CT, she was the daughter of the late Sidney and Betty Zucker Kadish. She was predeceased by her older sisters Marion Greenberg and Ruth Kadish. Graduating from Weaver High School in 1957, Harvey and Arline were King and Queen of her Senior Prom. She worked for over 25 years in the insurance industry for Aetna and Fireman's Fund. After retirement, she and Harvey moved to The Villages in Florida in 2005 enjoying their life there immensely taking advantage of all that the amazing community had to offer. She was a proud member of Temple Shalom Sisterhood and became a Bat Mitzvah at the age of 73. She loved to play Mahjong every week with a very close and wonderful group. They enjoyed traveling especially going on cruises with their many friends from The Villages. She was fiercely loved by her children, grandchildren and extended family who would argue that she was the most beloved woman on the planet. Some of her fondest memories were made at the Connecticut shore with her grandchildren where she would make the best dolly bars and potato salad that could be found anywhere. She had a special place in her heart for her neighborhood friends on Patrick Place. People were drawn to her because of her boundless and truly genuine kindness creating an extraordinarily large circle of friends. To meet Arline was to become her friend and she could always be counted upon for anything. The family wishes to extend a special thank you to Steve and Cindy Greenberg for their invaluable and loving care and assistance. In lieu of flowers, donations should be directed to the Alzheimer's Association, alz.org.

Collins, Donald E. MCKOWNVILLE Donald E. Collins, 85, of McKownville, died peacefully on Saturday, August 4, 2012 with his family by his side. Mr. Collins was born in Albany, and lived in the area all his life. He was employed by the New York Central Railroad both before and after serving in the U.S. Navy during World War II. He later was employed for 35 years by the Watervliet Arsenal until his retirement. He was a life member of the Wigand Post #8444 of the VFW and the Colonie Elks Lodge #2192. He was an active member of the Western Turnpike Golf Club, and was on the board of directors of the Albany Bowling Association. Mr. Collins bowled for nearly 65 years, and in 1984 was inducted into the Albany Bowling Association Hall of Fame as a recipient of the Lifetime Achievement Award. He was an avid hunter and fisherman. Mr. Collins is survived by his beloved wife, Virginia Childs Collins; his daughters, Joanne Passineau (Tom), and Sharon Barcomb (David); his grandchildren, Lisa Keating (Roger), Stacey Breakell (Douglas), Heather Tagliaferro (David), and Megan and Gregory Barcomb; his great-grandchildren, Annabelle and Reegan Keating; and by several nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his sister, Eleanor Griessel; and his brothers, Nelson and Peter Collins. Funeral services will be held in the Hans Funeral Home, 1088 Western Ave., Albany, Wednesday morning at 8:15, and from there to All Saints Catholic Church, Homestead St., Albany at 9. Relatives and friends are invited, and may call at the funeral home Tuesday from 4-8 p.m. Interment will be in Memory Gardens, Colonie. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests memorial contributions to Community Hospice of Albany, 445 New Karner Road, Albany, NY 12205. To leave a message of condolence for the family, send a sympathy card, or obtain directions to the funeral home, please visit www.HansFuneralHome.com

Registered nurse at East Orange General Hospital, 68 Azucena A. Cresencia, 68, of Hackettstown, formerly of Elizabeth, died on March 29, 2009, in her home. David Wayne Edwards II Known as Wayne, finished this life's journey on Tuesday, June 26, 2012. Wayne was born in Newark, NJ on October 16, 1960 to David and Joan Edwards. He lived in West Virginia, California, Oklahoma, Virginia, and Florida before settling in Indiana. When he wasn't playing baseball, skiing, boxing, golfing or practicing his bass, he opened his own software consulting business. Of all his accomplishments serving as the president of the Indianapolis Adult Baseball League was one that made him the most proud. During his baseball career Wayne was awarded the 2002 and 2006 Cy Young Award. He was a competitor by nature and his passion was being involved in the game. Besides his mom and dad he is survived by his beloved wife of 27 years, Jeri Lee and their two dogs (Jake and Elwood); his sisters and brother, Carol (Howie) Scalzo, Victoria (David) Mann, and Joseph (Jessica) Edwards as well as various in-laws, out-laws, nieces and nephews. He was a man of faith and ended this life with his hope firmly placed in the saving grace of Jesus Christ. "So remind me of your promise, when it is time to go - that every goodbye will be an everlasting Hello… A memorial service will be held on Friday, June 29, 2012 at 4:00 p.m. at the Worship Center of Hamilton County, 2200 Sheridan Road, Noblesville, IN 46062, where friends and family are invited to gather from 3:00 p.m. until time of service. In lieu of flower donations may be made to Play ball Indiana or Horizon International. Everyone is invited to sign the guestbook or leave a story by visiting fisherfuneralservices.com. Fisher Family Funeral Services has been entrusted with Wayne's arrangements.

Viewing will be held on Thursday and Friday, from 9:00am until 6:00pm and Saturday 9:00am until 12:00noon. Shmily, see how much I love you.
